name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Gabrielius Landsbergis on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the state of EU-Russia relations (2015/2001(INI)) (A8-0162/2015).

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all let me thank all the shadow rapporteurs – Ms Jaakonsaari, Mr van Baalen, Ms Fotyga, Mr Meszerics and Mr Šoltes – for all their work, and for the proposals that were made and amendments that were tabled during the process of preparing this report. I would also like to thank all those colleagues – MEPs and Parliament staff – for their very valuable input into this very sensitive and important matter that we are here to discuss: EU-Russia relations. I would like to note that while preparing the report I was planning on going and taking the opportunity to hear what the officials in Moscow had to say. Unfortunately, my fact-finding mission did not take place, since my delegation was not let into Russia. We can only regret that now, 19 of our colleagues find themselves on the illegal Russian visa ban list. This is not only disrespect to the European Parliament but an insult to the EU as a whole, which bases international cooperation on transparent and peaceful dialogue. When preparing for this speech I looked for inspiration from Churchill’s Fulton speech. The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom saw the dramatic geopolitical changes that were arriving in his wake when he said these words: ‘If the Western Democracies stand together in strict adherence to the principles [of the United Nations Charter, their influence] will be immense and no one is likely to molest them. If however they become divided or falter in their duty and if these all-important years are allowed to slip away, then indeed catastrophe may overwhelm us all’. When everyone in Europe was tired after the war, it took great courage to name the situation, as it was – if not acted upon – possibly as dangerous as the situation created by the Nazis. There are countries and people who would say the same thing about today’s situation. Europe’s post-war peace order is challenged by the occupation of Crimea and continuing Russian military aggression in Ukraine. There should be no fear in naming it that way. But the European continent had not only the Cold War: it also had the fall of the Berlin Wall and the Singing Revolution, which was one of the reasons that made my speech here today possible. It all happened in a semi-peaceful way. It seemed that history has indeed come to an end: democracy and the rule of law are prevailing over aggression and unlawfulness and war. Further EU enlargement is an excellent example of peaceful European order. So one could say that there is a solution, there is a possibility of building a peaceful cohabitation with all the countries on the continent. But at this moment it is not Europe which will decide it. The European Union adheres to the very clear principles of the rule of law, transparency and self-determination, therefore numerous different formats and initiatives were offered to Russia in order to usher the Russian people to the path of democracy and reform. The European Union was even generous in offering strategic partnership or ‘common spaces’ initiatives, but the respect of human rights and democratic principles kept on deteriorating in Russia. Europe even turned a blind eye when people in the Kremlin were breaking the established order of international treaties. Europe did not do much when the Russian troops entered Georgia’s territory and remained silent during the establishment of the Gazprom monopoly in certain countries and during trade wars when Russia would close down its borders under political pretexts. But Europe is not there any longer. After the illegal annexation of Crimea, after the MH17 plane was shot down from the sky, Europe took Churchill’s advice and spoke out, and it will speak again, I am sure. There will be more and tougher sanctions if the international obligations set out in two Minsk agreements are not respected and if more people die because the guns keep flowing through the unprotected border. Europe will speak out when the rules of the internal market are challenged by uncompromising monopoly companies which long thought that corrupt deals would keep them above the law. Europe will say a word or two when the political parties that disagree with the very principles of European Union, like democracy, receive funding from financial institutions linked to the people running the Kremlin. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the quality and depth of EU-Russia relations is a determining factor for the stability and prosperity of our continent. Our partnership was severely impacted last year by the illegal annexation of Crimea and the destabilisation of Donbas. But Russia is also an important economic counterpart and an essential partner for the solution of many pressing international problems. This is the backdrop of the report you are debating today. I appreciate your efforts, in particular those of Mr Landsbergis, which have made this report a very important contribution to the debate on how best to shape relations with Russia. Let me take up the key political messages in your report. First comes the issue of unity. I fully share your conviction that our Russia policy is strong and successful only if it enjoys the unanimous support of all 28 EU Member States. The EU must continue acting on the basis of a broad and principled consensus on the Ukraine conflict and on its relations with Russia. This does not mean reducing our policy to the lowest common denominator. Quite the contrary – it means pursuing a comprehensive approach, responding to immediate concerns but with strategic patience and vision. The work of this House is an example of EU unity. I understand that the draft report has been adopted by an overwhelming majority in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET). I hope that the plenary vote will also reflect this, in order to send a clear political message about the views of European citizens. Second, there is the issue of balance. Your report contains strong criticism of Moscow’s actions such as the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol, its destabilising policy in Donbas, the multiplication of hybrid threats throughout Europe and the shrinking space for Russian civil society and media. At the same time, you are equally strong in stating the EU’s readiness to develop a constructive, predictable and mutually-beneficial relationship with Russia. Balance is at the core of our approach to the Ukraine conflict. On the one hand, we have been firm and decided to adopt sanctions. On the other hand, EU Member States and EU institutions are engaged in the search for a political solution to the conflict. Work is done in the Normandy format and in trilateral talks on trade and energy. The EU provides substantial assistance which is clearly conditional on real reforms in Ukraine. These efforts will continue unabated. Such a balanced approach should be followed between the EU and Russia. Dialogue and engagement should go together with resilience and firmness. We cannot turn a blind eye to security risks in sectors like energy, cyber-space, civil aviation or the impact of propaganda on our democracies. We must enhance our capacity for resilience and clearly state our red lines. At the same time, there is an imperative for cooperation based on the inter-dependence and complementarity of our economies, on historical and cultural traditions and on our capacity to make a difference when we act jointly. We should more often exercise our responsibilities as actors in a complex world of global and regional challenges. Based on mutual respect, the EU should remain ready to develop a new, positive relationship. Thirdly, the Commission shares your commitment to a comprehensive approach to our Russia policy. As High Representative Mogherini said in this Chamber at the start of her term last autumn, we believe that a successful foreign policy depends on success in internal EU policies fully committed to this principle. The work by High Representative Mogherini, with Commissioners Šefčovič and Malmström, on the trilateral talks on energy and trade proves we are on the right track. Fourth, let me stress the issue of integrity. The EU stands firmly behind democratic values, respect for human rights and a rules-based international order and will continue to do so. These fundamental principles underpin our commitment to the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine. They are the basis for our call on Russia to respect its international commitments, be this in the field of governance, security or international trade. We have maintained our support and assistance for civil society organisations and human rights projects in an increasingly challenging environment. Despite the deterioration of relations, we will enhance people-to-people contacts in all fields – from education, culture and research to cross-border cooperation. Let me finish with a crucial point in your report – perspective. I see that the very first plea you make in your report is for the EU to develop a contingency plan for the short term, as well as a comprehensive plan for long-term relations with Russia and with the EU’s East European partners. I share the reasoning behind this call. Events in Crimea and Donbas should not prevent us from taking a broader horizon for identifying the challenges we face and the opportunities to be exploited. EU Foreign Ministers agreed back in January to continue dialogue with Russia at expert level on the resolution of regional conflicts and tackling global challenges. Further engagement with Russia should be gradual, with Russia’s fulfilment of commitments under international law and steps for rebuilding mutual trust. For this to develop, we need a long-term vision – a strategy that we must develop further. To achieve a vision for EU-Russia relations that can embrace all scenarios, our reflection should already start now.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, what is most important in our relations with Russia is to be consistent and united. Relations between us and Russia have never been as bad as they are now. They are a result of the aggressive policies of President Putin. But let us not forget that there is a Russia other than the one we are dealing with now – the Russia of Sakharov, Politkovskaya, Nemtsov, Kovalyov and Memorial, and of all those Russians, of that great nation, who have been honoured with our Sakharov Prize. Russia is not fulfilling the Minsk agreement, and this is at the core of our relationship with and attitude to Russia. The position recently taken at the G7 Summit – that the G7 is in favour of continuing the sanctions and, if the need arises, increasing them – is the best answer to Russia’s present aggressive policy. Contrary to what some say, the sanctions which we are applying hurt the core of Russia’s economy. Thus they should bring a result, despite the fact that, so far, they have not changed the course of the Kremlin’s policy. Russia has recently blacklisted 89 people from the European Union, including 19 Members of the European Parliament. This is a very hostile act because it attacks the European elite in its relations with Russia.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the European Union has won the Nobel Peace Prize as a recognition of the promotion of peace and stability on our continent. I believe that this now obliges us in our relations with Russia, even though it sometimes seems very difficult. Because without Russia there will be no peace in Europe, as Helmut Schmidt, a veteran of eastern politics, has said. And, as the Commissioner also said: 'The more united the EU is vis-à-vis Russia, the more certainly we can contribute to European core values: democracy, the rule of law, human rights.'  The Socialist Group wants to speed up dialogue and diplomacy. Parliamentary diplomacy is also important. That blacklist of several European politicians and MEPs published by Russia was ill thought out and only deepened the cycle of mistrust. My group has had a positive impact on the Landsbergis report before us. Russia must implement the Minsk agreement and respect the right of Ukraine and its other neighbours to make political choices. The annexation of Crimea is contrary to international law and must never be accepted or recognised. But despite all this, the doors must be opened to dialogue and the aim must be to build new trust. Common interests and challenges include the fight against climate change, terrorism, cross-border cooperation, and, for example, the Northern Dimension policy is an example of how everyday cooperation is already under way at the moment. It is quite right to condemn, as the report does, the restrictions on freedom of the Russian media and the Internet, and we should also be concerned that Russia supports the activities of the extreme right in the EU Member States. The Socialist Group calls on the External Action Service and I hope Commissioner Jourová will take this message forward that the Member States and the Eeas will raise issues of homophobia and violence against LGBT people. There really must be a relentless policy on Russia, but at the same time new confidence must be built. Global problems will not be solved without cooperation between Europe and Russia. We're also tied to each other by geography. And this is a good starting point when we start to carry out the great task given to us by the Nobel Peace Prize. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I agree with many of the views expressed here by Mrs Jaakonsaari, but I lacked clarity and determination to 'put a dot over and'. Are the Socialists firmly in favour of maintaining sanctions against Russia, because that is the main subject of the European Union's decision? Can we hear an unequivocal 'yes' to upholding sanctions?

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: The answer to the blue card question. – Sanctions are absolutely necessary and, as Mrs Merkel has recently suggested, it is also possible to toughen them up. But it is important all the time to ensure that new visions of cooperation are also opened up. As the Commissioner said there, if we only list each other's sins from one report to another on both sides without opening up anything new, this spiral will get worse. I wouldn't want that to happen.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your First of all, I would like to express my regret that high representative Federica Mogherini is not here today. This is an important debate, this is an extremely important debate. We are talking about a truly changing international order and Russia, which, in this changing order, is trying to regain significant influence in the world at the expense of our region – including your regional member, The Commissioner. This is done through aggressive policy. The consequences of this aggressive policy have also been tested by the governments of which I had the honour of being a member, because we wanted to maintain, like you, dialogue with Russia. We wanted this dialogue to be friendly.  However, it is important to be aware of what Russian policy we are dealing with at the moment. That this is a country that, in its doctrines – both in military doctrine and in the concept of foreign policy – assumes strikes in close proximity if it considers that Russian interests are being violated. And unfortunately, russia recognises that it is violating its interests in almost every case, the simplest of things. And it is not that the framework of our debate is outlined within the framework of dialogue, economic interests and the convergence of the culture of our countries. Not only that, because there is a real serious threat, including in our territories, of hybrid warfare, of armaments in Kaliningrad, of violating the international legal order. We are dealing with our lack of decisions. Sanctions must be maintained. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mr President, I am sure we all have an illusionless picture of Russia and what is happening at the moment, but do you believe at all that it is possible to develop vision cooperation, re-engagement. Is that possible in your thinking at all?

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (Interpretation of the blue card question was not available) I just wanted to listen to her question, certainly. I just replied by intuition to one phrase: ‘re-engagement’. But it would be better to listen to the whole question.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I am sure that we all have the Russian picture – we have no illusions – but I want to ask whether you agree with the Commissioner that there should be, and could be, a kind of vision developed looking towards the re-engagement of Europe with Russia.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Madam, surely it is extremely necessary to develop a clear vision. In my opinion, Russia is now backing off any policy of re—engagement. Good examples of this are Russia’s decree banning transport to and from Afghanistan, and its breaking—off of talks with the Minsk Contact Group led by Heidi Tagliavini.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to compliment Gabrielius Landsbergis, who has made a resolution which combined all the credible forces in this Parliament. So thank you for doing so, Mr Landsbergis. The basis will be the return of international law by Russia: that is, of course, that Crimea should be given back to Ukraine and those who signed the Budapest Memorandum should be helping in this and should not be absent. Secondly, Russia should stop its involvement in eastern Ukraine and adhere to the Minsk Agreement – and only facts on the ground can change our position towards Russia. It is a two-track approach: it means being hard on Putin but willing to cooperate with Russian civil society, because many Russians want peace as well. It will take a lot of time. In this Parliament we always want things to happen overnight, but Putin has a long-term strategy of crippling Russia’s neighbours. So also to return Putin, or a successor, to international law will take time, and we have to be tough. We should not give in – let time do its work. There are no speedy resolutions, no business as usual. To conclude, there is that blacklist. But I think it is a list of honour. It is an honour to be on a list with so many colleagues who are pro-Ukrainian but who also love the Russian people and want to get Russia back on track. So again, to be on that list is an honour and a pleasure. We will not change anything. Putin has to change. That’s it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Mr van Baalen, thank you for accepting my question. I am afraid that, alas, I am not part of what you call the credible forces of the European Parliament, since I am less harsh on Russia than most Members of this Parliament.  However, you said one very interesting thing: you stressed that we had to get rid of a totally negative attitude towards Russia and that we had to cooperate with Russian civil society. You are right to be concerned about this cooperation. But do you think we can cooperate with Russian civil society if we practice an embargo?

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, this is of course possible. We will invite people, students, people of goodwill – they are welcome – and normally people of goodwill who are on this list also want to go to Russia to speak to their counterparts. That is goodwill, but it seems that goodwill is not much appreciated in Moscow, unfortunately.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Much has been going wrong in relations with Russia for years and is piling up: in order to turn this process around again, we need confidence-building instead of self-righteousness and great power, we need empathy instead of emotions or political fog candles, we need a clear increase in joint discussion and, above all, cooperation instead of further spirals of escalation or exclusion. Only those who want to assert themselves right-wing or driven by selfish interests, be it political or economic, step on the accelerator of escalation or that of over-pre-division on both sides. These would be important political axioms against which a report on the question of how to proceed in relations with Russia would have to be measured. But that is precisely what the rapporteur does not do. At the same time, it eludes the question of why relations with Russia are where they are and what this state of affairs has to do with our policy. Where the analysis is lacking, however, no strategy, even a common one, can arise, so there is only room for the game over gangs on the eve of the next EU summit, which is supposed to continue to wave through the sanctions against Russia, which are increasingly openly questioned by the Member States. The report should obviously not seek a way out of the impasse in relations, but should also help to discipline governments and, at the same time, help to promote processes of integration. In this sense, the assessment made by Parliament's services in rejecting amendments must be accepted. Unfortunately, the report is not a strategic INI report, because we need a change of strategy (the President is withdrawing the speaker's speech).

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very important one. Mr Scholz, you too are one of those who, in the last few days around the Elmau Summit, have repeatedly asked Germany, around the Elmau Summit, whether European policy towards Russia, the international policy of democratic governments, is not an insult to President Putin. This is a psychological argument that responds to what the European Union has done so far. What have we done and why have we done so? Something catastrophic has really happened in Ukraine since last spring. Not only has the country lost a large part of its territory – much of its industrial base has been destroyed – but it has killed well over 5000 people in that country, tens of thousands of people have been injured and crippled, we have thousands of traumatised children who have lived for months in the cellars of Donetsk and Luhansk. Although a plane in which many Western Europeans have sat has also been shot down, we in the European Union have not reacted militarily and as a great power, but we have responded with economic sanctions, diplomacy and negotiations. And this is extremely important for the European Union and its self-image, it is a change for the better and a change that just goes to the idea of soft power and has absolutely nothing to do with these ideas of great power that you have just described. The Minsk agreement is so far the only relevant thing achieved, based on these other foreign policy ideas of the European Union. And that is why, in order to make progress in this attempt to restore peace to eastern Ukraine, the most important thing for me in this report by Mr Landsbergis is that we do not abandon the sanctions, but that we bind them to the implementation of the Minsk agreement in a comprehensible, even reliable way, for all parties involved. And at this point, the next summit must also be quite consistent. It does not have to be a question of whether we need more or less sanctions. It must be about strengthening our diplomacy and our negotiations with this idea of economic sanctions, which are an alternative to military escalation. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe, however, that we should also talk about ourselves and great other changes. I think Donald Tusk was right when he proposed the Energy Union as a response to dependence on Russia. However, what has been on the table so far is not the major strategic blueprint that could make us more independent. For that we would have to (The President withdraws the speaker's speech)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year of work here and I am increasingly convinced that what kills not only the image, but also the effectiveness of our action, is the opportunistic and selective application of European principles and values in foreign policy, not according to reality, but rather geopolitical interests, realpolitik and other interests to be achieved. This report mentions many times violations of democratic principles, the rule of law and human rights in Russia. It stresses corruption and the threat of the country's freedom of expression and information.  Clearly, many of these critical issues are absolutely true, but I wonder why, for years, they have always been ignored and deliberately forgotten, when relations with Russia were so convenient to many of our states, that I also remember so many beautiful photos of our former prime ministers and presidents arm in arm with Putin? I wonder why, let us forget to point out that, as far as corruption and discrimination against certain categories of the population are due, today's Ukraine is certainly no better placed than Russia? This has also happened, including with Libya, and I could mention Gaddafi, I could mention many other cases as well. And I look forward to working with you on the future relationship with China, because I really want to see if there will be all these great champions on the defence of human rights and democracy, when I talk about Tibet, Iuguri, the death penalty and systematic violations of human rights democracy in the Asian giant. I want to see if there will be all these defenders of conditionality, the strict application of cross compliance or whether the business as usual will continue in that case.  China, which is then one of the great beneficiaries of our relative policy, given that instead of seeking balance, we have pushed Russia, its traditional adversary and now increasingly close energy partners – see Western and Eastern Route projects – into its arms, economic, military and political.  And on the subject of energy, I wanted to say to the rapporteur that when it comes to European resilience, I would like to remind him that the only possible one is based not so much on diversification, but on a real new deal on renewable energies, which would guarantee our energy independence. I will always be on the side of those who want real conditionality, always, and not on that of those who have memory gaps in command, nor on that of those who seek pretexts for a crazy arms race, taking away resources indispensable to our peoples, especially the Mediterranean ones, who are now on their knees because of the crisis and the sanctions that are affecting ourselves more than hitting Russia. The real war is the most dangerous we have in our own home: the war against poverty and marginalisation. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Castaldo, I understand that you are criticising the report. The issue that you raised and I did not see in the report, you are saying that the European Union would encourage the arms race. The Commissioner explained why the European Union must have a common policy and show vision. How do you want relations between the European Union and Russia to be not conflicted?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. My dear colleague, thank you for your question. I am not so critical of the report itself, I am critical of the general approach that the European Union is taking in its foreign relations. In my opinion, there is no other solution than a diplomatic solution based on soft power. But it seems to me that we are saying this in this report here, but our actions do not go that far and many of our Member States are simply calling for a greater increase in budgetary expenditure within NATO and greater military commitment. In my opinion, it is not in the interests of our peoples and it is certainly not in the interests... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: Mr President, unfortunately, the work of Mr Landsbergis offers us yet another example of this House's blindness to responsibility in the Ukraine crisis. The catalogue of untruths is impressive and I will give only an excerpt here. First, the 2008 Georgian crisis, which is blamed on Russia, when in 2009 the report of the independent international commission, headed by Swiss diplomat Heidi Tagliavini and funded by the European Union, established that Georgia was responsible for the conflict. Similarly, it eluded Mr Landsbergis that the annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol to Russia was the democratic expression of an overwhelming majority. I turn to the partiality of the report regarding the non-compliance with the Minsk agreements. Unbiased observers agree that violations exist on both sides. When one reads a text so unconcerned with truth, one can only worry about the grip of the war party here, a party of war that relentlessly tramples any hope of dialogue with Russia. I therefore call on the proponents of peace in Europe and dialogue with Russia to defeat this dangerous text. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: blue card issue. – I would like to ask my French colleague whether he believes that the Basque separatist movement is also an expression of a democratic Basque nationality and whether he would support the separation of the Basque region from France.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, to my knowledge, there is no popular expression of the Basque movement, there is no majority, there is no will in the Basque Country to achieve independence, on the French side at least. Therefore, this topic does not need to be. We must compare what is comparable: the case of Crimea is absolutely not comparable to the situation of the Basque part of France.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would first like to congratulate Mr Landsbergis on the quality of his report.  Indeed, we are now experiencing a major crisis in our relations with Russia, because russia is no longer, as we said, a strategic partner. It is a very aggressive power, both in terms of its domestic policy and in terms of its external relations.  At the domestic level, we know that it is no longer possible to talk about a democratic regime. It is a regime confiscated by a party and personalised, which creates a huge problem in political dialogue. Dialogue which, moreover, is no longer possible. We are far from direct and sincere exchanges with this part of the world.  I would then like to say that it is still becoming unbearable to hear the voices of our colleagues who reproduce the messages from Moscow as they are. It's like the 1980s with this false pacifist discourse, held precisely by people who are - in some cases - paid directly by Moscow. It's still unacceptable. To this, the European Union must respond with very harsh sanctions in order to silence the voices of those unconscious who speak to us from countries sotipended by Moscow. I'm sick of it. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I heard your speech, and there is a lot of huff and puff today about what should be done. Do you agree that there is a very limited range of things that the EU mouse can do to affect the Russian bear? And when you talk in this harsh rhetoric and tough way, you need to be very careful about what might lead from it – and this is from someone who, I can assure you, is in the pay of nobody whatsoever except the British taxpayer.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I think that the only solution available to us now is to help the Ukrainians to fight Russia, because it is a war taking place on their territory. We must therefore use all the means at our disposal, at Member State and EU level, to help these people defend themselves. It is a right of defence that the English once loved. Now that they themselves are at war with Europe, they are inventing anything to break this action.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my group hopes that the resolution we adopt on Russia will demonstrate European resolve to be united in expressing our concerns about the internal situation in Russia and the deterioration in our relations with Russia, but united, too, in sending a signal that we want to find a path to return to long-term dialogue and cooperation. This report is not just about what happened in Ukraine, but some of the spirit of Minsk – which Members across this Chamber have said they want to see upheld – should also be demonstrated in how Members conduct the debate and in the content of it. That is a comment aimed at those who seek simply to criticise Russia and ramp up the rhetoric, but it includes those from Syriza in Greece, to the Front National in France, to the United Kingdom Independence Party, whose almost uncritical support for the current position of Russia is deeply dangerous. There can be no business as usual with Russia. It is right that Russia was excluded from the G7 meeting this week, because its politicians and people need to understand that if you break international law, you cannot expect to contribute to international law-making. I have to say that I join the condemnation of the blacklisting of 89 EU politicians. I am worried by the tit-for-tat inclusion of travel bans on politicians on both sides. I would like to see politicians able to travel and to meet together. That is not to deny that we have serious disagreements, but because the only way such disagreements could ever be resolved is through dialogue and negotiation and, with due courtesy, I make the same point to President Schulz. That is why Russia’s politicians and media should also notice paragraph 4 of the report, where we explicitly say our objective is a return to constructive dialogue and that we set conditions for that, which are both realistic and achievable. It is why we identify in this report not simply the differences but also the shared interests we have with Russia. I have just come back from Iran, where the Russian offer on nuclear enrichment could be a key part of securing a nuclear deal, but where Russian exportation of missiles to Iran equally threatens a very different future. In Syria, too, we want Russia to engage and not to block international diplomacy, which recognises the overriding need to end violence and to hold to account those responsible for that violence. If Russia does not want to be seen as a military aggressor and as anti-democratic, it must not simply align itself with others who clearly are, and if Russia wants to be treated with respect and as a partner – and I reiterate that we would like to return to a situation where that is our relationship – then Russia could take a strong step towards that by genuinely engaging with us and other international partners on Iran and Syria, and in other international conflicts, to demonstrate that cooperation is possible and that interests are indeed shared. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab I agree with you that we should remember people-to-people contacts. We should remember, because power passes away, while the nation continues. We should delinee these two concepts. But would you agree with the view that, in these people-to-people contacts, it is particularly important to have contacts between young people in order to educate young people in a spirit of mutual understanding, tolerance and values close to the Union?

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I do think it is incredibly important to support civil society exchanges, which is why I express concern at the law on so—called ‘undesirable organisations’ and would make the point that the NGOs that Russia is targeting are not a threat to its constitution, security or defence. They are part of the solution; they are not part of the problem.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – Together with some other colleagues, I was also banned from entry for Russia on the bus. It shows to me the hopelessness and cynicism of a regime that is increasingly driven by revanchism. Putin sees himself as the guardian of "tens of millions" of Russians outside the borders, whom he must protect. This idea of the 'Ruskiy Mir' gives him unprecedented popularity, but is primarily intended to secure the dominance of his political and financial elite. I quote from the interesting Chatham House Report 'The Russian Challenge', published a few days ago: "This Russia cannot be integrated into a Europe based on international rules unless there is a fundamental change of direction in Moscow. That change has to come from within!" An emphasis in the Landsbergis report, which I want to emphasise, is therefore that it is important for the EU to keep the lines of communication with Russian society open and improve, that the EU sends clear signals to all those who bear responsibility in Russia, that Putin's path is a dead end, but that we are ready to become a strong partner again if circumstances change.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the current difficulties in EU-Russia relations are mainly due to the intensification of geopolitical confrontation in Europe. In Ukraine, it led to civil war and an international crisis, as a result of which the EU and Russia have even imposed sanctions on each other.  A solution must be sought to improve relations between the EU and Russia in order to resolve the Crisis in Ukraine peacefully. The Minsk 2 Agreement must be implemented. Russia must do so for its part and contribute to the separatists' compliance with the agreement as well. For its part, the EU must influence the Ukrainian Government to fully implement the agreement. Ukraine's new Constitution, which will enter into force by the end of this year, with decentralisation of power as a key point, and permanent legislation on the special status of certain regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, will play a decisive role.  In addition, the EU must do all it can to ensure that constructive cooperation is again achieved in EU-Russia relations.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. –   Mr Väyrynen, you are from Finland – Finland, which has a long history of relations with Russia, not always very happy. Do you not think that we should have a common position and a real common foreign and security policy of the European Union countries towards Russia – more solidarity among us towards Russia? Otherwise it is going to be difficult with peaceful means alone to make Russia comply with international law.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: The answer to the blue card question. – Mr President, I agree that we must have a common policy in relation to Russia. On the other hand, we all know that there are different views in the Member States, including in this House, and we need to negotiate what the common line is, what we are doing together. I think it is very important for the Union to make every effort to promote peaceful solutions and to seek to develop peaceful cooperation with Russia and also with other countries.

name: Tamás Meszerics (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, let me also congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Landsbergis, who has worked hard to find common ground. He has secured a very large support base for this report, and deservedly so. I would like to encourage all our colleagues in this House to support the very same report in the vote. The message is entirely clear, and many of our colleagues have already mentioned it: we need to maintain unity and uphold sanctions as long as Russia is not changing its policies both externally and internally. The message is clear, but we should also emphasise that we have no problem with the Russian people. We would like to have Russian society as partners; we would like to engage with anyone and everyone in Russia who finds an interest and a clear motivation in working together with us. What we have a problem with is Russia’s current leadership, and especially the way they use state power, both internally and externally. This is something we simply cannot condone and go back to business as usual. The Russian leadership very often relies on the concept of sovereignty. At some point they even called their system a ‘sovereign democracy’. I shall not go into how far it is a democracy now, but we should be fully aware that sovereignty has its limits. One of the limits of sovereignty is the sovereignty of your neighbour, and this has been violated by Russia in the last year and a half. The other obvious limit on sovereignty is international law and international norms. Until and unless Russia goes back to endorsing the international norms and international law relevant to its behaviour, there is no room for re-engagement. However, once that happens, we need to find a way to live together peacefully in this region with Russia. But the ball is in Russia’s court. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – The motivation for sanctions, which you support, is to impose hardship in order to change behaviour. The behaviour that the EU wishes to change is to project its own preferences on Russia rather than Russia’s preferences on its own people. Do you therefore believe that you or the EU have omniscience on democratic values and principles, that you can impose them on any country across the world?

name: Tamás Meszerics (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, let me remind you that the way we arrived at sanctions was fully democratic. Nobody in this House has ever questioned whether the sanctions the European Union imposed on Russia were democratically arrived at. Secondly, what we would want to change is Russia’s behaviour in areas where it does not have sovereign powers to decide the fate of people, including Donbas, eastern Ukraine and Crimea. This is where we would like to see change, and I think that is just right.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the tragedy of this foolhardy quest, in the guise of increasingly overt expansion of EU neo-imperialism whilst calling for a greater of role for the European Union on the international stage, underlines exactly how you misjudge the shift in global power. Your evangelical desire to become a so-called ‘strategic player’ in world affairs leads you to seem oblivious to the need to engage in a real diplomatic approach to secure better lasting EU-Russia relations. This extension of the EU’s tentacles eastwards underlines how your most significant foreign policy of recent times has turned out to be an utter failure. You completely underestimated Russia’s resolve in Eastern Europe and now the citizens of eastern Ukraine are paying the price for your folly. I agree with you that Russia is far from innocent in this crisis, but there is blame on both sides and the EU’s actions have done nothing to promote peace and reconciliation. Where are we now after all of this from the self-declared preserver of European peace? In the most dangerous world since the collapse of the Iron Curtain, NATO – which of course has many EU members who are minded and muddled by the EU common foreign, security and defence policies – has for the first time been singled out as a threat in Russian defence thinking, leading to increasing penetration into Member States’ territories and, alarmingly, a more aggressive nuclear doctrine than ever before. For the first time since 1975, the UK is entering into a debate about our EU membership, at the very time that EU—Russia relations are at their lowest ebb and on the back of the British Prime Minister David Cameron’s open call for the European Union to stretch, in his own words, from the Atlantic to the Urals.  I wait with bated breath to see whether, unlike in 1975, our politicians will be far more honest about the real intentions of how the EU intends to morph into a federal superpower. One thing is for certain though: history will be your judge. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – There is something called international law: being a member of the Security Council of the United Nations, humanitarian law, crimes against humanity. When I was in the Bosnian war, the British people – the British troops, the British government – stood up for peace in Europe in a brilliant way. Why, 20 years later, are you not ready to denounce an invasion with tanks, with thousands of troops from Russia fighting a war in Europe, with two million refugees? How would you make peace in Ukraine – with your appeasement?

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – It is a very straightforward answer, Frau Bildt. When you speak of the Balkans war, you spoke of mandates from the United Nations, you spoke of mandates through NATO; what I am highlighting here is the approach of the European Union, which seeks to impose its tentacles further east, at the same time provoking the Russian bear. The highlight of this debate – which has been highlighted by Herr Schulz up there, it has been highlighted by Monsieur Lebreton at the back, it has been highlighted by Signor Castaldo – is EU-Russia relations. This debate is turning into a love fest for EU expansion, and that... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mario Borghezio (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a lack of a great European vision of relations between the European Union and Russia, which is essential for the future of Ukraine itself and of our friends and colleagues in the countries of Eastern Europe. What advantage can they have from being crushed in the near future on the border of a Russia that feels threatened? Italy is paying heavily for the error of these sanctions. That is enough with these sanctions, as the Confindustria of my country says! This slows down our economy. We Italian patriots say no more sanctions, but we also disapprove of sanctions against diplomats and especially against our colleagues. It is a wrong policy of mutual retaliation, but as Italian patriots we welcome President Putin to the Milan Expo tomorrow. Welcome! It is time for a more effective policy, federalist thinking wins, not the Eurosceptics who say: they are wrong. The heirs of Spinelli's thought say it takes an inclusive policy, federalist thinking says enter, enter not out. You have to ... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is in the interests of the European Union and Russia to have good relations with each other. It is in our political interest to have good relations to ensure peace and freedom, and it is in our economic interest to have good relations. The European Union has the right to do so. There are concrete proposals for free trade areas, the resumption of the partnership agreement, the modernisation treaty. Because Russia is in a catastrophic economic situation by its own wrong decisions. But these relations can only take place on condition of compliance with international law. If we do not accept the principle that has been European law since the Helsinki Treaty, namely the territorial integrity of a country and the sovereignty of a people, we will not make any progress here. Ukraine, with 70.80% of the population, has adopted the pro-European course in every election since the early 1990s. And we are taking this pro-European course because this country wants to go down the liberal path, as other European countries have done. Poland's path is an example of Ukraine. Today, Ukraine has four times less gross domestic product than Poland, although it still had the same in 1990. That is why Russia can have relations and sanctions can be abolished if it fulfils Minsk and in this way creates conditions for the restoration of international law. International law is our basis for Europe ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would start by saying to the Commissioner that we all consider ourselves – except those in flagrant conflict of interest with Russia – blacklisted. This is the very moment to say that we have been blacklisted, directly or indirectly, by Russia without having violated any norm or any international law. Russia has done that. I will now turn to my language, Romanian. Dialogue has been and remains the key word in the EU-Russia relationship, it has been the European Union's generic approach with all its partners, and this report is a key report at a key moment for our relations with Russia. On the one hand, we note, according to the special OSCE monitoring mission and NATO, the constant military support provided by Russia to the separatists, and on the other hand we continue to hear the rhetoric of denial of Russia's involvement in the conflict in Ukraine, and even an outrageous interview by Putin that denies the evidence, saying that the West should not feel threatened by Russia. To all that, I said, is added the blacklist adopted last week surreptitiously showing Russia's true intentions. We must remain anchored in our European values and not deviate from the principles we all believe in, but we cannot remain indifferent to such provocative actions. I personally welcome President Martin Schulz's initiative to put restrictions on access... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am objective in this debate because I, too, am blacklisted. I thank all my colleagues for their solidarity on this issue. Hello other colleagues in one club. Congratulations to Mr Landsbergis for a very good report, although It seems to me that here we can cite such a Chinese proverb that 'the better is the enemy of the good'. I think this report would have been even better without some amendments, but of course the majority decide.  The European Parliament must take a hard line, because surely a more diplomatic, more integrated European Commission or the European Council will not do it for us. The European Parliament has always defended human and citizen rights more, including in the context of our European neighbours, than other European institutions. We cannot waive this obligation. And that there is in Europe, also here, the "party of friends of Russia", then we all see, know and feel it.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, whether we like it or not – and I must stress I certainly do not – we are already back in the times of the Cold War. Now it is a hybrid Cold War. Contrary to what he says publicly, this was Mr Putin’s deliberate policy aim, and he fully achieved it. It is not about getting back Ukraine, it is about Putin staying in power. It is about the re—Sovietisation of Russia. The old Bolshevik methods are being well tested, through external aggression and foreign enemies, internal suppression and isolation of Russian society from the West. We, the democratic world, have learned our lessons from the Cold War – though I do have some doubts after listening to our debates today – which are the following: a united and solid EU, a strong transatlantic partnership and full solidarity with those who cherish common values. It is also about us being able to deal with political bribery, such as in the shameful case of Madame Le Pen’s party. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Auštrevičius, for the first time I find myself agreeing with you in this Chamber – that is quite frightening, isn’t it? – when you say that we seem to be heading back towards a Cold War. In that analogy I do believe you are right. But how do we approach the greater diplomatic question? Is the answer really more EU expansion eastwards, more association agreements – for example in Central Asia, on the south-east of Russian boundaries? Is that only going to exacerbate the situation further and potentially make Mr Putin even more irate?

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – You are on the right way: I mean you are making some progress. Indeed, if you agree with some of the theses put forward by many of us, it is the right direction. As long as EU policy is based on international law and genuine partnerships – and indeed, free trade and political associations and partnerships – I think this is the right way. We have to extend our partnerships with the neighbourhood and we do not threaten the neighbours, unlike Mr Putin: he comes with tanks, we come with banks.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL).
text: – US President Calvin Coolidge once said, "America's business is business". What is the main concern of the European Union? Business, I hope.  Our trade with the Russian Federation amounts to approximately EUR 120 billion. The United States only has 3 billion, but it is pushing us into sanctions that are stupid, senseless and counterproductive and that are damaging to us. While our trade with the Russian Federation has stagnated, the United States' trade with the Russian Federation has increased by 6% in the past year. I think that we should finally think about and stop playing the role of useful morons for the United States. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Ransdorf, I would like to thank Mr Ransdorf for his After all, they have very good relations, including open channels of dialogue with Russia, with Moscow, with the Kremlin. Have you criticised in recent days that President Putin has signed a decree imposing the highest penalties for publishing in Russia the names of soldiers who have died in action outside Russia? This is obviously something that must be criticised. You can do that with your relationships. Do you do that?

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – President Putin interviewed Corriere della Sera and said that only a madman or a fool would assume that Russia wanted to attack someone abroad.  I think he is right, given that, of course, the Russian Federation is weaker than the Soviet Union, and that the Russian Federation's weapons budget is one-eighth of what the United States has. The United States, by the way, has an arms budget that exceeds the 12 countries behind the United States.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Harms, I would like to thank Mrs Harms for her I think you have to repeat the question to Mr Ransdorf. I do not think it was the interpreters who were involved. But I am very sorry that Mr Ransdorf – I almost want to say, in the best manner – did not give the answer to the question.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I have received numerous congratulations during the past 10 days for being on the blacklist, but I must say that I am not very pleased. I am not amused and I am not happy, because what we are seeing is Russia simulating many actions and measures that the European Union is taking towards it, and these sanctions against persons entering the Russian Federation are a mockery of democratic principles and the rule of law. There is no transparency, there are no individual justifications, there is no possibility of appeal, and I expect the European Union to protest against such measures. We have a problem with Russia simulating other measures, and now – with regard to these sanctions and the blacklist – we have heard Foreign Minister Lavrov saying that they tried to contain themselves for a long time in the face of the EU sanctions against Russia, but then they were forced to react, in line with the best principle of international law, which is mutuality and reciprocity. This is a mockery of international law – let’s face it. If this is the kind of partner we have before us, what can we expect? However – to come back to Mr Landsbergis’s report – I agree with everyone who has said that the EU must remain open to a constructive relationship and to dialogue leading to that, and that the EU wishes to return to cooperative relations with Russia, should the Russian authorities meet their international legal obligations. It is our duty to find openings of this kind. However, in the current situation, with Russia again increasing and accelerating its military measures against Ukraine, it is of the utmost importance that the EU stands firm.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We are discussing today a difficult, complicated and very unfortunate subject of relations between Russia and the EU. My own party's view is that military action is the wrong way to go to achieve a good result. The only sustainable way in a democratic and modern society is to have a deep and in-depth dialogue with the parties involved in a conflict.  In this conflict, the EU wishes to re-establish cooperation with Russia, provided that the Russian authorities comply with their international and legal obligations. Through the annexation of Crimea and the warfare against Ukraine, which is very much an act that is not accepted by the outside world as a whole, Russia has put itself in a situation where the EU has been forced to act with, among other things, sanctions as a peaceful lever.  In response to this, Russia has established a so-called blacklist of undesirable politicians who are now not allowed to visit Russia. This is not an act worthy of a modern country and will certainly not improve Russia's reputation abroad.  People are suffering every day this conflict is going on and, unfortunately, people are also dying. It is simply not dignified, what is happening, not at all. A democracy is based on responsibility, respect for people and their lives, and acceptance of people's desire for freedom. I would like to call on Russia, as a step on this road, to pack up its stock and withdraw from Crimea. Start a dialogue, and do it now.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the draft report before us outlines the difficulties in our relationship with Russia, from its aggression in Ukraine to allegations of corruption and the suppression of fundamental freedoms of speech, the press and political opposition. Member States have shown solidarity with those affected through a programme of sanctions, and the UK has supported those. But ultimately a solution needs to be found recognising international law and agreements, and through diplomatic channels. In the run up-to July, when these sanctions will be discussed again, I want very quickly to indicate how destabilising these sanctions have been for agriculture markets across Europe, particularly in the dairy and pork sectors. Even within my own constituency of Northern Ireland, product has been refused entry into Russia, costing processors there significant amounts of money. Amidst sending a message of zero tolerance to Russia and solidarity with those impacted by aggression, if sanctions are to continue, the Commission must ensure that there is adequate help to sectors across… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Landsbergis on a good report. Russia has always been a tough neighbour to Europe. It is a country that bases its relations with Europe on a 'split and rule' policy. That is why the Landsbergis report also essentially reflects the compromise between the optimistic and north-eastern pessimistic view of the South-West of the European Union on relations between the European Union and Russia.  We all need to be aware that Putin, in an attempt to smash us, is essentially offering a new Munich and a new Yalta. He wants to restore the spheres of influence in Eastern Europe and create a buffer zone in which Russia reserves the right to decide on national fates.  Europe must be able to respond with one voice. Sanctions must not be reviewed before Russia has fully complied with the minsk ceasefire. Europe must be able to respond to Russia by ... (MePs stopped.) (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: , answering the blue card question. – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Dear Mrs Kalniete, Are you aware that calling for further sanctions and pressure against Russia against the existing political regime will also suffer, including those who helped you and your family survive in tomsk, to survive the Stalinic repression that helped you survive? They're going to suffer, too.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: blue card issue. " You know, Mr. Mamiqui, if you know so little about Siberia, you better keep quiet. Three of my grandparents, two grandfathers and my grandmother, died in Siberia. My mother almost died of starvation. What help can you talk about here?

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, honourable Commissioners, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The European Union and Russia adopted economic sanctions against each other, are taking measures to replace imports and exports on both sides, a blacklist of officials, in fact lists, increased funding for defence. The parties are convinced that they are only answered by the actions of the opposing party, as Russia and the European Union have different milestones. Russia is convinced that the European Union was the first to support the removal of the elected President of Ukraine, Yanukovych, but the European Union, for its part, believes that russia has been the first to take crime directly. This session will accept two reports with content that deteriorates this relationship even further, and this is a continuation of the confrontation: like two cars running toward each other, and none of the drivers want to stop or give way, because everyone is convinced of their own righteousness. Dear colleagues, if there is a clash, there will be no winners. Perhaps it is time for both sides to stop, to impose a moratorium on insults and to enter into a normal dialogue? Thank you!

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the awful reality seems to be that Russia is getting away with her aggression – perhaps not surprisingly, given the weaknesses in the EU approach. Firstly, the effectiveness of EU sanctions is limited by the fact that they do not restrict the sale of Russian gas to Europe. To confront Russian aggression effectively, certain European countries must wean themselves off reliance on Russia for energy – and by the way, we should open the Energy Chapter with Turkey. Secondly, we must recognise that it is the Transatlantic Alliance, embodied in NATO, that is the essential guarantor of European security and which is the defence organisation that Moscow takes seriously. NATO needs to be revitalised. EU meddling in defence risks undermining these efforts and dividing the Transatlantic Alliance. Thirdly, more must be done to discourage countries that are EU Member States from doing deals with Russia, such as offering naval port facilities, which undermine Western security and solidarity.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: – Relations between the European Union and Russia have been moving us for several months and we are actually at an impasse, in a vicious circle. I sometimes feel that sanctions are being imposed and sanctions imposed and that it has actually become a kind of power play. Who's got the biggest? Who dares to go the farthest? And in the meantime, young Russian people are growing up with anti-Western propaganda and it is our fruit growers, our vegetable growers, our meat growers who are paying the net high price of the boycott.  My father taught me one big lesson in life: never argue with your neighbors unless you're willing to move. Well, we can't move. I have heard a lot of people here today who say that they are happy and proud to be on the list. Well, I'm actually really glad I'm not on that list. Politicians need to engage in dialogue, politicians need to travel. Russia s a great country. I therefore intend to visit this country soon.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Although it has been repeatedly said in this Chamber that there are doubts about the value or impact of the sanctions policy, I would like to ask my fellow Member what, in a situation where Russia wants a different Europe, what exactly should be done.  (The Member repeated his question because there was a lack of interpretation.) Several people have raised the real value and effectiveness of the sanctions policy, but I would like to ask my fellow Member that, in a situation where Europe wants a different Russia and Russia wants a different Europe, what exactly should we do besides try to put strong pressure on the Russian party. Thank you!

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. – Your question is not entirely clear to me, colleague. We do have that pressure. We have to keep talking as politicians. We shouldn't like putin or like or correct him. He's just the president of Russia. We have to be respectful of him. I believe that the solution to the conflict, as some members have also said, is that we enter into a new debate on NATO, on the European security architecture and that we engage in that debate with Russia.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today's resolution is another link in the chain of resolutions that shape today's European foreign policy. A policy which, in the service of the furious conflict of interests over hegemony in the region's energy map, is completely indifferent to the disastrous effects on the peoples of the region. And this ruthless war of interests is ruthlessly invested with calls for respect for international law, as Mr Brok has previously said, describing the relations sought with the Union's strategic partners. The false dilemma of bad Russia not meeting the conditions of a European strategic partner is a farce. It is sufficient to look at the list of European strategic partners so far to understand how much this policy respects international law, democracy, state sovereignty, human rights. Ladies and gentlemen, with the revival of cold war political practices, the cultivation of fear, uncertainty and insecurity, I ask you directly the question: do you really believe that this is the positive vision and hope we give to the peoples of Europe? That this is the united Europe we want?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, I have heard plenty of good advice given to Russia. Elmar Brok says that Russia is in a catastrophic situation. Please bear in mind that the national debt is 13% of GNP. No country occupied by the European Union has such a good result. Perhaps you should rather listen to some good advice given by the Kremlin. I agree that it is not good that Moscow is increasing financing of the media, but plenty of Russian media are being financed by foreign powers, which is much more dangerous. One should bear in mind the fate of the Ukrainian state destroyed by the Americans – like Syria, Egypt, Libya. After democratisation, Serbia lost Kosovo and Ukraine has lost Crimea and Donbas. What would Russia lose if the Americans arranged a new Maidan on Red Square – and who would acquire it? Moreover, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – I welcome the Landsbergis report, and I welcome it, inter alia, because it is not limited to Russia's aggression towards Ukraine, but also does not forget Georgia and Foreign Policy.  I recently visited not only Mariupol, but also defence positions in Srokin, together with other colleagues in the European Parliament, and I can therefore confirm from my own experience much of what the Landsbergis report describes. The Minsk agreements are becoming a piece of paper that the Putin regime does not take seriously. Neither the ceasefire, nor the absence of heavy weapons, nor the release of people such as pilot and MEP Nadya Savchenko, have fulfilled any of this. I therefore believe that the European Union should toughen up on sanctions against the aggressor without losing hope that, following the fall of the Putin regime, Russia will once again become an EU partner, as in the past.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Putin's Russia has begun aggression with the illegal occupation of Crimea and continues it in the Donbas, not only against Ukraine's independence, against international law and global peace and security. We don't want war. We are and have always been open to dialogue and cooperation with Moscow, despite the blacklists of European politicians. So we have to impose economic, financial and other sanctions for many economic and other interests that are affected. Putin has European disunity. Let's change his turns. Sanctions will have to be strengthened if Russia continues to violate the Minsk Agreements. But it's important to direct them. The Russian people already have to endure the gag and adventure imposed by Putin's authoritarian regime. It is essential that the European Union supports, politically and financially, human rights defenders, bloggers, independent media, academics or NGOs, finally independent civil society in Russia.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – As rapporteur for this House on relations between the European Union and China, I have recently been very concerned with relations between Russia and China and also the implications for the EU-Russia relationship. Mrs Mogherini, our High Representative, has recently been in Beijing and I would like to ask the Commissioner to put two questions to her. I'm sorry she's not here.  There is a huge deepening, without precedent, analysts say, of relations between Moscow and Beijing. How does this affect EU-Russia relations, especially in this crisis situation?  There is often talk of a constructive contribution by China on the world stage. Well, I would like to ask the High Representative what the constructive contribution has been from China on the de-escalation in Ukraine. What constructive input has there been on the part of China to achieve a pacification in this terrible situation?

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, from my personal point of view, the Landsbergis report – especially its initial version – is unfortunately good proof of the aphorism that the road to hell is paved with good intentions. We cannot avoid bias if rapporteurs are feeling strong emotions related to the subject of the report. We all know the tragic history of Eastern Europe. Politicians from this region may be an important source of information about Russia; however, it is a big challenge to all of us to write balanced reports on Russia and to consider various points of view in a constructive way. Regrettably, Mr Landsbergis is no exception. We always have to consider the atmosphere in the rapporteur’s Member State. I fully agree with the approach of my colleague Paavo Väyrynen, but this report is unfortunately not that balanced. Colleagues, there is still a glimmer of hope for normalising relations with Russia, but this report is hardly a step in the right direction. EU-Russia relations are much more important than our political ambitions. Therefore, despite the fact that I partly agree with the statements of the paper, I cannot support even this improved version. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I have a question to Ms Toom, because I know that she is from a party which has an agreement with the Russian leading party. You said that there is hope that there will be an improvement. Can you elaborate? Maybe you have a better idea of what is going on in Russia. Where is the hope? Where are the changes in Russia?

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, it is true that we have a real agreement, just like 36 other European parties, including the party of Mr Jean-Claude Juncker. But I am a Member of the European Parliament, not of the Russian Duma. I feel that if we have ambitions to have some kind of dialogue with Russia, then we have to stay more constructive and free of emotions.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, some colleagues give me the impression that they feel very good in the comfort and security that this Parliament provides to draw up ideas for solving a problem, based more on emotions caused by history than on logic and realism. Whether we like it or not, Russia and the European Union are neighbours and immediate action must be taken by both Russia and the European Union, so that we can move towards balance and condescension, cooperation and realism.  We call on the European Union and Also Russia to immediately stop the actions that create tensions in their relations, because this above all annoys the peoples, the populations, the citizens. Thousands of people are killed on the streets and inside their homes. Sanctions do not help in this direction and should be abandoned. The economic war is victimizing the peoples of the region. Our continent has no more tensions.  We are seeking a Europe of cooperation and solidarity, a Europe that says 'no' to confrontation and war. Unfortunately, however, the report we are being called upon to discuss does not build bridges in this direction, but rather it is the cold war climate and the confrontations. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you about the 20th paragraph of the Landsbergis report, which talks about financial support for independent organisations. Does it have a chance to implement, in the context of Russian law on agentural activities? Will we not harm these NGOs?

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. – The truth is that I did not understand the question, but much more I do not understand why it is addressed to me. It is a question addressed to Russia. I don't represent Russia here, what can I say to you?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Report, point 11: We are extremely concerned about the increasing restrictions on internet freedom in Russia. Speaking of which, Edward Snowden has been a political refugee in this terrible Russia for two years now. When does the Union finally want to get him out of there? Point 12: it is about the fight against Russian propaganda, obviously against Russia Today and other televisions. In exactly the same tone as the Communists did about the need to pursue Free Europe, Radio Free Europe.  Point 15: calls on the EU to provide support to ensure high levels of journalistic standards in Russia. I just saw citizenfour about Edward Snowden. I recommend everyone to check it out. Here I see in my mind's eye the scene where, in the basement of the Guardian, the British secret service broke the media on which journalist Glen Greenwald received information from Edward Slowden about the unmasking of the secret service terror state. Are you sure we are the good teachers in these matters?

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to the fact that this report can obtain such a large, broad majority in this House. It creates clarity, it does not gloss over anything, but it also creates opportunities for the way out and the resolution of these crises. Congratulations! Dialogue, however, presupposes a willingness to be sincerity. Our biggest problem is the different perceptions. If Russia does not call the annexation an annexation, but it is an annexation and therefore a violation of international law, if Russia makes a blacklist and does not have a justification for a single person and we make sanctions that have the justification for the annexation, and if Russia instructs people to put fake news into the networks – as Ludmilla Savchuk has said – then I must ask Russia to do the necessary reasons for the annexation. to look reality in the eye, to honestly identify the crises and problems and to be ready for dialogue.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ms Lybacka here expressed the view that we should distinguish between Russian society and power, and I believe that this is a very important observation. Where does the power of Russian power come from – president Putin at the moment? Simply out of public acceptance. I wanted to ask what is the vision, the opinion of the Russian public about the European Union, if one in five prime ministers of this Community goes individually to Russia, asks for something there and does not maintain what we call the unity of the European Union based on our common goals? Let us also remember that Russia is an important, still global partner for us. Its position at the UN is important, its position in the fight against terrorism is important, including in the islamic state, in relation to Iran and Syria, Iraq, and therefore, as has been stated, we need a strategic, sensible and long-lasting relationship. I do not agree with Mr Carver, we do not behave imperialistly, we want a principle: do not violate the territorial integrity of our neighbour.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Language is an important aspect of diplomacy. In this respect, I think it is very positive that the Landsbergis report is a little less excited than the previous report on Russia.
