Unfortunately, the situation has not been very pleasant in recent days. After the Russian side disclosed its list of bans on entry into Russia, the outcry here in the EU was great. But it had to be clear to everyone that Russia would respond to the Western travel bans with similar countermeasures. Incidentally, it had been known for months that such a list existed. Sanctions always cause damage to both sides. We are currently seeing this in the economic sanctions imposed by the EU. According to Russian data, trade with the EU fell by 10% last year and by as much as 18% with Germany. This is costing us a lot of jobs. Perhaps this would still be understandable if US imports to Russia had not increased by 6% at the same time. This shows that the damage is very great if the sanctions demanded by the United States in particular are enacted, but then lose market share to the United States.

name: n/a
text: – There are many reasons why I cannot support this resolution, even if it is better than the original form. For example, the text inflects democracy in all its downfalls, proclaims an interest in dialogue with Russia, and is built to continue to prevent its renewal. He unilaterally accuses Russia of all the sins that fit into the text. On the other hand, I am missing a similarly hard document criticising tolerance for the marches of SS veterans and nationalists and neo-Nazis, e.g. in Kaunas or Riga. After all, let us first look at compliance with our own internal rules so that it does not happen that the President of Parliament, without a mandate from Members, arbitrarily decides to suspend the activities of a properly established EP delegation.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Landsbergis' report is still unbalanced, despite the slowdown. He does not try to mediate or balance, but he pours gasoline on the fire. How can we refrain from presenting on both sides the violations of the Minsk ceasefire? How can we refrain from giving any results on the Odessa massacre in such a report? How can it be that we are working with associative terms and saying that a plane that fell from the sky and does not say that it is not clear to this day who was responsible for the unfortunate downing of this flight? We should not react to the corresponding provocations that we ourselves initiated before. It is not acceptable for us to impose entry bans on the part of the EU and then, conversely, to be upset about Russian entry bans.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union's relations with Russia have deteriorated greatly. The cause is Russia's behavior with Ukraine, including its annexation of Crimea. The 21st century requires conduct that is respectful of international law that Russia has ignored. Today's globalized world presents significant global challenges, such as climate change terrorism, disarmament. It is true that in order to meet these serious challenges we need dialogue and cooperation with Russia, an important global player and great military and energy power. However, the European Union has lost confidence in the Russian authorities. We no longer perceive Russia as a strategic partner after what happened. It is essentially Russia, which must change its line of behaviour, to put an end to this situation of mistrust. The first thing is to fully comply with the so-called Minsk Agreements. What happened recently in Marinka indicates the opposite and, logically, the so-called "blacklist" of Union personalities, who are not allowed to enter Russia, is also a step in the wrong direction.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the G7 has just wrapped up and, instead of being a participant, Russia is now on the receiving end of warnings of further sanctions. It has only itself to thank, and we may indeed need to increase pressure even further. We also need to reflect on the fact that the Russian Government has not just succeeded in hoodwinking its own population into supporting a policy that is putting the country on a collision course with its neighbours and wrecking its economy, but what is of real concern is that it is also, increasingly, gaining traction in our own Member States and even with Members in this House by wielding the power of money, energy and disinformation. This may impact our ability to take a strong stance and defend our interests. Therefore, only strong yet realistic demands will secure our citizens’ interests. The door must remain open for dialogue, but our red lines should remain strong and clear: no return to business as usual unless the Minsk Agreements are implemented, the territorial integrity of Ukraine is restored and the OSCE-based security order in Europe is respected.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – Let us not forget that President Putin's impunity has not started in Ukraine and has not happened since yesterday. Poland has still not recovered the black boxes and wreckage of the government plane on which the Polish elite, led by President Lech Kaczynski, was killed on 10 April 2010. It has been Putin who has been investigating Smolensk for five years. I regret that, once again, the European Parliament resolution will not call for an international investigation into this matter, that the European Union has not helped Poland to explain the causes of the Smolensk disaster, that the European Parliament censored the Smolensk exhibition, which demanded only the truth about Smolensk, and that the leaders of the largest European countries are hiding the truth about Smolensk.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I am happy that this report mentions the growing issue of Russian propaganda, not only in Russia itself but also in neighbouring countries such as the Baltic States and Ukraine. An open and free internet is becoming one of the building blocks of our democracy, but it is also a powerful tool in the hands of authoritarian regimes. What is happening in Russia now is an information war, as all channels are used to spread lies and conspiracy theories. We cannot, however, fight Russian propaganda with EU or US propaganda, although we need to make all possible efforts to guarantee that Russians get uncensored information about what is going on in their country and in the world. We should not underestimate the power of words when those words are lies. I therefore call on the Commission and on the Member States to step up their efforts on this front. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I agree with you that we must not fight propaganda with propaganda. Do you agree with me that, as regards Russia, the key is going to be pragmatism rather than political idealism? We all have concerns about the current appalling situation, so do you agree that the real question is: what will make a practical difference?

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – What would make a practical difference is to guarantee that the Russians get uncensored information so that they have access to decide for themselves what is going on in the world and in their country. As long as the information is censored or directed in the direction that the regime wants it to go, then it is not a free decision.

name: Georg Mayer (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am certainly not a defender of Vladimir Putin. But let's stand out a little bit about this emotional debate about Putin, and let's see what lies ahead. Then I am very surprised at the measures that are being proposed here. On the one hand, I find it very remarkable that, for example, funds are made available by us to monitor all the Russian media. I also find it quite remarkable that funds should also be made available to monitor the reporting of political parties and organisations. Ladies and gentlemen, this reminds me very much of the cold war. That's something I certainly don't want. As an accompanying measure, President Schulz will then deny the Russian ambassador access to this House. Ladies and gentlemen, do you think that is reasonable? Do you think that this is a sensible competence for the European Union to resolve conflicts? For me, it's not. I can only congratulate you on this, because you can be anxious and anxious.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr! I should perhaps point out, on behalf of the President, that the Russian ambassador has not been denied access to the House. This has been misreported in some German-language media.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, first of all, I thank my colleague Landsbergis for a quality full report that sends pertinent political messages on relations between the European Union and Russia today.  In recent years, the European Union wanted partnership, wanted cooperation and wanted a relationship with Russia based on mutual respect. And what did she get? She received Moscow's policy, which through the doctrine of the Russian world brought back to the center a policy of zones of influence that, either by creating active or maintaining frozen conflicts, supporting rebels, occupying the territory of neighboring countries or even annexing it in her own parliament, showed that she does not hold up to international law and European values at all. Such a policy is unacceptable. Playing the map of trade relations, energy dependencies, these are the elements on which Russia seeks to disunies members of the European Union.  Therefore, at this time, with this report we must send a policy of unity of support to those countries that want to choose their European path, and equally tell Moscow firmly that this as it behaves today is not the policy of a responsible member of the Security Council.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on the point of the misunderstanding of what the sanctions imposed by President Schulz were exactly, the text restricts free access to Parliament to the Ambassador and one other named diplomat. It is not only a German newspaper, but half of Europe that misunderstood. The President would have done better to ask the Legal Service before formulating sanctions to impose on a third country.

name: President. –
text: I have corrected a misinterpretation by one colleague here in the House. You have read the correct text, and the correct text confirms what I have just said.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Does September 5, 2014 tell you anything else, or February 12, 2015? Indeed, on these two days, the two agreements were signed in Minsk, which, if they had been respected, would have made our meeting today and much more unnecessary. But that has not happened. Russia has signed both treaties, but Russia has so far failed to implement them. Not Russia alone, mind you! There has also been little progress in Ukraine. We are still waiting for more rights for the regions, we are waiting for action against intolerable corruption, we are waiting for oligarchs to stop viewing state resources as self-service shops. Russia, meanwhile, is trying to drive a wedge between individual Member States of the Union. And Russia is gaining sympathy from the far right and the far left, including those who sit here in the House, baiting them with money or credit. We saw through this game. It must come to an end quickly.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in 1999 Putin swept to power in Russia, offering to bring order to the chaos, and we thought we would see Russia becoming part of a Western, democratic system. This was in the heady days when we were still busy celebrating the end of the Cold War. In our haste, it seems that we overlooked some of the small print that Putin had included in the text. Now we can see that his real goal was to recreate, by force if necessary, a crony capitalist version of the Soviet Union. Where Putin has not succeeded in bullying his neighbours into joining the Eurasian Customs Union, he has spread war and chaos. In 2008 he invaded Georgia and now he is invading Ukraine, after annexing Crimea. Such ambitions, as recently declared by the G7, must have clear and serious repercussions in our relations with Russia. I have always been a strong supporter of EU sanctions, which must continue for as long as a threat to Ukraine remains. Putin rages against a unipolar world: what he intends, in reality, is the unravelling of the post-war settlements, based on the rule of law and human rights, in favour of the ‘might is right’ dogma.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, today during the debates on Mr Landsbergis's report, the question of the European Union's relations with Russia is once again raised. The report clearly reflects our deeply damaged relations and calls into question the fundamental principles of security in Europe.  However, we must ask ourselves the question "Can the European Union imagine a return to previous relations with Russia?" and "What action plan must the Union draw up in order to get back on the path of dialogue?". Blacklisting European politicians and members of this Parliament does not help to achieve this progress. Moreover, this predisposes the conflict in Ukraine to become frozen, and our experience with Georgia shows that this is a serious obstacle to the development and stability of the countries concerned and their convergence with the European Union.  The use of energy as a major foreign policy instrument is a prerequisite for the crisis to grow and the effects to be reflected in other parts of the region. In this regard, I support the rapid establishment of a strong European Energy Union.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, let us unite in supporting this report to send a clear message: the European Parliament does not accept Russian aggression towards its neighbour or threats towards Europe, and the Kremlin propaganda will not succeed in dividing us and destabilising Europe. Yes, we should negotiate, but from a position of strength. And what are our strengths, colleagues? They are our economic power and our unity. Therefore, I call on the Member States to stand firm and united and, at the Council meeting on 25 June, to renew the sanctions, as an instrument of our determination for peace in Europe, until the Minsk agreement is fully implemented. An attack against a Member of the European Parliament is an attack on the people of Europe. Therefore, I feel more proud than intimidated to be on the blacklist. It shows that we are doing a good job. The attempts to censor me make me more determined to speak up and to be committed to peace in Europe.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, the events of recent years confirm Russia as the most important neighbour of the European Union, which has a great influence on many aspects of the functioning of the Union. From interdependence in the energy sector to ever-sensitive European security issues to the impact on the Union's internal relations. Instead of being our partner in crisis hotspots across the common neighbourhood where the European Union and Russia can collectively seek answers to challenges, aggression against Ukraine, economic sanctions, lists of undesirables, a growing suspension of democracy and the absence of real dialogue are the reality of current relations. Unfortunately, the preconditions for partnership are not met: the relationship of trust, respect for international principles and signed agreements. The Minsk agreement also does not work as an agreement on a temporary ceasefire. And without fair respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity and security order in Europe, partnership is not possible. Announcements of the co-ordaging of the Baltic republics or the limitations of the Western Balkan states, where the measure of forces with the West is also happening, are also dangerous. Perhaps an illusion, but I still hope that President Putin will know with an open mind tomorrow to hear humane messages during his meeting with Pope Francis.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: – Sharing common values is a fundamental pillar on which we must build our external policy. We are not value-compatible with Russia at the moment. Unfortunately. The values of cooperation, solidarity and mutual support run counter to destabilisation, violence, non-respect of agreements and international law. We are seeing that instability and relativism are very easy to bring ever closer to our borders. On the other hand, democracy, rule of law and respect for human rights are becoming increasingly difficult to build beyond our borders. Union policy can only be effective if the Union is united. Here I see a major challenge to our common foreign and security policy. It is not possible for short-term benefits to become the motives of our policy towards Russia.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the actions taken by the Russian Federation continue to undermine any immediate prospect for reengagement and cooperation on the part of the EU. The Russian blacklist of European politicians and officials, including a large number of Members of this Parliament, adds yet another obstacle to mutual trust and to repeated efforts for a peaceful and sustainable solution to the current crisis. By illegally annexing Crimea and waging an armed conflict against Ukraine, Russia has intentionally chosen not to be a partner. Breaching its international commitments including the United Nations Charter, the Helsinki Final Act, the Budapest Memorandum and the Paris Charter, Russia has contributed to thousands of deaths in Eastern Ukraine. Yet no opportunities for genuine and constructive dialogue with Moscow will be spared. The Russian Federation is and remains a prerequisite for the de-escalation of the conflict and a political, lasting solution. In the long term, the ultimate objective is and must be that of restoring dialogue and engagement with Russia to achieve peace on the European continent.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I am fully convinced of the following: that pursuing a strategic partnership based on common values and principles between the European Union and Russia was a real intention; that war is the worst possible way of regulating issues of inter-international co-sim in Ukraine, as well as relations between Russia and Ukraine; that war violence on European soil is a tragic paradox that is at odds with political developments since the fall of the Berlin Wall and is a threat to peaceful development in the region; that no country wishing to share European values and principles voluntarily with the European Union is a threat to any other country in the world; that without respect for the rules of international law and agreements, progress can not be made in mutual trust, without which there can be no partnership.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Mr President, re-balancing policy towards Russia would require a more self-confident role for the EU as an autonomous security actor, not least through greater engagement in the resolution of the existing frozen conflicts in the Eastern Neighbourhood. We need deeper cooperation in the field of defence and security, working towards a vision of common European armed forces with an integrated operational command, as well as a fully-fledged EU intelligence agency. We need an energy union: a joint mechanism to coordinate Member States’ negotiations of bilateral energy supply contracts and, ultimately, to empower the EU to negotiate contracts on behalf of the Member States. That is a way to overcome the strongest tool Russia has for dividing the Member States.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I appreciate that the Landsbergis report is based on the quality of truth and realism – based upon, I would say, positive conditionality. The message to the European Council is very clear. Sanctions have to be continued – and even strengthened without any hesitation – because they have made a significant difference already. If not, Mr Putin would have already attacked the next targets, possibly the Baltic States. There is no dilemma about whether to have dialogue or not; it is about the substance of dialogue. In 1938 Hitler dismembered Czechoslovakia as a result of dialogue with some democratic states, and a big war followed. So, in the same fashion, Mr Lavrov called in Munich this year for dialogue. The Ukranian crisis, he said, is an instrument to force the West to negotiate a new security system. So our message is: it is not about dialogue, it is that Mr Putin has to change or be changed.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is indisputable that the Russian regime has unfortunately evolved in an increasingly autocratic sense, with disrespect for individual freedoms and disrespect for the actions of opposition s and minorities.  This also contributes, to a large part, to the fact that, at the external level, there is a systematic violation of some basic principles of international law and, from this perspective, the positions that the European Union has adopted over the last few months, with the support, moreover, of the United Nations, have proved to be the most correct and the most appropriate. This, however, should not lead us to lose sight of the geopolitical importance of the relationship between the European Union and Russia. Someone has just referred to the fact that we are seeing a tendency for Russia to strengthen its relations with China and I believe that, on that level, we should be careful in how we approach the possibility of increasing the sanctions to be imposed on Russia. On the one hand, we must support those who fight for human rights in Russia. I think that is absolutely fundamental. On the other hand, we have to have some consideration in how we approach the Russian issue in international terms.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Russia signed the Budapest Memorandum in 1994, in which Ukraine renounces its nuclear arsenal in favor of Russia. For this, Russia undertakes to respect Ukraine's territorial integrity. Twenty years later, Russia has grossly trampled on this treaty. It's not the first time. Any treaty signed with Russia is worth the paper it's written on.  And it's not the last time. Today, Russia is violating the agreements signed in Minsk and once again showing its contempt for democratic principles and respect for international law. I ask you, Commissioner, how much longer are we going to be humiliated by the Russian Federation?

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – I congratulate my colleague Gabriel Landsberg for his very important and relevant report. The European Union has been working consistently for many years to develop a mutually beneficial strategic partnership with Russia. However, the illegal annexation of Crimea, the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and the apparent mention of democracy and human rights in Russia itself are a serious test for the European Union and a test of its solidarity. The Baltic states are well aware of what russia's current neighbourhood means. They were the first to feel the brunt of the restrictions and sanctions imposed by Russia on their economies. But he stood up. For many years, we have been saying that Russia is using energy as a tool of political pressure. The European Union must therefore draw the right conclusions and make every effort to create a strong European Energy Union. Only a solidarity, not a single and divided Europe, will be able to withstand external pressure. I therefore want to believe that the European Union will pass the test of solidarity with Russia.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all, congratulations to Mr Landsbergis on his report. I think it is important to state that we want open relations, dialogue and cooperation with Russia based on respect for international law. But this is the problem. The regime of Putin is breaking international law and undermining the European peace order, and he is waging war in the free nation of Ukraine in Europe. This is the fact and reality. No one is threatening Russia. But the Putin regime fears democracy, the rule of law and freedom of expression. They fear the open dialogue that we want. That is why some of us are blacklisted, because they want to blacklist freedom of expression and democracy and the open society. So let us turn this into an increased dialogue underlining sanctions for breaking international law, but an open cooperation with respect for international law.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we criticise Putin-ruled Russia for all the reasons listed in the Landsbergis report. As the European Union, we cannot afford to accept lightly the violation of the principle of territorial integrity to which Ukraine has been the victim and on which the world balance is based. In this respect, Russia must demonstrate its willingness to respect the Minsk agreement, which is still largely lacking.  Unfortunately, the five-year conference on the revision of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has just ended, unfortunately with nothing of the matter. Here, too, there has been a heavy exchange of accusations between the US and Russian delegations. Well, I strongly believe that improving relations between Russia and the European Union must also necessarily move on from the issue of nuclear power. Let us think of the important role that Russia plays in the negotiations with Iran, which have reached their crucial stage.  The reconstruction of a lasting relationship of friendship and mutual respect with the Russian people is therefore also fundamental for global security issues. The resumption of dialogue and diplomatic action must find the European Union the protagonist, despite the latest deplorable blacklist affair, against which rotten apples have also been taken.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also congratulate the rapporteur on this successful report. The arbitrary and unjustified measure by the Russian authorities to ban European politicians and officials, including myself, from entering their territory is another step in the wrong direction that the Russian authorities are taking.  This growing pressure from Putin on Europeans hampers the efforts of the international community to create a constructive dialogue that generates a peaceful and lasting solution to this geopolitical conflict that we live in our neighbourhood. This is what this Parliament has denounced and that is how COSAC said last week in Riga.  We then need to ask ourselves what the Russian authorities intend: peace or permanent confrontation through the violation of the territorial integrity of their neighbours? Inclusion in the European family or isolation? Peer dialogue or punishment for those who dare to think differently?  I conclude, Mr President, ... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, let me express my disappointment that only 10% of the Members of the European Parliament are taking part in this debate today, that the Council has not even come and that no group chairman other than Mrs Harms is taking part in this debate. I believe that the opportunities we have will not be used if we have such a debate in this way. Perhaps it is because the report and the discussion do not bring much new things. Unfortunately! Because, and I am sure the rapporteur too, we would have liked to have discussed something new here if there had been a positive development. Let me just make two or three brief points. One is the issue of sanctions. Of course, sanctions only make sense if we stand by them until the situation has improved. There is no such improvement, and that is why there is no return on sanctions at the moment. On the other hand, it is also clear that this can be a two-way path, free according to the motto 'more for more and less for less'. If we are heading in the right direction, we will also want to reduce these sanctions. If it goes in the wrong direction, it will not be the last sanction we have introduced. The blacklist is clearly a step in the wrong direction. I very much agree with colleagues and colleagues saying this. I would add – and we probably do not all agree on this – that the inclusion of Duma deputies on the sanctions list was also a mistake, and is perhaps the only mistake that strikes me about the sanctions. After all, it cannot be right in the long term for the Lavrovs and Putins and Medvedevs to be available as interlocutors, but parliamentary dialogue is not. In this respect, we should consider how we can maintain this parliamentary dialogue in the future at a level that is appropriate and does not contradict what has been said so far. My final point is that I believe that we need disarmament – that is what the Minsk agreement provides for. And we want this Minsk agreement to be respected. This applies to all sides, including the Kiev side, but primarily to those who have nothing to look for in this country, and these are foreign soldiers.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Thank you, Mr President. "Unification makes power" is Bulgaria's motto, and that is exactly what we need today more than ever in the European Union. Europe must remain united in the face of the challenges we face coming from the east and south.   Russia, instead of being our natural partner, sees an adversary in our face. Unfortunately, the ruling administration in the Kremlin has not only maintained the mentality of the Soviet Union, but is also trying to forcibly rebuild this alliance under a new name. However, this new Soviet administration misses an important detail, and this is that such an alliance should be voluntary and attractive to its citizens.  And practice shows that democracy is attractive. Many young people from all over the world want to immigrate towards Western democracies and the United States. Moreover, many of the families of the ruling Russian administration, including the children of Mr. Putin and Lavrov, have decided to live in the Western world. The kremlin's current governance model is not attractive. At the same time, the European Union cannot be idly by and not respond to the aggressive propaganda machine. I would also like to call for the restoration of Nabucco and to support my colleague Landsbergis's report.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Mr Begin by thanking Mr Landsbergis for a balanced report which underlines that Russia is no longer a strategic partner of the European Union. Let us regard this resolution as a very important starting point for the Council of Ministers' further discussions on the issue of sanctions. The lifting of sanctions would de facto be a recognition of the Crimean Peninsula as Russian. Furthermore, when we know that Putin has the opportunity to put an end to the war in eastern Ukraine, it would also be a victory for the strategy of violence and division applied by the Kremlin. It is not europe that is going to change, it is Putin who is going to change. An extension of sanctions is necessary for Ukraine's sake, for the credibility of our foreign policy and for safeguarding the security policy rules that have applied in Europe since the Second World War.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – The right to life, freedom of expression and association, respect for the borders and sovereignty of states, are just some of the principles governing the European Union. Russia's violation of these values, through actions to annex Crimea, to destabilize Ukraine and the region, was likely to attract a set of measures, from the international community, aimed at correcting these slippages. Russia must understand that, although the European Union wants a strategic partnership aimed at common interests, this will not be possible as long as it manifests itself as a rival to the rule of law, and the Minsk agreement, although it was to become a reality, today is increasingly being violated.  We draw the attention of the Russian Federation that, however much the Member States depend on the energy component, they will never accept the violation of the basic principles of security in Europe. The European institutions and The Member States will remain in firm position against any aggression likely to endanger peace and stability in the region.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, to me the most important question in our relations with the Russian Federation right now is how we move forward in these relations. I would course prefer that we move forward on the basis of common values – but do we share values with a political leadership that invades another country or that pursues an illegal annexation of the territories of another country? I am afraid we do not. In fact I am pretty certain we do not share common values with them. Until Russia decides to be a trustworthy partner for the free world, I think our number one objective should be to help countries in the Eastern Neighbourhood which are under pressure from Russia. We have to tell the people in these countries that we want these countries to be strong, independent and developed, and the Russian Federation wants these countries to be weak and controllable so that they can be blackmailed. We should use the financial and institutional means that we have to help these countries develop to build strong and independent institutions at home, and we have to resist the Russian propaganda there. We should communicate to the people of these countries what the benefits of cooperation with the EU are for those people.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I congratulate Mr Landsbergis on a excellent report and I would like to draw attention to three key points. Firstly, I would like to stress the need to maintain the uniform position of the Member States vis-6 towards Russia. Russia is making efforts to break up European solidarity. The European Union must speak with one voice in this situation. Let us remember that we can only be effective in international politics if we are united.  The second issue concerns sanctions, which were introduced in response to Russia's aggression against Ukraine. I would point out that this aggression continues, as evidenced by the separatist attack on Marina near Donieck. Further maintenance of sanctions is necessary in this situation. Russia must pay a high political, economic and financial price for its aggressive policies.  Thirdly, the Union has become the subject of an extremely aggressive propaganda campaign and a campaign of pressure from Russia. We must effectively counter this Russian propaganda and expose and stigmatise Russian influence agents – increasingly active in our countries. I ask my fellow Members to support mr Landsbergis' report.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE).
text: – Colleague Landsbergis has done a very thorough job and provides a broad summary of EU-Russia relations. As the report and many European politicians say, it is undeniable that EU-Russia relations are at rock bottom and no improvement is expected until the Minsk agreements are fully implemented. The illegal annexation of Crimea, the hybrid war against Ukraine and its deliberate destabilisation all confirm that Russia has violated international law and norms.  The fact is that there are currently 42.5 thousand Russian soldiers and separatist militants currently supported and armed by Russia in the Donbass Basin, and that since the Minsk ceasefire agreement, the fighting has not subsided and more than 4,000 violations of the ceasefire have been violated, of which 120 have opened fire on populated settlements. In fact, artillery attacks by separatists have doubled since April, killing another 150, including 50 civilians. It is therefore for the European Union to step up, supervise and bring the two countries back to the negotiating table as soon as possible. Thank you!

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Mr President! Firstly, thank Landsbergis for a strong report, which will be accepted by a large majority in parliament. Russia has shown time and time again that, with Putin at the forefront, it does not respect democracy, human rights and freedom of the press. The destabilising actions in Ukraine are also a breach of international obligations and a violation of democratic principles. The conflict in Ukraine is a threat to security and peace throughout Europe. I believe that as long as Putin rules Russia, the course will not change, but we must maintain and extend our sanctions against Russia. There is no doubt that when we look at our energy policy in Europe, it says to me at least that we need to become independent in the long term, because this conflict will not be resolved here and now. That is why Europe must ensure that we become energy-independent from Russia in the future.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. We have now had a very long debate with a great many blue cards at the beginning. I can therefore only carry out a very shortened catch-the-eye procedure. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, the tension in relations between Russia and the European Union will continue. This is because the outlook for the Russian economy has deteriorated, particularly after the fall in international oil and gas prices. President Putin chooses confrontation with the West as a means of rallying Russian public opinion around a regime that cannot effectively address the problems of everyday life.  The European response to this challenge should be economic, since that is where we have the comparative advantage. A first economic intervention of strategic importance should be in favour of Ukraine, which is also under the greatest pressure from Russia. The issue of Ukraine's debt and the financing of its development must be addressed immediately, because by maintaining economic uncertainty we favour Russia's strategy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the daily chronicle of Russian actions seems to be aimed at destabilising the international democratic community, and I am deeply concerned that Russia is now acting openly as if it were our rival by pressing Europe's borders.  I agree with the motion for a resolution which does not disremit attempts to re-establish a dialogue, at least on shared values and principles, such as democracy, the rule of law and common interests. For the European Union, in my opinion, two directions are being deployed that I believe must be followed: the diplomatic firmness that any partnership is possible only where the Russian authorities comply with their international and legal obligations and the awareness of energy vulnerability and the need to equip themselves with autonomous resources; a system of mutual trust, based on democracy, territorial sovereignty, respect for human rights and the rule of law, must be re-established through dialogue and cooperation; A sound European Energy Union must also be developed, with a free, transparent market and an adequate proportion of renewable energies, so that energy is not a key instrument of Russian foreign policy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, there is no doubt that the solution to our relations with Russia is to solve the problem in Ukraine. There is no doubt that Russia's annexation of Crimea is a clear indication that the current Russian government does not care too much about European deals and agreements.  But what I want to emphasize here is the need for our friends in Ukraine to understand, especially now that they are preparing a new Constitution, that Ukraine as a state should be a strong and highly decentralized state, in respect of many European states and many experiences that we have, especially when we talk about protecting national communities, protecting minorities, linguistic, cultural, national minorities. I think this combination of a decentralized state with the protection of minorities can be key to solving our problems with Russia.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate has shown yet again how important Russia is for us, in terms of both the risks that Moscow’s policy poses and the opportunities that are offered for mutually-beneficial cooperation. We must be fully prepared to face such risks and protect our citizens from hybrid threats. At the same time, we should not lose determination to build on the opportunities and further develop our relations. Let me now react to several contributions which we have had. The European Union is not being humiliated or allowing anyone to humiliate. We are firm and united on our sanctions. These show clear support for Ukraine and at the same time impose a cost on the violation of international law. In reaction to the debate on the blacklist, let me quote High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini: ‘We did protest and will continue to do so in all circumstances.’ Unfortunately, Federica Mogherini cannot be present for this very important debate today on EU relations with Russia, as she is currently chairing the EU-CELAC summit. I will report to her your main messages and I am sure that you will have the opportunity to discuss this important item with her soon. Let me thank you for your fruitful exchanges. Your report is a timely and strong document. I look forward to its final adoption later this week.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I should like to thank colleagues for the debate and for their options. We must understand that Russia today is at a crossroads: but which path will it choose? The one of the old ways of Cold War times, or another one of cooperation and adherence to international norms? I am convinced that the Russian people are not willing to make war; they want peace, like all of us. Therefore Russia is capable of change, and that change will come from within. We have to support those who still dare to speak out for democracy and human rights in an atmosphere of suppression, murders, poisonings and harassment. It is up to the EU to show and encourage the Russian leadership that the path of folly and aggression will not pay for Russia. We continue to stand with good intentions towards Russia; but saying that, it is commitments first rather than incentives first. Once the Minsk Agreement is implemented and Crimea is set on the path to be returned, Europe will be ready to engage with Russia. At the same time we have to be conscious about the influence that the Russian leadership is trying to gain within the EU, trying to divide us and not let us be united. We have heard that – some of it today, here in this House – from some of the politicians as if they were under the influence of the Kremlin. The Kremlin will have to decide which path to take, but the EU will take its time to become more united, more resilient to propaganda, to trade pressures and energy wars. By our vote in this House we will send a clear and strong message to Russia. We will show that Europe is united and standing firmly for universal values. Europe will stand committed to its principles of democracy, the rule of law and peace. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Colleagues! I am grateful for this long, lively and interesting debate. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 11 June. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The events of recent days clearly show that Moscow does not want a permanent de-escalation of the situation in the east of the continent. Over the past dozen months, the Union and its Member States have given President Putin countless times the opportunity to come face to face with the situation in which he found himself. Finally, we must come to terms with the fact that the current situation is not the result of unpredictable coincidences, but of deliberate actions by Russian politicians. They clearly want the situation in Ukraine to escalate and relations with Western countries to deteriorate. To this end, Russian aircraft and military ships violate our territorial space. To this end, World Trade Organisation rules are being violated and energy raw materials are being used as a foreign policy instrument. This needs to be made clear – it is not us who have caused this conflict, and we are not tightening it with astonishing regularity. Even the current crisis of the massive influx of illegal immigrants into southern European countries stems from the Kremlin's actions. Had it not been for Moscow's support to the Bashar al-Assad regime, the Syrian civil war would have long since ended and there would have been so many tragedies. Europe must therefore rethink its relations with Russia. It will certainly not be a strategic partnership in the coming years. A new formula for cooperation is needed.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. – Russia is not showing respect for the signed agreements such as the Minsk Agreement and for the international democratic community and its law-based order, which is leading to chaos. Russia violated Ukraine’s sovereignty under the Budapest Memorandum signed in 1994 and breached its obligations by annexing Crimea. Russia does not seem to foresee an end of its aggression because it renewed the production of the supersonic strategic bomber and missile carrier. Russia does not admit its direct involvement in the war from Ukraine, but on the other hand Russia refuses to sign the UN nuclear annual report because the document lists Sevastopol as being located in Ukraine. Double standards!  Another fact is the persistent repression of political activists and political opponents, and I have in mind the following cases which ended up with the death of: Anna Politkovskaya, Natalya Estemirova, Boris Nemtsov, Sergey Magnitsky, Alexander Litvinenko. I condemn the fact that Russia turned a blind eye towards the signed agreements; Russia neglects the persisting culture of impunity which proves that Russia doesn’t have any respect for its own people, neither for members of the international community!

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – I consider that the EU must demonstrate commitment, unity and solidarity in sanctioning the Russian actions against the applicable international law rules. It is necessary and important that the current international legal framework be fully respected. The EU needs an effective approach, especially regarding the economic, defence and security areas, in order to internally strength the EU, to update and improve the existing instruments and to amplify its reaction capacity to the evolution in its neighbourhood  that affects European security. It is necessary to sustain the Eastern Partnership countries in their efforts regarding internal reforms, in relation to all relevant domains – economic affairs, minorities, democratic governance – in order for such countries to have sovereignty and be able to decide for themselves, based on their national interests, including regarding their options for foreign affairs policy or integration into international organisations.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – EU-Russia relations would have great potential to return to normal if Russia were to accept the right of its neighbours to determine its own future and, in practice, contribute to the resolution of frozen conflicts. The premise of this is that Russia will no longer see the West and Europe as an enemy and a security risk. Instead of spending large resources as if it were to deal with the threat from the West, it would be wise for Russia to focus on the real security threats, which certainly do not rely on the West, but from the South, and these threats are common in Europe and Russia. Thus, the normalisation of EU-Russian relations requires Russia to see the world as it is now, not in the pattern of 20th-century confrontation. Russia's behaviour, which concerns the deprivation of liberty of specific people, is very disturbing. The life of Estonian policeman Eston Kohver has been robbing Russia for nine months. He's still in jail in Russia, away from his loved ones, including young children. He must be released. Because as long as Russia does not value humanity, it is also very difficult to expect an intrinsic change in EU-Russian relations.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – The geopolitical environment in which we are located requires EU Member States to be united. But to keep the peace around us is not enough. We need partners. Such a partner should have been Russia, whose latest actions point in a completely different direction. The unjustified ban list of European diplomats who are barred from access to Russian territory was another step towards the isolation of the kremlin's current rulers. Another dialogue path was interrupted. Instead of pulling out of eastern Ukraine, Russia is challenging Europe and risking a more serious confrontation. The worst predictions have been confirmed that the goals of today's rulers in Moscow are far from European values. Failure to comply with the Minsk agreement cannot help reduce or lift sanctions against Russia.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. –  We are facing a situation that results from a build-up of mistrust and an extended powerplay that have gone out of control. One major reason for this is that all sides involved have not been acting in good faith. Ukraine, where complex and longstanding jealousies between communities have festered for too long, is racked by civil war. It has become the testing ground for a confrontation between the EU’s soft power and Russia’s boots on the ground. It is the Ukrainian people who have suffered most because of the crisis. I cannot have confidence in the version of one side or the other regarding the Ukrainian crisis, nor in the proposals that they are making regarding the future organisation of the European space. A resolution of the crisis can only emerge when there is a transparent description of the legitimate aspirations of all sides involved, especially including the Ukrainian communities of east and west; agreement across the board to respect such legitimate aspirations; and then agreement regarding a long term plan under international law, to give them satisfaction. This should take into full account the historical realities and contemporary interdependencies that define the European space.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – As regards relations between the European Union and Russia, I consider that Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, direct and indirect participation in the armed conflict in Ukraine and violation of Georgia's territorial integrity undermines democratic and international principles. Moreover, the economic coercion and political destabilisation that Russia is pursuing towards its European neighbours constitutes a conscious violation of international law.  In view of this, the European Union must thoroughly assess the relationship with Russia and prepare a comprehensive plan on the future of relations with Russia and its eastern neighbours. For years, the European Union has strained to build a mutually beneficial strategic partnership with Russia and remains open to such a relationship and dialogue in the future when the preconditions are met. Russia is an important partner of the European Union and we should, for mutual benefit, define and constructively establish a long-term sustainable relationship based on respect for international law.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. –  I fully support extending the European Union’s sanctions towards Russia. Furthermore, I applaud Mr Schulz’s decision to restrict the Russian ambassador’s free access to the European Parliament. This sends exactly the right signal to Russia which is exercising Byzantine and Soviet diplomacy even to this day. I would like to remind to some of my colleagues in the European Parliament who have expressed their concern about this decision that this is not a full access ban; it simply removes the additional privilege of unfettered access. Moreover, the Estonian police officer Eston Kohver who was abducted by force from Estonian territory nine months ago is still illegally detained in a Russian prison. The European Union cannot remain idle regarding this clear violation of international law and human rights. Ceterum censeo, Eston Kohver has to be released immediately and returned to Estonia.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The strengthening of the EU's defensive military capabilities must be matched by the stimulation of the economic development of these regions, which are predominantly underdeveloped and therefore vulnerable to Russia's expansionism, which is also expressed through a propaganda and economic offensive. The EU must also strengthen its eastern flank economically. The high level of poverty in the north-eastern region of Romania exposes the north of Moldova to increased risks in the face of the propaganda and economic actions instrumented by Russia. The recent massive land purchases on the right bank of the Prut by interest groups close to Moscow are a wake-up call for this. I believe that the European Union must invest urgently in the economic recovery of its border regions, as well as in the development of alternatives to Russian propaganda. At the same time, closer monitoring and halting Russia's support for radical and extremist parties in EU Member States is needed.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – (IT is extraordinary) that this report is concerned about the increasingly intense contacts and cooperation tolerated by the Russian leadership, between populist, fascist and far-right European parties and nationalist forces in Russia. The majority of this Parliament, on the other hand, does not seem at all concerned about the enactment last May of laws in Ukraine that criminalise communist ideology and symbols, preventing the activity of the Communist Party of Ukraine, as well as other Ukrainian democratic and anti-fascist forces. It seems that the majority of the EP no longer bothers the presence of fascist forces in the Ukrainian government and the repression of democratic freedoms.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Mr President of Mongolia, Mr Elbegdorj. It is a great honour and a pleasure for us to welcome you to the European Parliament today. Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work Mongolia, your country, is a country of an old and very rich civilisation and the land of a very young and very vibrant democracy. Twenty-five years ago, for the first time, a free and democratic election took place in your country. Last year, under your leadership, you successfully mastered very difficult situations with the formation of a government of national unity. Now you can tackle the economic and sustainable development of your country with great strength and broad support. The geographical location of your country between the two large and powerful states – the Russian Federation and the People's Republic of China – is certainly not always easy; we have just talked about this in our bilateral discussion. Mongolia's achievements are all the more impressive, not least because of what you call the third-party policy. Mongolia is certainly a beacon in the region. That is why it is particularly important for us – and we are pleased, Mr President – that your country will host the next ASEM Summit in June 2016. This ASEM Summit is certainly essential for building bridges between Europe and Asia and for finding common solutions to the manifold regional and global problems. I am quite sure that we can make great progress in your country's capital. I hope, on behalf of my fellow Members, that by then the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between Mongolia and the European Union will be ratified by all parliaments. Mr President, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work Welcome to the European Parliament!

name: Tsakhia Elbegdorj
text: President of Mongolia. – Mr President, I would like to begin with something simple: thank you. Thank you, Mr President, for inviting me. Thank you, Members of the European Parliament, for giving me this opportunity to share my views with you, the distinguished representatives of 28 sovereign states of this great continent – Europe. I am the youngest of eight sons. For generations, my family lived as nomadic herdsmen in the western highlands of my country, in the ranges of the Altai Mountains. My mother and father never dreamed that, one day, their youngest son would speak from this respected podium to the most caring hearts of democracy: the European Parliament. (Applause) But this is not about me. I am here to speak for my people about my country. I am proud of my motherland, Mongolia. I am proud of our history, our culture, our traditions and the natural beauty that surrounds us. But most of all I am proud of our spirit and our values. The brief story of my country’s modern history and our journey to democracy will sound familiar to many of you. In the early 1920s, Mongolia came under communist rule, which lasted for seven decades. During the Stalinist purges one out of every six adult men was killed. More than 700 Buddhist temples were burnt to ash. The foreign and domestic agents of the communist experiment targeted the very spirit of our nation. But they were not destined to win, not destined to last forever. In the end, our will to live free prevailed. (Applause) After many years, our defining moment finally arrived. On the cold morning of 10 December 1989, we organised the first unauthorised public street meeting in our capital city, Ulaanbaatar. I was fortunate enough to be chosen by my fellow democracy fighters to moderate that historic event. ‘We have remained silent for a long time: this is our time to work; this is the time for reform’ – these were my opening remarks. That morning, we demanded our rights – of freedom of assembly, of speech, of religion, and freedom of the press. We demanded the right to create a multiparty system, conduct democratic elections, and begin market reforms. It was the beginning of my country’s journey to liberty, justice and openness. That was a tough journey to embark upon. During that time, our neighbour – the Soviet Union – was intact. Its grip and control was still tight, powerful and overwhelming. In our other neighbour’s capital, the Tiananmen Square massacre had happened. Its shockwave was still fresh and influential. In Mongolia, the old regime was stubborn. The old mindset was strongly resistant to change. We organised many meetings, demonstrations and hunger strikes. We tried to eliminate every reason for violence. We always called for compromises, for peaceful solutions. Indeed, Mongolia’s democratic revolution was totally peaceful. Not a single shot was fired. Not a single window was shattered. Not a single drop of blood was shed. (Applause) A month from now, Mongolia will celebrate the 25th anniversary of its first full democratic, multiparty election. Since that historic day on 29 July 1990, we have had full-scale democratic elections for parliament seven times and for the presidency six times. And since that day, a quarter of a century ago, we have transformed from a dictatorship to a democracy, from being one of the most isolated, closed communist regimes in the world, to one of the most open. Today we have a dynamic market economy, and a vibrant, plural, creative society. Our per capita GDP has increased more than 20-fold. Our private sector now produces more than 80% of our gross domestic product. I want to talk about some of the virtues at the core of our young democracy, virtues we hope to strengthen in the coming years through cooperation with our partners in Europe and elsewhere. Individual freedom is the cornerstone of our democracy. Mongolians love freedom because we have earned it through hard work. Government in a free country is not the property of any specific group of people. In order to sustain a healthy society, we must keep nurturing and challenging it every day. The beauty of freedom is that it is a learning process. It is the healing system of human society. We can make mistakes, but mistakes will not cost us our lives, as in a dictatorship. That is why we love freedom. (Applause) Mongolia is among the top countries in the world in terms of the number of media tools used per capita. We have only three million citizens, but it feels like there are three million journalists too! This is great. People have the right to question authority. Transparency and interaction make us stronger. That is why Mongolia is proud to be chairing the Freedom Online Coalition. We will use this opportunity to promote access to the internet for all. We will support the UN’s effort to create a comprehensive convention on internet freedom. As our society becomes more open, we increasingly hear voices concerned for safety. But we should not depart from universal values in response to today’s security concerns. We see that violent extremism continues to evolve and threaten but, by contrast, our commitment to freedom, tolerance and peace must stay unbending. I therefore applaud the European Parliament for its brilliant initiative to adopt a charter of fundamental digital rights in the 21st century. Let us continue to work together to advance this great digital revolution. (Applause) I want to say a few words on elections, government and accountability. New technologies have been vital to the health of our democracy. In our last three elections we used electronic voting machines and a biometric voter registration system. These fraud-prevention measures assure voters that their participation will make a difference. Of course, instilling confidence in government goes beyond elections. Mongolians are deeply interested in how the government spends their hard-earned tax money. To ensure transparency, we have developed a very effective monitoring system – the ‘Glass Account Law’ – that mandates online disclosure of public expenditure. One challenge we face is the growing size of government. In response to new challenges, government functions tend to increase and government becomes bigger, more bureaucratic, and more distant. Technology has the opposite tendency: it becomes smaller, more functional, and more user-friendly over time. To tackle this, I put forward a smart government initiative, which incorporates new technologies to allow our Government constantly to adapt to new challenges. Turning briefly to corruption: corruption is an infectious disease that grows in darkness. It destroys the fundamentals of a fair, just and secure society. It scares away honest partners and investors. It robs people of opportunity and devours the fruits of their hard work. To exterminate this evil, we must shine a light on corruption – ensuring that it is exposed and that those responsible for it do not escape justice. I am proud to say that, in just four years, Mongolia has risen from 120th to 80th place on Transparency International’s corruption index. We still have work to do, but we are making good progress in cleaning up our beloved country. We have also made progress in the sphere of human rights. The foundation of justice is respect for human dignity, central to which is the sanctity of human life. Under no circumstances is capital punishment acceptable. (Applause) Before 18 June 2009, Mongolia was regarded by Amnesty International as one of the worst countries in terms of capital punishment. That was the day I took my oath as President of Mongolia. That same day I saw on my desk two draft decrees. I had to make the choice on whether or not to have two men executed. I chose life, and I kept to my decision – and I began delivering that message to the public and to our decision-makers. (Applause) It was not easy to exercise leadership on this issue, but in 2012 my country ratified the UN’s International Covenant which aims at the abolition of the death penalty. There have been no executions in Mongolia since June 2009. Let me be clear: capital punishment is ineffective and barbaric. From this podium I would like to thank the EU and all our European friends who support and encourage us on this important cause. (Applause) Honourable Members, reform of the judiciary is imperative for us. Reforming our legislative and judicial frameworks is an important part of the efforts to build a free and fair society. It has been one of my priorities, and we have taken great steps to modernise all aspects of the justice system, from police and prosecutors to courts and judges. People’s confidence in a fair court of law is being restored. A free society must also be an inclusive one. Women are the backbone of the family and the bedrock of a nation. They bring life into the world. Often it is they who care for the old, the sick, and those in need. They are our mothers, our sisters and our daughters. For society to advance, we need more women in public service at all levels, from local to global. (Applause) I am proud to report that, at our last election, we tripled the number of women in our Parliament. With more women in power, I think we would have more harmony, more engagement, less suffering and less conflict. (Applause) I would also like to say a word about education. Education is the ground on which our future success will be built. I went from a family of herdsmen to Harvard. I want other young people to have the same opportunity. We are working hard to build our capacity in schools, universities and other academic institutions. We are particularly grateful for being able to draw on the expertise of the Council of Europe’s education programmes to strengthen our institutions. I understand that all democracies should not look the same. We have to respect differences. Democracy is a representative form of government. In any nation it should reflect the cultures and traditions. But in every decent society you will see a common trend: democracies limit the power of the state; they tend to be responsive to their people’s grievances; they protect human rights, with impartial and consistent rule of law; they support healthy civic institutions, independent media and judiciary; they fight corruption, invest in human capital and recognise gender equality; and they allow people to choose their leaders in free and fair elections. Mr President, honourable Members, these are all issues on which Mongolia and Europe share common values and on which we value your cooperation. Mongolia and Europe are old friends, as shown by a letter from the Mongol Ulziit Khan to Philippe le Bel, which dates back 710 years. It says: ‘How can we consign to oblivion the friendship our forefathers, grandfathers, fathers and brothers so cherished, who, being far apart yet feeling near, exchanged words of wisdom and gifts of peace?’ It is in this same spirit that I speak today of opening a new chapter in Mongolian-European relations. With the fall of communism, relations between Mongolia and Europe have again blossomed. Your financial, technical and humanitarian assistance and cooperation greatly aided our efforts to build a free, democratic society, and for that we are grateful. In 2014, Mongolia and the EU celebrated the 25th anniversary of our diplomatic relations. I see the cooperation between the European Parliament and the Mongolian State Great Khural as being crucial to the continued strengthening of our partnership. We have already made great strides together, including the establishment of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between Mongolia and the EU. I would like to thank the Member States that have ratified that agreement. There are now more opportunities than ever for European investment. First-rate European companies are coming to Mongolia to invest, often in partnership with our companies. As the Government takes steps to improve the investment climate, such opportunities are rapidly increasing. We hope many of you will see our country’s beauties and its potential at first hand in 2016 when Mongolia proudly hosts the 11th Asia-Europe Meeting. I sincerely look forward to welcoming the leaders of the EU and of the Member States to my country, and I assure you it will be a memorable summit. Mr President, honourable Members, Mongolia’s commitment to international cooperation is strong. We recently launched an initiative called the Forum of Asia. We hope this will serve as a much-needed mechanism to promote the regional integration of all sovereign nations in Asia, promoting equal representation of their diverse interests. My government is now working to finalise this concept and is inviting interested parties to contribute ideas that will aid its realisation. Friends, Mongolia does not have any intention to lecture others about democracy. Yet we do have lessons to share. With Kyrgyzstan, we are sharing our lessons learned in building effective parliamentary democracy and enacting legal reforms. With Afghanistan, we are conducting training for diplomats and public servants. With Myanmar, we are hosting media workers, journalists and civil society members. With North Korea, we are engaging in economic and security dialogues. We strongly believe Mongolia can make a substantial contribution to regional security in North-East Asia and beyond. We understand the consequences of the Cold War. Because of our experiences under both communism and democracy, we are uniquely suited to serve as an honest broker in promoting peace and security in that region. As part of our efforts to build regional understanding, in 2013 I announced the Ulaanbaatar Dialogue on North-East Asian Security, an initiative similar to the Helsinki dialogue. We have hosted a number of meetings and conferences on topics beyond security matters, such as energy, women and nuclear issues. My country has been pursuing nuclear-weapon-free status for 23 years. (Applause) In 2012, the five permanent members of the UN Security Council signed a joint declaration reaffirming our nuclear-weapon-free status. While nuclear power may remain a viable energy option for some, any nation seeking to build nuclear power must not endanger the peace and security of their independent neighbours. We take seriously our common responsibility to promote peace. The Mongolian military proudly wear blue helmets and serve along with fellow UN peacekeepers to maintain international order and security. Mongolia has become one of the 20 largest peacekeeping contributors in the world. So far, more than 12 000 Mongolian peacekeepers have served on active duty in hotspots around the world. This is a significant number if you consider the small size of our population. We Mongols are proud to serve, and proud to contribute. Mr President, honourable Members, once again, I would like to thank the European Council, the European Union, the European Commission, and you, the European Parliament, as well as the nations of Europe, for constantly supporting my country, Mongolia. The Mongols say: ‘The finest of men is tested in need. The finest of horses is tested in riding.’ You were with us when we needed your support the most. You were with us when we needed your voice of encouragement. You are always with Mongolia, complimenting us on our success and helping in our challenges. The EU is the world’s premier invention for advancing global prosperity, peace and harmony. Mongolia will be a strategic anchor for the EU in the East, helping to advance our shared values and interests and working to build peace, democracy and engagement in Asia. Friends, let us continue working together.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I think I am speaking on behalf of all of you when I thank the President for this speech. Mr President, even though you have slammed one side, I think I can tell you on behalf of all my fellow Members that we have not heard such an encouraging speech in a long time. We would like to thank you for your presence here and for your speech and also for the invitation to intensive cooperation with your country. Thank you for this great moment that you have made possible for us here. Thank you very much, Mr President. (Applause)

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I just wanted to make two comments because, on the one hand, it was, as they say, just a technical adjustment. How do we deal with the farmers' crisis reserve, which is not fully needed? This will, of course, be returned to farmers. In this respect, this is good news. We have kept our word. However, I would also like to draw the attention of my colleagues to another story: we should ensure that farmers are able to prepare themselves for possible crisis phenomena, including with political help. We should also look again at this very issue in the relevant committee. The best help is self-help, and if you can accompany them politically, that would be a fine thing.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as always with these budgetary considerations, it is put to us in rather technical language and it is easy to lose sight of the quantity – the sums – that we are talking about. The human brain is not designed to deal with billions. These are for us astronomical figures which evolution was not intended to assist us to picture. So let me try. The UK net contribution last year to the EU budget was GBP 9.8 billion and the gross contribution was GBP 19.2 billion. That is enough to build 36 NHS hospitals or, if you want to look at it the other way round, it is enough to give the entire country a reduction in their council tax of more than 60%. These are huge figures. I would appeal to the people who are marching against austerity and government cuts to ponder this fact: we have spent more in these contributions than we have saved across the whole of domestic spending with the entire government cuts programme. If ever there was a cost-free reduction, this is it.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR).
text: Madam President! In the Danish delegation to the ECR, we have chosen to abstain from voting in favour of the Crisis Fund, as it does not hit 100% right. We know that it may prove important to have a reserve for the future crisis, but at the same time also that only those farmers have paid the price for the international and political disagreement between the European Union and third world countries, such as Russia. This causes many job losses and exports for Danish farmers. Minimising direct payment to farmers is therefore a very hard measure to use, since farmers are already suffering because of the crisis. We would therefore like to be allowed to consider options other than simply reducing their payment. That is why we think this should be considered a little better, so thank you for the word!

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of budgetaryly providing the Fund for the crisis situations of peasants because I think it is very important, but I will be very attentive to see how this Fund is used. I think that when the crisis situation comes from the wrong decisions taken by the European Union, such as the Russian veto, the funds must come from elsewhere and this money should not be used to alleviate these crisis situations.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam Chairman, every year the percentage reduction of direct payments is determined, which is allocated to the reserve for agricultural crisis situations. Thus, under this proposal, direct payments in 2016 for 2015 will be reduced by 1.39% per farmer, for aid above EUR 2 000, and this will provide an amount of EUR 441.6 million to be allocated to the crisis reserve. Personally, like many of my colleagues, I object to the use of this reserve to repair the damage that farmers suffer for political reasons, for which it is necessary to provide budget-wide funding, not just from budget lines for agriculture. In the event of natural disasters and disasters, epidemics and similar crises, this reserve will be of enormous importance for the recovery of agriculture.  The Republic of Croatia and our farmers are exempt from this allocation for the crisis reserve, because we still do not use 100% of the amount.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam Chairman, I supported the 2015 adjustment rate report establishing a so-called emergency fund of EUR 441.6 million in the 2016 budget, which will be replenished from direct payments awarded to farmers exceeding EUR 2 000.  This exempted small farmers from these measures, which I welcome. Support from all European farmers except Croatian, Romanian and Bulgarian will be reduced by 1.39%. The good news is that Croatian farmers, regardless of the fact that their incentive money will not be taken for the filling of the crisis fund, will be able to use the funds raised in crisis situations. This is logical because Croatian farmers do not use the 100% amount of direct payments from the European budget. We will not reach this level of eu funds usage until 2022.  I take this opportunity to once again call on the Commission to ensure from its reserve damages for farmers who have perished as a result of the Russian embargo and who are suffering enormous damage for the second year in a row due to political decisions.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I supported this because I believe we need to help farmers who are in crisis. Unfortunately, at this stage in Ireland, the common agricultural policy has become an institutional creation that has put many small farmers in crisis. The very funding that goes to many countries, and in particular Ireland, has created an un-level playing field, whereby the richest farmers get the biggest payments and the smallest farmers get the smallest payments, creating a situation where you are driving the small farmers out of business and whereby only the farmers on big payments can get loans to purchase the farms of the smaller farmers. So the common agricultural policy, far from resolving a crisis, is actually creating a crisis in my country. The last Commissioner, even though he is a Member of the EPP, is described in Ireland as a communist by the rich farmers and members of the EPP.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Article 25 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 provides that a reserve should be set up to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of significant crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products by applying at the beginning of each year a reduction in direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism referred to in Article 26 of that regulation. In accordance with Article 26(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, in order to ensure compliance with the annual maximum limits laid down in Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, a percentage adjustment of direct payments should be fixed. This report seeks to unlock these provisions and set the adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015.
