That is why I voted in favour, although I believe that when the crisis situation comes from the wrong decisions taken by the European Union, such as the Russian veto, the funds should come from elsewhere and this money should not be used to alleviate these crisis situations.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the measures taken to mitigate crises in the agricultural sector. A reduction in direct payments (VO 1307/2013(EU)) to farmers will create a reserve to support the further production and marketing of agricultural products in the event of a crisis. European farmers are now being paid the direct payments reduced by an adjustment rate. The adjustment rate will not apply to Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia until 2016 or 2022.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim is to create a reserve that would support the agricultural sectors in the event of a crisis. However, this creation of a reserve implies a reduction in direct payments, i.e. aid paid under the common agricultural policy. The payment of these aids does not depend on production but on certain standards defined by the CAP.  The amount of this reserve is expected to be EUR 441.6 million, while CAP funds have already decreased by 20% in 15 years.  This would be a further blow to our agriculture.  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP believes that agricultural subsidies should be a matter for the nation states, not the European Union.  As a consequence, I voted against this resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because this annual action is aimed at responding to a possible agricultural crisis. It would then offer the European Union a budgetary weapon to respond to a crisis that could hit a sector already severely weakened by the Russian embargo and the vagaries of climate and stock market.  However, despite this mechanism, the incomes of European farmers are still too unstable. This issue will have to be addressed in the years to come, like the "Farm bild" of the United States. For my part, I am in favour of the creation of an agricultural insurance fund.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the creation of a reserve that can be used to support agricultural sectors in crisis. To do this, the Commission wants to reduce direct payments, i.e. the funds that farmers receive under the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy).  Direct payments are assistance to farmers in the form of income that is not related to production but which depends on compliance with certain standards defined by the CAP ("greening"). The amount of the reserve planned to alleviate crises in the agricultural sector is 441.6 million euros at current prices. For the creation of this reserve, a direct payment adjustment rate has been set: it will apply mainly to those above 2,000 euros. This measure is not only insufficient, but it also further handicaps farmers because they are the ones who are punctured. It is a false solution that has nothing to do with mutual aid because the amounts provided for the crisis reserve are withdrawn from farmers, legitimate aids dedicated to them. Once again, farmers are paying the price for the inconsistency of EU policy. It should be remembered that funds dedicated to agriculture under the CAP have already decreased by 20% in 15 years. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the draft regulation of Parliament and the Council setting the adjustment rate for direct payments for the 2015 calendar year, I find it interesting to note that Article 25 provides assistance to the agricultural sector in the event of production or distribution problems.  The agricultural sector has often been the victim of injustice and denial. That is why I think it is justified to give this aid to farmers in case of problems.  I think it is important to provide farmers with the assurance of some equal treatment between them. That is why I am positioning myself in favour of the adjustment rate for direct payments for the 2015 calendar year.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation setting the adjustment rate provided for by Regulation (EU) 1306/2013 for direct payments for calendar year 2015 should enable the establishment of a crisis-usable reserve to support the agricultural sectors. However, the creation of this reserve of EUR 441.6 million will be matched by the reduction in direct payments, i.e. aid that farmers receive under the CAP.  This is bad for our farmers because we are actually reducing their aid without additional support. This sad observation is only the result of European agricultural policies which have reduced in fifteen years the funds allocated to farmers by 20%, a decrease which particularly affects my country, France.  So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 When negotiating the new CAP, I strongly opposed the 'financial discipline' mechanism behind the Siekierski report on the 'rate of adjustment of direct payments for the calendar year 2015'. In order to express once again my opposition to this system, I abstained today.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament approves at first reading the commission's proposal to set the annual reduction rate of direct payments in accordance with Articles 25 and 26 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 and in accordance with Article 8, (1) of Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013, which is fixed at 1.393041 %.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it sets out Parliament's position on the regulation fixing the adjustment rate applicable for calendar year 2015. With a report, Parliament adopts the Commission's proposal with minor amendments. The EU Treaties lay down the basic rule of union funding: the Annual Budget of the Union must be consistent with the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). In order to support the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products, the financial discipline mechanism established in the previous Regulation provides for the establishment of a crisis reserve in the agricultural sector by making minor adjustments to direct payments at the beginning of each year. This is what Parliament supported with this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Although the proposed regulation, which I supported, is an annual adjustment to the current situation, it is a small, but not insignificant, pebble in the mosaic of faster adaptation to changes in the EU agricultural market. The EU's crisis reserve will be around €441 million in 2016, so it is of the utmost importance that these funds be used prudently. That reserve is established by applying, at the beginning of each year, a reduction in direct payments by means of a financial discipline mechanism. Indeed, the cap's provisions for financing market-related expenditure and direct payments provide for the setting of an adjustment rate for direct payments where the forecasts on the financing of the measures indicate that the annual ceilings in force are exceeded. In order to ensure equal treatment of farmers, the proposed Regulation therefore provides that the adjustment rate applies only to payments for which aid applications have been submitted during the calendar year to which the financial discipline applies, irrespective of when the payment is made to farmers. For 2015, the adjustment rate will therefore be 1,393041 %, which means that all subsidies paid under the aid application of at least EUR 2000 will be reduced by that percentage.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the creation of a crisis reserve for payments in agriculture. As a result of the gradual introduction of direct payments of adjustment rates, the regulation only applies to Bulgaria and Romania as of 1 January 2016 and to Croatia only from 1 January 2022.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to fund an emergency fund for the agricultural sector that will make it easier for this vital sector of the European economy to overcome crisis situations.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation setting the adjustment rate provided for by Regulation (EU) 1306/2013 for direct payments for the 2015 calendar year.  Under the guise of common sense, this measure conceals the Difficulty of the Union in responding to the problems of the citizens of the Member States. Indeed, this proposal will have the effect of reducing the direct payments desired by the common agricultural policy. Let us be clear: we are proposed to take money away from farmers and give them back in another form. This is much more like a communication action than a real measure because this proposal, behind a hard-hitting and misleading effect, will not produce any of the desired effects.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the measure. There is still my opposition to the principle that it is always farmers who are paying for market crises.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The agricultural sector is particularly sensitive and exposed to various economic changes. In order to anticipate and be able to cope with the occurrence of a major crisis in this sector, it was proposed to set up a crisis reserve.  This reserve will be established through a reduction in direct payments of 1.393041 per cent for calendar year 2015 for all Member States except Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania. In the event of a crisis, this reserve will be mobilized to allow farmers to continue their activity.  I voted in favour of this report, which shows European solidarity.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting the rate of adjustment of direct payments under Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 for the calendar year 2015.  The European agricultural sector has on several occasions been hit by serious crises which have affected both agricultural production and the distribution of products. I am thinking, for example, of the Russian embargo, the end of milk quotas and, more generally, unpredictable factors such as climate and globalisation, which often have negative impacts on the sector. I believe that the establishment of a reserve is of the utmost importance in these cases.  The amount of the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector, which is expected to be included in the Commission's draft budget for 2016, amounts to EUR 441.6 million at current prices. In any event, medium-term intervention by the Commission in setting up a fund devoted to crises in the agricultural sector, which is made up of funds not distracted from the Community's agricultural budget, is desirable.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report of which I was shadow rapporteur. This proposal aims to implement the provisions of Article 26 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 and Article 8 of Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013. It seeks to set the percentage rate of the financial discipline adjustment rate in respect of the calendar year 2015. The application of this adjustment rate will result in the reduction of the amounts of direct payments for budget lines covering expenditure relating to aid applications submitted by farmers in respect of the calendar year 2015 (financial year 2016). In simple terms, there is a reserve fund for agricultural crises. The total amount of this fund will be EUR 2 800 million (Art. 25 of Regulation 1306/2013), with equal annual payments into it of EUR 400 million, until 2020. These payments are to be paid by applying a ‘financial discipline mechanism’ on the direct payments, meaning that a certain percentage is withheld from direct payments over EUR 2 000, and those funds are to flow into the agricultural reserve fund.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I believe that the UK’s agricultural policy should be decided by a sovereign parliament at Westminster, and not by EU institutions.  Accordingly, I oppose EU expenditure in this manner.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agricultural sector is an important element in the EU’s economy. It represents the livelihood of a number of its citizens and needs to be supported. By voting in favour of this report I have agreed to the establishment of a crisis reserve in case of a major crisis in the agricultural sector.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Siekierski's report because I believe that farmers should be supported, not least because of the serious crisis in the sector. The first budget estimates for direct payments and market-related expenditure in the 2016 draft budget indicate that the net available balance for EAGF expenditure is not likely to be exceeded. Consequently, the application of financial discipline seems to me to be inappropriate.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I rejected this proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council setting the rate of adjustment for direct payments for 2015. Of course, the objective may seem laudable in itself: it is to create a pool of funds to support agricultural sectors that are experiencing a crisis. Very attached to French agriculture, I could have supported such an initiative if it did not claim to have such support financed by the farmers themselves, including the cuts in aid that are currently dedicated to them and which they badly need. The proposed regulation provides for a reduction in CAP aid. However, funding for agriculture under the Common Agricultural Policy has already fallen by 20% in 15 years. Under the guise of an equalization mechanism, this proposed regulation will in fact lead to the Commission amputating direct payments from farmers. It will now be up to the latter to settle the salty bill that Brussels has left them through its policy of suicidal austerity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We welcome the fact that the EU is taking the initiative to create a reserve for crises in the agricultural sector with the aim of providing additional support to farmers in cases of serious crises affecting agricultural production. The fact that a significant amount of around EUR 450 million is being fixed for 2016 demonstrates the EU's political determination to shield the agricultural sector. I believe that the agricultural sector is very important for the social and economic cohesion of the EU and for the prospect of stimulating growth. The EU can take the lead in primary production, provided that it continues the considerable and important support of the agricultural sector. I believe that the agricultural sector can be the engine of European development as long as there are aid strategies as well as significant investments in Georgia.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning the fixing of the rate of adjustment of direct payments for the calendar year 2015 as provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1306/2013. In order to support the agricultural sector in the event of a crisis, provision is made for the establishment of a reserve by applying, at the beginning of each year, a reduction to direct payments through a financial discipline mechanism. The amount of the reserve to be included in the Commission's draft budget for 2016 amounts to EUR 441.6 million. The rate of adjustment of direct payments applies only to direct payments over EUR 2 000. In Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania, direct payments are being phased in during the calendar year 2015. Therefore, financial discipline will not apply in these Member States.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it is important to be able to support the agricultural sector with an additional type of aid in the event of even more serious periods of crisis than those we are already experiencing. In order to do this, it is necessary to be able to create a reserve, obtained by applying at the beginning of each year a reduction to direct payments through a financial discipline mechanism. As regards 2015, the measure provides that the amounts of direct payments to be granted to a hypothetical farmer for an application for aid submitted for the year 2015 will have to be reduced by 1.393041% in all Member States except Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of Mr Siekierski's report because, specifically, this report provides for the establishment of a reserve, amounting to EUR 441.6 million, to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products. In addition, the report provides for a reduction in direct payments through a financial discipline mechanism and is applicable only to payments exceeding EUR 2 000 to be granted to farmers in the corresponding calendar year. I hope that this financial instrument will bring benefits to the agricultural sector, which has unfortunately been put to the test by a number of factors such as the Russian embargo, the international crisis and climate factors.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report establishing the adjustment rate by which direct payments to farmers under support schemes shall be reduced for the current calendar year. However, it remains imperative that farmers who face basic challenges such as the size of their land as well as challenges related to their capacity are assisted.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Article 25 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 provides that a reserve should be set up to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of significant crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products by applying at the beginning of each year a reduction in direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism referred to in Article 26 of that regulation. In accordance with Article 26(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, in order to ensure compliance with the annual maximum limits laid down in Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, a percentage adjustment of direct payments should be fixed. This report seeks to unlock these provisions and set the adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015. That is why I voted in favour, although I believe that when the crisis situation comes from the wrong decisions taken by the European Union, such as the Russian veto, the funds should come from elsewhere and this money should not be used to alleviate these crisis situations.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is a procedural angle to a mechanism which is there to support the agricultural sector in the most trying of times. As I wholeheartedly support such mechanisms to support and preserve such an important industry, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a Union extended to 28 Member States there are different types of agriculture and important development gaps in the agricultural sector, which has led to the emergence of new requirements and perspectives specific to this area.  We welcome the establishment of a reserve for major crisis situations affecting both agricultural production and distribution, and we hope that there will be no such crisis situations.  Although the adjustment rate under financial discipline does not apply in Romania, with direct payments being progressively introduced in the calendar year 2015, I stress once again that full alignment of direct payments in the EU-28 should be ensured as soon as possible.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report foresees a reduction in direct payments of 1.393041 per cent in all Member States, with the exception of Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania, amounting to EUR 441.6 million, through budgetary discipline mechanisms to support the crisis reserve for 2016. This reserve is intended to be used to support the agricultural sector in the event of a major crisis.  Nevertheless, it is necessary to ask whether it is normal that farmers, currently victims in all markets and throughout the year of a crisis of mainly diplomatic origin, should still be harmed the following year at the time of the regulation of aid. I believe that farmers have the right to expect a show of solidarity from the European institutions. Weighing all these elements and taking into account the importance of having a functional reserve in a context of multiple crises and risks to the dairy sector following the abolition of quotas, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Support for the agricultural sector is a pillar of the European Union. Budgetary mechanisms have been put in place to deal with unforeseen crises. This is the case with the crisis reserve formed from an amount taken from the annual envelope of direct payments allocated to farmers.  With this vote, we approved at first reading the setting of the adjustment rate at 1.39 per cent of the amount of direct payments for 2015. The reserve thus constituted amounts to more than four hundred and forty-one million euros. Funds not spent at the end of the year will be returned to farmers in the form of direct payments.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In order to support the agricultural sector in the event of major crises affecting agricultural production or distribution, the European Union is building a crisis reserve by implementing a reduction in direct payments.  It is in this sense that Parliament has supported, for the year 2015, a 1.4% reduction in direct aid above EUR 2,000. However, this reduction will not apply to Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia, where the agricultural sector needs more active support from the EU. The outermost regions of the Union, because of their geographical peculiarity and their island character, will also continue to benefit from an exemption.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ Direct Payments. While I understand the importance of ensuring budget lines are in place to guarantee direct payments are made to farmers, I am opposed to the fact that all farmers should have to contribute to a crisis reserve that to date has only benefited a select few.  For instance, dairy and pig farmers in my constituency, who have been affected by the Russian import ban, received no support to deal with the fallout of political actions between the EU and Russia.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council setting the adjustment rate provided for by Regulation (EU) 1306/2013 for direct payments for the 2015 calendar year.  Under the guise of common sense, this measure conceals the Difficulty of the Union in responding to the problems of the citizens of the Member States. It suggests a solution to the difficulties of the agricultural sectors by reaching out to better remove it. Indeed, this proposal actually consists of a reduction in the direct payments desired by the common agricultural policy.  Let us be clear: we are proposed to take money away from farmers and give them back in another form. This is much more like a communication action than a real measure because this proposal, behind a hard-hitting and misleading effect, is of great futility.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of a crisis fund to cover losses to farmers is a good idea, especially to react in force majeure, as is now the case with export bans to Russia.  In Bulgaria, this has affected a number of sectors, including livestock farming and horticulture. Such a mechanism should exist. Worryingly, the provision of the financial resource provides for an adjustment of basic payments at the specified rate of 1.393041. This is a short-sighted decision because this actually reduces subsidies as a kind of guarantee for the payment of aid for a future uncertain event. In this sense, we may regard this mechanism as a kind of insurance or guarantee premium. However, the idea of the mechanism described is quite different and should be separated from the surcharges and provided separately and not deducted from producers' subsidies. There are much more flexible options.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission plans to transfer EUR 441.6 million from the direct agricultural aid budget to the Agricultural Crisis Fund at current prices by 2016. The withdrawal adjustment rate will be approximately 1.4%. This withdrawal of 1.4% is not significant and will not hit farmers. I welcome the fact that the European Commission has decided on a sufficiently moderate withdrawal.  Unfortunately, this has not always been the case. One of the barroso commission's last measures last autumn would have been a significant curtailment of this year's farmers' subsidies. Fortunately, this plan has not been carried through because of the decisive action taken by the European Parliament and the Council. In this work, my fellow Member Tamás Deutsch and I have taken a lion's share in Parliament. The financial withdrawal under the current proposal will not hit farmers, so I voted in favour of the adoption of this report in line with the direction of the European People's Party.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The amount of the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector to be included in the Commission's Draft Budget for 2016 is EUR 441.6 million at current prices. To achieve this amount, it is necessary to apply the financial discipline mechanism to direct payments. However, both preliminary forecasts of direct payments and market-related expenditure do not require additional financial discipline measures. As a general rule, farmers who submit an aid application for direct payments for a calendar year N are paid during the fixed period of the financial year N+1. Therefore, in order to ensure equal treatment of farmers, the adjustment rate should apply only to payments corresponding to aid applications submitted in the calendar year to which financial discipline applies, regardless of the date on which payment to the farmer is made. I agree with the application of a reduction rate of 1.393041 % to the tranche of more than EUR 2000 of direct payments made to farmers, corresponding to aid applications submitted for the calendar year 2015.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it does not take enough account of the interests of French and European farmers, who are particularly affected by the consequences of the Russian embargo.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal is to define the rate to be applied to cap direct payments, with a view to establishing a financial reserve, to support the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting agricultural production or distribution. The Regulation stipuorders that the total amount of the reserve will be EUR 2 800 million, with equal annual tranches of EUR 400 million (2011 prices) for the period 2014-2020. It also provides that this adjustment rate should only apply to direct payments exceeding EUR 2 000.  The application of this adjustment rate will result in a reduction in the amounts of direct payments for budget lines relating to the expenditure stemming from aid applications submitted by farmers for the calendar year 2015 (financial year 2016). The total reduction resulting from the implementation of this mechanism amounts to EUR 441.6 million and the percentage of the adjustment rate will be 1.393041%. We agree with the constitution of this reserve. Two aspects, however, deserve further consideration: - The need to complement the reserve with additional funds from the EU budget (not withdrawn from direct payments) in the face of serious crises: - The possibility of introducing the principle of progressivity, with differentiated rates, higher for higher payments.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing \ u2012 In order to ensure equal treatment of all farmers, it is therefore appropriate to provide that the adjustment rate is to apply only to payments in respect of which aid applications have been submitted in the calendar year in which financial discipline applies, irrespective of when the payment to farmers is made. The European Commission's proposal therefore envisages creating the necessary reserve for farmers.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the reserve that the CAP foresees in the event of serious crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products. This reserve is, however, subsidized by a remodulation of the direct payments of the farmers themselves, to whom a percentage is then reduced. I cannot vote in favour because we are opposed to the principle that it is the farmers themselves who pay 'twice' for market crises.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it would lead to British farmers contributing a disproportionate amount of their direct payments to fund a crisis reserve which they do not exploit. The adjustment rate for direct payments would only be applied to direct payments per farmer in excess of EUR 2 000. Farmers throughout much of Central and Eastern Europe receive payments of less than EUR 2 000. Therefore the burden would fall upon countries such as the UK, which receive higher amounts per farmer.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to express my positive vote for the fixing of the adjustment rate for direct payments in 2015. This will provide a reserve that will allow additional support for the agricultural sector in the case of major crises affecting agricultural production or distribution by applying, at the beginning of each year, a reduction to direct payments with the financial discipline mechanism. Even if I truly hope that the crisis reserve will not be needed, I believe that, if such event happens, it will be an important resource for the European agricultural sector, from which we will all benefit. I thank the rapporteur and the shadows for their active role in supporting the agricultural sector in Europe.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I very much welcome Maria Noichl's motion for a resolution on the new EU strategy for equality between men and women. The path, although still too slow towards gender equality, is a priority that Europe cannot afford to underestimate.  Combating the social and sexual discrimination which unfortunately still has too alarming an index in the EU is the only way forward to maintain the commitments that Europe is proposing and proposing as strategies for growth and development, overcoming wage and gender equality gaps, incentives to increase and renew the labour market, and overcoming the contingent moment of economic crisis also thanks to the contribution of , also at the apical level, of women's energies and abilities, combating all kinds of physical violence, mortification and sexual threat.   There can be no development unless we decide to invest in education for respect for and recognition of equal dignity of all the resources that our society has, regardless of gender, religion, culture and the sexual choices of the individual. Capitalising on human value and restoring freedom, consideration and respect for those who do not always have freedom today: I am convinced that this objective can lead to the achievement of Europe's main growth objectives.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the adjustment rate for direct payments for the 2015 calendar year, because I am convinced that, despite all the market opening and market orientation, our agriculture, but above all the rural, family-run agriculture, needs reliable support. We want to preserve small and medium-sized farmers in Europe because it is the main pillar of rural structures and guardians of our cultural landscape. Direct payments are a crucial contribution to this.

name: n/a
text: in writing. ‒ Although I do not wholeheartedly agree with continuous support to the common agricultural policy, I did vote in favour of the Siekierski report on the adjustment rate for direct payments in respect of 2015, because I believe that if we are legally bound to pay, we should ensure that payments are made in a timely manner. I also believe it is important that the Commission set up an agricultural crisis reserve that could provide emergency support to the sector when needed. Crucial in gaining my support, however, was the fact that crisis measures undertaken on the basis of this regulation are paid for by the farmers themselves, because it is vital we avoid pressure on additional union financing.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ With uncertain weather conditions, diseases, pests, exchange rates and other uncontrollable variables, farming is a volatile industry and becoming increasingly so. For this reason, a crisis reserve helps increase investor confidence, it supports our food security and keeps prices for farmers and consumers consistent over the medium term. Due to its size, the EU is vulnerable to asymmetric shocks in the agricultural sector but it is this size that also allows the EU to pool its risk. For this reason, farmers, consumers and the market in between benefit from the crisis reserve. However, the concept of pooled risk should also imply a shared contribution to the reserve. What we see with these proposals is an uneven distribution of contributions, if any contributions are made by farmers at all. Farmers in the UK are already being squeezed by downward pressure on prices and I believe it is too much to ask them to contribute more than their fair share to the reserve. The Commission needs to review how the agricultural reserve is funded as well as the common agricultural policy as a whole.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal because it tends to reduce direct payments to farmers under the CAP.  These direct payments have two advantages. On the one hand, they encourage farmers to use better practices for the environment and consumer health. Thus, there is a "green payment", or greening, which aims to pay for specific actions in favour of the environment, by improving the environmental performance of agriculture in terms of biodiversity, protection of water resources and the fight against climate change. In France, the green payment accounts for 30% of total direct payments. On the other hand, because direct payments are not production-related, they protect farmers from market price fluctuations. In principle, this reduction aims to create a reserve of 441.6 million euros to support the agricultural sectors in crisis.  However, the planned adjustment rate will reduce direct payments to farmers who receive more than 2,000 euros. In the end, this reserve, which is normally designed to cope with agricultural crises, will weaken some farmers by reducing their incomes.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of allocating 1.39% of direct payments to farmers and ranchers towards the crisis fund this year, As provided for in Articles 26 and 8.1 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 respectively, in anticipation of possible natural or other disasters that may seriously affect Union crops this year.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The creation of a crisis reserve for the agricultural sector is an indispensable financial instrument. In Poland, where agriculture is still a significant part of the economy, we watched with great concern the struggles of farmers who, after the introduction of the Russian embargo, tried in vain to acquire new outlets for their products.  I voted in favour of the report on the correction factor for direct payments for 2015, as I fully support farmers' rights in the European Union and consider the right to protection of their work and property to be one of the most important. I consider it appropriate to adopt the report of the Committee on Agriculture, which allows farmers to receive even partial compensation in the event of a natural disaster or economic crisis. The experience of last year has taught us that having a financial reserve that can be activated in times of crisis is a prerequisite for ensuring the stability and further development of the European agricultural economy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour Party colleague, voted in favour of this report as it strikes the right balance between protection and remuneration of creators and the public interest in accessing cultural content.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council fixing the adjustment rate applicable for calendar year 2015 provided for in the Regulation. Parliament supported this report with minor direct payments at the beginning of each year to create a crisis reserve in the agricultural sector. This is an important step towards reducing the serious crises in the agricultural sector, which have a hard impact on production and the consumer.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal to set up a reserve for crises in the agricultural sector. In practical terms this means that there will be a cut of 1.39% in the single farm payment to fund this reserve. It will not apply to direct payments of EUR 2 000 or less, so at least those farmers on very low payments will be exempted. I am also supportive of the proposal that this reduction will in future only be applied to direct payments in excess of EUR 5 000.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report establishing a correction coefficient for direct payments. I also commend the rapporteur, Mr Siekierski, for his work on this document. I believe that it is particularly important to provide additional support to the agricultural sector at the moment. The sanctions imposed by Russia on the European Union have particularly affected European agriculture. The losses of polish farmers only related to the export ban to Russia amount to 500 million dollars. I therefore believe that it is right and legitimate to include the proposed amount of EUR 441.6 million as a reserve in the event of a crisis in the agricultural sector.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The regulation on the financing of the CAP provides for additional financial support to agriculture in the event of an unforeseen crisis. This is entirely justifiable and has the potential to protect fragile rural communities in any Member State in the event of such a crisis. I accordingly voted in favour of this report and condemn the short-sightedness of MEPs voting against.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of allocating 1.39% of direct payments to farmers and farmers to the crisis fund this year, As provided for in Articles 26 and 8.1 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 respectively, in anticipation of possible natural or other disasters that may seriously affect Union crops this year.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council to set an adjustment rate for direct payments provided for in Council Regulation No 100/2013. 1306/2013 for 2015, due to the importance and support this gives to an agricultural sector facing serious difficulties.  The situation on the global market requires the creation of a crisis fund that will provide concrete support and certainty to European farmers. It is necessary for farmers to feel the real solidarity of the European Union in order to regain a kind of trust and strengthen European agriculture. However, it is important to ensure croatian, but also Bulgarian and Romanian farmers, the possibility of acceding to certain assistance and financing measures in case of crises.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which harms French farmers by reducing direct payments, which are very valid. On the one hand, they encourage farmers to use better practices for the environment and consumer health. Thus, there is a "green payment", or greening, which aims to pay for specific actions in favour of the environment, by improving the environmental performance of agriculture in terms of biodiversity, protection of the water resource and the fight against climate change. In France, the green payment accounts for 30% of total direct payments. On the other hand, because direct payments are not production-related, they protect farmers from market price fluctuations. In principle, this reduction aims to create a reserve of 441.6 million euros to support the agricultural sectors in crisis.  However, the planned adjustment rate will reduce direct payments to farmers who receive more than 2000 euros. In the end, this reserve, which is normally designed to cope with agricultural crises, will weaken some farmers by reducing their incomes.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Czes-aw Siekierski's report on direct payment adjustment rates in 2015. In order to compensate for any major crises in the agricultural sector, a reserve for these exceptional situations is set up every year. To feed this reserve, a reduction rate of direct payments is applied. This year the reduction rate was set at 1.393041%. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council setting the adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015.  In the face of the Russian embargo, the EU must apply financial discipline in order to preserve the crisis reserve for European farmers. Moreover, the 1.4% decrease will affect farmers very little and only affects direct payments of EUR 2,000 or more.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I believe that Austria, as a net EU contributor, should insist on a maximum of returns from EU pots or.dem EU budget. In this context, I support the concerns of Austrian farmers and/or Agriculture and oppose the reduction of a fund whose activities I cannot influence as a parliamentarian.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is important to support the agricultural sector in case of major crises. For this reason, a reserve for crises should be established and included in the Commission draft budget for 2016 covered by the financial discipline mechanism applied to direct payments.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is only an approval of an adjustment rate proposed by the Commission on a purely technical basis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Siekierski's report on the rate of adjustment of direct payments for the calendar year 2015. Specifically, the report provides for a reduction to direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism to the extent of 1.393041% in all Member States, applicable only to payments of more than EUR 2000. I believe that it is the duty of this Parliament, in order to strongly support the agricultural sector, to adopt effective financial instruments to combat emergency situations for a sector that is currently being severely tested by many factors, including the Russian embargo and the end of milk quotas, and which depends on unpredictable factors, such as climatic factors and international crises.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed regulation because it reduces the direct payments that farmers receive under the CAP, under the pretext of creating a reserve fund. The amount of money dedicated to agriculture under the CAP has already fallen by 20% in 15 years, so it is deplorable to reduce them further. This is all the more critical because many farmers are in a difficult situation, not least because of two EU decisions on the end of milk quotas and the embargo against Russia.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it.  The Aim of this European Parliament's proposed regulation is to create a reserve to support agricultural sectors experiencing a crisis. To this end, the Commission wants to reduce direct payments, i.e. the funds that farmers receive under the CAP.  The expected amount of this reserve is 441.6 million euros at current prices. For the creation of the latter, a direct payment adjustment rate is set. It will apply mainly to those above 2,000 euros. This measure is not only insufficient, but it also further handicaps farmers because they are the ones who are punctured. It is a false solution that has nothing to do with mutual aid because the amounts provided for the crisis reserve are withdrawn from farmers, legitimate aid intended for them. Once again farmers are paying the price for the inconsistency of EU policy, especially since these funds have already fallen by 20% in 15 years and it is therefore inappropriate to reduce them even further.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Article 25 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 provides that a reserve should be set up to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of significant crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products by applying at the beginning of each year a reduction in direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism referred to in Article 26 of that regulation. In accordance with Article 26(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, in order to ensure compliance with the annual maximum limits laid down in Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, a percentage adjustment of direct payments should be fixed. This report seeks to unlock these provisions and set the adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015. That is why I voted in favour, although I believe that when the crisis situation comes from the wrong decisions taken by the European Union, such as the Russian veto, the funds should come from elsewhere and this money should not be used to alleviate these crisis situations.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. This report increases the volume of general payments for agricultural land. Of course, there is still an abysmal difference between what farmers receive in Latvia and France. But it's better than nothing. The approved adjustment will improve the situation of farmers in the EU in general. I voted for it and that was a roll-call vote.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a regulation is in line with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and with the rule that the annual budget of the Union must comply with the multiannual financial framework. This financial discipline mechanism will ensure a more balanced distribution of payments between large and small beneficiaries in the agricultural sector. The adjustment shall apply only to direct payments exceeding EUR 2 000 to be granted to farmers in the calendar year concerned.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council fixing the rate of adjustment of direct payments provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 1306/2013 with regard to the calendar year 2015, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/6/2015 and because the creation by the EU of a reserve for crises in the agricultural sector is ultimately financed by the farmers themselves by reducing the Community aid paid to them.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal. It provides for the creation of a reserve that would be used to support agricultural sectors that are experiencing a crisis. According to the Commission's estimates, the amount needed for this reserve to be able to compensate for crises is EUR 441.6 million. To form this reserve, the European Commission intends to reduce direct payments, an income-in-income aid that farmers receive under the Common Agricultural Policy.  We strongly oppose this measure, which is insufficient and disabling for farmers who are being stripped of some of their legitimate aid.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation fixing the rate of adjustment of direct payments. I consider it appropriate to apply the adjustment rate only to payments for which applications for aid were submitted in the calendar year to which the financial framework applies, irrespective of when the payment is paid to farmers. In this way, equal treatment between all farmers can be guaranteed.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council sets the rate of adjustment reduced to 1.393041% of direct payments under agricultural support schemes of more than EUR 2,000. I believe that this is a necessary measure, which will allow the creation of a financial reserve from which to draw in the event of emergencies related to the agricultural sector. That is why I have chosen to support mr Siekierski's report with a vote in favour.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of considering it essential to safeguard financing the agricultural sector in the event of natural or other disasters affecting agricultural production and distribution.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the European Parliament's draft resolution setting out for calendar year 2015 the percentage adjustment of direct payments provided for in the Regulation on the financing, management and monitoring of the Common Agricultural Policy.  According to the approved rules, we have agreed on the percentages of adjustment in aid to be granted in this financial year, with a reduction of 1.393041% in the amounts of direct payments exceeding EUR 2,000 and for farmers applying for aid compared to calendar year 2015. We have also established that this reduction will not apply in Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The report on the adjustment rate for direct payments for the calendar year 2015 deals with small reductions in direct agricultural payments in order to increase the crisis funds in the agricultural sector to EUR 446 million. However, since I want to get the most out of our farmers and take the view that as much of the money paid as possible should go back to Austria, I reject the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the formation of a reserve to support the agricultural sector in cases of major crises. This reserve would be established by applying, at the beginning of the year, a reduction to direct payments through a financial discipline mechanism.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This is a reserve designed to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of major crises affecting production or distribution. It is constituted by applying, at the beginning of each fiscal year, a reduction in direct payments.  The amount of the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector, which is expected to be included in the Commission's draft 2016 budget, amounts to EUR 441.6 million. To do this the share of reduction in direct payments in 2015 will be 1.393041%. While this is a technical adjustment, it nevertheless deprives farmers of some of the expected payments in order to have, perhaps one day, a crisis reserve. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the proposal, the aim is to create an agricultural reserve that would support the agricultural sectors in the event of a crisis. However, this creation of a reserve implies a reduction in direct payments, i.e. aid paid under the CAP. This aid does not depend on production but on certain standards set by the CAP.  The amount of this reserve is expected to be 441.6 million euros. Cap funds have already fallen by 20% in 15 years.  This would again be a major blow to our agriculture.  So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report setting the adjustment rate provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 for direct payments for the calendar year 2015. This ensures that the special reserve to provide support to farmers in the event of serious crises is ensured, making it unnecessary to use additional financial discipline measures.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it deals with technical matters concerning the application for support for those in the agricultural sector who face a major crisis. The ultimate goal is to apply a financial discipline mechanism on this matter.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Common Agricultural Policy has allowed European agriculture to maintain itself, including in difficult regions, to develop, produce sustainably and make quality products available to all.  By voting for CAP reform, our goal was to make direct payments fairer and greener, strengthen farmers' position in the food chain, ensure food security, ensure the sustainability of the agricultural sector and make the CAP more efficient and transparent.  In this context, the financing regulation for the period 2014-2020 provides for the creation of a financial reserve to respond to a potential agricultural crisis by taking from any direct financial aid of more than 2,000 euros a percentage of 1.39 per cent. Although this represents only a tiny portion of direct payments, its usefulness may be beneficial in the future.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report on the adjustment rate for direct payments, which will set the rate of financial discipline for 2015 as foreseen under the Horizontal Regulation of the CAP in order to set up the agricultural crisis reserve.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The level of direct payments should be aligned with the amount voted on for this purpose in the budget by a joint regulation of parliament and the Council in the light of the legitimate needs received. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for this regulation in order to allow payments.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to create a reserve that can be used to support agricultural sectors experiencing a crisis. To form this reserve, the Commission wants to reduce direct payments, which farmers receive under the CAP.  Not only is this measure insufficient, but it also further handicaps farmers because they are the ones who are punctured. It is a false solution that has nothing to do with mutual aid because the amounts provided for the crisis reserve are withdrawn from farmers, legitimate aids dedicated to them.   Once again, farmers are paying the price for the inconsistency of EU policy. Funds for agriculture under the CAP have already fallen by 20% in 15 years, which is therefore unwelcome to decrease further.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reduction of direct payments, regulated in Article 26(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, with the purpose of establishing a reserve to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting agricultural production or distribution, regulated by Article 25 of that legislation, deserves my agreement. Furthermore, where it is recommended to adjust the adjustment rate for direct payments where the forecasts for the financing of measures financed under that sub-limit for a given financial year indicate that the applicable annual ceilings will be exceeded. The proposal for a reduction rate of 1.393041 % to the tranche of direct payments under the support schemes in Annex I to Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 made to farmers, corresponding to aid applications submitted for the calendar year 2015, deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation setting the adjustment rate provided for by Regulation (EU) 1306/2013 for direct payments for calendar year 2015 aims to set up a crisis-usable reserve to support the agricultural sectors. However, the creation of this reserve is in contrast to the reduction in direct payments, i.e. aid that farmers receive under the CAP. This reserve would be endowed with 441.6 million euros.  However, this provision is not only insufficient but also harmful to farmers, since it is a matter of reducing the amount of their aid, without additional support funds. It thus allows the Union to cast a modest veil over the consequences of its disastrous agricultural policy, notably the 20% reduction in funds allocated to farmers in 15 years.  So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report in order to allow for timely distribution of direct payments and provide for the crisis reserve should the agricultural sector be in need of emergency support. Importantly, any crisis measures undertaken on the basis of this regulation are paid for by the farmers themselves, with any pressure on additional Union financing thus significantly reduced.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which specifies how to build a reserve of support for the agricultural sector in the event of major crises affecting production or distribution. This reserve is created by applying a reduction on direct payments to farmers during the year.   According to Regulation (EU) 306/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council, an adjustment rate for direct payments must be determined when the funding forecasts for the measures for a given year indicate that the annual ceilings will be exceeded. The amount of the reserve as set out in the Commission's draft 2016 budget amounts to EUR 441.6 million. The 1.39 per cent adjustment rate proposed by the Commission was adopted. It will be applied to direct payments of more than EUR 2,000 to farmers for applications for assistance submitted in the 2015 calendar year.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this Commission proposal referring to the power conferred on us by Article 25 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 to provide for the establishment of a financial reserve with the aim of providing additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products. In this respect, we consider it necessary to apply a reduction in direct payments by the mechanism of financial discipline referred to in Article 26 of that regulation. The amount of the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector, to be included in the Commission's draft budget for 2016, will therefore be EUR 441.6 million at current prices. To cover this amount, the financial discipline mechanism should be applied to direct payments under the support schemes listed in Annex I to Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council for the calendar year 2015. We believe that this procedure is an indispensable instrument for ensuring equal treatment for all European farmers.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this technical report, in the opinion of the European Economic and Social Committee, on the commitment made by the Council representative on 1 June 2015 to approve Parliament's position and the report of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This regulation aims to implement the provisions of Article 26 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 on the financing, management and monitoring of the common agricultural policy and Article 8 of Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 on direct payments to farmers under the 2014-2020 support schemes. The proposal provides that the amounts of payments under the support schemes referred to in Annex I to Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013, exceeding EUR 2 000, to be granted to farmers for aid applications submitted for calendar year 2015, should be reduced by 1.393041% for all Member States except Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this report to create a support mechanism for the agricultural sector in case of major crises affecting the agricultural production or distribution. This will create the mechanism that will enable the EU to resist crisis situations better and to prevent with financial means a major agricultural crisis.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with a small reduction in direct agricultural payments. The aim was to increase the crisis fund in the agricultural sector to EUR 446 million. Our goal is to bring as much money back to Austria as possible for our farmers. Since this fund cannot be influenced by us and could have a negative impact on Austria, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the adjustment rate of direct payments for 2015 because this legislation will support the agricultural sector in cases of major crises affecting production or distribution. A crisis reserve amounting to 2.8 billion euros is planned for the period 2014-2020.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft establishing a reserve for additional support in the event of major crises affecting agricultural production or marketing, while reducing direct payments which could create unfair conditions of competition.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Direct EU support is essential for the development of agriculture and to maintain and increase its competitiveness. It should be noted that direct payments are one of the most important instruments of agri-policy. It is therefore essential to ensure a level playing field for all farmers and to help them successfully absorb EU support. It should be noted that direct payments provide a sufficient level of income, thus motivating the expansion of agricultural activity, competing on the market, and not retreating from agricultural production. In order to balance the budget, it is necessary to ensure that direct payments are used in a targeted and efficient manner. The competitiveness of farmers needs to be increased and their income stability ensured.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Siekierski's report because I believe it is appropriate, in order to ensure equal treatment for all farmers, that the rate of adjustment should apply only to payments for which aid applications were submitted in the calendar year to which the financial framework applies, irrespective of when the payment is paid to farmers.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Agriculture and farmers face many challenges today that can be increasingly difficult to bear. From market distortions to which "salt has wound" added a Russian embargo and the abolition of milk quotas, to climate change and nature that respond unpredictably every so often and leave dire consequences on the food production sector.  Therefore, a decision on the formation of a crisis fund is justified, and I supported it because it will be possible to intervene from this fund when necessary and to help the affected agricultural producers in the biggest crises. In my view, this fund should not finance the indemnity of farmers suffered as a result of the Russian embargo, but that this purpose should be taken from the reserve of the general EU budget, as the Russian embargo is due to a political decision and has no causes in the agricultural sector.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation setting the adjustment rate provided for by Regulation (EU) 1306/2013 for direct payments for calendar year 2015 aims to set up a crisis-usable reserve to support the agricultural sectors. However, the creation of this reserve is in contrast to the reduction in direct payments, i.e. aid that farmers receive under the CAP. This reserve would be endowed with 441.6 million euros. Not only is this provision insufficient, but it is even harmful for farmers, since it is a matter of reducing the amount of their aid, without additional support funds. It thus allows the Union to cast a modest veil over the consequences of its disastrous agricultural policy, including a 20% reduction in the funds allocated to farmers in 15 years.  I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ As farmers applying for direct payment aid for one calendar year (N), they receive payments within a certain payment period in the financial year (N+1). In addition, Member States may make late payments to farmers after the end of that payment period, within certain deadlines. These late payments may be made in the next financial year.  Where financial discipline applies in a given calendar year, the adjustment rate should not apply to payments for which aid applications have been submitted in calendar years where financial discipline does not apply. Therefore, in order to ensure equal treatment of farmers, it is appropriate to provide that the adjustment rate should apply only to payments for which aid applications have been submitted in the calendar year in which the financial discipline applies, irrespective of when the payment was made to farmers.  For this reason, I support the rapporteur's opinion adopting the position at first reading on setting the adjustment rate for direct payments provided for in Council Regulation (EU) No 1001/2013. 1306/2013 for calendar year 2015

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by a fellow Siekierski MP setting an adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015.  At the beginning of each year, a reserve should be established to support the agricultural sector in the event of major crises affecting agricultural production or distribution, such as the Russian embargo, applying a reduction in direct payments under the financial discipline mechanism. The amount of the agricultural sector crisis reserve projected to be included in the Commission's draft budget for 2016 is €441.6 million in current prices, and the percentage adjustment rate for the financial discipline is 1.393041% calculated taking into account the fact that it will only apply to direct payments per farmer exceeding €2,000 and not all Member States.  In this context, it should be noted that Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia are in the process of phasing out direct payments in calendar year 2015 and as such are exempt from the application of financial discipline.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the regulation fixing the rate of adjustment of direct payments. I believe that it is right to offer additional aid to a sector such as agriculture, which is of prime importance in the EU, if there are crises that can reduce production and consequently the distribution of production. As is clear, it is a sector subject to a certain randomness, mainly due to climatic factors and available resources, and it is right that a rate of adjustment of direct payments should be fixed in the event that the financing forecasts for measures falling within a given financial year may exceed the level of the applicable annual ceilings.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the adjustment of direct payments, also because it is in line with the Position of the Czech Republic in this area. I consider the financial discipline mechanism to be effective and beneficial.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament revised the adjustment rate for direct payments to farmers for 2015 and agreed on a rate of 1.4% for applications for assistance in calendar year 2015.  I voted in favour of revising this rate, which will allow the Commission to respond better in the event of a crisis affecting the agricultural sector. It is important to be able to guarantee funds to farmers in the event of a crisis, especially at this time, given the Russian embargo on certain European agricultural products.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that it is crucial to ensure respect for the principle of equality in the treatment of farmers. To this end, if financial discipline measures are necessary in order not to exceed the amounts of the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector for a given calendar year, the adjustment rate should not be applied to payments whose aid applications have been submitted in calendar years other than that to which financial discipline applies.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament approves at first reading the commission's proposal to fix the annual reduction of direct payments in accordance with Articles 25 and 26 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 and in accordance with Article 8, (1) of Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013, which is fixed at 1.393041 %.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to support the agricultural sector in situations of serious crises that could affect production and/or distribution, the European Commission has proposed the creation of a financial reserve of a total amount of EUR 2 800 million, established by implementing, at the beginning of each year, a reduction in direct payments through a financial discipline mechanism. The great added value contained in this Regulation is the result of the application of the adjustment rate only to direct payments exceeding EUR 2000, which makes it possible to safeguard and exempt small producers.  The application of this adjustment rate of 1.393041% of this adjustment rate will lead to a reduction in the amounts of direct payments for budget lines relating to the expenditure stemming from aid applications submitted by farmers for the calendar year 2015. That is why I support this proposal, to which I have voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Commission's proposal without any changes.  This proposal deals with the financing, management and monitoring of the common agricultural policy and more specifically on the percentage of the adjustment rate for financial discipline for 2015.  For example, direct payments under aid schemes to a farmer are reduced by 1.39% in order to supply and build up the reserve in the event of a crisis in the agricultural sector.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Siekierski resolution on the rate of adjustment of direct payments for the calendar year 2015; It is a technical report which is 30 years of action in favour of the agricultural sector in situations of serious crisis. It was decided that the European Union would provide for a reduction from the previous budget line of direct payments in order to transfer this amount to the crisis fund.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain as I remain perplexed about the mechanism underlying the adjustment rate, which provides for recovering resources to deal with any crises in the agricultural sector by reducing farmers' direct payments and thus always weighing the cost of any crises on the agricultural sector itself.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of allocating 1.39% of direct payments to farmers and ranchers towards the crisis fund this year, As provided for in Articles 26 and 8.1 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 respectively, in anticipation of possible natural or other disasters that may seriously affect Union crops this year.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Article 25 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 provides that a reserve should be set up to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of significant crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products by applying at the beginning of each year a reduction in direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism referred to in Article 26 of that regulation. In accordance with Article 26(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, in order to ensure compliance with the annual maximum limits laid down in Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, a percentage adjustment of direct payments should be fixed. This report seeks to unlock these provisions and set the adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015. That is why I voted in favour, although I believe that when the crisis situation comes from the wrong decisions taken by the European Union, such as the Russian veto, the funds should come from elsewhere and this money should not be used to alleviate these crisis situations.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to support the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting the production or distribution of products, provision is made at the beginning of each year for the establishment of a reserve through the application of a reduction in direct payments. The proposal to change the rate of adjustment of the financial framework for the calendar year 2015 adopted today will serve this purpose. I therefore chosen to vote in favour of this measure, trusting that – in the following financial year – the funds allocated to the crisis reserve and left unused will be made fully available to farmers in the form of direct payments.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The crisis reserve of the Common Agricultural Policy, which is constituted through this procedure, is a final resource in cases of extreme crisis which, by its nature, requires the contribution and solidarity of all farmers and beneficiaries of direct payments. The proposal exempts from this contribution all beneficiaries whose annual amount received is equal to or less than EUR 2000 and I believe that this exemption should be in a higher amount. The Russian embargo has tested the crisis management tools we have in the European Union to address serious situations of imbalance in agricultural markets, where sectors such as milk and fruit and vegetables have been particularly affected. So far, it has been possible to use instruments other than the crisis reserve. I hope that the new European Commission will have the political will to develop appropriate instruments for prevention and situations of widespread crisis. And this is because activating the crisis reserve for these cases would not only be insufficient but would produce a double penalty for farmers.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As a result of technical problems, I was not able to vote on this report. However, as rapporteur, I obviously support it and my intention was to vote in favour of it. The CAP Financial Discipline Mechanism is a good example of solidarity, as direct payments to farmers for 2015 will be reduced by 1.45 to create a crisis reserve in 2016. Until now, no such reserve has been used, as free resources were available in the CAP budget to combat crises, which meant that this money would return to farmers the following year.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EPLP voted in favour of the report in order to allow timely distribution of direct payments and provide for the crisis reserve should the agricultural sector be in need of emergency support. Importantly, any crisis measures undertaken on the basis of this regulation are paid for by the farmers themselves, with any pressure on additional Union financing thus significantly reduced.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation. The reserve proposed by the Commission for 2016 amounts to EUR 441.6 million. In the event of a major crisis affecting agricultural production or distribution in the EU, i.e. slovakia, it will be possible for Slovakia to benefit from these funds. In the event of non-exhaustion of this reserve, these funds shall be reallocated in the normal way between the Member States.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council fixing the adjustment rate for direct payments laid down in Council Regulation (EC) No 1306/2013 for calendar year 2015 was proposed by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. It states that, according to financial estimates, EUR 441,6 million is needed to cover agricultural crises reserves. This reserve will be included in the Commission's 2016 budget and will require the use of a financial discipline mechanism to cover it in calendar year 2015. The European Parliament and the Council of the European Union have thus adopted a regulation to reduce aid applications by an adjustment rate of 1,393041 % in calendar year 2015. This rate shall apply to amounts of direct payments exceeding EUR 2 000 granted to farmers on the basis of an aid application. As adjustment rates are only gradually introduced for Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia, the reduction is not taken into account for applications from the latter countries. I believe that the report on the proposal for a regulation is good and I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation setting the rate of adjustment of direct payments under the common agricultural policy for the year 2015. This is the annual exercise aimed at creating a reserve to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises in the production or distribution of agricultural products. This reserve stems from the reduction, at the beginning of each year, of direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism: to cover the amount of the reserve in the European Commission's draft budget for 2016 – EUR 441.6 million – a reduction of 1.4% is planned, which will apply to payments over EUR 2000.
