Although the creation of the reserve is a positive element of the new CAP, I would like to point out, however, that the mechanism of financial discipline derives from the decrease in the agricultural budget under the 2014-2020 Financial Perspective, which have left the agricultural budget free of room to respond to unpredictable events, such as natural disasters or high price volatility. It is therefore necessary to reflect on new and more effective crisis management solutions, which can represent a safety net for farmers, in order to enable them to compete in the global market.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ Direct payments as one of the instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy should ensure the productivity of European agriculture, the preservation of the rural population and equally adequate financial income for farmers. However, the application of financial discipline from a specific amount does not ensure equal treatment of all farmers and leads to the realisation of direct payments due to the different structure of agricultural production in the Member States.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report concerning the agricultural sector for a slight decrease in the amount of direct payments.  It is essential that a reserve intended to provide additional support for the agricultural sector, in the event of major crises affecting agricultural production or distribution, must be established at the beginning of each year in order to ensure compliance with annual financial limits for the financing of market-related expenditure and direct payments, all in accordance with Article 25 and Article 26 of the Regulation. Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1306/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this initiative on a slight reduction in the amount of direct payments to help farmers and the agricultural sector in the European Union in cases of major crises. It should be noted that these adjustments apply only to direct payments granted to farmers in the corresponding calendar year exceeding EUR 2 000.  In addition, in order to ensure equal treatment of all farmers, the adjustment rate will apply only to payments for which aid applications have been submitted in the calendar year in which the financial discipline applies, irrespective of when the payment was made to farmers.  Furthermore, as a result of the gradual introduction of direct payments, the adjustment rate only applies to Bulgaria and Romania as of 1 January 2016 and to Croatia, which I represent in this Parliament, only from 1 January 2022. In other member states, the amount of direct payment reductions for calendar year 2015 will only decrease by 1.39 percent.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report setting the adjustment rate for direct payments for calendar year 2015. The aim is to establish a crisis reserve to support agricultural production in times of crisis, such as the Russian embargo. It is about solidarity in practice. In this context, I would like to point out that it is necessary to introduce very clear conditions for beneficiaries and also to ensure that the distribution of funds is supervision. In the long term, however, we need to put in place instruments to deal with the crisis. We must not wait for the next crisis.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the design of social policies, and in particular in times of crisis, direct benefits must play an important role. The benefits referred to in this regulation are therefore also important to protect small and medium-sized enterprises from the effects of the neoliberal policies in place, with the result that the crisis deepens, and through market liberalisation the attacks on large enterprises intensify.  That is why we disagree with the reduction of direct payments. On the contrary, we support their strengthening and in particular the abolition of neoliberal policies. We have therefore voted in favour of the report, which proposes direct payments.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Direct payments to farmers as a result of a crisis, affecting agricultural production or distribution, should not be delayed and made at a later date. Also, for the calendar year 2015, the budgetary adjustment, in most rural countries, the economic crisis and the looming extension of sanctions on Russia, is not consistent with a reduction in the adjustment rate for direct payments.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important that the adjustment rate of direct payments and the reserve formation can be implemented transparently by the Member States. I welcomed the European Commission's decision to treat as public data from 31 May this year who had access to what EU support. In my opinion, corrupt practices in the Member States can be hampered by transparency. I am sure that the European Institutions will keep all forms of the fight against corruption on the agenda and that measures such as this will achieve real results. The report will also be able to monitor perverse practices such as those which unfortunately also characterise the Hungarian government. Direct payments and various damage funds are now increasingly migrating to friends of pro-government politicians, oligarchs and ministers in Hungary. In many cases, it is unbeatable, although this is obviously provided by a corrupt government. Conflicts of interest are multiplying and there is little consolation in the recent arrest of two important executives of a paying agency. In Hungary, almost 100% of the public land applications have been won by oligarchs, while the Hungarian people see that the European Union is doing nothing about this land theft!

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal. In this regard, as a general rule, farmers applying for assistance for direct payments in a calendar year (N) receive these payments within a certain payment period of the year (N-1). However, Member States can make late payments to farmers beyond this payment period, within certain deadlines. These late payments can be made in a later fiscal year.  When financial discipline is applied for a given calendar year, the adjustment rate should not apply to payments for which applications for assistance have been made in calendar years other than the calendar year for which financial discipline applies.  Therefore, in order to ensure equal treatment among farmers, it should be expected that the adjustment rate will apply exclusively to payments for which applications for assistance were made in the calendar year for which financial discipline applies, regardless of when the payment to farmers is made.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the adjustment rate for direct payments in respect of 2015. It is a technical report with the aim of reducing 2015 direct payments by 1.39%. This reduction in direct aid is needed so that EUR 441.6 million can be found for the EU agriculture budget’s 2016 crisis reserve.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this regulation as it establishes a reserve intended to provide additional support for the agricultural sector in the event of major crises affecting agricultural production or distribution, which I consider potentially extremely important and beneficial for the Croatian farmer. Since the setting of this rate is done by mechanical calculation and applies only to direct payment amounts exceeding EUR 2 000, I consider it commendable and justified to exclude the smallest European farmers from the same, which will not further jeopardise their already low incomes. As a Member of Croatia, I also hold it right and fair to decide that the above-mentioned financial discipline does not apply in Croatia, Bulgaria and Romania, as those Member States of the Union are still in the process of phasing out direct payments in calendar year 2015.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report setting the adjustment rate for direct payments for calendar year 2015. In order to protect the agricultural sector in the case of major crises, we need to provide reserves. We will achieve this by reducing direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism. The amount of direct payment should be reduced by 1.393041 % in all Member States except Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in FAVOUR to allocate 1.39% of direct payments to farmers and farmers to the crisis fund this year, As provided for in Articles 26 and 8(1) of Regulations 1306/2013 and 1307/2013 respectively, in anticipation of possible natural or other disasters which may seriously affect Union crops during this year.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in FAVOUR to allocate 1.39% of direct payments to farmers and farmers to the crisis fund this year, As provided for in Articles 26 and 8(1) of Regulations 1306/2013 and 1307/2013 respectively, in anticipation of possible natural or other disasters which may seriously affect Union crops during this year.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on the adjustment rate for direct payments in respect of 2015. I believe that the establishment of rules for direct payments to farmers is a very important element of the EU budget 2016. We ought to support the agricultural sector and agricultural production and also underline the importance of this draft resolution as  a very good first step to take for the simplification of application forms for small farmers.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about the establishment of a reserve to provide additional assistance to the agricultural sector in the event of a crisis. The reserve is constituted through a financial discipline mechanism. This report, which follows the provisions adopted in 2013 in relation to the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and the reform of the CAP, should be adopted.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Article 25 of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 provides that a reserve should be set up to provide additional support to the agricultural sector in the event of significant crises affecting the production or distribution of agricultural products by applying at the beginning of each year a reduction in direct payments through the financial discipline mechanism referred to in Article 26 of that regulation. In accordance with Article 26(1) of Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013, in order to ensure compliance with the annual maximum limits laid down in Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, a percentage adjustment of direct payments should be fixed. This report seeks to unlock these provisions and set the adjustment rate for direct payments for 2015. That is why I voted in favour, although I believe that when the crisis situation comes from the wrong decisions taken by the European Union, such as the Russian veto, the funds should come from elsewhere and this money should not be used to alleviate these crisis situations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The report on the adjustment rate for direct payments for the calendar year 2015 deals with small reductions in direct agricultural payments in order to increase the crisis funds in the agricultural sector to EUR 446 million. However, since I want to get the maximum out of our farmers and take the view that as much of the money paid as possible should go back to Austria, I would have rejected the report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The need for a reserve for crisis situations is not at issue. But rather the fact that this CAP is itself a permanent factor of crisis. The latest reform has maintained scandalous inequalities in the distribution of CAP funds – between countries, producers and producers. Liberalisation and market orientation are the order words. Millions of small and medium-sized farmers are well aware of the meaning of these words: prices that do not compensate for production, the ruin of millions of farms, the concentration of production, the increase in food dependency and the imbalance in the agri-food balances of several countries. Competitiveness is another watchword. But some receive double or triple the payments per hectare allocated to others. So it's easy to be competitive. In Portugal, many thousands of small and medium-sized farmers struggle to survive and stay in business, with production prices that often do not cover production costs. For these, it is not the meagre EUR 500, which will receive a single payment, that will end the crisis.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – I consider it a big mistake that a comprehensive amendment by the Faction of the European People's Party has not been approved, because it has dealt with the very heart of the problem of gender equality. It offers concrete measures to help women in better employment in the profession, in public life, to combine professional and family roles, while not leaving out the fight against violence against women.  In my opinion, it was quite acceptable to other political groups as well, and I am convinced that the European People's Party, our faction, will return to this problem and that this is our position document. Unfortunately, I could not support Mrs Noichl's final report because the amendments which omneled fundamentally negative parts from this report that go beyond the competence of the European Parliament and the European Union have not been approved.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I did not agree with the list of demands for equality, although I am very much in favour of equality. I am in favour of increasing the number of women employed, I am in favour of promoting flexible working time models, I am in favour of combating violence against women. But much of the important things that have to do with equality are settled by the Member States in their responsibilities. If Europe interferes in maternity protection rules, it goes too far. If we even call for the right to legal abortion, we are interfering in the constitution of the nation states. Therefore: yes to equality, no to this presumptuous report!

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam Chairman, the promotion of equality has always been the focus of the European People's Party and I am very proud to speak out in defence of our values in the European Parliament today. I'm sorry that the left groups are orchestrating items that don't fall under this resolution to me. We have proposed an alternative resolution in which we have set goals and frameworks, at all levels, local, regional, national, and also in all areas, education, health, work, etc.  We are determined to fight violence against women, but in my opinion the role of member states is key. The European Union should not interfere in all areas. We want to process gender equality, but also in Member States, taking into account rights, but also individual laws, such as family law and the constitutions of individual countries. I therefore advocate that this area be an area of subsidiarity.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think there is a very large majority in this House who are in favour of greater equality between men and women. We all know that we still have a lot of work to do in the European Union. However, I would like to say that we can only achieve this objective together – by which I mean the European Union and the Member States. That is why it is extremely important to sort out responsibilities and to advise the European Union to talk about what it is responsible for and not to interfere in the matters for which the Member States are responsible. That was precisely the great deficit of Mrs Noichl's report, which I therefore could not agree to. And we therefore missed a great opportunity today. Today, the House could have adopted a report by a huge majority. But that is precisely what has not happened, and I very much regret that.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, anyone who still clings to the idea that the European Union is an association of nations should just look down the list at the topics covered by this gender equality report: pay, workplace rules, violence against women, media portrayals, abortion rights. Whatever else this is, it is not an association of states collaborating intergovernmentally. For what it is worth, I voted against, because I do not think any of these things should have to do with Brussels. But I have to say that I resent the slightly bullying tone implicit in the debate that, if you are voting against this report, it is because you do not care about violence against women or because you do not care about media portrayals. Can we not take it as common ground that everyone in this Chamber is concerned about these issues? The argument is about the location of decision—making. On sensitive issues of this kind it should be determined by our national democratic mechanisms and procedures. It is precisely because it is important to us that we want the decisions to be taken not by unaccountable bureaucrats, but by elected representatives whom we can hire and fire.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: – Thank you, Madam President, I supported the report on the European Union Strategy for Equality between Women and Men post-2015, because I am convinced that involving women in decision-making processes at all levels is essential for gender equality policy.  Although half of Europe's population is made up of women, our policy does not reflect this fact. Most meps – 63.1% and 75% of MEPs in national parliaments are men. As the representation of women depends to a large extent on political parties, in so far as they determine the candidate lists for the relevant elections, I call on the European Parliament to take a common initiative with an appeal to national parties to help women acquire the necessary political skills and to include them on the electoral lists.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we voted in favour of this report on the strategy for equality between men and women because we believe it is going in the positive direction.  However, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take advantage of the vote on this report to recall that in my country – in Spain – we are a long way from meeting the objectives of equality and to point out that austerity policies, sponsored by both the Troika and the old parties in our country, have helped to deepen the differences between men and women.  I will say this very clearly: in Spain, precariousness has a woman's face; in Spain, wages of misery have a woman's face; in Spain, the care of the elderly and minors without public aid has a woman's face.  Ladies and gentlemen, the main enemy of equality in Europe and Spain is not only machismo, but the destruction of social rights and workers' conquests.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – The European Parliament has just adopted another document that directly undermines the most important of human rights, the right to life. This decision is not just a bad moral choice, it is an action that undermines the credibility of any declaration by this body on human rights. You lead Europe on the road to perdition. Unless there is a great awakening of consciences, unless there is a great agreement of people of good will in Europe, in all the peoples of Europe, we will not save the future of our continent, our civilization. This is really a choice between life and what has been voted on today – death.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam Chairman, I am concerned that this Parliament is spending taxpayers' money to produce documents that are contrary to the interests of the citizens who elected us. I am concerned when Members of Parliament applaud the adoption of amendments that impede every human being's right to life. I'm concerned when dialogue and agreement on general people's values are not possible in this hall.  The Noichl report has caused a deep division in this Parliament, it is against the values I believe in and live in and that is why I voted against it. I also voted against this report because 48% of the paragraphs of the report are in direct contradiction with the EU principle of subsidiarity, 35% of paragraphs are not related to the topic of the report itself, 42% of paragraphs show open discrimination against men, and it is a report on equality, 17% of paragraphs contain a serious risk of restriction of freedom of speech and media, freedom of education and freedom within the conclusion of contracts, 7 paragraphs introduce elements that are not scientifically proven and unfounded allegations. This report is a disgrace to the European Parliament.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I abstained on the final vote on this report. The report contains many good points, such as the proposal to address the needs of women with disabilities, access to the labour market, zero tolerance when it comes to gender-based violence and the call for 2016 to be named as the Year of Combating Violence against Women and Girls. I fully support the call to Member States to combat precarious work and the need to counter the feminisation of poverty, which is driven by non-standard forms of work such as zero-hour contracts in voluntary part-time work, etc. However, I could not support Recital S stating that access to reproductive rights should never be restricted. Virtually all Member States have some restrictions, and anyway this is a matter for the Member States to decide, not the EU. Recital U demonstrates an uninformed and narrow-minded perspective on single-sex schools, and I could not support it. And the call for disaggregated gender data on everything from climate change to energy has no proven added value.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil le a lán de mo chomhghleacaithe atá tar éis caint, táim i bhfabhar cothromaíocht idir fir agus mná. Ach ní raibh mé in ann glacadh le a lán de na moltaí anseo mar bhí siad ag dul thar fóir. Bhí baint acu le cumhachtaí nach mbaineann linn.  Dá bhrí sin, bhí mé i bhfabhar thuarascáil PPE. Bíodh sin ráite, tá a lán moltaí maithe anseo, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le hionadaíocht pholaitiúil, le pá agus le foréigean. Ba mhaith liom dá ndéanfaimis níos mó chun foréigean a chosc, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le buachaillí óga. Ba chóir a mhúineadh dóibh agus a chur ina luí orthu nár cheart dóibh riamh lámh a ardú i gcoinne mná nó cailíní. Dá bhféadfaimis é sin a dhéanamh mar thús, bheadh dul chun cinn maith déanta againn.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I have voted against this report, as it called for the Commission to bring in a compulsory quota system for women in the workplace. As an MEP who was elected onto my party’s list without a quota and then elected without a quota by the public, I find this demeaning and insulting to all hard-working women up and down the UK. We should live in a meritocratic society where women are encouraged to achieve their goals, and we should address the issues that are keeping women from reaching these goals. We should not treat women as just another number in EU stats, and we certainly should not be forcing businesses and parliaments to have mandatory quotas.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this Chamber has just approved a report with implications on sex education, the traditional family, gender quotas in boardrooms and who does the housework in the house. This is not the responsibility of the state, let alone the super-state. This motion brings further shame onto the EU. I am proud to have voted against this. When the referendum day comes in the UK, I implore the British people not to be fooled by thinking that any of this is about trade. This is not about trade. This is social engineering and an assault on traditional values on an enormous scale. So, when referendum day comes, vote to leave and vote for freedom.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when Britain joined the European Union – or ‘Common Market’ as it was then known – we were told it was a trade agreement. The British people were misled, and thanks to UKIP forcing the establishment to hold a referendum we will soon be able to correct that error. The undemocratic European Union should not be taking decisions on abortion, whether you like it or not; on sex education in schools, whether you like it or not; on lesbian, gay and transgender roadmaps, whether you agree with them or not or even know what they are; or, indeed, on creating university chairs in gender studies and feminist research – which is a waste of money for people in my constituency who are going to food banks in this recession. I say this as a homosexual who fights for homosexual equality, and as a firm believer in ladies’ rights. But these matters must be decided in our ancient British House of Commons and our recently-reconvened ancient Scottish Parliament. That is why I voted against this ludicrous political-correctness-on-stilts: the EU strategy for women and men. This is the sort of nonsense that demonstrates how out of touch this Parliament is with the men and women ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Madam President, I did not vote in favour of the report because I believe that a number of its forecasts are national competences. However, this report can be a good start to encourage steps to bridge the gap between men and women in the real economy. We all know, after all, that only 5% of the chairmen of the boards in the European Union are women, that only 18.6% of the members of the supervisory boards are women, that only a third of the self-employed, those who set up businesses, are women, while 60% of the new graduates are women.  What don't women do well? Don't they work long? Don't they have new ideas? Aren't they consistent? They are doing all this, I think, and their presence in the real economy cannot be guaranteed by stifling quotas. A true framework of encouragement must be created that will allow female power, female ingenuity, female sensitivity to be present in economic development.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report. We have a situation in Ireland where thousands of women are forced to take the boat – or get an airplane if they can afford the flight – to have an abortion in England. We are going around patting ourselves on the back – and rightfully so – for voting in favour of gay marriage, and apparently we are all equal. However, I would say there were quite a few poor unfortunate women on the boat on the evening that we voted in favour of gay marriage who actually would not have felt that equal at all. One part of the report that I do find a bit strange (and I do find it in general a bit strange) is that if you mind your own children at home, you are not considered at work, whereas if you mind someone else’s children in a crèche you are considered at work. Now I think that if you mind your children, you are at work. Why not include that as work and not as being unemployed? – because my mother was very employed when she was minding us.

name: President. –
text: I will give the floor to Mr Woolfe who somehow didn't make it to the list.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I am sure that a lot of people would not like to see me on the list, but thank you very much. I say that to make a light of humour to fill this Chamber. This is an own-initiative report by a Member of this House, Mrs Noichl. An own-initiative report is an opportunity for an MEP to freewheel, to create ideas for himself, to make himself look good to people in this Chamber and to issue an opportunity for the Commission to make rules on people across Europe. It is not about gender and equality; it is simply an opportunity for people in the Commission to control the nation states of Europe. That is why I opposed this particular motion. I support gender equality and I support rights for women, but I believe that they should be controlled from the British Parliament. We will have a referendum next year, where the people of Britain will have the opportunity to say whether they believe the European Union should control their lives or whether the British Parliament should control their lives. I believe it is the British Parliament.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015. The report contains many urgent proposals for action against, for example, men's violence against women, discrimination and the gender pay gap. However, the report also contains proposals which I cannot support, for reasons of subsidiarity, for reasons of subsidiarity. These include forced quotas and family policy.  With regard to the wording on sexual and reproductive health, I maintain my view that the EUROPEAN Union should respect the fact that responsibility for health policy belongs at national level. In substance, the Christian Democrats believe that in pregnancy there are two individuals worthy of protection and that it is therefore in society's interest to reduce the number of abortions, but that the woman has the right to make the decisive decision on abortion during the first part of pregnancy.  The Christian Democrats believe that the state and the legislator cannot be neutral to the ethical dimension of the issue of abortion. This report makes no mention whatsoever of the fact that the foetus also has a protective value. I voted against the report, after an overall assessment of the content of the report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report sets guidelines for a new Equality Strategy 2016-2020, following the failure of the still-current 2010-2015 Strategy, which has failed to address the problems of inequality between women and men in the EU in any of its areas. Although the finally adopted report is particularly uns ambitious in areas such as ambiguous differentiation between forced and legalized prostitution, in the field of reproductive rights and access to safe abortion (leaving it at the discretion of the Member States) or obviating that the root cause of the sharpening of the feminization of poverty has to do with serious cuts in public services , the text approves giving a mandate to the European Commission to develop a specific directive against gender-based violence, to include the gender dimension in all policies and to include gender groups among the objectives of the Strategy. That is why I voted for it. Finally, I would like to express my rejection of the alternative proposal put forward by the People's Party not only because of its conservatism but also because it tried to tear down the document voted on in the Committee on Women and Gender Equality.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Equality between women and men is recognised by the EU as both a fundamental value and a goal. Against this background, the EU has the power to legislate to combat discrimination against women and men in their diversity. I welcome this resolution, which calls on the European Commission to ensure that both women and men are not disadvantaged on the basis of their ethnicity, class, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, religion, citizenship or age. The plenary voted in favour of high-quality and accessible services in the areas of sexual and reproductive health and rights, as well as safe and legal abortion and contraception. I share this view, even if this is not so much a European issue as a matter for the Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Under the guise of equality between men and women, the Noichl report is in fact a homosexual propaganda text containing the most radical demands of LGBTI ("lesbian-gay-bi-trans-intersex" ratings). In addition, the promotion of LDCs and GPA, the modest term for mother-carriers, and the promotion of the rights of minorities and immigrants. The spread of gender ideology is also present in this report, with no obvious link to the title of the report. Together with my colleagues at the National Front, I tirelessly defend the values of the traditional family, which are the building blocks of our identity.  For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity requires decisions to be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen. Decisions on issues such as quotas in the boardroom are decisions which should be taken by the Member States concerned, not by the European Union. This report was not in keeping with that principle, and I felt it necessary to vote against – whatever my personal opinions on some of the issues contained within the report. Notwithstanding that, the report itself was very mixed: it safeguarded some important rights (which should be done at national level) whilst also proposing dangerous state interference in various areas.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I abstained from voting on this text. It is a report of initiative without legal scope, in the guise of a catalogue of good intentions, some of which run counter to my convictions.  I consider that my mandate in the European Parliament has three objectives: the first is to take part in the drafting and voting of normative texts, the second is to monitor and evaluate the policies led by the European Union, and finally, the third is to move the institutions of the European Union towards federalism. Many of the texts put to the vote are incantatory and not edial. The European Parliament does not come out of this kind of debate for which the Union has no competence.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported Maria Noichl's initiative report on the Union's strategy for gender equality after 2015 because the current finding shows that equality between men and women is not a concrete reality.  Indeed, it is important to propose actions aimed at ending discrimination against women and strengthening their place and representation in society. This would include, for example, taking steps to provide equal wage opportunities in the labour market or balancing family and work life.  I voted for this resolution because we must send a message to the Commission to push for an ambitious policy in this area.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a strategy to promote gender equality, which pursues clearer objectives and better supervision of this strategy. I agree that the new strategy for promoting gender equality should be clearer in order to curb discrimination in the labour market, education and decision-making. It is also important to strengthen the mechanism for monitoring its implementation. This is stated in the draft resolution, which the EP will discuss on Monday, and will decide the next day whether to support it.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Estrella, Lunacek, Tarabella, Panzeri, Noichl... these relationships follow each other and are similar: again and again the promotion of gender ideology, that of the so-called LGBTI ("lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual... and intersex), that of ultra-communitarian minorities who vehemently deny the natural differences and complementarities between men and women.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The 2010-2015 Strategy for Gender Equality has come to an end, but the European Commission has yet to propose a new strategy. This report therefore sets out the demands of the European Parliament. We call on the Commission: - a separate new strategy for women's rights; - real gender mainstreaming across all policies, including the use of structural funds; - many actions to combat violence against women: a DIR, 2016 as a European year, ratification of the Istanbul Convention; - measures for work-life balance, including child care, the maintenance of the IDD maternity leave, a paternity leave ID and a review of parental leave; - better participation of women in decision-making and entrepreneurship, including through quotas; - health measures, including access to abortion and contraception; - actions to combat stereotypes in culture, education and the media, including through teacher training; - taking women's rights into account in external policies, including access to family planning and abortion.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The adopted report, which I have strongly supported, sets up the European Parliament's position for the new EU strategy for gender equality designed by the European Commission for the period 2016-2020. It is a success because it presents specific actions to strengthen the rights of women with disabilities, migrants and ethnic minorities, Roma, the elderly, single mothers and the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex groups.  It also urges the Commission to propose new legislation to protect women from violence and they want all Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible, a matter of enormous importance on which I am personally very involved. We hope, and we will be vigilant, that the Commission will take note of our recommendations and make progress on gender equality, which is still much needed, as evidenced by all the reports and studies analysing the issue of gender.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Maria Noichl's report on the Union's Strategy for Gender Equality contains good elements as it is true that there is still much progress to be made on equal pay or work-life balance.  Nevertheless, it is totally unacceptable on other points, especially when it no longer hesitates to deviate on certain subjects related to gender theory, minorities or sex education. Moreover, this report does not respect the principle of subsidiarity at all and de facto infringes on the prerogatives of the Member States.  Thus, policies on abortion and contraception or sex education are not within the competence of the European Union and therefore have no place in this report. The text also deals with considerations of ethnic minorities such as roma and makes the LDC an individual right which I strongly oppose. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because we still face problems and challenges in the gender equality area in Europe. We still have an unresolved problem of pay gaps, which affects the lives of both working and older women, as women receive lower pensions and are more likely to be poor in old age. In addition to these problems, there is also a need to talk about non-discrimination in the labour market, about adequate and guaranteed social guarantees, and about reconciling family and working life. The fight against all forms of violence against women and girls should be a priority on the gender equality agenda, and we call once again on the Commission to initiate European legislation to combat and prevent violence against women. In addition, it is still noticeable that women are significantly less involved in political, public and economic decision-making, and there are still cases of discrimination in businesses, business and politics. We therefore call on the Commission and the Member States in the report to raise women's awareness of learning opportunities in these areas and to ensure that women have the same opportunities as men in order to get the job and career.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that respect for member states' competences is key in order to protect equality, particularly on moral issues and on issues related to family policy. Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making. The report does not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party and, for this reason, I was unable to support it in the final vote.  At the same time, I would like to state that promoting equal opportunities for women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions.  I regret that this is not sufficiently reflected in the report. In my opinion, the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool and the submission of reports that go beyond the subject of the report and want to convey messages that do not fit the subject must stop.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. First, I would like to thank my colleague Noichl for her excellent work and appreciation of the contribution of a large number of colleagues. The latest Gender Equality Strategy did not produce significant results. That's why I think it's necessary for this one to be more ambitious. Achieving gender equality is a precondition for achieving the EU's overall objectives, such as increasing employment and reducing the wage gap. I put in my own amendments to make it easier to finance projects for women entrepreneurs. However, I don't think it's right to concentrate only on the economic approach to gender equality. I also asked for the introduction of sex education in schools to be supported in order to combat gender inequalities as successfully as possible.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because of its banal absurdity. It calls for EU interference in the education systems of Member States, with specific regard to sex education for children. The EU has no competence in this area, and no right to intervene in this matter. The ridiculous call for re-distribution of household chores between men and women verges on insanity – how can an institution meddle to this extent in the private lives of citizens? Finally, the potential dissolution of companies who do not achieve the correct ‘gender balance’ on their boards is dangerous and anti-business.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution with my vote because I believe it is essential for Parliament to take a serious stand on the issue of gender equality and discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. The world is evolving rapidly and we must give women and homosexuals the dignity they deserve.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Institute for Gender Equality noted that despite steady progress on the road to gender equality in recent years, there has been a lag behind the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.   Women in the EU currently have an average unemployment rate of 12.5% higher than their male colleagues, a wage and pension rate of less than 20%; they are under-represented in public and private management roles, and unfortunately they are still victims of physical, sexual or psychological violence every year. How much longer do we want to tolerate this inequality? Our Parliament must urge the Commission to review its strategy to achieve the objective of full equality by 2020. The right to protected motherhood, the self-determination of one's own choices and the use of one's own body, the right to effective equality in pay and opportunities for work, career and political representation, the right to respect and equality in every aspect of public and social life are not unattainable utopias but fundamental human rights, which will become a reality if The European ruling classes work in this direction. Let's do it and we won't get to 2020 with the shame of having failed again.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the Union for Gender Equality Strategy for the post-2015 term. This report is a fabric of far-left stereotypes. We must not be fooled by the communitarian vision he proposes. This report is dangerous both in its desire to promote migrants' access to Member States and in promoting gender theory. Various arguments are worth special attention and that is why it is regrettable that they have been drowned in a mass of inconsistency. The subject of discrimination against women in Europe must be considered and not swept away as quickly by the majority in place.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality has been a major theme over time. Member States must be concerned with creating the framework within which each individual can freely manifest himself according to his or her own conscience, in compliance with legal provisions and moral principles. I voted against the Report on the EU strategy for gender equality post-2015 because I want to stress that, although I agree with gender equality between women and men, I cannot agree with the sacralisation of lesbian and gay rights, but is against sanctions against them, for this reason alone. The European Union as a whole must ensure that individual rights and freedoms are respected and, whenever it finds slippages, intervene firmly and unequivocally. Respect for moral and biblical perceptions must govern any society which must be concerned, including the perpetuation of the human species, which will certainly not be able to take place by encouraging same-sex marriage strappy and, in any case, by encouraging adoptions by them.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. Without prejudice to the abortion rights that I believe women should evaluate, the measure is intended to subvert the traditional family in order to be voted on.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. We must ensure that the principle of equality between men and women is respected in all Member States. A European Union strategy for gender equality in line with the principle of subsidiarity is needed.  I voted in favour of the epp Group's alternative resolution while expressing my support on the importance of access to abortion and contraception for all and on sexual and reproductive rights. However, some paragraphs of the original report seemed unacceptable to me, deliberately flouting the principle of subsidiarity and respect for the competences of the Member States. I therefore abstained on the Noichl report.

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. The reason why I abstained in the vote in the first part of paragraph 2 of this report was the lack of clarity of the term 'differentiated and specific LGBTI roadmap'. In my opinion, it has a dangerous discriminatory tint and undermines what is an important principle for me, namely that one way to ensure equality is not to treat equals differently.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015.  With this resolution, Parliament has given a strong signal that the EU's new post-2015 strategy for gender equality should include clear objectives, concrete actions and more effective monitoring to make progress in the fight against discrimination in the labour market, education and decision-making. Furthermore – and I consider this to be an absolutely important point – the resolution calls on the Commission to propose new laws containing binding measures to protect women from violence (including from new forms of violence, such as cyber-harassment, cyber-stalking and cyber-bullying) and calls on the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible. On our continent we still have to deal with 20-25% of women who suffer physical violence at least once in their lives, while around half a million women are even subjected to genital mutilation, right here in Europe. The European Union can no longer confine itself to mere denunciation and must ensure that European legislation on gender equality is fully compliance.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am an active campaigner raising the issue of equality for the UK’s Gypsy and Traveller communities, and accordingly support the principle of equality, I voted against this strategy as I feel strongly that the issues of gender equality  raised in this manner don’t create a level playing field in relation to individual ability. I was elected to this place in second spot on UKIP’s West Midlands list, behind my colleague Jill Seymour.  Jill was voted to the top of that list in a fair and equal ballot of UKIP party members, and accordingly, I have more respect for ladies who achieve on merit, rather than those in similar positions on the ground of gender equality.  I believe that it is insulting to successful women that they may be mistakenly looked upon in some quarters as only being in such a position by virtue of legislation.  The result of this proposal is accordingly counter-productive.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this report as it does not respect the principle of subsidiarity with regard to certain rights, particularly on ethical or family law issues, such as abortion. On the other hand, I fully agree and concur on a number of important issues raised in the report, such as measures to address violence against women, to find new measures of reconciling family life and work and measures seeking equal access and participation in political and social life. I fully agree that these measures should be included in the EU’s new strategy for equality between men and women and be effectuated without delay.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, the result of careful work, lays the foundation of the new strategy for equality between men and women, a characteristic element of any society that wants to be mature. This deals with this issue in a cross-cutting way, going from combating violence against women, to the different needs of women in relation to work, the right to health – which is a universal right – and also sexual and reproductive rights. It is important for the European Union to recognise these requirements and to take them on board, and I have therefore voted in favour of them.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the draft report on the European Union strategy on gender equality is a 'no' vote. And it is a no sufferer, because I know perfectly well that, in fact, equality between men and women in all areas of life is progressing too slowly.  But this equality will never be achieved through the devalue of the family, which represents, on the other hand, a serious cultural retreat of Europe. It is not through the recognition of gay families or same-parenthood that men and women will be guaranteed the same rights. It is certainly not by means of a law that prevents adopted children from knowing their natural parents that women will be more like men and not even being able to have unseeded children. For all these reasons, I was unable to vote in favour of this resolution. Equality between men and women is achieved by legislation that protects life from conception to its natural end, through aid to families, to working mothers, by establishing equal pay, by promoting reconciliation between private and professional life, by guaranteeing equality in education. That is what each Member State should do, even without the European Parliament being told.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The equal treatment of men and women is a fundamental right that must be respected. I regret that there are still many barriers preventing this in Europe.  The fact that there are differences in the salaries of men and women is completely unacceptable. Access to flexible forms of work and ensuring a balance between work and personal life has to also be assured. These are crucial points which we must progress on. I regret, however, that I had to abstain on this strategy as there are some points that I cannot agree with. The issue of maternity leave is one where a one-size-fits-all strategy will not work, and is best left to the Member State level. Furthermore, I do not believe that the introduction of compulsory quotas is a way to enhance gender equality effectively in the long term.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which, tinged with ideology, develops a miserable conception of women. The latter is seen as a member of an oppressed community that must be liberated through work, the dignity of women being, in this report, conditioned on their production capacities in the labour market. I am also concerned about the logic of gender theory inherent in this report: sex education courses, pro-LGBT propaganda, promotion of LDC, abortion, etc. All these deadly 'progress' envisaged by this text by Mrs Noichl and which, moreover, trample on the competence of the Member States, since family and health policies are excluded from the competences of the Union under Article 4-2 of the FUE Treaty. There is also a provision for a quota policy to put women at the head of companies, as if they could not rise to such positions by their skills alone. Because I am an ardent defender of the dignity of women, I will continue to fight against its denial initiated by the processes of gender uniformity by pure militant dogmatism.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I share my colleague’s opinion that no enough is being done to promote gender equality. Ms Noichl notes in her report that the introduction of compulsory quotas in institutions for women to be able to achieve top positions has proven to be effective is countries where it has been applied.  Irrespective of the various differing opinions on the introduction of quotas in this House, we should all agree that the gender pay and pension gap for equal work remains unacceptably high.  In order to increase employment rates for women, there needs to be a fair system of maternity and paternity leave. After all, why should a father not be entitled to the same amount of days off work as the mother? In Sweden, for example, where we consistently see gender equality policies bringing positive results, the government also encourages couples to take equal time off work.  Education plays an important role in combating inequality, discrimination and stereotyping. Women’s role in society is evolving and government policies should reflect this, and certainly not lag behind society’s views on gender equality.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report in question was presented at a decisive moment for the European Union since during the course of this year, using the twentieth anniversary of the approval of the objectives of the Beijing Platform for Action and the revision of the Millennium Development Goals, data on the progress made in the field of gender equality worldwide were presented.  The EU's objective is to make steady progress towards effective equality between women and men, considering, unfortunately, that traditional gender roles and stereotypes still profoundly influence the distribution of tasks in the family, in education, in work and in society in general. According to Data from the European Commission, only 5% of CEOs in the EU. The next five years are essential for a more concrete application and rooted in all areas of this strategy belonging to a larger set of equality objectives that the European Union must be able to guarantee to its citizens, such as: ethnicity, the social class, sexual orientation, religion, citizenship or age. The report set out fundamental objectives for the implementation of rights recognised by the EU Treaties. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this measure as it contains sensitive and controversial provisions on ethical issues that need to be investigated further. The GROUP of the European People's Party has therefore decided to vote against the EU strategy for equality between men and women because it is not in line with the group's guidelines.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that gender equality is a serious issue and, as such, must be dealt with without ideological prejudice. It is true that, unfortunately, in 2015 we still have to remember that human beings have equal rights regardless of their gender. However, at least as far as the competences of the European Parliament are concerned, it is also worth remembering how much some issues have been forcibly included in this report because they are not directly relevant. On the basis of these considerations, I have decided how to vote.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Several indicators show that Member States have evolved towards greater gender equality. However, this form of inequality remains a frequent reality, affecting women in particular. Parliament must play an active role in the defence of equality, in particular by contributing to the definition of a European strategy. However, it should not intrude on the competences of the Member States, nor should it take advantage of reports which should seek the greatest possible consensus in the field of national law or the convictions of each member, such as abortion. In agreement with the generality of this report, I have decided, however, to abstain.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report because I support the EPP's alternative motion for a resolution. The own-initiative report goes in the right direction on many issues, such as the call for an increase in the employment rate of women, the promotion of flexible working time models and the fight against violence against women. There is still much to be done in terms of equality in the Member States. However, on issues relating to sexual and reproductive health and the rights to abortion that go with them, the rapporteur's demands must be rejected. Abortion is not a European issue, but a matter for the Member States. The right to legal abortion must be rejected!

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again we are faced with an attempt to use such an important report and theme, such as equality between men and women, forcing some concepts that cannot be shared. Some people in here say that it is the progress and development of man and our society that must include the right to abortion as a fundamental human right, to change the concept of parenthood beyond the natural right, to ensure sexual and reproductive health, without explaining with what limits. In my opinion, the European Parliament should endeavour to provide firm and effective answers to the real problems of daily life, such as the situation of young people, who do not have a job or the means to form a family and bring children into the world. The right priorities should be re-established on our political agenda.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as tabled by the Committee on Womenʼs Rights and Gender Equality since this does not respect the principle of subsidiarity on issues related to abortion. It calls upon the Commission to introduce sexual health and reproductive rights including abortion within its work programme. This clearly runs counter to subsidiarity. The report does however raise important issues such as measures to address violence against women, to find new measures for reconciling family life and work, measures seeking equal access and participation in political and social life, and also to create incentives for competent training in the critical use of the media to encourage the questioning of stereotypes. These are measures which have been spoken of repeatedly in the past and which really deserve more effective action without further delay.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presents the European Union's strategy for achieving the main objectives concerning equality between women and men after 2015. Considering that the right to equal treatment is a fundamental right recognised by the EU Treaties, which is emblematic and deeply rooted in European society, which is essential for the further development of european society, which should apply both in legislation, practice and jurisprudence and in real life, I voted in favour of this report. The EU has historically taken important steps towards strengthening women's rights and gender equality, but in recent decades there has been a slowdown across the Union in political action and reform with regard to gender equality. That is why I believe that the next strategy must give new impetus and take concrete action to strengthen women's rights and promote gender equality.  I am voting in favour of the Noichl report because it calls for access to information, prevention, safe, effective and accessible contraception, termination of pregnancy and safe and legal sterilisation, as well as assistance with adoptions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report sets guidelines for a new Equality Strategy 2016-2020, following the failure of the still-current 2010-2015 Strategy, which has failed to address the problems of inequality between women and men in the EU in any of its areas. Although the finally adopted report is particularly uns ambitious in areas such as ambiguous differentiation between forced and legalized prostitution, in the field of reproductive rights and access to safe abortion (leaving it at the discretion of the Member States) or obviating that the root cause of the sharpening of the feminization of poverty has to do with serious cuts in public services , the text approves giving a mandate to the European Commission to develop a specific directive against gender-based violence, to include the gender dimension in all policies and to include gender groups among the objectives of the Strategy. That is why I voted for it. Finally, I would like to express my rejection of the alternative proposal put forward by the People's Party, not only because of its conservatism but also because it tried to tear down the document voted on in the Committee on Women and Gender Equality.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is part of a decisive moment, twenty years after the adoption of the objectives of the Beijing Platform for Action and the revision of the Millennium Development Goals, it is a question of assessing the progress made in the field of equality between women and men throughout the world. Unfortunately, everything suggests that the results will not, once again, be fully satisfactory and that progress is still being made too slowly. European policy must no longer confine itself to having objectives which, however ambitious they may be, remain so. Instead, it must produce and develop effective, coherent and realistic strategies aimed at eliminating all forms of discrimination against women and men in their diversity. The data continues to be depressing. One in three women in the EU has experienced psychological or sexual violence at least once in their lives after the age of 15. At present, 74.2% of men are employed, compared with 62.5% of women. The same can be said of other forms of discrimination. I voted in favour of this report because I think this is the time for a bold step forward, which puts the Union at the head of the battle for the abolition of all forms of discrimination.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Noichl report, despite the fact that it contains several wordings with which I can agree, could not be supported. The aim of the report is to develop a strategy to tackle inequality between women and men after the 2015 period. It is a regrettable fact that women continue to be discriminated against in many areas of life. The report rightly points out that equality between women and men is, among other things, an important economic resource for promoting just and inclusive economic growth. It is an unsustainable situation that lower salaries for women inevitably lead to lower pension contributions, which, of course, means lower pensions. The pension gap stands at roughly 39%, forcing many women below the poverty line.  It should be appreciated that the report tried to find solutions to these problems, but in my opinion it went beyond the values of the People's Party and achieved a number of objectives that did not respect the principle of subsidiarity. The Union cannot be expected to formulate measures or take action in areas which fall within the competence of the Member States, including health and family policy. Unfortunately, the people's alternative resolution did not receive sufficient support and, thanks to the cooperation of the left-wing coalition, the report contained requests, measures and tasks that caused me to be unable to support the report in the final vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is aimed at addressing the fact that by the end of this year, the Commission's strategy for equality between women and men will come to an end. Aside from addressing key instances which can further contribute to gender equality, such as the stronger policies to combat gender violence, the introduction of paternity leave and the backing of strong directives such as the women on boards directive, the report also deals with stronger rights for LGBTI persons, with a particular reference to LGBTI bullying in schools and preferred gender. The report calls for more opportunities for people needing IVF treatment and gives a strong message towards countering discrimination – thus I voted in favour of this report as a whole although, regretfully, the report also included references to sexual and reproductive health rights and abortion – as I have done in similar reports.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the economic independence of men and women is a major element of gender equality. The current economic crisis risks throwing us into the past, with women eventually being affected more than men. That is why I believe that efforts to improve labour market participation and access to business management decision-making positions and not only should be among the priorities on the agenda.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the European Parliament's contribution to the European Commission's reflection on the development and presentation of a new EU strategy for gender equality after 2015.  I support the proposals made by this report on the fight against violence against women or wage inequalities, women's vulnerability to poverty, unemployment and discrimination.  Nevertheless, the report also mentions issues that fall within the competence of the Member States and which, in according with the principle of subsidiarity, cannot be decided at the level of the European Union, namely the issues of reproductive and sexual rights, abortion and finally the promotion of medically assisted reproduction. The EPP had proposed an alternative resolution which I supported because it respected the division of powers prescribed by the European treaties between the Union and the Member States, but which did not get a majority of votes. I therefore voted against the report for the reasons already mentioned.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report which, once again, takes the fundamental subject of equality between women and men hostage to deal with other subjects, in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity. This text, which has no binding legal force, in particular encourages Member States to promote medically assisted reproduction and to amend their national family laws. These issues fall under the competence of the Member States and not the European Union. From then on, it was impossible for me to support such a text.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report identifies the objectives that the Commission will have to pursue in the area of gender equality for the post-2015 future. Too much discrimination against women persists in Member States, particularly in relation to access to decision-making positions, in the labour market and in education. These discriminations must be swiftly corrected.  The European Union must pay attention to the particular situations of single mothers, elderly or disabled women and be uncompromising in the fight against violence against women and whose perpetrators must be strongly condemned by the Member States.  Finally, in health, the EU must ensure better access to contraception and safe and legal ivy. Although legislative and regulatory policy on reproductive health is the responsibility of Member States, the Union can add value, including by sharing positive experiences and best practices in the health programmes and policies of Member States and candidate countries.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Once again, I regret that in an important text on equality between men and women beyond 2015, some political groups are using the European Parliament as a forum and therefore introducing paragraphs on subjects that are outside the competence of MEPs.  Unfortunately, this attitude leads to the division of votes in Parliament on a problem that would have required unanimity! I did not want to obstruct this text, which contained many good elements such as the fight against violence against women and stereotypes, the promotion of equality at all levels, the development of women's entrepreneurship and the reduction of wage gaps, but I was also unable to support it because of the lack of respect for the principle of subsidiarity. I therefore abstained.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making.  Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party and, for this reason, I could not support her in the final vote. At the same time, support for equal opportunities between women and men remains one of the key priorities of the PP group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions. I regret that this position has not been sufficiently displayed in the report.  I am convinced that respect for member states' competences, particularly on ethical issues and on issues related to family policy, is key to protecting equality. I cannot support a report with its title, but not a realistic equality of opportunity.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I am one of 341 MEPs who voted in favour of the Maria Noichl report because I believe that, despite certain social, cultural, political and economic achievements, the place and representation of women is still too fragile in our European societies and deserve to be strengthened.  While the issue remains, of course, a privileged area of States, a proactive EU policy is also needed on violence against women, for example. Some wanted to drag us into a sterile controversy on the issue of the introduction of the LDC for same-sex couples, on which the adopted text does not pronounce at all. Similarly, the EPP's attempt to empty the text of all its substance by tabling an alternative resolution was thwarted.  After the adoption last March of the annual report on the progress (or not) of equality between men and women carried by Marc Tarabella, this vote is another step in favour of women's rights.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. As an advocate for equal rights, I supported this resolution on the European Strategy for Gender Equality after 2015. We need new rules, particularly to better combat new forms of violence against women and girls, particularly cyber-harassment and cyber-bullying.  The feminization of poverty can lead to an increase in sexual exploitation and forced prostitution. Member States should explore ways to discourage clients and adopt programmes to help women who want to get out of prostitution. Another register also includes promoting affordable child care and child care facilities to enable women to balance their private and work life and increase their employment rates.  However, I abstained from voting in favour of certain provisions which, in my view, either did not respect the principle of subsidiarity, or did not fit with the purpose of the report, or were contrary to my personal convictions.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making. Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party, and for this reason I could not support her in the final vote. At the same time, I would like to state that promoting equal opportunities for women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions. I regret that this position has not been sufficiently presented in the report.  I am convinced that the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool and that the submission of reports that go beyond the subject of the report, rape the boundaries and send messages that do not fit the subject must stop. I am convinced that respect for member states' competences, particularly on ethical issues and on issues related to family policy, is key to protecting equality. I cannot support a report with its title, but not a realistic equality of opportunity.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I feel it is very important to continue to take decisive steps towards strengthening gender equality, I abstained on the EP report regarding the EU strategy for equality for women and men post 2015. I agree with most of the contents of the document. However, I have previously expressed my dissatisfaction with the adoption of the Maternity Leave Directive in its current format, as well as rejecting any calls for mandatory quotas for women as a tool to achieve gender equality. This resolution included these two items, which was the reason behind my abstention.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, last month the number of women elected to our national Parliament at Westminster rose by a third. Female MPs now represent 29% of the House of Commons. This signals positive change and embodies the improvements that we have seen in recent years toward encouraging more women into civic and political life. This report does place focus on many important drivers for change: tackling domestic abuse and other violence against women, focusing on personal development and essential skills to empower women of their accord, and the need to support and work/time balance for young mothers. I fully support efforts to make next year, 2016, the European Year on Combatting Violence against Women – and we need a more proactive approach from the Commission to realise this.
