Neither I nor my Party believes that the EU should have the right to intrude on what are Member States’ responsibilities to uphold equality how they see fit. We fully oppose these efforts to promote singular strategies aimed at women only, and in equal measure we oppose the attempts to use the issue of women’s rights as a means of supporting abortion on demand.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the Union's Strategy for Gender Equality after 2015.  This report is a little-hidden mix of amalgams, stereotypes and Europeanist ideology. It scatters some sensible and acceptable points in order to make the whole thing credible. We must not be fooled by the communitarian vision he proposes. This report is a step away from reason, both in its desire to promote migrants' access to Member States and in promoting gender theory.  Various arguments are worth special attention, so it is unfortunate that they have been drowned in a mass of inconsistency. The subject of discrimination against women in Europe must be considered and not swept away as quickly by the majority in place.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men post-2015 because I believe that the foundation of a healthy society is the traditional family. It is unacceptable to me that the Commission should be called upon to oblige and amend legislation to the service of the LGBT community, which is a minority. Against the background of the demographic catastrophe in Bulgaria and in Europe as a whole, where the population is ageing, I believe that a major theme should be support for women who have children, not so much their so-called inclusion in the labour market. We need a strong and healthy family with a model of more than 2 children.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against, because in many of its points it focuses on cases of equal treatment of ROMA, other immigrants, homosexuals and abortions. The movement's position is contrary to all this.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making.  Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party, and for this reason I could not support her in the final vote.  At the same time, I would like to state that promoting equal opportunities for women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions. I regret that this position has not been sufficiently presented in the report. I am convinced that the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool and that the submission of reports that go beyond the subject of the report, rape the boundaries and send messages that do not fit the subject must stop.  I am convinced that respect for member states' competences, particularly on ethical issues and on issues related to family policy, is key to protecting equality.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 Equal opportunities is a challenge, it is an objective, it is a mission for all Members of the European Parliament. It's not the heritage of any political party. The Strategy we had put forward in 2010-2015 is now over and a new strategy is needed to end discrimination and, above all, to address the main challenges of equality in the workplace. You have to work to break stereotypes and educate on equality, which means co-educate. It means educating in values and betting on inclusive education. We must also bet on ending gender-based violence. It is the greatest attack on human rights, and a direct consequence of inequality.  On the other hand, poverty remains mostly feminine, and the most vulnerable sectors, such as single women, immigrants, disabled women, older women, ethnic minorities and LGBT groups are also the hardest hit. We are all united in this struggle and, therefore, it is necessary for the left to separate the issue of abortion, since that is where we are divided, and let us work on what unies us.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as it calls on the Commission to develop a new specific strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe, which aim to create equal opportunities, with a view to putting an end to all forms of discrimination to which women are exposed in the labour market. The new strategy must strengthen the rights of different groups of women, including women with disabilities, migrant and ethnic minority women, Roma women, older women, single mothers and LGBT. It must make society more aware of the problem of violence against women, as well as prevention, access to justice and support for victims. The resolution also calls on the Commission to recognise the importance of sexual and reproductive rights, to work towards the implementation of sex education programmes in schools and to ensure advice and contraception opportunities for young people. It calls for accessible services in the areas of sexual and reproductive health, termination of pregnancy and safe and legal contraception. Finally, it urges the European Commission to include sexual and reproductive health and rights in its next EU health strategy, in order to ensure gender equality.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I support the EU's long-term and forward-looking gender equality strategy, and I voted in favour of the resolution in the final vote. However, I voted against certain elements relating, for example, to quotas and parental insurance, because I do not believe that the EUROPEAN Union should decide in these areas. I supported other partial votes, for example with regard to the right to abortion, but I would like to emphasise that this is not an area of legislation at European level.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Progress in the EU has been slow and much is still to be done in the coming years. The EU is preparing a new strategy for gender equality post-2015. Gender equality is one of the founding principles of the European Union. The Gender Equality Strategy 2014-2015 contains a set of commitments that are assessed each year in a Report by the European Commission. The European Union needs a new strategy with effective measures to deal with the subject and suggest ways to continue the evaluation. At the same time, new and lasting forms are needed, with binding and non-binding measures, taking into account the various forms of discrimination that women face. It is resofound that the European Parliament has already voted in favour of a gender balance on boards and the fight against violence against women.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because, while I understand that strict wage equality is established between men and women, this text does not take into account mutual and respective complementarities, and it is part of an ideological framework of 'protection of minorities'.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses in a critical yet light, some of the policies followed in the last five years on gender equality in the EU. It considers that, at EU level, some objectives have remained to be achieved on the road to genuine gender equality, covering all aspects of life, the right to integrity and a dignified life. Refers to exhausted economic models based on a sexual division of obsolete labour; violence against women; gender pay inequalities; household tasks, care for children and the elderly, mostly in charge of women; the failure of policies aimed at a work-life balance. It reaffirms that the face of poverty is fundamentally feminine and has been aggravated by the economic crisis, precarious, part-time jobs, low wages and pensions, the difficulty of access to basic social and health services and the extinction of jobs, particularly in the public sector, among other important aspects. We voted in favour, although there are some aspects in the report from which we have distanced ourselves. This is the case with quotas, the paragraph which legitimises the European Semester and the concept of 'forced prostitution'.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ 2012 The year 2015 is a very important year in assessing the progress made by the European Union in the field of gender equality. In fact, despite the existence of various initiatives, there is still an unequal approach and conditions of employment on grounds of gender discrimination. The present report confirms the findings of previous years, in particular the fact that ensuring gender equality in all areas of life is progressing very slowly. The strategies adopted by the European Union to improve the situation are ineffective and inefficient. It is for this very reason that we need to focus in the coming years on adopting very effective and precisely targeted legislation that will eliminate all forms of discrimination against women, but also against men.  The citizens of the Member States of the European Union do not deserve to make endless excuses for the economic and financial crisis and the consolidation of the budget. We must be aware that achieving gender equality is also of great importance for the economy and the economy, and is important for sustainable and inclusive growth. In future, we must focus on taking such measures and adopting legislation that actively combats violence against women, creates a level playing field for both men and women in the labour market, enables women to hold more leadership and management positions in the business sector and more involve women in decision-making processes.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The title is misleading given the contents of the text. I condemn without ifs and buts all kinds of violence, especially against women. I am voting against the text because it has been exploited by inserting a debate on ethical issues that are unrelated to the object in question.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it goes far beyond the remit of the FEMM Committee and encroaches upon national competences. This detracts from a number of serious issues concerning women's rights, such as trafficking, sexual exploitation and violence against women.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the adoption of a new separate strategy on gender equality and women’s rights in the EU.  It is especially important to prioritise the fight against violence against women.  New forms of violence against women, such as those found in social media, are also an urgent matter that needs to be dealt with. We should be very active on combating violence, tackling pay gaps, and on ensuring that women can reach equal positions in the working world.  I especially support the new approaches for reconciliation of private and professional life introduced in the report, to be dealt with a strong focus on care and working time arrangements. I thank the rapporteur and the shadow for the great job done and I am sure that it will have very positive outcomes in our societies of the future.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool. In order to protect equality, respect for member states' competences is key, particularly on ethical issues and family policy issues. I cannot support a report that does, in its title, but does not serve a realistic equal opportunity in its content.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making.  Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party, and for this reason I could not support her in the final vote. At the same time, I would like to state that promoting equal opportunities for women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions. I regret that this position has not been sufficiently presented in the report.  I am convinced that the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool and that the submission of reports that go beyond the subject of the report, rape the boundaries and send messages that do not fit the subject must stop. I am convinced that respect for member states' competences, particularly on ethical issues and on issues related to family policy, is key to protecting equality. I cannot support a report with its title, but with its content, which is not in the interest of realistic equal opportunities.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has once again had to vote on a report containing a number of positive ideas with a view to achieving equality between men and women, which is irreparably tainted, however, by the inclusion of devious and unacceptable provisions within it. In this report, too, the European Parliament shows that it has forgotten the value and sense of the family. In a Europe that wants to be the standard-bearer of universal rights, the only forgotten rights are those of children. I was therefore obliged to vote against this report, not in substance, because we strongly reaffirm the right of a child to grow up in the family with a father and a mother, but also from a technical point of view, because family law falls within the competence of the individual Member States and not those of the European Parliament.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. – The path to gender equality is a priority that Europe cannot afford to underestimate: the path to full equality is equality of rights and opportunities between women and men is still going too slowly and I expect a breakthrough from this European legislature. Combating social discrimination, fighting abuse and violence harshly, overcoming gender pay and opportunity gaps, encouraging new and more inclusive labour policies are just some of the immediate actions that Europe must focus on in order to propose a higher level of protection and rights.  There can be no equality unless we decide to invest in education for respect and the recognition of equal dignity of all the resources that our society has, regardless of gender, religion, culture and the sexual choices of the individual. Capitalising on human value and restoring freedom, consideration and respect for those who do not always have freedom today: I am convinced that this objective can lead to the achievement of Europe's main growth objectives.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the Noichl report on the EU's strategy for equality between women and men for the period after 2015, because, in the form agreed, it clearly leaves the EU's sphere of competence in over 50 per cent of the points and violates the principle of subsidiarity. I was at the forefront of the wording of the alternative resolution, which was narrowly rejected in Amendment No 1.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental rights of the European Union. There is still a great deal of catching up to do in this area. For example, women earn on average 16.4% less per hour worked than men. In the Czech Republic, Austria, Estonia and Germany, the difference is over 20%. We therefore need a new gender equality strategy and I strongly support gender equality. However, the new strategy goes beyond the EU's competences. Family or health issues are still the responsibility of the Member States. I think it is wrong that the left and the Greens are now calling for a fundamental right to abortion. The protection of life must be paramount here. Gender equality covers many areas of life, but the legal framework for abortion is clearly a matter for national parliaments. Instead, we should focus at European level, for example, on combating trafficking in women and forced prostitution.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I wholeheartedly support the Noichl report, because I believe the EU should be an engine to secure gender equality across Europe. Because of inequality, women still earn less money than men for the same job. They are victims of discrimination in their pensions and on the labour markets, and face a higher risk of poverty and social exclusion. Women also account for 80% of human trafficking victims.  These are issues on which the EU can make the difference, and it boggles the mind that anti-gender radical traditionalist movements have been virulently attacking the report, pushing for a watered-down vision for gender equality instead. I applaud the fact that MEPs refused to cave in to the pressure and backed clear and ambitious measures put forward by this report, calling for equality for all.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. – The British Conservative delegation is pleased to support an alternative resolution to the Noichl report. The alternative resolution focused on a number of concerns that prohibit women from full equality: equal pay, discrimination in the workplace, violence against women and media portrayal of girls and women.  We are deeply concerned about the direction and content of the Noichl report and are unable to support many aspects including: a call for the Commission to create an EU model of sex education, claims that women have careers without ʽsignificant progressionʼ, demands on Member States to collect and analyse gender-related data when the EU has a dedicated Gender Agency.  Whilst some of our concerns are about content, others relate to more profound and ideological reasons based on what we think the EU should and should not be doing. The British Conservative delegation is opposed to more EU legislation in the area of social policy. We do not believe that the EU as an institution should accede to international conventions – this is for national governments to do. We believe that matters concerning adoption, criteria for asylum and official information on identity documents are for national governments to legislate on, not the EU.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report adopted in the FEMM committee. This report, and as the European Commission's strategy on women's rights and gender equality expires this year, a call is being made to adopt a new independent equality strategy for women's rights and gender equality, aimed at creating equal opportunities and ending all forms of discrimination. It is a comprehensive report calling for concrete action and proposing a number of measures in areas where significant progress in equality is needed.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men in the post-2015 period because it violates the law of the Treaties and the fundamental principle of subsidiarity contained there in them. The European Union does not and should not have competence in the field of family law.  In addition, this document is aggressive towards unborn children. It contains provisions calling on the European Commission to actively disseminate abortion not only among EU Member States. I do not agree with the model of reproductive rights promoted by this report, which promotes the demand for access to abortion as one of human rights and a reflection of women's freedom and equality. I therefore supported the First Amendment, which was an alternative resolution highlighting the principle of subsidiarity. This amendment, in contrast to the spread of the 'gender' ideology, called for the modernisation and improvement of the conditions of pregnant women and working mothers in order to make it easier for them to reconcile work and private life. I regret that the European Parliament adopted Mrs Noichl's report instead of the balanced proposal put forward by the alternative resolution.

name: Sylvie Goulard (ALDE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday lunchtime, 9 June, the European Parliament voted in plenary on Mrs Noichl's report on the European Union's strategy for gender equality after 2015.  A few clarifications in order to dispel any misunderstandings: this is a report that is not binding. The European Parliament does not adopt a directive or regulation with legal effects. It gives indications;  These matters remain the responsibility of the Member States. Therefore, the scope should not be exaggerated. It is because it is somehow "off topic" that I abstained;    However, gender equality is a major issue: equal pay, access to education, non-violence, the fight against discrimination and poverty. On these points, I share many of the provisions of the report, without acknowledging myself in its entirety.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my Labour Party colleagues voted in favour of this report because I believe the EU can and should be the means of securing gender equality across Europe. Gender equality and women’s rights were founding principles of the EU and on many issues women still look towards Europe for the vindication of their rights.  Because of inequality, women still earn less money than men for the same job; they can also face discrimination in relation to their pensions and often face a higher risk of poverty than men.  This is a very important and timely report. Progress on gender equality has been slowing in recent years and this report and the direction it gives our outlook in other areas is vital. We should look at all EU policies with female-tinted lenses; we should assess how EU policies will impact on women and what we can do better.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 9 June, I abstained on the vote on the text on the European Union's strategy for equality between women and men after 2015.  Indeed, although I strongly support the need to develop female entrepreneurship, the reduction of the wage gap and the fight against violence against women, at home or in business, certain objectives were cartoonish or even unrealistic and certain provisions undermined the values of the family, which nevertheless fall under the principle of subsidiarity. On this point, I would like to point out that the EPP Group had tabled an alternative resolution that was in line with our moral and ethical values and which respected the principle of subsidiarity. Unfortunately, it was rejected.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. There is a reality that we cannot deny: that of women who always earn less than men for the same job, are discriminated against in the labour market and at the time of their retirement, are more at risk of poverty and social exclusion, or who do not have access to health services in the event of an abortion. In the face of this reality, Europe can and must react, being ambitious to finally advance their rights.  That is why I voted in favour of this report, which specifically calls for a directive to combat violence against women, the lasting reduction of gender disparities in wages and pensions, the reduction of stereotypes through targeted education, and ad hoc actions for all women in the world who are subject to different discriminations , and measures to balance private and professional life.  Far from questioning the principles of subsidiarity, this non-legislative resolution proposes concrete actions to end discrimination. It is therefore a question of implementing the treaties at the heart of which is equality between women and men.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on an EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015, because the European Union has still not achieved true gender equality, with european countries collecting only 54 points out of 100 on average, according to an index compiled by the European Institute for Gender Equality. We must strive to prevent discrimination against both women and men on the grounds of their ethnicity, sexual orientation, religious opinion, disability, class, nationality or age. Until these problems of equal rights are resolved, the European Union will not be able to fully achieve its economic and social objectives, and gender equality must be understood as a strategically important global challenge that we need to address.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making. Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party, and for this reason I was unable to support her in the final vote as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation. At the same time, support for equal opportunities between women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions. I regret that these positions have not been sufficiently presented in the report.  I am convinced that the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool and that the submission of reports that go beyond the subject of the report, rape the boundaries and send messages that do not fit the subject must stop. I am convinced that respect for member states' competences, particularly on ethical issues and family policy issues, is key to protecting equality. I cannot support a report with its title, yes, but not a realistic equal opportunity with its content, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I abstained in the final vote this report contained very many good points – such as the proposal to address the needs of women with disabilities in order to ensure their increased participation in the labour market, and the call to the Commission to propose a legal act to strengthen the approach by Member States on the prevention and suppression of all forms of gender violence, with a zero tolerance approach.  I fully support the call to designate 2016 as the European Year for combating violence against women and girls as well as the call on all on Member States to combat precarious work and the need to counter the feminisation of poverty driven by women employed in non-standard contracts such as involuntary part-time work, zero-hour contracts etc.  However I could not support Recital S which states that access to reproductive rights should never be restricted. Virtually all Member States have some restrictions and anyway it’s a matter for Member States to decide, not the EU. Recital U demonstrates an uninformed and narrow-minded perspective on single-sex schools and couldn’t be supported and the calls for gender data on everything from climate change to energy have no proven added value.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Today, a "EU strategy for equality between women and men for the period after 2015" was voted on. There is much sensible and also unreasonable in this report. But both should be left to the electorate in the Member States. For this reason alone, the decision was simple for me: I voted against this report. Anything else would have been a flagrant violation of the principle of subsidiarity laid down in the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. We Moderates have voted in favour of the main proposals in the vote on gender equality. We are in favour of a gender equality strategy at EU level on those issues where Europe decides jointly. It is at European level that we can best combat, among other things, trafficking. On the other hand, we are opposed to the left-wing rhetoric and superficial economic theories contained in the report, which directly contradict their purpose. It is spender policies and deficits that have put an end to the money that welfare needs and that have undermined jobs and employment. In many cases, the report lacks respect for the Member States and the self-determination of individuals, which risks eroding Swedish legislation in areas such as family policy, LGBTQ rights and abortion rights. These issues belong in the Member States, and we Moderates do not want to bring them up at EU level, which would – as with all other EU issues – force compromises with other countries and values other than those that characterise current Swedish legislation.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making. Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party and I was therefore unable to support it in the final vote. At the same time, I would like to state that promoting equal opportunities for women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we see things differently, because we have different cultural and social traditions. The principle of subsidiarity therefore gives us the opportunity to express these different positions. I regret that this position has not been sufficiently displayed in the report.  I am convinced that the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool. The submission of reports that go beyond the subject matter of the report, rape the boundaries and convey messages that do not fit the subject must end. I am convinced that respect for member states' competences is key to protecting equality, particularly on ethical issues and on issues related to family policy. I cannot support a report with its title, but with its content, which is not in the interest of realistic equal opportunities.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this very important and timely report. It sets out the need for a concrete plan of action on gender equality over the coming years. Progress on gender equality has been slowing down in recent years and there is clearly scope for a renewed equality agenda. Recent research conducted by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights found that a third of women have experienced physical or sexual violence, so it is really vital that we have in place the laws, financial resources and political will to tackle that. Gender inequality pervades almost every part of society, so we must continue to respond in a holistic way and take account of multiple forms of discrimination. Maria Noichl’s report is very strong in this respect.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Once again, the real debate on equal treatment between women and men has been phagocytized by groups on the left of the chessboard who, instead of focusing on the factors of inequality and promoting initiatives such as combating stereotypes and promoting female entrepreneurship, have been working to turn back on supporters and opponents of the LDC. It is regrettable to note that in every debate on such central subjects for which there is much to be said, these groups upset the balances in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity and above all try to impose an ideology far from being shared by all. Through these systematic manoeuvres, I see above all that they succeed in making citizens more tense and playing into the hands of those who denounce the omnipresence of the European Union in their choice of life.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is wide-ranging in its scope and highlights the fact that we have some way to go before achieving gender equality in the EU. The distance to be travelled is perhaps evidenced by the large number of Members voting against. I voted in favour and am pleased that the majority of this House did likewise.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report adopted in the FEMM committee. This report, and as the European Commission's strategy on women's rights and gender equality expires this year, a call is being made to adopt a new independent equality strategy for women's rights and gender equality, aimed at creating equal opportunities and ending all forms of discrimination. It is a comprehensive report calling for concrete action and proposing a number of measures in areas where significant progress in equality is needed.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the EU Strategy for Equality between Women and Men after 2015, as I have been advocating respect for human rights, equality and tolerance, the right to diversity, equal rights of all minorities, the right to free expression, and to combat any form of discrimination and violence from the beginning and all my political activity.  Gender equality is a fundamental value of the EU. Equality and equal right to act should be achieved in all segments of the social and economic environment, equally in education, health, culture, employment, political action, the exercise of social rights, etc.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The Noichl report illustrates the societal drift that the Union encourages. Under the guise of gender equality, it promotes LGBTI propaganda, the use of LDC and GPA. This report uses the excuse to fight gender equality as a means of promoting the rights of minorities and immigrants. I stand up for the values of the traditional family. Indeed, it is impossible for me, as with a majority of French people, to imagine this new conception of the family proposed by the Noichl report. This completely mistaken view of the family, as well as the LGBTI propaganda that the Noichl report defends, is unbearable to me and it is for these reasons that my vote on the Noichl report was negative.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on my colleague Maria Noichl's report on gender equality after 2015. Although equality between women and men can only be encouraged, this report took a maximalist and ideological turn that made it unrealistic and, above all, impinged on the principle of subsidiarity, which is nevertheless the basis for family policy.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the European Union's strategy for equality between women and men after 2015 because, although the fight for gender equality is a priority for the European Union, it should not be used as an excuse to contravene the principle of subsidiarity by imposing measures on abortion, as this subject should not be in this debate. The European Union must focus on the challenges within its competences, such as ensuring equal pay for men and women or combating all forms of discrimination.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given the amount of work that still needs to be done to achieve gender equality between women and men. I did not however support proposals including a gender equality criteria in public procurements and in EU-funded research projects as I believe this could have a negative effect on small companies or small research teams. It is indeed likely that they would fail to meet this criteria, unlike big universities or companies that have more means and resources to meet such targets.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I repeat that gender equality is an important concern, which I am also committed to. However, I reject an undifferentiated gender strategy that does not take into account regional and national specificities or focuses on 'side shows'. Achieving real equality cannot be achieved by, for example, promoting early childhood sexualisation, changing language or setting quotas. Genuine equality is created when there are equal opportunities and recognition for equal performance, for example, when women earn the same amount as men for the same performance. Unfortunately, this is not the case and is not supported by this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my group in these recommendations. Gender equality is a fundamental value of the EU, and despite policies and strategies aimed at promoting this, full gender equality is still far from being achieved. Equality between men and women has been central to the EPP Group’s priorities, and the alternative resolution presented by the group is a good, pragmatic framework for us to follow going forward. Violence against women is a pressing issue that must be resolved, and I am strongly in favour of the actions proposed in this resolution.  Regarding education and access to the labour market, this proposal is strong. It is imperative that we strive to develop female entrepreneurship in both urban and rural areas, through advice, training, facilitation of access and reduction of obstacles. Increased participation of women in political and economic decision-making is another aspect of this proposal. Ireland has made good progress in this regard, and I hope that a strong resolution today will advance that progress further.  The EU’s new strategy must emphasise the key role that Member States have to play in the fight for gender equality, and this resolution respects the powers of the Member States, for example in terms of ethical or family law issues.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very much pleased of the outcome of the vote. This report calls for an ambitious EU strategy for women’s rights and gender equality for the next five years and sets out ambitious and concrete proposals. Today women still earn less money than men for the same job. They are victims of discrimination for their pensions, on the labour markets and face a higher risk of poverty and social exclusion. We must do our best to eradicate such discrimination in Europe and beyond. Europe can be the engine to promote women’s rights around the world.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the Noichl report. This is an excessive exaggeration of the gender mainstreaming policy that began decades ago. I am very much in support of equal opportunities, but not of equal outcomes! In addition, under the heading 'Equal opportunities', the Noichl report contains a covert all-round approach to social policy: 35% of the proposals contained do not deal with equality between men and women. 48% of the proposals contained violate the principle of subsidiarity. I had initially voted in favour of a drastically weakened compromise motion by the PPE Group on the grounds of uniform majority voting against the Noichl report, although I did not fully agree. Unfortunately, it did not find a majority in plenary.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I do not agree with everything the report on the EU strategy for gender equality mentions for the period after 2015, I have decided to support it. The primary reason is that the report emphasises the right to make decisions about one's own body and to self-determination, which is a prerequisite for universal equality. I fully agree with this position, because I believe that this should be an inseparable right of every woman. Moreover, I considered it important to call on the Commission to support the Member States in ensuring quality, given geographical conditions for adequate and accessible sexual and reproductive health services, related rights and safe and legal abortion and contraception, as well as universal healthcare. Moreover, the economic factors of "equality" are very striking. The employment rate for women is 63% and if employment is expressed in full-time equivalents, it is 53.5%. Given that the gender pay gap is 16.4% and the pension gap is on average 39%, it is clear that women can only dream of equality from an economic point of view, and I find this unacceptable. I am afraid that the changes will be slow, but I am still glad that the European Parliament is engaged in such a subject.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed when implementing the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making.  Mrs Noichl's report did not sufficiently reflect the values of the People's Party, and for this reason I could not support her in the final vote. At the same time, I would like to state that promoting equal opportunities for women and men remains one of the key priorities of my group. I am delighted to be able to speak with one voice in order to defend our values. It is natural that we are different in our perceptions, because we come from different cultural and social backgrounds, which is why the principle of subsidiarity ensures that we are able to take these different positions. I regret that this position has not been sufficiently presented in the report.  I am convinced that the issue of equality between women and men should not be used as a tool and that the submission of reports that go beyond the subject of the report, rape the boundaries and send messages that do not fit the subject must stop. I am convinced that respect for member states' competences, particularly on ethical issues and on issues related to family policy, is key to protecting equality. I cannot support a report with its title, but with its content, which is not in the interest of realistic equal opportunities.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men in the post-2015 period has raised a number of controversies, including on the principle of subsidiarity. This non-legislative document has, above all, political value in setting the standard and direction of equality policies in Europe. I consider the most important chapters on women in the labour market to aim at reducing the employment gap, the wage and pension gap, which are 11%, 17% and 39% respectively in Europe. As a result, women are poorer than men and more likely to be victims of domestic and sexual violence. Economic independence and equal opportunities for access to the labour market, including high positions, are important demands of this report.  On issues that differentiate positions within the group, I voted in favour of the Maternity Directive, quotas on company boards, the anti-violence directive and the European Observatory on Violence, incentives for paternity and parental leave, easier access to in vitro, quotas on electoral lists, access to health and reproductive rights services, education in this area and incentives for gender research and studies. As in the previous report on this subject, I was against paragraphs on increasing the availability of abortion for social reasons.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Mr President, at today's sitting I voted in favour of the Union's strategy for equality between women and men. The report raises better the issue of women's rights, the discrimination they face in different aspects of life and gender equality as a whole. Instead of a programme focused on former 'equality between women and men', we therefore took a broader role. We live in 2015 in a Europe where one third of women have faced physical or sexual violence in their adult lives, and where women's employment is still more challenging in many places than men and the employment rate as full-time work is just over 50%. The pay gap between women and men is 16.4 per cent and the pension gap is as much as 39 per cent. There is no economic growth or prosperity when half the working-age population is underrepresented in the labour market. The solutions to these problems will help not only women, but also men, for example, in helping to reconcile the work and home life of parents with young children. Finnish women, too, are faced with an outrageous amount of violence that is too rarely addressed. The differences in wages and pensions are almost as bad for us as in many other EU countries. I am also proud that, as a Parliament, we have wanted to take into account single-parent and rainbow families.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that equality between men and women in all areas of life is progressing only slowly. With the adoption of this report, we have called on the Commission to draw up and adopt a new specific strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe, which aim to create equal opportunities, with a view to putting an end to all forms of discrimination to which women are exposed both in the labour market and in all forms of violence against them. I strongly support and believe in the importance of combating violence against women and girls. I call on the European Union to consider accession to the Istanbul Convention. With today's vote, we have called on all Member States to sign and ratify the Convention and through the new strategy to work actively to put an end to violence and injustice against women.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to give a negative opinion to Mrs Noichl's proposal. The report deals with matters that are the responsibility of the individual Member States and I therefore believe that, in principle of subsidiarity, the national level is the most appropriate forum for discussing and legislating. I am a strong supporter of equality between men and women, but some paragraphs in the report refer to sensitive issues, but not directly related to it. We had an alternative text with my colleagues in the PPE, which dealt with these issues from different points of view, but unfortunately this proposal did not receive the support of the majority of this House.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the Noichl report on the Union's strategy for gender equality after 2015. In dealing with issues relating to family policy, ethics, societal issues such as the rights of same-sex couples, this report, which was supposed to present the European Parliament's proposals as part of the 'new post-2015 EU strategy for equality between men and women', actually too much encroached on the competences of the Member States , thus going against the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I chose to reject the Noichl report in favour of the alternative resolution put forward by the EPP Group. The latter proposed a concrete strategy to effectively promote gender equality in the European Union. Thus, the reduction of wage inequalities, the improvement of women's access to positions of responsibility in both the political and corporate worlds, the free access of young girls to the training of their choice, but also the need to strengthen the fight against violence against women, were at the heart of this alternative resolution.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution on gender equality takes stock of the inequalities women face in Europe: wages, work, participation in decision-making processes, whether in business or politics, access to health, culture and education. From this assessment it calls on the European Commission to take concrete action to reduce these differences with clear objectives.  For the time being, it remains essentially to major statements while real progress, for example on maternity leave, remains unresolved. The question of a balance between family and work life is also addressed. Through this text, the European Parliament also calls for better protection against violence against women. It also calls for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women. Finally, he does not forget to recall that women are the first victims of the crisis and that it can result in a "feminization" of poverty favouring the most violent exploitations. I have therefore supported this text, which takes a complete look at the problems facing women in our societies and, above all, calls for concrete progress.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it takes advantage of its laudable objective, which is to ensure equality for men and women, to enshrine the theory of gender to which I am hostile.  It also wants to impose in schools an education of children against prejudice against LGBTI people; In my view, in the case of young children, this issue should be exclusively the responsibility of families. Finally, he wants to "promote medically assisted reproduction" in a far too general way, which leads me to think that he is trying to open it up to singles as well, whereas in France it is reserved for couples. Unfortunately, this report was voted on by a narrow majority. One consolation, however: the FN vote allowed the rejection of an amendment that wanted to create "gender chairs" in universities.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. On the face of it, the aim of this report is to combat violence and discrimination against women. I am in favour of certain aspects (fighting harassment, forced prostitution, unfair dismissal of pregnant women, forced marriages, female genital mutilation, marital rape, etc.), but the Commission takes the opportunity to facilitate the right to asylum, help women from ethnic minorities, extend certain rights to people according to their sexual preferences, etc. It is therefore a communitarian policy.  Moreover, the European Union continues to interfere as it wants to give itself the right to modulate its funding aid according to the respect of these rights which it wants to defend. Interference that interferes even in schools where gender theory will be explained with the intervention of LGBT associations in front of students. The same will for the promotion of medically assisted reproduction and abortion. On the other hand, it contains no reference to certain practices related to Islam (stoning). This document serves as a pretext to promote not women's rights but an ideology.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because with its approval Parliament is asking the European Commission to develop and adopt a new strategy that is more ambitious than the previous one and sets clear targets to end all forms of discrimination faced by women in the labour market, wages, pensions, economic and political decision-making , access to goods and services or work-life balance, and define key priorities such as combating gender-based violence. The defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions, is also prominently included. In addition, a strategy is requested that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women (disabled, elderly, immigrant, minority, LTGB, etc.), and that takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report sets guidelines for a new Equality Strategy 2016-2020, following the failure of the still-current 2010-2015 Strategy, which has failed to address the problems of inequality between women and men in the EU in any of its areas. Although the finally adopted report is particularly uns ambitious in areas such as ambiguous differentiation between forced and legalized prostitution, in the field of reproductive rights and access to safe abortion (leaving it at the discretion of the Member States) or obviating that the root cause of the sharpening of the feminization of poverty has to do with serious cuts in public services , the text approves giving a mandate to the European Commission to develop a specific directive against gender-based violence, to include the gender dimension in all policies and to include gender groups among the objectives of the Strategy. That is why I voted for it. Finally, I would like to express my rejection of the alternative proposal put forward by the People's Party, not only because of its conservatism but also because it tried to tear down the document voted on in the Committee on Women and Gender Equality.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015. Today's high competition in the labour market makes many women, fearing losing their jobs, simply afraid to opt for motherhood. It is therefore extremely important to ensure that they are also extended after the end of the maternity period and to guarantee social protection for women who, by reason of the nature of the employment relationship (service contracts), are not entitled to maternity leave at all. We cannot face an ageing population unless we take action to stimulate demographic development by protecting women's rights.  In the context of educational activities, we need elements of equality policy in education programmes in order to teach young people mutual respect, tolerance and to combat all kinds of prejudices and stereotypes. Social campaigns also play an important role in this regard, highlighting important problems, mobilising action and promoting certain norms, behaviours and values.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the call for states to change their legislation in light of "the changing definition of family with regard to lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender parenting." To do this, calls for quotas for women in businesses, child sex education and many other neo-Marxist recommendations.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the new strategy for equality between women and men and I voted in favour of the own-initiative report because it is time to quit the useless political talks and act! We need to take action and make sure that the right to equal treatment, enshrined in Article 20 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, is being respected.  Unfortunately, even though after the adoption of the Lisbon Treaty, the Charter of Fundamental Rights is binding upon Member States, the reality is that in some areas gender equality is not reached. According to Eurostat, there is still a huge gender wage gap of 20% between women and men. In addition, high-level decision making positions are still mostly occupied by men. Since the previous Commission strategy was too weak, this report will send a strong message to the Commission that there is political will to shift the current direction of EU policy on gender equality.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This year the Women's and Men's Equality Strategy 2010-2015 ends, so it is necessary to assess the progress made and meet the objectives and create a new strategy for the upcoming period. I did not support Mp Marie Noichl's report containing guidance for the new strategy because I do not believe that certain points belong to this report and are sensitive in nature and relate to fundamental human values.  I support equality between men and women, but I do not support planting ideological issues under the issue of equality and that is why I voted against this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The report ratifies the strategy for gender equality and deserves approval. I voted in favour of the document in general. But, as is often the case in the European Parliament, the excellent ideas of supporting motherhood, for women's work are intersmeshed with the struggle for the rights of sexual minorities. In the vote by parties voted against the first part of paragraph 2 (a special roadmap for gays and lesbians), I abstained in the amendment to paragraph 24 (a human being can choose his sex), voted against the adoption of children by gay couples (paragraph 31, vote in parts) and also abstained in part 3 of paragraph 52 (abortions , even if they are carried out under the hygienic conditions of the hospital) and I also abstained in paragraph 60 (sex education in schools). Under the conditions of high rates of infant mortality and population decline in Latvia, these measures will only further deplete the population.  You have to bring more children to light, raise them and give them education. With respect to the woman's great mission.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Insufficient resolution of this issue hinders the universal development of the Union. In order to adopt the EU Strategy for Equality between Women and Men for the post-2015 period, it is therefore essential to analyse and evaluate carefully the measures taken so far. From the right to the integrity of a person and a dignified life, to a better distribution of care for dependants and caregivers, to the full use of gift and qualifications, not all objectives have yet to be achieved within the EU. In the area of gender equality, the European Commission and the Member States must adopt clear and comprehensible rules that will lead to an urgent solution to this problem.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/6/2015, and because this report recognises and takes into account that equality between women and men is a fundamental value of the EU, enshrined in the relevant EU Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution because I believe the EU should actively support and promote strategies that actively strive for gender equality, including an end to the gender pay gap and to discrimination and violence against women.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. Although this report has some positive aspects - the fight against genital mutilation, child marriage, early or forced, forced sterilization, marital rape, protection of pregnant workers, the fight against harassment, etc. - it also has serious negative aspects and goes far beyond the legitimate provisions of the European Union. It encourages immigration and communitarianism by differentiating women's groups; it imposes gender theory by introducing "good practices" of sex education in schools; it encourages medically assisted reproduction "for all", despite the indecent cost to the taxpayer. This report goes so far as to interfere with the private lives of households by proposing to encourage men to participate more in domestic work, a blatant invasion of the privacy of households. All these excesses lead us to vote against this report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the text of the resolution 'on the EU strategy for gender equality, although I have always been an active defender of the principle of equality between men and women as a fundamental cornerstone of the basic principles enshrined in law. The concept of the family, as a place of the relationship between men and women, is a fundamental value to be defended and strengthened. The family must continue to be the most common social unit in a social system. The resolution adopted is not binding on the Member States of the European Union, as the regulation of family law is to be considered the exclusive competence of national governments.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. Although I have always been a staunch supporter of women's rights, with a view to their wider integration into the community's economic and social life, I have decided not to support Mrs Noichl's report. In my opinion, the text of the document is not fully consistent with the aim that it should have pursued, that of providing the European Commission with guidelines for the definition of a strategy for gender equality for the coming years, concrete and forward-looking.  While I agree with the references to the need to strengthen the European Union's efforts in the areas of equal pay for men and women, the fight against gender-based violence and the need to improve the level of participation of women in the decision-making process, I believe that the paragraphs in the text devoted to issues whose competence, as laid down in the Treaties, falls to the Member States, has undermined the reliability of this report. The rapporteur's lack of inclination to dialogue during the drafting of the report has, in my view, helped to undermine its quality.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour despite the rejection of several gue/NGL amendment proposals linked to issues as important as austerity measures and their negative impact on gender equality and equal rights of migrants in the EU, as well as others linked to LGBTI rights. I believe that very important issues have been included, such as an inclusive family definition, which recognises lgbti single parenthood and parenthood, as well as the right to legal and safe abortion, without forgetting the call on the European Commission to include sexual and reproductive rights and health within the EU Health Strategy.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. More than symbolic, Mrs Noichl's resolution presents concrete and clear-key ideas for the implementation of a new Union strategy for gender equality for the period 2015-2020.  If the text voted has no binding value for The Member States under the Community Treaties, it aims to influence national practices in a way that I consider welcome. It prioritizes the fight against violence against women, while taking into account new forms of harassment. It sets itself as a workhorse to combat inequalities between men and women in such crucial areas as the level of wages or pensions. Finally, it promotes new approaches to better balance work and private life (increased number of nursery places, parental leave).  As a socialist, I obviously vote for it!

name: Kostas Mavrides (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The right to equal treatment is a fundamental right recognised in the Treaties of the European Union and it is essential for the further development of its societies. However, for a large part it only exists on paper. Women still continue to experience domestic violence, wage inequality and workplace discrimination. According to a FRA survey published in 2014, the female employment rate is 63%, whereas the gender pay gap stands at 16.4 % for the EU. In addition, women’s participation in the labour market does not always translate into influence and positions of power.  Women make up only 37% of Members of the European Parliament, 15.6% of bank CEOs and 37% of Supreme Court judges. Finally, one in three women have reported some form of physical or sexual abuse since the age of 15. Ms Noichl’s report manages to address and exposes these issues by breaking down survey findings by gender and proposes effective, coherent strategies to do away with all forms of discrimination against women and men. For example, amongst others it calls on the Commission to adopt a strengthened approach to prevent all forms of gender-based violence. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because this report contains a purely gender mainstreaming ideology and does not offer any solutions to actual equality between men and women.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this Report as it included certain elements which are a Member State competence under the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The text calls on the Commission to "develop and adopt a separate new strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe". In concrete terms, the proposals aim to combat gender-based violence, promote equal pay, guarantee sexual and reproductive rights, such as abortion rights or medically assisted reproduction. I defend this text in the face of reactionary forces seeking to undermine it. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Noichl report is a text which, under the guise of equality between men and women, promotes the objectives of a few very militant minorities who for ideological reasons flout the views of the silent majority. While it is true that the specific cases of transsexuals must be taken into account in the best medical and social way, other proposals cannot be accepted by legislation to date. Even if the fight against violence and discrimination against women is a step in the right direction, some proposals are the sum of unseemly amalgamations. This project being an activist, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite being in favour of all initiatives to eradicate violence against women and against gender discrimination at legislative, cultural and political level, I believe that matters which are sensitive and deeply fracturing from a sociological point of view have been introduced into the text and should be dealt with separately. Hence my unfavorable vote.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ While this report contained amendments aimed at ending discrimination based on gender identity and protecting the rights of the LGBTI community, the final version of the report contained unacceptable references to the right to abortion in Member States. I could therefore not support the final version of the report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Gender equality and women's rights are in themselves a political objective, and beyond an important tool for economic growth and social well-being. I am very pleased that the European Parliament has voted for an ambitious strategy to strengthen women's rights and ensure equality between men and women in all areas of socio-economic and political life.  By voting for this strategy, we have contributed to the effectiveness of the post-2015 agenda, because it is only by empowering women to create a better world that we can move forward on all fronts. We have given substance to a noble objective which is a fundamental right enshrined in the treaties of the European Union and which is essential to the development of our society.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I am outraged at the adoption of another own-initiative report that goes beyond the competences of the EU and pushes gender ideology, a woman's right to abortion as a fundamental human right, compulsory sex education and so on. I strongly oppose the suppression of sexual and reproductive rights that are deeply contrary to human dignity. Member States must have exclusive discretion in matters as serious as those which, in view of the various socio-cultural differences, simply cannot be harmonised. Although I support the elimination of discrimination between men and women, this report goes beyond the issue.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls for a new separate strategy on gender equality and women’s rights in the European Union. However, I have voted against the paragraphs calling on Member States to implement measures on abortion, sexual and reproductive rights. The EU has no competences on abortion policy at national level and can therefore not interfere in Member States’ policies in this area, which we should fully respect.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a committed supporter of gender equality, I am pleased to support any motion that can be hoped to speed up this process, which is worryingly slow in all respects.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The Noichl report calls on the Commission to recognize all the excesses related to gender theory and communitarianism, under the guise of combating discrimination and violence against women, among others. Some of the proposals are absurdly angelism, in particular measures for migrants, Roma, ethnic minorities, the imposition of gender theory in schools, the promotion of the LDC, etc. It should be noted that there is no reference to discrimination and violence related to Islam in this motion for a resolution, which is surprising to say the least. The necessary fight against violence and discrimination is not greatly increased by this militant text, which certainly cannot be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Union needs a new strategy that gives greater impetus to the promotion of gender equality. The statistical data show us that we have made considerable progress. However, huge inequalities continue to exist. In full respect of the principle of subsidiarity, I consider it essential to support initiatives and strategies for reconciling work and family life, in particular through a network of school support, tax support and labour flexibility. I also agree that we should focus on the importance of family planning and train through education.  However, I cannot agree with the criterion of equal treatment and gender as a prerequisite for the award of public contracts, nor with the conditioning of our support to developing countries. Once again, strengthening that our relations with third countries must take into account the attaining of gender equality.   I believe that this document addresses controversial issues which concern each Member State in particular, so in the final vote I abstained.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The Noichl report includes laudable objectives, including promoting equal pay for men and women, increasing women's participation, access to employment for pregnant women, etc.  However, other aspects are critical to say the least. The report aims to make the LDC an individual right, resulting in a "right to the child" that I cannot validate. It also includes remarks on the condition of ethnic minorities such as Roma who have little to do with the subject. Considering that this text concerns areas of competence which fall within the full sovereignty of the Member States, and denying the European Union and its institutions the possibility of legislating on societal matters out of respect for the principle of subsidiarity, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs have led calls for an ambitious EU strategy on gender equality; I voted in favour of the Noichl report as it makes a series of relevant recommendations to address shortcomings on key issues like the gender pay gap and the under-representation of women in decision-making.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the strategy for gender equality in the European Union after 2015.  Indeed, although equality between women and men is one of my priorities, this report contains measures which, by their unrealistic nature, ultimately penalise the advancement of women's rights. On the other hand, I voted for the alternative resolution tabled by my political group, which proposes concrete objectives to develop female entrepreneurship and reduce the wage gap between men and women, still by more than 16%. The EPP resolution also calls on the European institutions and Member States to take urgent action against violence against women, whether in the family or in business, and to combat stereotypes that breed inequalities.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Noichl report on the Union's strategy for gender equality after 2015. We must all work for equality between women and men, both in private and professional life, throughout life. There are too many differences in hiring wages and careers that make women poor. The European Union must be the guarantor and engine of the equality of citizens and the representation of women in all spheres of society, in accordance with the European charter of fundamental rights.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report sets important objectives for the EU and the Member States. The risk of taking a step backwards in the protection of women's rights is always lurking: in times of difficulty, such as the economic crisis of recent years, it is the weakest who suffer the most and, unfortunately, this has been the case for women on so many fronts, first and first and first of all in employment. The only way not to lose ground is to continue, incessantly, to walk. This is our role and, more generally, the role of the institutions: to extend rights and strengthen the instruments that guarantee them. There are many actions to be taken: from investing in women's entrepreneurship to spreading more flexible ways of working that allow greater reconciliation between the professional sphere and private life, to strengthening women's rights with regard to their person, their destiny and their bodies. These are actions that not only help women but serve us all to create a better environment, not only fairer but also more prosperous, richer. And it is precisely where some people hesitate or retreat that the EU has a duty to lead, while continuing to raise the bar of rights.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted strongly against this text. I am obviously in support of equality between men and women, but the propensity of the left to want to include in this type of resolution provisions that are irrelevant and which are the responsibility of the national authorities is unbearable. My position is clear, as long as there are provisions (such as the LDC) in the texts on equality between men and women that fall within the national debate.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Noichl report because I found many controversial aspects within it. Firstly, reading the title, one expects to be faced with a certain type of subject which has been my personal political battle for several years, namely the promotion of equality between women and men. None of this. Once again, questions have been put into this subject which have little or nothing to do with it. This is yet another manoeuvre tainting matters which are strictly a matter for the Member States, on which the Union can only intervene when its action is considered more effective than that undertaken at national, regional or local level. For this reason, having noted that this is not the case, I think it would be appropriate for the principle of subsidiarity to be respected.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for the EU strategy for equality between women and men post 2015 report because it will help draw up and adopt a new separate strategy for women’s rights and gender equality in Europe aimed at creating equal opportunities, with a view to ending all forms of discrimination suffered by women in the labour market, with respect to wages, pensions, decision-making, access to goods and services, reconciliation of family and working life, all forms of violence against women and to remove discriminatory structures and practices related to gender.

name: n/a
