text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy as it outlines important guidelines for us to follow in order to address the ongoing problems that women face throughout the Union. Unfortunately, discrimination still exists, abuse still exists and the pay gap still exists. We all need to do more to fight for the eradication of these issues, and the text of this report, while not perfect, helps considerably in showing that we need to move away from the backward mindset which, sadly, so many politicians around Europe still support.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the EU strategy for gender equality after 2015 is not a redundant but necessary document. It can be debated whether the breadth of its scope goes beyond what the EU should say and what it should influence, but the basic and indisputable pillars of gender equality policy are not missing from the report. These include, in particular, the principle of equal pay, namely closing the gender pay gap, closing the pension gap between women and men as a direct result of the wage gap, and adopting appropriate measures to reconcile motherhood and working life, for example in the form of part-time support. Today's reality in a number of countries, including the Czech Republic, clearly demonstrates the need for a report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report deals with gender equality in all walks of life. Equality in particular concerns homosexuals, transgender and intersex people. Another priority is to promote gender mainstreaming. I voted against this report because it only identifies problems, but no solutions and new strategies that could eliminate the problems.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report sets out Parliament's position in preparing a new European Commission strategy on women's rights and gender equality. In particular, the report calls for concrete action on issues such as violence against women, discrimination in the workplace, reconciliation of family life with work life, the role of the media, the place of women in leadership positions, in education, institutions and external relations. In addition to these aspects, the report mentions the importance of sexual and reproductive rights, including abortion or LGBT rights. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. It is clear that real gender equality is progressing slowly both within and outside the EU. The EU must develop effective strategies to ensure gender equality in order to eliminate all forms of discrimination against men and women. The proposal deals with the fight against violence against women, the gender pay gap, the participation of women in more active leadership positions, parental leave, health care, access to fertility treatment and the prevention of trafficking in human beings. All of these are issues that need to be seriously addressed to help women, mothers and daughters, who are often in an unequal position.  I also consider it very important that the EU is serious about its communication with third countries. Thus, the issue of women's rights must be treated as a human right and must always be included among the issues in the neighbourhood policy, development cooperation and the conclusion of trade links and diplomatic relations.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. In favour of the Commission's next five-year gender equality strategy, the European Parliament has shown that it wants progress towards equal rights between men and women to continue. It should be noted, however, that the road ahead is long. Although I welcome the adoption of this strategy, we cannot sleep on our laurels. We have to keep fighting inequality. The objectives of eliminating discrimination in the labour market and defending women's physical integrity and health remain not fully achieved. We need to continue to combat new forms of violence against women. The reconciliation between family and work life remains a utopia for millions of women. Over the next five years we will have to continue to remove barriers and obstacles to achieving real gender equality in Europe.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I do not agree with the distortion of the concept of a traditional family. I am only in favour of a traditional marriage between a man and a woman. The family is a union between one man and one woman. I therefore do not support any other options for consideration or the extension of the concept of family. Family policy is a matter for each Member State. A family in which children are born from a union between a man and a woman is one of the cornerstones of the foundation of that state, and by abandoning the concept of family or narrowing it down to a homogeneous marriage, we destroy those foundations. It is necessary to support and promote member states' efforts to preserve traditional values. The rights of sexual minorities must not be indiscriminately defended and other people's interests and rights are ignored or disregarded. Sexual orientation cannot and must not be a reason to obtain exclusive rights. Equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women must be ensured. It is therefore essential that women and men should have equal opportunities to exercise their freedom of choice in deciding how they want to make a career and reconcile work and family.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality cannot be reduced to the mere recognition of the same rights, but must above all result in the vigorous application of good practices that reduce the discrimination to which women are subjected in everyday life. These disparities are most evident in the workplace, where women continue to earn less than their colleagues. I therefore support Parliament's call for a new directive that reduces the wage gap and encourages women's participation in decision-making processes, including through the introduction of leave measures for both parents. I agree with the ambitious proposals made in the report on equality between men and women and have therefore voted in favour of it. Europe can act as a spokesperson for gender issues, with a new strategy that includes provisions for the prevention and condemnation of all forms of violence against women and the promotion of educational programmes aimed at combating the stereotyped image of women.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report on "equality between women and men after 2015" because, despite some wishful talking about combating violence against women, it promotes EU policy that intensifies the exploitation of women and places new burdens on working families. The increase in women's employment is linked to "flexible forms of work" with hunger wages, in the name of the "combination of work and family life". As a solution to the acute problems, the "equal sharing of care and care tasks" between the sexes is promoted, i.e. the responsibility for the care of dependent members of the State, which has the obligation to provide public free services to the couple, is transferred. Also revealing is the call for the implementation of the "Barcelona objectives" which provide for the operation of paid childcare services, with often unskilled staff, abolishing the right to comprehensive free pre-school education for children. Finally, the report calls for "reducing the differences in pensions between men and women" with the well-known downward equalisation of rights. The only way is for women, young couples, the people as a whole to build on their experience by claiming recovery of losses and meeting their modern needs in conflict with the EU and monopolies.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the work done by the rapporteur and the changes in committee, I had to vote negatively, due to the intransigence shown by the house in wanting to discuss the issue of LGBT parenthood.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite pressures which, I admit, surprised me, and virulent attacks, the European Parliament has taken a big step forward in trying to achieve real equality for all citizens, regardless of gender. I believe that, in the end, reason has prevailed, and the report that I voted for comes with both ambitious objectives and concrete proposals for immediate action. Personally, however, I cannot help but rebel at the thought that such a report, which only normalizes an aberrant situation for our times, has become the target of groups or politicians with Attitudes of the Middle Ages. I think it is unacceptable, in Europe and anywhere in the world, for a woman to have a lower salary than a man for the same work in 2015, to be a victim of discrimination and to be subject to senseless risks, which can expose her to major social dangers, such as poverty or exclusion!

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is unfortunate that a report on the EU Strategy for equality between women and men pretending to bring light to the empowerment of genders, finishes proposing actions which are out of scope, directly violating the principle of subsidiarity on issues related to the family, health and education.  It is unacceptable that the report aims at providing political legitimation for the EU to make access to abortion and population control the political priority of the international development policy after 2015, in clear contradiction to the ruling of the ECJ in the case of Brüstle v Greenpeace, in which it was unanimously stated that ‘life begins after conception’ and against the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 3, which says that ‘Everyone has the right to life, liberty and security of person’, including the unborn. This is also recognised in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and other international human rights instruments. There exists no right to abortion under international law, either by way of treaty obligation or under customary international law and no United Nations treaty can accurately be cited as recognising a right to abortion. Therefore I support the alternative resolution tabled on behalf of the EPP group.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the adoption of an alternative EPP resolution to this report, but the alternative resolution did not get the necessary majority of MPs and therefore I ultimately voted against the Noichl report because unfortunately it failed to be fixed.  The Noichl report contains a number of highly controversial sections concerning sexual and reproductive rights that call for abortion as a human right, calls for the legalization of LGBT marriage and the promotion of LGBT road maps at EU level. In the area of development aid, it calls for universal access to sexual and reproductive rights including access to abortion, as 80% of women in Africa engage in agriculture place particular emphasis on integrating a 'gender perspective' into all elements of food safety programmes, promote gender ideology and gender perspective in every respect, and calls on the Commission to develop models of best practices for sex education.  The Noichl report is unacceptable to me, because it does not promote equality between men and women, but is an expression of gender ideology that aims to change the fundamental values that Europe inherits and that are written into our hearts as people.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report proposed by Maria Noichl contains some good elements because it is true that there is still much progress to be made on such important and concrete issues as wages, work-life balance or access to employment for pregnant women.  Nevertheless, it is totally unacceptable on many other points. First of all, it does not respect the principle of subsidiarity and blithely encroaches on the prerogatives of Member States and even third states. Thus, policies on abortion and contraception or sex education are not within the competence of the European Union and therefore have nothing to do in this report.  The text also mixes considerations on ethnic minorities such as the Roma and makes the LDC an individual right, thus creating a right to the child that I cannot validate. Overall, it presents a very materialistic view of the issue, aimed at making women employees as hard-as-scor in men. That is why I am resolutely against this report.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Today we had a vote on a report prepared by MEP Maria Noichl on the European Union Strategy for Equality between Women and Men after 2015. I voted against this report because I believe first and for all that the report contains a number of elements that do not in any way help women affirm their important role and rights in all segments of society.  I regret, first of all, that we are unable to reach an agreement or consensus in the European Parliament on such an important topic. When it comes to equality between women and men, we should not have ideological discussions but continue to act constructively on the real improvement of women's positions and rights. Given that this is an evident attempt to grossly breach the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, I believe that in the context of the creation of better legislation, the European Parliament should step up its support for national parliaments in controlling this principle, so that the adoption of rules at European level is of genuine value added to legislative activities at national level.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that Parliament today approved this report, prepared by the Member of the Social Democratic Faction, Maria Noichl. I am particularly pleased with this in view of the great pressures of some strongly conservative politicians, for which gender equality is still an indigestible part. The report contains a number of concrete proposals in favour of full equality of women, whether it concerns their financial income, pensions, stereotypes in education, the right to abortion and, last but not least, measures to harmonise professional and personal life. I consider it essential to call on the Commission to present as soon as possible a proposal for a directive to combat violence against women. However, I consider the report approved today only to be the first step to be taken by the European Commission with a new comprehensive strategy in this area. However, I believe that the European Parliament, which in May strongly called on the European Commission to unblock the legislative proposal on maternity leave, has sent a sufficiently clear signal that it sees the equalisation of women in society as an important priority and will continue to engage intensively in this regard.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report (in any case it is an own-initiative report with no legal value for the Member States), not because it is against equality between men and women, which I certainly support, but because I found the report unclear and tramples on the value and meaning of the traditional family. In addition, the report goes against the principle of subsidiarity, since the issues dealt with in family law are a matter for the Member States and therefore the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As part of the 20th anniversary of the adoption of the Beijing Agenda goals and the deadline for the Millennium Development Goals, progress on gender equality will be reassessed around the world. In this context, the European Union has published a new strategy for gender equality after 2015.  During this plenary session, MEPs adopted the Commission's proposal. I voted against this report because I believe that the text touches on areas under the authority of the Member States. In particular, I would like to point out that the elements relating to sexual and reproductive rights and sex education fall within the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. – (PT) As a supporter of the development of a strategy for gender equality and having therefore supported the alternative resolution tabled by my group, I voted against the strategy put forward by the Socialist rapporteur for not reviewing these proposals put forward by the left.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome the vote in Maria Noichl's report, which calls on the Commission to develop a European strategy for gender equality for the next five years. Women continue to face widespread wage and pension discrimination, and are at greater risk of poverty and social exclusion.  Physical and moral violence against them remains a worrying reality, including on the internet and on social networks. Stereotypes against them persist, especially in the media. In the face of this unambiataking finding, the report calls for a directive to combat violence against women, and calls for an end to discrimination in the labour market, or to tackle stereotypes through education.  The text also calls for measures to better balance private and professional life, including by rethinking parental leave. Finally, it addresses the essential issue of sexual and reproductive health and rights, by offering sex education programmes in schools, while promoting access to safe and legal abortion and the promotion of assisted reproduction in Member States.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. This lunchtime, the European Parliament has made its contribution to the implementation of the European Union's strategy for gender equality for the next five years. Today, in the European Union, one in three women experience physical and/or sexual violence once in her life after the age of 15, only 62.5% of women are in paid work compared to 74.2% of men and only 5% of EU CEOs are women. Gender equality is progressing only very slowly in key areas of society (employment, leadership, financial resources, health, culture, education, etc.) and is still far from being achieved. The European Institute for Gender Equality Index shows this, with the EU averaging only 54 points out of a total of 100. By rejecting the EPP's alternative and very conservative resolution and supporting an ambitious strategy, the European Parliament has clearly positioned itself in favour of an effective and coherent policy to eliminate all forms of gender discrimination.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The economic crisis and the resulting austerity measures have not treated men and women equally. The women left at a disadvantage and this one became accentuated. Many European governments have implemented measures that exacerbate the negative effect of the economic crisis on women. We have seen a regression in the progress made towards gender equality and we must be able to respond sensitively and firmly in an attempt to reverse this trend. We can't keep waiting for things to work out on their own. The economic crisis cannot serve as a pretext to further aggravate social and gender inequalities by subtracting the rights gained. On the contrary, it is the times of crisis that serve as a test for our humanity. The dominant growth model and the sustained political orientations do not serve these purposes. There is always an alternative that does not mean to attack human rights. We're the ones who make the alternatives. Economic growth can be reconciled with high rates of human development and gender equality. Just want it. The adoption of the Noichl Report was a very important step in this direction.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the initiative report on the European Union's strategy for gender equality after 2015. Equality between women and men is a basic value of the European Union and the European Union must integrate it into all its activities.  In voting in favour of this report, I call for action in several areas such as violence against women and gender-based violence, women's participation in decision-making and entrepreneurship, the availability of abortion opportunities and legal and safe contraceptive devices, etc. By this vote, I also hope that women, but also men, will be able to have more flexible forms of work in order to reconcile work and family life at best.  In order to act effectively in these many areas, it is essential that the Commission drafts its strategy in the form of a concrete action plan. The pursuit of equality between women and men is an important objective for me, and I will therefore be very attentive to the debates that will deal with this subject in the future in the European Parliament.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. They spend twice as much time as men doing household chores and taking care of children; their pay is always lower than that of men; their rights, such as abortion, are regularly questioned; and finally, a third of them have already suffered sexual or physical violence... This is the situation of women in the European Union. A progressive text, Maria Noichl's report proposes many solutions to combat inequalities such as the introduction of more flexible forms of work so that men and women can better balance work and family life. He suggests introducing parental leave to be distributed between both parents but with strong incentives for fathers, such as non-transferable parental leave.  The establishment of mandatory quotas for better representation of women in decision-making processes, the guarantee of the availability of abortion and the promotion of medically assisted reproduction are all proposals from this report that can mark the beginning of a new European Union push for women's rights. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report takes a critical approach to gender equality policies within the EU, demonstrating, through the analysis of some indicators, that Member States have evolved towards greater gender equality. In this regard, I believe that the European Parliament, as well as the European institutions and the Governments of the Member States, should play a proactive role in promoting gender equality, but the European institutions should scrupulously respect the principle of subsidiarity as enshrined in the Treaties. To that extent, and because I believe that this own-initiative report introduces matters which should fall within the competence of each Member State, I have decided not to support the adoption of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to make a contribution from the European Parliament to the European Commission's development of a new EU strategy for gender equality after 2015. It is important that efforts and actions are taken to achieve true equality between men and women, and we have always made it a priority. To do this, the Commission's new strategy must take into account the central role of Member States in pursuing this objective.  However, I have chosen to abstain on the final vote of this report as it contains good elements such as the fight against violence against women or support for women's participation in decision-making and entrepreneurship. Nevertheless, certain elements of this text fall within the competence of the Member States and not that of the European Union.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am proud to have voted 'no' to a European resolution with an exclusively and obtusely ideological content: I am convinced that equal dignity is given by difference, not by a type-approval that is passed off as equality. Given that it is not my intention or, I hope, any Member of the European Parliament' s intention to discriminate against anyone, I personally believe that at a time when the economies of most European countries are being put to the test, it would have been wiser to present, as the PPE did, a document that would not safeguard women's rights, but with a particular focus on families. In any case, I welcome the ppe's united position on this very bad text, which, instead of enhancing the uniqueness of women and their irreplaceable role, aims to achieve gender approval by forcibly eradicating natural differences.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to vote against because I consider the measure, as a whole, to be inadequate in relation to the stated purposes.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report adopted in the FEMM committee. This report, and as the European Commission's strategy on women's rights and gender equality expires this year, a call is being made to adopt a new independent equality strategy for women's rights and gender equality, aimed at creating equal opportunities and ending all forms of discrimination. It is a comprehensive report calling for concrete action and proposing a number of measures in areas where significant progress in equality is needed.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This year will be 20 years since the adoption of the so-called Beijing's Platform for Action, which commits states to the stated goals for achieving gender equality. However, when assessing the progress since its adoption, it turns out that gender equality is only happening very slowly. The European Union should therefore adopt a strategy for the next five years. This is also called for by my colleague Noichl's report, which I supported with my vote. It is unacceptable that the gender pay gap in some European Union countries is still up to 30% and women are at greater risk of poverty as a result. A higher proportion of part-time and precarious working hours for women also contributes to this, resulting in lower pensions. The reconciliation of family and working life remains problematic.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report sets guidelines for a new Equality Strategy 2016-2020, following the failure of the still-current 2010-2015 Strategy, which has failed to address the problems of inequality between women and men in the EU in any of its areas. Although the finally adopted report is particularly uns ambitious in areas such as ambiguous differentiation between forced and legalized prostitution, in the field of reproductive rights and access to safe abortion (leaving it at the discretion of the Member States) or obviating that the root cause of the sharpening of the feminization of poverty has to do with serious cuts in public services , the text approves giving a mandate to the European Commission to develop a specific directive against gender-based violence, to include the gender dimension in all policies and to include gender groups among the objectives of the Strategy. That is why I voted for it. Finally, I would like to express my rejection of the alternative proposal put forward by the People's Party, not only because of its conservatism but also because it tried to tear down the document voted on in the Committee on Women and Gender Equality.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the definition of a new European strategy for gender equality in order to combat discrimination based on sex and ensure equal opportunities for men and women. However, I have chosen to vote against the own-initiative report by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality because many controversial points have been included which are not only the exclusive competence of the Member States, but also go beyond the initial objective of the proposal. I am talking, for example, about adopting and recognising parenthood for LGBT couples. In this respect, the text is the result of a radical ideological stance that does not reflect the divisions of European civil society on this issue. I think that by adopting this report, instead of promoting the fight against discrimination, we are 'discriminaing' instead with those who believe in the value of motherhood and the complementarity of men and women.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the report by Mrs Noichl. It is an incisive report on diagnosis: it is true that we cannot remain trapped in exhausted, environmentally unsustainable economic models based on an obsolete sexual division of labour and overcome by the integration of women into the labour market. It is also clear and determined in what can be done differently from now on. It calls for a recent injustice to be corrected immediately by calling on the Commission and the Council to ensure that gender equality is integrated into all 2020 Strategy programmes. Finally, the report is ambitious, as it could not fail to be, as to the role that the European Union must play in the world, in collaboration with Member States, including their competent authorities, in promoting gender equality, within or outside the Union's borders, and on the need to pursue these objectives, both through the concept of gender mainstreaming in all areas , as well as concrete specific measures.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs have led calls for an ambitious EU strategy on gender equality which includes measures to tackle violence against women, the gender pay gap and the underrepresentation of women in public life.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ despite some of its positive proposals, the resolution seeks completely unacceptable interference in areas such as health, family law, education and training and others that fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States, and the principle of subsidiarity must be respected here. At the same time, however, this proposal does not respect at all the most basic human right, namely the right to life or other fundamental human rights, such as the right to consetion, the rights and obligations of parents to raise their children, the right of children to know their parents, etc. At the same time, the proposed strategy for equality between women and men completely neglects the informal and invisible work carried out primarily by women, nor the associated investments in human capital within the family. Moreover, the natural family and natural preferences of both sexes are completely absurdly presented here as undesirable stereotypes. At the same time, the proposal seeks to promote completely inadmissible instruments, such as an even distribution of domestic work between men and women or quotas for political parties. This is an unprecedented interference in the private sphere of citizens and political actors, undermining the EU's most fundamental principles, i.e. personal freedom and democracy. I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the EU Strategy for Equality between Women and Men after 2015, as I think the European Union should be a role model for gender equality and promoting women's rights. I support the development of specific mechanisms to strengthen the rights of various groups of women, including women with disabilities, migrant women and ethnic minority women, Roma women, older women, single mothers and LGBTI members.  I am in favour of a "zero level" tolerance of violence against women, and I believe that Member States should support strengthening society's awareness of the problem of violence against women. Annual campaigns should be promoted to raise awareness of the source of violence and to involve society as a whole, in particular men and boys, in the fight against violence against women.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although gender equality within Europe has seen positive developments in many areas of private and public life over the last decade, I think, and I am also based on my own experience, that ensuring real gender equality in all areas of life is progressing very slowly. This is confirmed by the Gender Equality Index of the European Institute for Gender Equality, which gives the EU average 54 points out of a possible total of 100 points. I supported the current report because I expect the new strategy to bring more concrete measures that could lead to more effective implementation of strategies that eliminate all forms of discrimination against women and men. I believe that the new strategy will contribute to strengthening women's rights and adopting new procedures that will make structural changes more effective for achieving equality between women and men after 2015. I believe that the elimination of gender inequality can only be possible if the strategy becomes part of changes in laws and policies that will create the conditions for systematic measures to implement changes at institutional level.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution and report by Ms Noichl on an EU Strategy for equality between women and men post-2015. It is most certainly the case that gender equality is still far from a reality for too many women (and men) in Europe. The EU can and should encourage Member States to achieve this goal, since it is only by creating an equal society that we will all benefit from it.  This report, however, poses a fundamental problem because of which I am not able to support it. It is in violation with the principle of the right to life and the sanctity of life. It does not reflect those fundamental, Christian values that we should uphold in the European Union and that aim at cherishing life and family.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The post-2015 report on the Strategy for Equality between Women and Men focuses on the fundamental rights of women and men. In 2015, the UN Millennium Development Goals programme was completed, which included, among other things, a goal to promote gender equality. In addition, research is underway by the European Commission on the impact of the EU strategy on gender equality between 2010 and 2015. The latter show that nowadays the division of work between men and women is still based on environmentally unsustainable economic models. This definitely needs to change. Equality between women and men must be included in all programmes, civil initiatives and actions. The rights of the LGBTI community must be respected and wider strategies against discrimination between men and women must be supported. The Commission was invited to include rights on sexual and reproductive health in the next strategy and to start working more actively on reducing the gender gap. The differences in the amount of wages and pensions are still high, which is fixed. In addition, it is necessary to provide sexual education in schools and to provide better access to information for young people in order to reduce gender discrimination. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report on a strategy for equality between women and men after 2015.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Eu ropean Union strategy for equality between women and men because I believe that better defined policy guidelines are needed for policy-making in this area for the period 2015-2020. We need clear objectives, concrete actions and more effective monitoring to make progress in the fight against discrimination in the labour market, in education and in decision-making. According to the data, the goal of equality in the EU is still a long way off: 33% of women have experienced physical and/or psychological violence, while the average wage gap in Europe is 16% and the pension gap is 39%. With this resolution, Parliament therefore stresses that specific actions are needed to strengthen the rights of disabled women, migrants, ethnic minorities, Roma women, older women and single mothers. Particular attention is also paid to ensuring work-life balance, stressing the importance of flexible forms of work which can enable women and men to reconcile work and family life according to their needs.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \u2012 It is essential to create better conditions for women. In the field of work, it is important to develop women's entrepreneurship and to reduce the pay gap between men and women, which amounts to 16.4%. Women's participation in political and economic decision-making should also be increased, but not in a violent administrative form through the introduction of quotas.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Establishing gender equality and promoting women's rights is one of the key development goals of any modern society. One of the main objectives towards achieving such equality is to eradicate discrimination with which women are exposed on the labour market, in terms of wages, pensions, decision-making, reconciliation of family and professional life, and all forms of violence against women.  I would certainly like to point out that I welcome gender equality with all its characteristics, but without violations of the right to life, which begins from conception, and therefore I do not support this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I vote with my EPLP colleagues in favour of this resolution because it calls for a distinctive roadmap for LGBTI rights which is not subsumed into the gender equality strategy, for a binding legislative act on violence against women, and for measures to increase women’s participation in the labour market and improve pay and working conditions. It also supports women’s human rights being included in all EU partnerships and bilateral negotiations and it stresses a number of issues relating to paternity leave, parental leave and flexible working, including 10 days of paternity leave.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ I did not support the proposal. Several points lead to an increase in the powers of the European Union to the detriment of the competences of the Member States. Moreover, many of the points presented will do more harm than any harm to efforts to equate women. One such thing is the call for quotas for women in public and private institutions. If these quotas were introduced, it would particularly harm women who have made their own efforts into the institutions in question, since it would not be possible to distinguish a job obtained on their own merits from a job that a woman has only acquired thanks to compulsory quotas.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015. Women's talents and qualifications must be harnessed. The presence of women on boards and in senior positions is a good thing. I am in favour of gender equality and I agree that we need to close the gender gap. However, I voted against the report because I believe that we respect subsidiarity in this area and that we respect individual Member States and do not interfere in the affairs of others. There are some areas in the report that cross the boundaries of subsidiarity. It's not good, it can be harmful.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted today against the report on the EU strategy for gender equality for the period after 2015, as unfortunately the resulting text does not take into account the PPE amendments, which have been led by efforts not to link the issue of gender equality with issues of reproductive health or the rights of persons with different sexual orientations, in addition, in a way that violates the principle of subsidiarity, which should be applied on these issues.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 For both the European United Left/Northern Green Left and the ACPL, equality between women and men is fundamental. That is why we voted in favour of the text despite all the individual disagreements we had. Our disagreements mainly concern the compulsory introduction of male-female quotas across the labour market. For us, the quota is half-measure, because in this way the real reasons for not participating in managerial posts (which have to do with the patriarchal structures of society, but also the deregulation of the labour market) are not addressed. However, we fully agree with the text on points concerning equal treatment of women in the labour market, tackling violence and gender-based violence, but also measures to be taken with regard to parental leave and improving opportunities for women in terms of their leave and work.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 In many parts of the report, it focuses on cases of equal treatment of ROMA, other immigrants, homosexuals and abortion.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that clear tasks and more effective monitoring are needed to implement the post-2015 gender equality strategy in order to achieve real results in combating discrimination in the labour market, education or decision-making. I agree with the notary of the resolution that it serves as a balanced and future-focused starting point for a new EU strategy for equality between men and women. I consider the request for the Commission to present comprehensive, binding rules on violence against women and girls and on gender-based violence as soon as possible is an important element. The resolution also points to the increasing incidence of poverty among women, which can lead to the spread of trafficking in girls, sexual exploitation and forced prostitution, and member states should therefore develop effective measures. Another important element is the part of the report that requires flexible forms of work for both men and women in order to balance family life and work on demand.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is still a long way to go to achieve effective gender equality and requires a 360-degree approach. I voted in favour of this report, which offers wide-ranging demands, including – but not exclusively – for work, social life and political life. In particular, this report undersoes the notion that women must have control over their sexual and reproductive rights through easy access to contraception and voluntary termination of pregnancy. Gender quotas can also play a role in the exercise of effective gender equality: in particular, on boards, in the world of entrepreneurship and research, they can be a necessary stimulus to overcome the current disparities in wages, real access and career opportunities. I voted against the amendment proposed by the PPE, which proposed a deliberately reduced and reductive approach and which, among other things, completely neglects the issues of quotas, sexual and reproductive rights, contraception and abortion. The 'philosophy' implicit in this amendment shows that, although it is now difficult to find someone who openly professes to be opposed to gender equality, there are still those who put obstacles in the way of achieving real equality.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 When we refer to the concept of equality of opportunity, we must develop a holistic view of it. That is why I believe that we need a new, unified and complex strategy, which the Commission will adopt as soon as possible, on the elimination of all forms of gender discrimination in Europe! Women need a fair and equitable framework that allows them to develop, personally and professionally, without fear and sprawling obstacles of preconceived ideas and wrong and outdated attitudes. This can only be offered if we stand in solidarity around the principles that make us strong, together with civil society and with all Member States.  The Commission must intervene decisively, in a stimulating manner, on the basis of an action plan, together with all its partners, in order to achieve all the objectives necessary to balance the gender ratio in the labour market, to attract as many women as possible to entrepreneurship, but also to unlock the potential of women to hold leadership positions in the areas they consider appropriate.  It is our administrative capacity to mobilise our resources at our disposal to create the necessary actions to eliminate the inequalities that unfortunately persist in society between women and men.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The main objective of The European gender equality policy for the next five years should be to develop effective and coherent strategies to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women and men in their diversity.  Women and men should be sure not to be discriminated against because of their ethnicity, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, religion, social class, nationality or age. There is also a need for a great deal of attention to multiple discrimination.  The repeated objectives for decades have been weakened by the ongoing financial crisis and fiscal consolidation measures in the Member States of the European Union.  Europe's economic, social and employment objectives can only be achieved when gender equality is complete. Gender equality must therefore be understood as a strategic and universal goal. In a context of crisis and the constant threat of regression, this objective must once again be reaffirmed in the European Commission's new strategy for gender equality.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is unfortunate that in the 21st century women are not only facing unequal treatment at work, including lower remuneration,  as well as other forms of discrimination in certain segments of society, but are regrettably facing harassment and violence. I see the report as a way of strengthening focus on this problem and attempt of introducing appropriate measures.  That is why I have decided to vote in favour of the report as such, while I have voted against a number of amendments (on gender quota or the inclusion of a maternity leave). Some amendments do not respect the principle of subsidiarity, some focus on measures which would increase significantly the administrative burden but would hardly achieve a proportionate result, regarding some one cannot have but serious doubts as concerns their relevance. I also found unacceptable those amendments which would affect public procurement rules or had the ambition to introduce legal acts of criminal nature.  As this is an own-initiative report and thus a declaratory political document, I voted in favour of the report regardless of some of the amendments. I subscribe to the political message but remain firm in my opposition to gender quotas and references to maternity leave at European level.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commitment of the Commission and the European Parliament to equality between men and women must be increasingly strong, not only a founding value of our being together in the EU, but also a means of restarting the European economy. I fully share the Commission's intention to continue to promote equality in all EU activities, both internal and external, as required by the Treaty. Much still needs to be done and our efforts must be directed, as indicated in this report, towards achieving economic independence, the elimination of gender-based violence, the defence and promotion of women's rights and gender equality at world level.  The issue of work-life balance must also be addressed, access to the labour market must be improved through the provision of care facilities and the effective introduction of family leave and flexible working formulae, with a particular focus on the participation of men. Pay gaps must also be reduced and eliminated, and we must not ignore the large number of women living in poverty and social exclusion. Europe can be the driving force behind promoting women's rights throughout the world.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. As a woman who has often faced discrimination in her career, I am deeply concerned by attempts to abuse our just struggle for equality by certain groups within femm boards. I find it scandalous and utterly intolerable this constant propagation and open imposition of so-called reproductive rights that perfidously attempts to push through in every resolution concerning equal treatment of women and men.  We must not forget that the wide availability of abortion as a contraceptive, which is at the heart of all the demands of feminists in this home, directly strikes at the freedoms and rights of other living beings, primarily the basic right of unborn children to live. I believe that this home has a sacred duty to protect those who are helpless, and unborn children are by far the most vulnerable group in this sense, because they cannot stand up on their own in defense of their right to life. As a mother, I believe that sex education as a mandatory subject in schools is a gross violation of the right of parents to choose the best and most appropriate way to raise their own child. Child-rearing should by no means be forcibly uniformed, but we should leave it up to parents as the most competent to decide when and how their child is ready to receive and maturely process very important information from the sphere of sex education.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained in the vote on the EU strategy for equality between women and men after 2015. Gender equality is slowly progressing, but there is still a lot of work to be done and the report has not responded to all my concerns. For me, it is a very important area that I believe that gender equality has not yet been fully achieved and which is one of those where progress could be made relatively quickly. It is about women's participation in entrepreneurship and leadership positions. It is unacceptable that there are still huge differences in the involvement of men and women when it comes to the meeting of the highest positions in politics and in large companies, even in entrepreneurship, the relationship goes to the benefit of men. The fact is that Europeans have a higher level of education compared to their male counterparts. Similarly, various studies show that a balance between women and men in leadership positions can lead to an improvement in European competitiveness in international markets. However, if we are to really make progress, we need to make shifts in the education system itself, which will focus on promoting entrepreneurship in general and breaking down the stereotype of male bosses.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In Europe there is still much work to be done to ensure substantial equality of women and men. In the labour market, women still earn less than men on average. They are normally underrepresented at the top of the career ladder and are overrepresented in the so-called less prestigious sectors of economy. In many Member States this imbalance in the labour market can be reproduced through education systems. Furthermore, women’s potential may be limited by unfair distribution of household labour. Traditionalist attitudes still affect the status of women in Europe. Domestic violence is another specific and urgent challenge for EU policies.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report adopted in the FEMM Commission. This report, and as the European Commission's Strategy on Women's Rights and Gender Equality expires this year, calls for a new independent equality strategy for women's rights and gender equality, aimed at creating equal opportunities and ending all forms of discrimination. It is a comprehensive report calling for concrete action and proposing a number of measures in areas where significant progress in equality is needed.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. Defending women in their mission to ensure the delicate balance between their family and professional life is unanimous. It is also vital to commit to defending the rights of the most vulnerable human beings, often in situations of dependency such as children, the elderly or the disabled.  However, on reading the proposals, how can we not be struck by the terrible contradictions that mark this relationship, particularly between its objectives and the means it advocates to achieve it? It should be explained how it is possible to defend women by advocating gender theory and gender indifferentiation, or how it is possible to defend the lives of the most vulnerable beings by defending abortion as an inalienable right. How is it possible to defend the balance of families by destroying its very conception and its natural definition?  The goodwill of all is held hostage by scabrous intellectual theories and above all disconnected from reality. This report will therefore do no favours and will further fuel voters' disgust for the European institutions if they do not free themselves from certain deadly ideologies. I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women is one of the fundamental principles guaranteed and defended by the European Union. In the Treaties, this common value remains an objective to be achieved in specific areas, in particular with regard to education and access to work, women's participation in decision-making, and combating new forms of violence against women, such as cyberbullying. I believe, however, that certain aspects of this Report, such as the recognition and promotion of abortion as a human right and the introduction of sex education programmes by the Member States, are not a competence of the European level, but of the Member States. I believe that the principle of subsidiarity, a fundamental principle of the functioning of the EU, must be taken into account, as areas such as family, education and health covered by this report are areas reserved for the competence of the Member States. I also believe that women's participation in decision-making in economic companies must be a consequence of professional competence, not the result of the imposition of mandatory quotas. I therefore reject the Report on the EU Strategy for Gender Equality post-2015.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report adopted in the FEMM Commission. This report, and as the European Commission's Strategy on Women's Rights and Gender Equality expires this year, calls for a new independent equality strategy for women's rights and gender equality, aimed at creating equal opportunities and ending all forms of discrimination. It is a comprehensive report calling for concrete action and proposing a number of measures in areas where significant progress in equality is needed.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report concerning the EU Strategy for gender equality, as I believe it is high time the Commission adopts a strategy for Women’s Rights and also for Gender Equality in Europe. This report addresses many important issues, from sex discrimination to the gender pay gap, very significant  problems of our societies that we should not pretend do not exist. Unfortunately, gender based inequalities are happening constantly in our continent, therefore the importance of this report is tremendous.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Commission should present as soon as possible a new strategy of equality between women and men that is more ambitious than the previous one, setting clear objectives in terms of employment, wage and pension gap, reconciliation of family and work life, equality in political and economic decision-making , etc., and key priorities such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread violation of human rights in Europe and the rest of the world and which affects all strata of society, or the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights, including easy access to contraceptives and abortion under safe legal and health conditions. A strategy that recognizes the special needs of the most vulnerable groups of women, the disabled, the elderly, immigrants, minorities, LTGB, etc., and takes into account the different types of family that coexist in our society.  The report we have adopted today may not be the best, but it is the result of negotiations and commitments supported by all political groups and consultations with all stakeholders.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report sets guidelines for a new Equality Strategy 2016-2020, following the failure of the still-current 2010-2015 Strategy, which has failed to address the problems of inequality between women and men in the EU in any of its areas. Although the finally adopted report is particularly uns ambitious in areas such as ambiguous differentiation between forced and legalized prostitution, in the field of reproductive rights and access to safe abortion (leaving it at the discretion of the Member States) or obviating that the root cause of the sharpening of the feminization of poverty has to do with serious cuts in public services , the text approves giving a mandate to the European Commission to develop a specific directive against gender-based violence, to include the gender dimension in all policies and to include gender groups among the objectives of the Strategy. That is why I voted for it. Finally, I would like to express my rejection of the alternative proposal put forward by the People's Party, not only because of its conservatism but also because it tried to tear down the document voted on in the Committee on Women and Gender Equality.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in the vote on this report.  The N-VA stands for an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all, as well as an equal opportunities policy tailored to and with attention to all diverse target groups. Violations of this equality, both at work and in private, are not acceptable to us. At the same time, subsidiarity is also important for the N-VA. We have an eye for the different levels of policy and the demarcation of powers. From this point of view, the report is problematic, given that issues such as education and employment are not primarily EU competences. The N-VA delegation is also concerned that some of the measures proposed in the report would lead to even more bureaucracy, with potentially detrimental consequences for the Flemish citizen's portfolio. The Noichl report also strongly supports quotas, an approach that the N-VA does not support. On the other hand, the N-VA delegation fully supports the main elements in the report, such as combating violence against women and girls, modern legislation focusing on single-parent families and LGBT parenting, a human rights-based approach to development cooperation and general access to health care as a fundamental human right.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my EPLP colleagues in favour of this resolution because it calls for a distinctive roadmap for LGBTI rights which is not subsumed into the gender equality strategy, for a binding legislative act on violence against women, and for measures to increase women’s participation in the labour market and improve pay and working conditions. It also supports women’s human rights being included in all EU partnerships and bilateral negotiations and it stresses a number of issues relating to paternity leave, parental leave and flexible working, including 10 days of paternity leave.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'It is shameful that we have yet to produce a report in 2015 on a strategy to promote equality between men and women. What is even more shameful is that the Conservative forces in this House felt it necessary to reduce various rights in their alternative report. The result of the vote is positive as a majority supported the report, although that majority should have been much larger. I was happy to vote for it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report on the European Union's strategy for gender equality. It is a good, fairly comprehensive report, which covers many of the themes that need to be addressed, such as violence against women, access to financial resources, education and health, or equal pay. It also takes up some very interesting aspects proposed by my group on the consequences of austerity policies on women. I also want to denounce the manoeuvres of the right of the Chamber to empty the text of its contents, particularly in the area of reproductive rights and the fight against violence against women. I also denounce the National Front, which has been particularly virulent in the debates on both the right to abortion and the fight against discrimination and harassment of LGBTI people. They have failed and I welcome that. I regret, however, that the paragraph on gender studies and feminist research was rejected, with a few votes. I voted for this report, but I remain convinced that much more needs to be done for women's rights in Europe, for solidarity and for the equality of all.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because this report contains a purely gender mainstreaming ideology and does not offer any solutions to actual equality between men and women.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important report because equal rights is one of the foundations of modern democracy. Our Union will not really be fulfilled until everyone has the same rights. In particular, I welcome the reference to 'LGBTI families', the first step towards a genuine and substantial recognition of the rights of all European citizens.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. – I reject the motion for a resolution by the Bavarian SPD MEP Noichl: the teaching powers of the European Commission for Sex Education in Schools; access to abortion and contraceptives for underage pupils without parental consent; adoption law for transsexuals, and then explicitly without the right of adoption children to know their biological parents; abolition of free elections by means of quotas; Warning that marriage and motherhood are harmful to health, quotas now also in marriage and family ("rules for the balanced division of responsibilities between family and household"); Control of national civil status law by the EU Commission in order to fully recognise individually preferred "gender identity" and to abolish "gender-specific indicators" (man/woman); Abolish the criminal offence of abortion and instead recognize abortion as a human right... The EU will become a huge system of governance of values and norms that are alien to the world. But there is no consensus on Noichl: out of 750 Eligible MEPs, only 341 voted in favour (45.5%), 281 voted against (37.4%) and 81 abstained (10.8%). Because the Christian Democrats were once again completely divided on social-ethical issues, half of the PPE-DE did not stick to its own voting list and voted with abstention, many votes against were missing in the end. The CDU/CSU also rejected this resolution only on the grounds of abortion and again only on the grounds of subsidiarity. Instead, my ECR Group voted almost unanimously against the Noichl report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because this is a landmark step in the continuing struggle for a more just Europe. The report is a strong call to the Commission and Member State governments to take action to fight the root causes of violence against women, to promote education for gender equality and to support initiatives empowering women in culture and media, among many other strong policy demands. I am delighted so many colleagues, both men and women, voted for the resolution, and I look forward to seeing what steps the Commission will take in response to it.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. I support the EU's long-term and forward-looking gender equality strategy, and I voted in favour of the resolution in the final vote. However, I voted against certain elements relating, for example, to quotas and parental insurance, because I do not believe that the EUROPEAN Union should decide in these areas. I also voted against the establishment of professorships for gender studies, because I believe that academia should remain free and that politics should stay away from the autonomy of universities. I supported other partial votes, for example with regard to the right to abortion, but I would like to emphasise that this is not an area of legislation at European level.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The adoption of the report is a blow to the European Union and the values on which it has grown. The provisions interfere with the competences of the Member States and are incompatible with national rules. Fortunately, the adoption of this report does not have any major consequences, as it is a non-legislative report and has no legal force. Instead, it is a victory for ideology over the law and can be used by LGBT communities to push left-wing gender ideology.  The Noichl report is based on the unfounded assumption that abortion is a human right. In addition, it deals with interference with education by implementing a gender perspective, promotes LGBT parenting and undermines the institution of the family. Such provisions of the report threaten the existence of a healthy society because they undermine what is its essence, namely the inalienable dignity of man and the natural differences between man and woman. Instead, they impose the adoption of a gendered vision of society, which actually represents a small part of it, facing the problem of rejection and marginalisation, as a natural state of affairs. That is why we must focus on building a strong and cohesive society, based on the traditional family, which is the best place for human development.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of gender equality needs to be addressed, but this report is outside the scope of the EU Treaties and thus violates the principle of subsidiarity. By approving this text, the European Parliament gives its consent to the European Commission to act in areas in which it has no competence and in which it should not intervene. Therefore, I could not support this report as proposed.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this document, we call on the Commission to develop a comprehensive strategy, with a period of at least five years, that addresses the issues of gender equality and, in particular, women's rights. I therefore voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary for the Commission to present as soon as possible a directive specifically addressing gender disparities in salaries and pensions, promoting the reduction of stereotypes through education and providing for targeted actions for all women suffering from multiple discrimination in Europe. I would like to end by renewing my call on the Commission to introduce measures to reconcile professional and private life.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the report on "equality between women and men after 2015" because, despite some wishful talking about combating violence against women, it promotes EU policy that intensifies the exploitation of women and places new burdens on working families. The increase in women's employment is linked to "flexible forms of work" with hunger wages in the name of the "combination of work and family life". The solution to the acute problems is the "equal sharing of care and care tasks" between the sexes, i.e. the responsibility for the care of dependent members of the State, which has the obligation to provide public free services, to the couple. Also revealing is the call for the implementation of the "Barcelona objectives" which provide for the operation of paid childcare services, with often unskilled staff, abolishing the right to comprehensive free pre-school education for children. Finally, the report calls for "reducing the differences in pensions between men and women" with the well-known downward equalisation of rights. The only way is for women, young couples, the people as a whole to build on their experience by claiming recovery of losses and meeting their modern needs in conflict with the EU and monopolies.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the main objective of European policy in this area should be to develop strong and strong strategies that would later lead to the elimination of various forms of discrimination against women and men. Gender equality in terms of employment, social policy and the economy must be seen as a strategic and universal goal for the future, not just after 2015.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Although this document is legally non-binding, it sends a certain signal of the mindset of the majority of Members present who are trying to model the image of a woman in society instead of focusing on creating the conditions for the free self-realisation of women.  I consider it wrong to overwhelm states with new and new legislation, to deploy quotas and to enter into policies that are, by their very nature, the functioning of the European Union within the competence of the Member States. I was therefore unable to support the report. I believe that if we really want to help girls and women in their education, application and overall status, we can achieve better results through patient and ant work at Member State level.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU Strategy for equality between women and men adopted by the European Parliament in the post-2015 period is extremely damaging and dangerous. First, its very creation is a misunderstanding. It not only interferes with the exclusive competence of the Member States to decide on world-view issues, but also defines social problems in a flawed way, full of ideological superstitions and simplifications. Secondly, it unilaterally and biasedly presents socially harmful phenomena such as abortion and gender ideology, and in a critical and incompatible way relates to the social roles of women and men, the traditional model of the family and the right of every person to live from the moment of conception.  This strategy is an example of the very harmful social engineering and negative impact of the radical voice of homosexual communities and the extreme left on the European political class – a voice that Europe should under no circumstances listen to if it wants to tackle the social and demographic crisis affecting it. I hope that we will be able to sustain this world-view madness together. Of course, I voted against this document.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. It is important that this Strategy for Equality between Men and Women should step down from the role to practice, which has not happened. This report has many truths with which we agree. The reality is that the issues of equality and, in particular, the enforcement of women's rights in 2012 cannot be placed in a dome, as they are deeply related to the great political and economic choices. And it would be good for the two major political groups to remember this strategy when they reach consensus on so many impositions on the Member States. It is that if the EU promotes cuts in public services, such as in child care services, it is the women who suffer the most. One of the biggest problems of the report is not to hold the EU and the troika accountable for the policies that have led to the situation we are in today and, in particular, to the situation of backsliding on women's rights. On the other hand, the report argues that support services for children and the elderly, as well as health services, should be 'affordable services' and not public services, as we advocate. We cannot yet stress our disagreement with the expression 'forced prostitution'. Nevertheless, in view of the overall meaning of the report, we voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam Chairman, I supported the report on the strategy for the protection and enforcement of rights and intellectual property in third countries, as it is necessary to undertake activities that will prevent and reduce the damages of infringements of intellectual property rights. The EU loses €8 billion a year as a result. However, forgeries and infringements of intellectual property rights pose not only a major economic risk and loss, but also a risk to human health and safety. Drugs are the most distorted category of products for the fourth year in a row. That is why it is necessary to work on this strategy and on improving the intellectual property protection system and helping third countries establish a better and more effective system of intellectual property rights.  That's why I supported this report.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, in this Chamber tomorrow it will be decided whether the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Programme goes forward, in the form of an agreement between the EU and the US. It impacts on all citizens across Europe and it has huge negative effects, and my constituents in the North-West have concerns, particularly over the NHS. This particular proposal is in exactly the same vein. It wants to give powers to the Commission to negotiate deals on intellectual property rights, on behalf of companies in the EU, with non-EU countries. Who do you think will benefit from such a deal? The small smart new company in Manchester with a bright idea, or the huge multinational, which works on secret EU working committees – will they be the ones who benefit from this particular proposal? I think Members know the answer to that, and it gives another reason why the UK should be leaving the European Union.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the 'strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries' was negative for a number of reasons. Firstly, this report contains a number of very different aspects which, in my opinion, should be dealt with separately because they present different problems: from counterfeiting, internet piracy and the liability of intermediaries and platforms, to the consideration of developing third countries, as well as to access to medicines and public awareness.  Secondly, I believe that the approach adopted and followed with regard to developing third countries is wrong. On the contrary, these countries would need more loose forms of protection, as several studies have pointed out, so that knowledge and knowledge can move more easily and freely. This would actually promote their emancipation and development. On the contrary, there is a neo-colonial attitude, based solely on a commercial logic of opening up new markets, which seems to favour european countries alone. My vote could therefore only be negative.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the indiscriminate use of intellectual property rights as a trade strategy against third countries. The legitimate protection of copyright and quality control of imported products cannot serve as an excuse for the creation of monopolies by large pharmaceutical and industrial multinationals, or for the expropriation of the knowledge and resources of third States and communities: because they have equal right to health, industrial development and scientific knowledge as those of the peoples of Europe.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The degree of harmonisation of intellectual property protection is comparatively low across the EU and with third countries. The WTO TRIPS Agreement obliges signatory states to adopt rules to guarantee minimum standards and effective enforcement measures. This report now takes into account the conflicting economic interests of intellectual property rights holders and users, as well as the increasing digitalisation that poses new challenges for intellectual property rights protection. Harmonisation, which includes third countries, is useful and desirable for many reasons, in particular to enable new market entry, to promote creativity and innovation and to ensure international competitiveness in this area. In addition, the report respects the specific situation of the pharmaceutical industry and responds to the conflicts between safeguarding competitiveness and economic interests and ensuring access to medicines. I consider international harmonisation in the field of intangible santhem and the creation of a global protection standard to be extremely useful and i therefore welcome the above measures.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The diagnosis made by this report is relevant but the solutions provided are inadequate. It is noted that European competitiveness is based on creativity and innovation and that, therefore, this creativity should be developed by improving the protection of intellectual property rights.  At present, the fight against intellectual property rights violations is very long and costly, especially for SMEs. Counterfeiting, which mainly concerned luxury goods, now affects consumer products.  But the solutions proposed in this report are inadequate. The creation of a European supervisory body would be costly and unnecessary. On the contrary, intergovernmental cooperation should be prioritised and the economic interests of states should be defended, including border controls. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I was astonished that there were no speakers scheduled for this debate, but I did contribute to the catch-the-eye session. A debate with just a handful of MEPs present is not much of a debate. I voted against, partly because this should not be a European Union competence, but also because I believe that the rights of small business must be safeguarded and I feel that this report does not do that. Finally, I am also concerned about the potential for this report to lead to the European Union interfering in third countries in an unacceptable way.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing.
