I voted in favour of this deliberation because in a context of technological development, increasingly globalised and online trade, the European Union needed to develop a new arsenal to combat infringements of intellectual property rights in third countries. This strategy aims, among other things, to help identify countries where there are weaknesses in the protection or respect of these rights.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to revise the strategy for the protection and protection of intellectual property rights in third countries. Intellectual property-based industries in the EU account for about 39% of all economic activity and account for about 26% of all jobs. Nevertheless, since the entry into force of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (1 January 1995), only a small part of the relevant IPR agreements have been concluded, although technological and societal developments have fundamentally changed the nature of IPR. The Communication sets out the need to promote research and innovation, difficulties in access to medicines and environmental changes as important challenges for the present and the future. Any external policy initiative is linked to internal policies and it is therefore important that the EU improves its internal intellectual property rules.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The report rightly points out that intellectual property rights (IPRs) are a major asset for the economies of Member States. But I voted against this text, which aims to cede IPR protection to the Commission: intellectual property is the responsibility of the Member States and the defence of its rights can only be done within the framework of intergovernmental cooperation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The most important element of the report, in my view, concerns the safeguarding of the circulation of generic drugs and stresses the balance between the production of generic drugs and the protection of pharmaceutical research. Indeed, it was necessary to find a balance between safeguarding intellectual property and access to medicines for the more vulnerable. Intellectual property-intensive industries account for about 39% of overall economic activity (some EUR 4.7 trillion per year) and approximately 26% of total employment (56 million jobs).  However, since the Trade-Related Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) Agreement came into force on 1 January 1995, only a limited number of important IPR agreements have been concluded, even as changes in technology and society have transformed the IPR landscape. Communication defines action for research and innovation, the issue of access to medicines and environmental issues as major issues of today and tomorrow. Any foreign policy initiative is inseparable from domestic policy measures, and therefore stresses the need for the Union to think carefully about improving its intellectual property regulation.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries raises good questions but provides the wrong answers. Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are a very important part of the strength of the European economy. Moreover, SMEs are the first victims of counterfeiting. I can only agree with the desire to better combat it by legal means. However, the infringements on the sovereignty of the States induced by this report are simply unacceptable. Indeed, I strongly deplore a desire to strengthen European integration in this area when the fight against counterfeiting is the most effective at national level and in the control of the external and internal borders of the European Union. The creation of one more European body would be costly and unnecessary. There is also a major risk of strengthening the logic of dispute resolution. For all these reasons, I can only vote against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the positions supported in the Moscow report on 'Intellectual property rights in third countries'. I am convinced that the defence of our companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, is primarily concerned with combating the violation of property rights, which are increasingly being respected in these countries and especially in China, damaging our production system.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The main reason is that the report discourages fair world trade, because it demands poor countries in the global South that they must meet the high standards of protection of intellectual property rights, otherwise they are denied market access. It is a trade strategy that only looks at the interests of big business in the EU, and not the need for development and fair trade. Nor has the report made any distinction between developing countries and the least developed countries, which hits the least developed countries hardest in terms of opportunities for favourable and developing trade. Furthermore, the report proposes the creation of a new European body on these issues, which I am opposed to. That is the main reason why I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. During the past decade, there have been significant changes in the area of intellectual property rights: substantial technological changes related to the Internet, increasing importance of emerging economies, challenges in access to medicines, and an increasing level of IPR violations, among others. Following the rejection of ACTA in 2012 by this Parliament, the Commission rectifies and proposes with this strategy a different and up-to-date approach to the protection of IPRs. This report, which I voted in favour of, calls for a more transparent and balanced public debate, with the participation of all stakeholders, and insists on strengthening IPR dialogues with third countries as well as customs cooperation. They highlight the Socialist amendments in favour of a multidimensional response to the problem of access to medicines, facilitating their access in less developed countries and supporting flexibility mechanisms that recognize the right to compulsory licensing.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is a policy for parliament to protect and protect intellectual property rights in third countries. The EU's competitiveness is increasingly dependent and will depend on creativity and innovation in the future. Intellectual property rights contribute to innovation and creativity and protect them as an essential challenge for European competitiveness, and the Union must develop a more ambitious strategy to protect its intellectual property rights through its trading partners in third countries. In this resolution, Parliament welcomed the Commission's efforts to strike a balance between the different interests. However, Parliament criticised the fact that it is not sufficiently clear from the Communication presented by the Commission in 2014 which measures and methods could achieve the results set out in the Communication, in particular what resources will be allocated to this and where they will come from, including in view of the limited resources currently available to support European rightholders exporting their products to or seeking to start up in third country markets.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed report, as I am aware that a higher level of awareness of the protection of intellectual property rights or the prevention of infringements resulting there from this can mean a more competitive European economy. We all face goods, services, visual or digital products that are the subject of intellectual property infringements on a daily basis. It is therefore of the utmost importance that the EU, where 39% of all economic activity and employing around 56 million people in sectors based on intensive use of intellectual property rights, should step up the fight against infringements of intellectual property rights, thus protecting or strengthening its own economy.   I believe that the protection of intellectual property rights and appropriate measures to combat infringements of intellectual property rights can make a significant contribution to the fight against organised crime, money laundering and tax evasion, and thus to the development of a fairer, sustainable and innovation-friendly market. Rapid global digitalisation is increasingly at the forefront of the issue of protecting and enforcing intellectual property rights in the digital world. It goes without saying that it is free to look at the latest film over the Internet or download the entire albums of our favorite artists. We rarely think that there is a lot of hard work behind a particular service, product, film or track that deserves fair pay. But with that kind of thinking, we all lose in the long run.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the protection of intellectual property rights in third countries is essential to defend the interests of our companies in the global market. I therefore believe that the Commission's proposal needs to be improved, especially as regards the protection of geographical indications of origin, which are just as important as other types of intellectual property rights.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Approximately 26% (56 million people) of total employment in the European Union and 39% of total economic activity (€4,700 billion) are generated by DIP-intensive sectors. This shows the need to protect them and to pursue a coherent approach in the various areas of Union action, both as regards the internal market and exports to non-EU countries, as well as the importance of involving all stakeholders in the sector, including SMEs. In order to do this effectively, we need to differentiate protection strategies by geographical area and distinguish between material and digital product protection policies in order to optimise the provisions necessary for each sector. The protection of intellectual property requires a clear and precise establishment of the extent and destination of IPR funding, with particular regard to EU IPR Helpdesks; we also hope that the regrettable lack of a single EU patent will be filled as soon as possible. It is also important to use this opportunity for debate to encourage research and innovation, in particular to overcome the problem of the accessibility of medicines and in the challenge of hydrogeological failure and global climate change, thus taking advantage of the main problems of our near future.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. While special attention should be paid to SMEs, which are increasingly facing illegal competition, the solutions proposed in this report will not help to stem this phenomenon.  The effectiveness of the fight against counterfeiting depends de facto on the control of our national borders. How can one claim to manage the flow of goods from a territory if it is pierced from all sides? The only solution to safeguard the quality of French products, their value and thus to ensure the survival of their manufacturers, would be to identify the origin of the counterfeit and to have the opportunity to stop it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the Strategy for the Protection and Implementation of Intellectual Property Rights in Third Countries. Intellectual property has been and will be one of the priorities of the European Union, the evolution of human society being based on creativity and inventiveness. Profile industries contribute around 38.6% to the European Union's domestic product, and the defence of these rights aims to promote people's ability to create concepts and values that lead to the economic development of society and the increase in the number of jobs. Europe itself is attractive to investors because of the legislative framework that preserves and promotes intellectual property rights. I welcome and encourage any steps taken at European Union level in this regard. I am convinced that both Parliament and the Commission will continue to support the progressive harmonisation of this sector.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I agree with the importance of combating the infringements of intellectual property rights that companies from third countries carry out against our production system.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of the report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. This report is Parliament's support for the European Commission's desire to revise this strategy. We need to protect our technology and innovative sectors in our trade relations with third countries. It is important to adapt to new global challenges that are profoundly changing the context of intellectual property rights. I voted for this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries.  The report represents Parliament's position on the European Commission communication on intellectual property, which presents a strategy to ensure better protection of intellectual property rights in third countries. The report has the merit of emphasising that the commercial nature of numerous IPR violations and the increasing involvement of organised crime in this type of violation have become a major problem. It also pointed out that the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime does not at present have a protocol on combating counterfeiting. I therefore hope, along the same lines as the report, that the Commission and the Member States will step up their efforts in this regard.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While I appreciate that intellectual creations need protection if creativity and innovation are to flourish, and this is the role of intellectual property rights (IPR), the impact that such has on developing countries cannot be disregarded.  The report stipulated that market access for developing countries is only provided on the condition of a developed IPR system that is functioning well. However, this is often an impossible threshold for developing countries to meet. The need for an equitable and even balance between the interests of the IP right holders and public interests relating to access to knowledge, natural resources and health has not been addressed in any satisfactory manner. Furthermore, the creation of an extra EU organ in the form of an Observatory for IPR is something which I reject. I would rather see the use of already existing mechanisms.  For developing countries, a pragmatic and flexible approach is required in order to assist them in maximising the potential of their own intellectual assets and further their integration into international trade, while achieving broader societal welfare. It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principal thrust of this own-initiative report is that there should be a significant ramping up of, and extension of, powers over the system of enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR). Although it asserts that prime responsibility for IPR enforcement rests with each Member State’s public authorities, we already have a European Patent Court, thus suggesting that the EU does not view Member States as the best vector for such enforcement. In any event, this will lead to legislation. UKIP is opposed to EU legislation, hence I voted against this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe and agree with the elements set out in this report in response to the review of the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. Whilst the approach used by the Commission is valued by the different stakeholders, it identifies positively the need to encourage research and innovation, the challenge of access to medicine, and the environmental challenge as some of the important issues for the present and the future. I fully support the view that any initiatives concerning external policy are intrinsically linked to internal policies, and therefore the EU should carefully reflect on internal improvements of its intellectual property rules in the effort to improve the standard protection and enforcement of IPR globally.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution which , while with the positive intention of remedying the lack of major agreements on the commercial aspects of intellectual property rights in international agreements, has certain weaknesses. These relate in particular to the definition of standards that would apply to third countries, the control of the liability of intermediaries and the management of piracy in foreign subsidiaries of European companies. Furthermore, the resolution calls for increased support from the Commission for large European pharmaceutical companies selling generic medicines in third countries, without any action being taken to clearly promote access to generic medicines at prices adapted to the cost of living in those countries.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which, while it mentions the real and concrete problems with intellectual property rights violations, particularly as a result of increased opportunities for counterfeiting via online sales platforms, is completely wrong about the solutions to this problem. Indeed, the European Union is once again using real problems to increase its powers at the expense of Member States and the interests of their citizens. The report calls, in this logic, for the integration of international standards brought by the WTO into the field of IPRs, including the principle of a dispute settlement mechanism - the famous idea that leads to the establishment of private courts allowing multinationals to sue states (as envisaged in TTIP). Worse still, the report calls for closer European integration in this area through enhanced cooperation led by the Commission. The best way to combat counterfeiting is to ensure control of the European Union's borders and, to do so, only intergovernmental cooperation would allow us to be truly efficient.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure concerning the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. EU competitiveness is based on creativity and innovation in which intellectual property rights (IPR) contribute. IPR-intensive sectors account for 39% of economic activity (worth around €4700 billion) and 26% of EU employment (around 56 million jobs). From these data, it follows that infringements of these rights - in 2013 alone, for infringement of ppe, 36 million items with a total value of EUR 760 million were seized - constitute a serious problem. In addition, it should be noted that the EU, as a member of the WTO, is bound by the constraints and standards of the TRIPS Agreement and that compliance with ppe is an integral part of the TTIP agreement between the EU and the US, which is currently under negotiation. The strategy therefore aims to combat IPR infringements, to inform and raise consumer awareness and to promote and protect them internationally (e.g. WTO). Finally, a European observatory for infringements of intellectual property rights is set up.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to guarantee European companies the protection of their economic interests in carrying out their activities abroad and especially in developing countries. This protection must be provided at European level for two reasons: on the one hand, the Economic Strength of the Union is based on the creativity and innovation of the companies that populate it. On the other hand, the procedures for combating infringements are excessively time-consuming and costly in order to be supported by individual companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. The introduction of such measures would make it possible not only to protect economic interests, but also to safeguard the health and safety of consumers and the environment. Counterfeiting is no longer confined simply to luxury goods, but also affects everyday goods: toys, medicines, cosmetics and food products, which can be seriously detrimental to health and the environment.  In 2013 alone, 36 million items worth more than 760 million euros were seized and 10% of these assets were made up of drugs. The problem is therefore a serious one and a specific strategy must be adopted to curb it.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the new strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries is the appropriate means of addressing more effectively the problem of infringements of intellectual property rights in third countries. Only then will we be able to improve the global level of protection and the enforcement of intellectual property.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Developing smart growth, encouraging a research and innovation-based economy, is one of the priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy. Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen cooperation between schools, universities, companies, research centres and IPR holders, also in order to prevent the phenomenon of counterfeiting, which no longer affects only luxury products, but also everyday goods such as toys, medicines, cosmetics and food products. In order to reduce the risk of infringements and avoid negative consequences for consumer health and the economy, it is important to establish a comprehensive legal framework that also converges with the interests of third countries, accompanied by policies aimed at combating organised crime, money laundering and tax evasion.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Europeʼs creative sector not only fosters economic growth but also promotes European diversity and culture. Protection of intellectual property rights within the European Union is well regulated even if it deserves better implementation within the Member States for the creators to effectively and fully benefit from this protection in such a way that provides users with fair access. Yet, protection of intellectual property rights deserves an equally effective enforcement system which needs to consider non-EU trading partners as a relevant and important stakeholder. A solid enforcement system addressing counterfeit is equally beneficial to creators and consumers. Basic common goods are also subject to counterfeit and can pose health risks to consumers. The interests of creators as well as consumers therefore deserve the best of protection. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the indiscriminate use of intellectual property rights as a trade strategy against third countries. The legitimate protection of copyright and quality control of imported products cannot serve as an excuse for the creation of monopolies by large pharmaceutical and industrial multinationals, or for the expropriation of the knowledge and resources of third States and communities: because they have equal right to health, industrial development and scientific knowledge as those of the peoples of Europe.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report goes in the right direction by identifying the main instruments for improving and strengthening instruments to ensure greater protection of intellectual property rights in third countries. Over the past ten years, we have seen significant changes in intellectual property rights: substantial changes in the technology sector, including the fundamental role of the Internet, the growing importance of emerging economies, challenges in key sectors such as pharmaceuticals, require serious reflection and an overall rewrite of the approach to discipline. In this respect, the Commission's efforts to standardise the approach both within the EU and aimed at third countries are to be welcomed. As far as Parliament is concerned, I think it is very important to point out that, while it does not fail to protect the interests and competitiveness of EU pharmaceutical companies and the ability to innovate, the need to make medicines accessible to people in the country in which they are marketed, adapting their prices to their standard of living, is stressed. I firmly believe that, while respecting work and protecting intellectual property, the right to care remains an absolutely superordinate and priority value.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following Parliament’s rejection of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) in 2012, the Commission took time to reflect on how to proceed in the area of intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and enforcement. The approach taken in ACTA, mixing hard goods with internet supervision, was deplorable, however IPR enforcement must be taken seriously, given the threats that infringements pose to EU creative industry, jobs and growth. This report welcomes the Commission proposal to review the strategy for the protection and enforcement of IPR in third countries and recognises that the approach used by the Commission is valued by the various stakeholders. As this report aims to protect the hard work of Europeans in third countries, I voted in favour of it.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the strategy for the protection and strengthening of intellectual property rights in third countries. I believe that, on this issue, as the report rightly emphasises, we need to seek a common and coherent European Union strategy, so that protection is greater and more effective both within the Union and outside it. In other words, we must renew our efforts to put an end to the current fragmentation of the common market and to be able to promote and make the most of our products in third countries as well, finally giving the EU a clear position in multilateral trade treaties and for a as well. This is also the direction of the Commission's Green Paper, which aims to extend the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products in the Union. Our aim must be to adequately protect the European creative industry and traditional know-how, combating counterfeiting and stimulating its competitiveness, while seeking a balance between the legitimate interests of intellectual property owners and end-users. In this direction, we must provide for a flexible approach that takes into account the needs of individual countries on certain specific products, such as pharmaceutical products, for which access must be guaranteed to all.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's position on the European Commission's communication, published in July 2014, on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries.  This communication was adopted in the context of the political and legal situation created by the rejection of the ACTA Treaty in July 2012 and believes that the debate between intellectual property rights holders and end-users must lead to the necessary improvement and adequate harmonisation of European domestic ip rights policies in order to improve standards of protection and respect at the global level. Considering that it is necessary to take this step, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Intellectual property rights cover a range of legal instruments: copyright, licensing, patents, trademarks or geographical indications. These are subject to convergence within the internal market, but it is equally important to create common standards with our trading partners. This ensures the quality of the products our consumers access by ensuring their traceability throughout the supply chain and combating counterfeiting. That is why I support the Commission's strategy on the protection and respect of intellectual property rights, while inviting it to go further.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries is part of a very important debate which has repercussions both on the European and national stage. This is a crucial issue because of its industrial policy implications, particularly in the area of innovation. In fact, a debate aimed at reviving growth and investment in Europe is becoming increasingly apparent. In this debate it is essential to include clear guidelines to be given to these investments: innovation is certainly a fundamental element to consider for an increasingly specialized And many excellences European labour market. A Europe that invests in innovation is also a more competitive Europe than other major international competitors. However, without adequate protection of intellectual property, it will be impossible to achieve the intelligent growth that undersoes the European Union's investment programmes and priorities in the Europe 2020 strategy. In addition, this is a problem of particular importance to SMEs, which is the driving force behind the European economic fabric. For this reason, I believe that this debate is fundamental to building a virtuous path towards solid growth in Europe with innovation and knowledge as its main guidelines.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The defence of intellectual property is paramount for Europe. If we want to maintain our full capacity to innovate and create, as well as maintain our technological and scientific lead, necessary for the growth and competitiveness and know-how of our companies, we must act in three directions.  Firstly, the European Union must ensure that existing commitments made with third countries are respected; better defend ourselves in multilateral organizations; convince our partners that better protection of rights will strengthen the confidence of European companies wishing to invest abroad.  Secondly, the Eu must have a more ambitious IP rights strategy in its negotiations of free trade agreements with third countries, particularly on the specific issue of geographical indications. Third, we must maintain a balance between the firm protection of intellectual property rights and our innovative industries on the one hand and development policy on the other. It is therefore necessary, for example, to promote in the WTO a system of licences targeted at vital medicines in order to lower the price and allow better access to them.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution because the Union clearly needs better tools to protect the Union's intellectual property in third countries. The commercial nature of many intellectual property infringements and the growing role of organized crime in these offences pose a serious threat to creativity and innovation. Creativity and innovation are key strengths of the Union in the global market. We have to protect them. The resolution calls on the Commission to address this extremely complex issue in order to balance the interests of rights holders, economic operators and end-users.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. Of course, special attention should be paid to SMEs, which are increasingly facing illegal competition. In addition, they are now available in all areas and not just in the luxury goods sector.  However, the solutions proposed in this report will not help to stem this phenomenon. The management of counterfeits de facto leads to the control of our national borders. How can one claim to manage the flow of goods from a territory if it is pierced on all sides? The only solution to safeguard the quality of French products, their value and thus to ensure the survival of their manufacturers is to identify the origin of the counterfeit and to have the opportunity to stop it. The Union does not allow us to do that.

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR)
text: in writing. – I support this report because it is very important that we do not just protect the internal market against counterfeit goods. We must also ensure protection against illicit goods coming from third countries and the effect a weak intellectual property rights (IPR) protection system might have on the EU. It is crucial that we provide assistance to third states in terms of consultancy and training on improving enforcement measures and maintaining high standards. Only a strong system with adequate protection measures will help us in the fight against illicit trade, child labour, financing of terrorist activities, etc. Therefore, I welcome the proposals on the overall situation concerning IPR in third countries and the enforcement thereof.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technological evolution has drastically transformed the way intellectual property rights are applied. Despite this, the agreements concluded after the entry into force of the International Agreement on the Commercial Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights in 1994 remain few. Consequently, this draft report seeks to remedy certain shortcomings such as the inclusion at World Trade Organisation level of international agreements on intellectual property rights. Although I agree with the initiatives promoted by the rapporteur, which largely incorporate the Commission's guidelines, I voted against. In fact, there are elements that are not in line with the positions of the M5S, such as the sole responsibility of the national authorities for respect for intellectual property rights and strong support for pharmaceutical companies by the Commission, which export medicines to third countries.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Technological developments, increasingly globalised trade, e-commerce and outsourcing have led to the need to create new measures to combat violations of rights in third countries. Among other measures, the strategy seeks to help identify countries where the protection and/or enforcement of intellectual property rights is weak. I share the idea that it is important for the EU and the European Parliament to show that they take the issue seriously and want to help improve the intellectual property rights system.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, because although I am particularly committed to the defence of property rights in general and intellectual property in particular, I do not want the European Commission to take charge of this issue, which must remain the responsibility of the respective States.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution clearly defends the interests of European industry which exports to – or settles in – markets in the poorest countries. The latter require the material protection of Europeans, unless they do not export or settle on the markets of those countries. The resolution calls for the protection of Intellectual Property Rights in the framework of the TTIP negotiations, thus legitimizing it, as well as its instruments and objectives. As you would expect, it makes it a model for all other free trade agreements. The resolution discriminates against the populations of the poorest countries in access to health care, justifying the need to take into account "market distortions caused by the resale of medicines" in those countries. The clear option is to safeguard the interests of the pharmaceutical industry to the detriment of the concrete need for often urgent access to essential health goods. The resolution makes the "granting of market economy status" dependent on the poorest countries the protection of european interests and places freedom of trade on this protection, to the ratification of WIPO treaties on trade mark law, benefits, phonograms and copyright, and is not worth foreign investment in those countries. These and many other reasons justify our vote against.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I consider intellectual property rights (IPRs) to be an essential element for growth and innovation. Trade is based on the protection of these rights and, therefore, adequate protection against counterfeiting on a commercial scale is necessary to improve the EU's competitiveness. To talk about intellectual property is not only about copyright, but also about trademarks, patents, etc., which are vital to the value of European goods and services. According to some statistics, about 39% of European GDP and approximately 26% of employment stem from sectors with a strong IPR component. Its importance is growing, as well as its strategic value as a tool of differentiation and competitiveness in the global economy.  We see that the importance of intellectual property chapters in EU trade agreements with third countries is growing, and that is why we believe that an improved, harmonised and broadly supported IPR strategy in the EU can be very useful in improving IPR protection and enforcement standards globally.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because the following statement is a direct contradiction: ʽwhereas competitiveness of the EU has, and increasingly will be, based on creativity and innovationʼ.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union should not only combat infringements of intellectual property rights within its territory within the Member States of the European Union, but should also focus its attention on third countries, as counterfeiting already affects commonly used products that can cause injuries or expose consumers to serious health risks.  In 2013, the customs authorities of the European Union seized almost 36 million items suspected of infringing intellectual property rights, with the value of the goods seized in exceeding EUR 760 million. These are figures that the European Commission should certainly not take lightly. The European Commission therefore faces the difficult task of having a technical and transparent public debate on the protection and enforcement of intellectual property and what this means for consumers. We must also not forget the call to improve the involvement of stakeholders in the debate on intellectual property rights. Better protection of intellectual property rights and effective application of the rules relating to them in third countries would provide a major incentive for investors from the European Union and other countries to invest, to facilitate the sharing of their technological skills and to modernise existing technologies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the importance of combating infringements of intellectual property rights that companies from third countries carry out against our production system.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the significant changes that have taken place in the area of intellectual property rights (IPR) over the past decade, I believe that protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights is indeed a very important issue to tackle in order to fight the threat that infringement poses to EU creative industries, jobs and growth. I welcome this initiative and I appreciate the fact that the approach taken in ACTA, which mixed hard goods with Internet supervision, was overcome. I am in favour of the Commission proposal to review the strategy for protection and enforcement of IPR in third countries. This approach is valued by the different stakeholders and underlines that any initiative concerning external IPR enforcement should carefully reflect internal EU development of IP rules. Finally, I would like to welcome the inclusions by our Group safeguarding the flow of generic medicines, which strikes the right balance between production of generic medicines and protection of pharmaceutical research.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome and voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to review the strategy for enforcing intellectual property rights in third countries. I INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY intensive industries generate around 39% of total economic activity in the EU (worth around EUR 4.7 billion per year) and approximately 26% of total employment (56 million jobs). However, since the entry into force of the Convention on trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights (TRIPS, 1 January 1995), only a limited number of major intellectual property agreements have been concluded, even though changes in technology and society have transformed the field of intellectual property rights. As important issues for the present and the future, the report clearly identifies the need to stimulate research and innovation, the challenge of access to medicines and environmental challenges.  I also welcome the fact that all initiatives concerning external policies are linked to internal policies and that, accordingly, internal improvements to intellectual property rules need to be thoroughly reviewed.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting intellectual property rights in third countries is a decisive and urgent need not only to offer the right protection to the innovation and creativity of citizens, but also from the point of view of competitiveness: just think that in 2013 the only goods intercepted by the EU customs authorities subject to infringement of intellectual property rights reached a value of 760 million euros. At the level of global agreements, wrong and cumberful action plans have been undertaken in the past, such as the failed attempt at the ACTA Anti-Counterfeiting Treaty, which was finally rejected by this assembly on 4 July 2012. With this new report, we have asked the Commission to legislate on such an important issue in an efficient and pragmatic way, avoiding the mistakes of the past.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mrs Moscow for her excellent work on this important report on combating counterfeiting and protecting intellectual property in the world. Europe is based on creativity, on the production of quality and ingenuity, and I find the commitments that this report calls for of the European institutions and the Member States very important. The protection of our creative and production capacity is an essential element for growth and economic sustainability in Europe. Counterfeiting is no longer confined to luxury products, but also affects everyday goods such as toys, medicines, cosmetics and food products: ensuring better protection is also a protection for the health of consumers.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries- partly because I consider the focus of better, universal access to affordable medicines in emerging countries to be a central issue in European development policy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Mosca report on intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries, given that it strikes the right balance between, on the one hand, consumer rights and, on the other, strong rules on IPR protection, which are crucial to protect our creative and manufacturing industries. I also applaud the attention given by the rapporteur to access to medicines and a patient-focused approach to IPR in the medical sector. I must say I am concerned by reports that the Commission is taking an increasingly aggressive approach towards countries like India, which excel in the production of high quality generic medicines. They not only comply perfectly with international regulations but are also crucial in ensuring affordable and equal access to high quality medication for wide sections of society. Let us not forget that monopolies are one of the main reasons why we do not have effective medicines in the EU to combat antimicrobial resistance, and why there is no treatment for many devastating diseases, like Ebola, in the third world. I urge the Commission to make sure that medicines are not luxury goods available only to the rich few.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against Alessia Maria Mosca's motion for a resolution on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. The report makes a clear observation: intellectual property rights determine a large part of the competitiveness of the European economy. The effectiveness of these rights requires a fight against counterfeiting, which increasingly extends to mass consumer products. In addition to the economic aspects, the fight against counterfeiting is also an important public health and safety issue. It is therefore necessary to punish violations of intellectual property rights. On the other hand, I object to the definition and application of these sanctions being delegated to international organizations that have not demonstrated their effectiveness. In reality, only Member States are able to effectively defend the intellectual property rights of their companies. In order to do so, they must be free to control their borders and to punish infringements of intellectual property rights themselves, even if they take the necessary measures against third countries that would allow counterfeiting to develop for export to their territory.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it calls for a rigorous extension of intellectual property rights standards in third countries, and even appeals to conditionality in this area to establish economic relations with these countries, without regard to the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights often undermine their industrial and development policies. In addition, the report addresses the problem of access to medicines from the perspective of large pharmaceutical companies, turning their backs on people's right to access medicines. The report responds blindly to past experiences, such as Ebola in West Africa or hepatitis C in Spain. There is evidence that research into new medicines is often not guided by public health demands, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. Current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs that are really needed.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my Labour Party colleagues voted in favour of this report on intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. The report strikes the right balance between consumer rights and strong rules on IPR protection, both of which are necessary if Europe’s creative and manufacturing sectors are to thrive.  I also support the approach taken by the rapporteur to the issue of access to medicines and a patient-focused approach to IPR in the medical sector. Generic medicines are crucial in ensuring affordable access to medication for many sections of society. It is important to ensure that they comply with international regulations and I am pleased that this report notes that there is nothing in IPR rules which would hamper the production of legitimate generic medicines.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on a strategy for the protection and protection of intellectual property rights in third countries, because, despite the fact that changes in technology and society have also led to a change in intellectual property rights, their protection is an essential challenge for Europe's competitiveness in working with third countries. Intellectual property rights help to promote innovation and creativity, thereby promoting competitiveness and the european union's movement forward.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. We must ensure a fair balance between rights-holders’ interests and end users interests. We also need the widest possible involvement of stakeholders so as to ensure a balanced outcome. The protection and enforcement of IPR are extremely important for the EU creative industries in particular. Furthermore, the strategy needs to be better adapted to the digital age, and we need to have strong collaboration between market surveillance authorities and customs authorities in order to ensure proper enforcement and policy coherence. This is not just about intellectual property rights but also about the problem of counterfeiting, which is no longer confined to luxury products but now includes goods such as medicines and foodstuffs.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on protecting and enforcing intellectual property (IP) rights in third countries because it rightly identifies the need for our external rules to reflect internal developments in intellectual property. In particular, I welcome the emphasis placed on access to medicine. It is vital that nothing in the rules on intellectual property rights inhibits the production and distribution of generic medicines.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the appropriate enforcement of intellectual property rights, and I consider that the EU should adequately safeguard these rights in its interaction with third countries. This report, however, over-emphasised aspects of health and safety in relation to intellectual property rights and I therefore voted against it.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it calls for a rigorous extension of intellectual property rights standards in third countries, and even appeals to conditionality in this area to establish economic relations with these countries, without regard to the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights often undermine their industrial and development policies. In addition, the report addresses the problem of access to medicines from the perspective of large pharmaceutical companies, turning their backs on people's right to access medicines. The report responds blindly to past experiences such as Ebola in West Africa or hepatitis C in Spain. There is evidence that research into new medicines is often not guided by public health demands, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. Current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs that are really needed.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Strategy for the Protection and Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights in third countries, as I believe that one of the roles of the European Union is to help third countries, but also other regional blocs, to advance democratic and legal values, such as the state of intellectual property protection, thereby contributing to the strengthening of this right within the Union itself.  Of course, globalisation has contributed to increasing this problem, but greater transparency and stakeholder involvement in intellectual property and better coordination of internal and foreign policy in this regard are also needed. At the same time, the fight against violations of these rights is also the fight against organised crime, which implies stronger cooperation with customs and market surveillance authorities and more effective international cooperation.  In addition, particular attention should also be paid to so-called 'e-commerce' which can pose a serious threat in this area and further encourage counterfeits.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against Alessia Maria Mosca's motion for a resolution on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. Of course, intellectual property rights determine a large part of the competitiveness of the European economy. The effectiveness of these rights requires a fight against counterfeiting, which increasingly extends to mass consumer products. In addition to the economic aspects, the fight against counterfeiting is also an important public health and safety issue. It is therefore necessary to punish violations of intellectual property rights. However, I am opposed to the definition and application of these sanctions being delegated to international organizations that have not demonstrated their effectiveness. In order to do so, Member States must be free to control their borders and to punish infringements of intellectual property rights themselves, even if they take the necessary measures against third countries that would allow counterfeiting to develop for export to their territory.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Alessia Maria Mosca's report on the protection and respect of IPRs in third countries. Industries that need IPRs for their work account for 39% of overall economic activity, i.e. EUR 4,700 billion and 56 million jobs. The good protection of patents and other IPRs in third countries, in order to combat counterfeiting of all kinds, is therefore an important issue for Europe, its citizens and its industry. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries because counterfeit products, especially medicines, pose a danger to European consumers and to the competitiveness of our European companies.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. This report contains many proposals for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries. Europe's innovative strength and creativity can only continue to be so successful and strong if there is a sensible strategy that protects against illegal exploitation. I therefore support this motion.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries because I believe that a equal environment on intellectual property rights will create favourable conditions of competition and open up new, safer markets for European exporters. The report underlines and supports the EC's commitment to prioritising the improvement of the protection of intellectual property rights within the World Trade Organisation and other important international bodies. More uniform protection rules in this area, including in cooperation with third countries, will help to develop trade and promote more effective cooperation both at European Union level and in cooperation with third countries, while promoting competition. Competition is the driving force for growth, which is why I supported this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report as it outlines a balanced EU approach to the important issue of intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. IPR is central to European businesses’ ability and willingness to innovate, and it is important to note the complex balance is required between right holders’ and end users’ interests, particularly in sectors such as pharmaceuticals where the capacity for innovation must be balanced with costs in third countries. Further, I support the calls in the report for further IPR support not only for EU economic operators in third countries via attachés and helpdesks, but also for technical assistance for countries seeking to improve IPR enforcement, as this can only lead to economic benefits for those countries.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it reflects the position that strong intellectual property rights (IPR) protection is important for our creative and manufacturing industries. It emphasises the importance of distinguishing between counterfeit hard goods and pirated online content. It also cautions that any external rules should reflect our own ongoing internal development of IPR protection. I am also pleased that it emphasises that nothing in IPR rules should hamper the production or block the transit of legitimate generic medicine.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, intellectual property rights (IPR) contribute to the development of innovation and creativity. Their protection is a central challenge for Europe's competitiveness and, therefore, the Union must have a more ambitious strategy for protecting intellectual property rights vis-à-vis its trading partners. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of Mrs Moscow's report, which has highlighted the importance of this issue with the aim of safeguarding European companies and their economic interests when operating abroad and in developing countries.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. We are against this report because we must first of all: - focus on the anti-counterfeiting policy recalling cultural issues and the essential aspect of the control of the external and internal borders of the European Union; - refuse to strengthen European harmonisation which causes Member States to lose sovereignty; - favouring a logic of intergovernmental cooperation within the framework of the regal prerogatives of the Member States and not supranational reasoning; - to defend and highlight the economic interests of each Member State.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it shows the Commission's willingness to take charge of the protection of intellectual property rights in third countries. However, I believe that this area must be the responsibility of the Member States and the logic of intergovernmental cooperation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. Non-compliance with intellectual property rights causes SMEs to lose money. Counterfeiting is spreading more and more and affects sensitive areas related to consumer products, especially with the development of online sales. If I agree with the observation, I am less so with the conclusions of this report, because there is still talk of reducing national sovereignty through the development of enhanced cooperation led by the European Commission. On the contrary, Member States should be allowed to strengthen controls at their borders and to prioritise intergovernmental cooperation by rejecting all supranational logic and the creation of a European supervisory body. Each Member State must be able to defend its economic interests.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the indiscriminate use of intellectual property rights as a trade strategy against third countries. The legitimate protection of copyright and quality control of imported products cannot serve as an excuse for the creation of monopolies by large pharmaceutical and industrial multinationals, nor with the expropriation of the knowledge and resources of third States and communities: because they have equal right to health, industrial development and scientific knowledge as those of the peoples of Europe.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Intellectual Property Rights in Third Countries. The protection of intellectual property in third countries is one of the problems of the whole European Union. If in the EU the situation is regulated and on the right track, in third countries piracy and theft emerge. I am proud to be one of the 521 Members who voted for and I am ashamed of the 164 voters against and the 17 colleagues who abstained.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Intellectual Property Rights and its proper protection contribute to the development of innovation and creativity, which is one of the preconditions for increasing the competitiveness of the European Union. It is therefore necessary to respond flexibly to cases of infringements of intellectual property, thus ensuring adequate protection and value. Counterfeit goods and copyright infringements currently concern not only branded goods, but also goods of normal consumption. Such copyright abuses not only have financial implications, but also endanger people's safety, life and health, especially with increasing online purchases. Therefore, the protection of intellectual property requires constant attention and the adoption of measures that will lead to its effective safeguarding.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on a 'Strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries', for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/6/2015, and because a legal framework for the protection of intellectual property rights is needed in order to overturn both the abuse of rights by intellectual property rights holders and the creation of monopolistic situations of exploitation and profiteering. In particular, in relation to pharmaceutical companies, which, by abusing their dominant position, have turned the marketing of medicines into an obscene over-profit-accumulating undertaking at the expense of third countries, the prices of medicines must be accessible to the poor peoples of Europe and third countries, because health is a public good and not a commodity.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against it. This report aims to give the Commission power over everything related to the protection of intellectual property rights (IPR), when this should remain a responsibility of the Member States. We reject the creation of yet another expensive and inefficient European body, where intergovernmental cooperation would suffice. It would be worth remembering that the priority here is to fight counterfeiting and protect our cultures, and that this is primarily through the control of the EU's external and internal borders.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on intellectual property rights in third countries, as it contributes to a favourable development of innovation and creativity, promoting the necessary 'smart growth', it is a policy that, by protecting intellectual property and acting against all infringements of intellectual property, contributes to producing a positive atmosphere for innovators. I consider it necessary to raise consumer awareness of economic damage and serious reasoning for the management of the Internet linked to the reality of PPE – intellectual property rights – given the digitalisation of the market and the birth of online platforms.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, signed by my colleague Moscow, sets out the conditions for adequate protection of intellectual property rights within third countries. I particularly welcomed the reference in the text to the need to launch an all-out fight against organised crime which benefits from the trade in counterfeit and pirated goods. Aware that greater protection of intellectual property rights would lead to an advance in economic growth, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because I understand that it does not take into account the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights are often used to undermine their industrial and development policies. Furthermore, the report addresses the issue of access to medicinal products only in view of the perspective of the pharmaceutical industry, calling into question the right of access to medicinal products. The EU should have already learned from the recent Ebola crisis that research into new medicines should be targeted for public health and not market reasons. The need for an intellectual property rights system that contains a fair and appropriate balance between rights holders and the defence of the public interest on access to knowledge, natural resources and health is far from the horizon of this report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament's proposal on the strategy to improve the protection and ensuring respect for intellectual property rights in third countries points to the importance of reaching agreements to move in this direction and we also want to draw attention to the need for internal improvements in our intellectual property rules. My support, therefore, for this report, to protect an industry essential for economic development and employment in the EU, and which we must among all protect and promote.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The aim of Ms Mosca's initiative report was to give the European Parliament's opinion on the European Commission's new strategy for protecting intellectual property rights in third countries. Despite the very poor approach taken by the Commission at the time of the ACTA negotiations, which was rejected by the European Parliament in 2012, the protection of intellectual property must be taken seriously. The infringement of intellectual property rights poses a threat to the creative and innovative industries, which account for 26% of jobs at European level.  With this in mind, the Mosca report sets out an ambitious roadmap for the Commission, not only by asking it to continue its efforts towards third countries, but also by inviting it to improve its internal rules for the protection of intellectual property. It also places clear red lines, for example to ensure that research protection does not come at the expense of access to care in the least developed countries. I voted for the report in favour of a smart approach to creation and innovation.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I chose the report because I believe it includes a sensible strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the EU needs better tools to protect intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. Many IPR infringements are commercial in nature and are often part of organised crime. This poses a serious threat to EU creativity and innovation in the global market, which require greater protection.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report validates the Commission's proposal to combat intellectual property rights (IPR) infringements in countries outside the European Union. With this text, it is as always a question of strengthening the "market" by imposing a IPR compliance clause on developing countries in free trade agreements. All the consequences of this system must be realized. The proposal strengthens the weight of large groups in these regions. Multinational pharmaceutical companies are thus encouraged to protect the secrecy of the molecules used making universal access to affordable medicines or the development of generic drugs all the more complicated. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In this report, the diagnosis is relevant but the solutions are poor. On the one hand, we see that European competitiveness is based on creativity and innovation and that, therefore, this creativity should be developed by improving the protection of intellectual property rights.  At present, the fight against intellectual property rights violations is very time-consuming and costly, especially for SMEs. Moreover, counterfeiting, which mainly concerned luxury goods, now affects consumer products.  On the other hand, the proposed solutions are bad. The creation of a European supervisory body would be costly and unnecessary. On the contrary, intergovernmental cooperation must be prioritised and the economic interests of states must be defended, including border controls. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have voted in favour of the report on the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. I share the guidance taken in the European Parliament resolution to step up the protection of European IPR in relations with its trading partners with the aim of developing the competitiveness of knowledge-based and innovation-based economies and combating the parallel economies that feed organised crime through broken products, which can also involve serious risks to consumer health and safety.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it encourages Member States to work together to formulate harmonised internal policies on intellectual property rights (IPR). It also stresses the need to keep the public well informed through transparent debates on matters concerning IPR and the enforcement of the IPR laws and regulation. It is encouraging to see the Commission living up to its promise to give this issue high priority in meetings at international level. It is essential that IPR is given the importance it deserves, as criminal gangs are becoming increasingly involved in schemes related to IPR infringements.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Intellectual property rights (IPRs) contribute significantly to the development of innovation and creativity. In developing countries, their protection is a key issue for their competitiveness and integration into world trade.  I welcome the European Parliament's vote to provide the European Union with a more ambitious strategy for protecting intellectual property rights from its trading partners. At a time when the digital world is becoming increasingly important in developing countries, such a strategy will help combat trademark infringement and patent infringement by operators from these countries. This is a step forward in the fight against copyright infringement, which has caused serious financial losses detrimental to businesses and the economy of developing countries. By voting for this strategy, the European Parliament confirms the European Union's interest in helping its partners develop a healthy and secure business environment.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Although the intellectual property sector accounts for around 39 % of the Union's economic activity and around 26 % of total employment in the EU, a limited number of intellectual property agreements have been concluded since 1 January 1995, when the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights entered into force, even if those agreements amended the whole area of intellectual property. Rejecting ACTA in July 2012, the Commission outlined the foundations of a new European strategy for the protection of intellectual property in third countries in 2014. It is undoubtedly important to take into account the different interests on both sides and to strike a balance between the interests of the holders of these rights and the users. I also agree that a distinction needs to be made between different levels of national maturity, taking into account barriers to trade in individual countries. As far as EU legislation is at stake, I support greater internal harmonisation for the consequent increase and enforcement of intellectual property protection globally.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the report on intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries, which aims to review the strategy for the protection and enforcement of IPR in third countries and recognises that the approach used by the Commission is valued by the different stakeholders. It also underlines the fact that any initiative concerning external IPR enforcement should carefully reflect internal EU development of intellectual property rules

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As intellectual property rights affect a very significant part of the EU's overall economy and jobs within the EU, the enforcement of these rights is crucial for the EU's economic interests both within the EU and in third countries. The report is, in my view, a decisive step forward on this issue, and I therefore voted in favour of both.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. If the importance of the fight against counterfeiting and illegal sales is rightly noted in this report, the proposals appear timid and are not based on the most effective tools that are Member States. It should be done differently with an emphasis on anti-counterfeiting policy, and recalling the essential aspect of controlling the external and internal borders of the European Union. It is then necessary to favour a logic of intergovernmental cooperation within the framework of the regal prerogatives of the Member States. The creation of an additional European body would be costly and undesirable. This report should therefore not be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The intellectual property industry accounts for around 39 % of the Gross Domestic Product of the European Union and directly and indirectly employs around 35 % of all employment relations in the European Union. Despite its vitality and size, the European Union loses €8 billion annually in its Gross Domestic Product due to contracting and piracy.  This report deserves my vote in favour because I believe that intellectual property is one of the keys to growth and innovation and for stressing the importance of combating infringement and piracy.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it argues that strong IPR protection is important for our creative and manufacturing industries. The report emphasises the importance of distinguishing between counterfeit hard goods and pirated online content. This was a key flaw in the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) in 2012 and a reason for its rejection. It also cautions that any external rules should reflect our own ongoing internal development of IPR protection. Key text on access to medicine has also been adopted to emphasise that nothing in IPR rules should hamper the production or block the transit of legitimate generic medicine.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. The aim is to protect creativity and innovation, the engines of European competitiveness and the pillars of the Europe 2020 programme.  It recognises that the EU needs a more ambitious strategy to protect intellectual property rights vis-à-vis its trading partners. Counterfeiting is no longer limited to luxury goods but also to consumer products such as toys, medicines, cosmetics and foodstuffs.  In 2013, nearly 36 million items suspected of infringing intellectual property rights were seized, worth more than 760 million euros. In addition to benefiting organized crime, counterfeit products pose serious risks to the health of consumers. The adopted report calls for the creation of a detailed legal framework, with an effective control mechanism, referring if necessary to repressive measures and sanctions, the implementation of which should not, however, unnecessarily weigh on legitimate trade.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the strategy for the protection and strengthening of intellectual property rights in third countries. As pointed out in the report itself, we should, on the one hand, congratulate the Commission on the good work it has done so far, but on the other hand we must continue to work towards greater cooperation between the various stakeholders in the sector and effective legislation. It is important to note that it is now necessary to distinguish between physical and digital goods, and that this differentiation is taken into account when it comes to regulation and sanctioning. Another key element of the strategy is the importance of regulating the price of medicines to the countries where they are sold, trying to strike the difficult balance between the necessary cost of research and the not only moral obligation to provide everyone with the opportunity to cure themselves. The communication is an excellent first step, but it must necessarily be followed up, considering that it is essential that the European Union equips itself with a coherent internal regulatory framework in this area, which would guarantee greater negotiating force both in bilateral relations and in multilateral discussions.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed the Commission's proposal to analyse the Strategy for the Protection and Respect of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR). Nowadays, IPR-intensive sectors in the EU generate around 39% of total economic activity (worth around €4 700 billion per year) and approximately 26% of total employment (56 million jobs). The Eu ropean Union absolutely must therefore equip itself with the best means of protecting the EU's intellectual property in third countries. In addition, the adoption of appropriate measures to combat infringements of intellectual property rights can play a key role in the fight against organised crime, money laundering and tax evasion.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Intellectual property legislation should follow digital development, in particular the online environment and different ways of dissemination. It must take into account the interests of all parties concerned, as well as the right of consumers to access content, as well as the protection of the work of European creators and artists. In enforcing intellectual property rights, it is important to emphasise the principle of proportionality, balancing the rights of content owners and users, which must be in line with data protection rules such as the protection of personal data. Furthermore, it is important to represent the interests of SMEs in this area.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU depends on industries that rely on effective IP protection. I voted for this report because the improved standards and enforcement in it will bring to light the available potential of EU exporters that can only be achieved if counterfeiting is effectively addressed and adequate standards, procedures and administrative resources exist.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is a perfectly sensible strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries. Intellectual property rights or the idea of a person or company can thus be better protected from duplicates.
