name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report targets intellectual property rights in third countries, which should enable them to better integrate into the globalised economy. Although the report seeks to develop the intellectual property potential of less developed countries, no differentiated approach has been adopted, leaving these countries in a clear disadvantage, particularly against multinationals in the pharmaceutical or agri-food sectors. Conditioning the market access of some third countries to the highest protection of intellectual rights excludes these countries from many development opportunities. That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft strategy for the protection and guarantee of intellectual property rights in third countries. The EU's competitiveness is increasingly based on creativity and innovation, and protecting them is crucial for Europe's competitiveness. The commercial nature of many infringements of intellectual property rights and the increasing involvement of organised crime in these offences have become an important problem, and to this end it is necessary for the Commission to draw up a concrete plan and to show where and how much resources are allocated.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour since it is imperative to facilitate access to medicines in the poorest countries, not only in terms of prices, which must be affordable for people in the country where they are sold, but also in terms of surveillance and control in the importation of medicines: 19% of seizures by customs authorities are medicines. We must push for an effective blockade of these imitations that undermine public health. The damage is irreparable, also because they decrease the possibility of circulation of generic drugs. It is our duty as Europeans to maintain a safe and unhindered flow of medicines. The suffering of thousands of people is at stake.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I believe that the commission's proposal to revise the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries is a step forward in developing a more ambitious strategy. It is necessary to ensure that intellectual property rights are properly legally protected, not only within the EU but also outside the EU. Given the nature and extent of possible infringements, the strategy should be better adapted to the digital environment and include strong cooperation with customs and market surveillance authorities and ensure horizontal compatibility. It should be noted that intellectual property is a legal and economic incentive mechanism. In addition, intellectual property rights also act as a mechanism for attracting investment, as they demonstrate innovative opportunities. In this context, clear measures and methods should be laid down to help achieve the objectives set. European rightholders who export their products to or pursue their products on third-country markets shall receive sufficient financial support.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the market for counterfeit goods – including pharmaceuticals – has benefited greatly from the recent digitalisation of sales, taking advantage of the legislative vacuum in the field of online commerce. Infringements of intellectual property rights therefore constitute a serious threat to the inventiveness of operators and to the health of consumers. I fully support the opening of a public debate on the importance of this issue, involving all rightholders, from citizens to businesses. The European Union needs to expand the protection of intellectual property, through the introduction of a modern copyright system that follows the trends of the digital age. Furthermore, it should not be ated that the intellectual property industry represents a pool of more than fifty million jobs throughout Europe. For these reasons, I supported the report presented to this House and I agree with Parliament's call for the Commission to support respect for intellectual property in international organisations and in agreements with third countries, as an important pillar for the creation of a competitive economic system.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The reports on the enforcement of copyright both within the EU and in its relations with third countries concern the safeguarding of the interests of business groups, not only in the so-called entertainment industry, but also in those active in the pharmaceutical sector, industry, information technology, etc. , patents for medicines, industrial products, etc., to the detriment of the peoples who have to pay for their medicines, for the enjoyment of artistic creations, information and other life-critical goods, which had to be public and free without business action. The authors of works, patents, etc. are not only not protected, but their exploitation is intensified by strengthening the system of so-called "intellectual property rights" in companies that acquire these rights and exploit them when they do not own them. The abolition of the exploitative system is a prerequisite for developing at the highest level the creative, scientific and technological possibilities that exist today, for workers to enjoy freely the achievements of human creation in all areas of their lives.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Moscow's report, as intellectual property rights (IPR) contribute to the development of a country's innovation and creativity, so I think it is right that the Eu ropean Union should have a more ambitious strategy for protecting intellectual property rights vis-à-vis its trading partners.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the Strategy for the Protection and Enforcement of Intellectual Property Protection in Third Countries, as I believe that the protection of creativity and innovation is needed and it is important that the EU, in cooperation with third countries, protect copyright and licenses. Promoting better protection of intellectual property rights and its application in the WTO and in all international circles is very important, in particular in order to open new markets for European exports.  Encouraging third countries to enhanced cooperation to mutually recognise the right to provide services to intellectual property legal professionals, and to cooperate more closely on copyright and licensing matters, is one of the key steps in achieving the objectives of the European Union. Regular interaction with all interested parties - rightholders, public authorities, civil society, the European Parliament - is needed to discuss the impact of intellectual property infringement in third countries, and to explain the European Union's efforts to improve the enforcement of intellectual property rights in these countries.  It is also important to protect EU economic operators and consumers in third countries. Establishing a dialogue with priority countries is important to facilitate the protection of intellectual property. The application of related rules in third countries opens up various opportunities for investors from the European Union and the world, a strong incentive for the advancement of new technologies.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries raises good questions but provides the wrong answers. Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are a very important part of the strength of the European economy. I can only agree with the desire to better combat counterfeiting, of which SMEs are the first victims.  However, the attacks on the sovereignty of the States brought about by this report are simply unacceptable. Indeed, I strongly deplore a desire to strengthen European integration in this area at a time when the fight against counterfeiting is more effective at the national level and in the control of the external and internal borders of the European Union. The creation of one more European body would be costly and unnecessary. There is also a major risk of strengthening the logic of dispute resolution. For all these reasons, I can only vote against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support colleague Mosca's report, which approaches this extremely complex topic in an objective way. The fact is that the debate on intellectual property rights should be based on expert consideration of previous experience, as well as future technological trends while maintaining consistency between internal and external aspects, distinguishing between physical and digital environments, taking into account the concerns of all stakeholders, including SMEs and consumer organisations, and seeking to ensure full transparency of interests and appropriate legitimacy in the pursuit of a fair balance of interests of all involved.  Also, the fact is that counterfeiting is no longer limited to luxury products, but also covers goods of frequent use such as toys, medicines, cosmetics and food products which, if counterfeited, can cause injury or pose a serious risk to consumer health. The distribution of counterfeits is best shown by the fact that 72% of counterfeits were found in small packages shortly before they were delivered to final customers.  As a result, the EU, as a leader in new technologies and the place of origin of most manufacturers from whom products are foremaved, needs better coordination between foreign and domestic policy and better awareness among consumers of the potentially harmful effects of these products on their health. In particular, I support the call for the protection of geographical indications when negotiating free trade agreements with third countries and in particular through negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP).

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported Rapporteur Moscai's report on the Strategy for the Protection of Intellectual Property Rights in third countries. As intellectual property rights contribute to the development of innovation and creativity and their protection is a key factor for Europe's competitiveness, it is evident that Europe needs a more ambitious strategy to protect intellectual property rights in relation to its partner affairs.  Recent studies have shown that sectors where intellectual property rights are intensively used account for around 39% of EU GDP and up to 35% of all jobs, taking into account indirect jobs, and according to some estimates the EU loses around €8bn of its GDP annually due to counterfeiting and piracy. Therefore, action should be taken to counter infringements of intellectual property rights, the way to protect the value of creation in the EU and in third countries, i.e. to reduce the risks they pose to consumer health and safety and to the environment, as well as to avoid economic and social consequences for EU businesses and producers.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Intellectual property rights are increasingly contributing to the success of an economy based on development and innovation, and I agree with what the report says, namely the need for the EU to have a more ambitious strategy in this area and also towards its trading partners. That is why I am in favour of the strategy put in place and have voted in favour of it; I believe that we need better protection and implementation of intellectual property rights within the World Trade Organisation so that we can open up new markets for European exports while defending intellectual property. I believe, however, that the EU, in its desire to improve external policy on intellectual property, should also pay attention to the internal improvements to be made to its rules on intellectual property law.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Intellectual property rights are a driving force for growth and innovation. Industries that often use intellectual property account for about 39% of overall economic activity and 56 million jobs. It is the importance of ensuring that these rights are respected in Europe and around the world and to strengthen their application.  In this context, the European Parliament has adopted the European strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report. It is important to guarantee the investments of our European companies in third countries and thus ensure a long-term trade relationship between the EU and third countries.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of understanding that, although the European Commission Communication contains many positive aspects, there are others that need to be improved and deepened.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Intellectual property is intended to properly reward our researchers, creators and inventors for their original ideas and creations, to encourage companies to invest in innovative solutions, services and products. It fosters innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. These are all reasons for us to continue our efforts with our international partners to improve standards for the protection of intellectual rights.  The Commission is therefore very good at deciding to review its strategy in this area. Moreover, the lessons of the ACTA misadventure have been learned: we must negotiate with lax countries on counterfeit products, clearly separating the digital world from tangible goods. This revision is welcome, because the fight against counterfeiting is more relevant than ever and Europe cannot win it alone. Wider international recognition of intellectual property rights and the strengthening of partner countries' capacity to protect these rights will lead to more innovation, and consequently more creative change and economic growth, for the benefit of the citizens of Europe and the world.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Intellectual property rights contribute decisively to the development of creativity and innovation. Your protection is a fundamental challenge throughout today that deserves our attention and concern. I believe, like the rapporteur, that the European Union should have an ambitious and cohesive strategy in order to protect intellectual property rights, just as I argue that this strategy should not only pass through EU Member States but also extend to third countries.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. During the past decade, there have been significant changes in the area of intellectual property rights: substantial technological changes related to the Internet, increasing importance of emerging economies, challenges in access to medicines, and an increasing level of IPR violations, among others. Following the rejection of ACTA in 2012 by this Parliament, the Commission rectifies and proposes with this strategy a different and up-to-date approach to the protection of IPRs. This report, which I voted in favour of, calls for a more transparent and balanced public debate, with the participation of all stakeholders, and insists on strengthening IPR dialogues with third countries as well as customs cooperation. They highlight the Socialist amendments in favour of a multidimensional response to the problem of access to medicines, facilitating their access in less developed countries and supporting flexibility mechanisms that recognize the right to compulsory licensing.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The fight against infringements of intellectual property rights (brands, patents, copyright, geographical names, etc.) is a priority for the competitiveness and proper functioning of Europe. In 2013, 36 million items (worth more than 760 million euros) were suspected of infringing intellectual property rights. That is why I supported the report that Parliament voted for, which calls for better consideration of the challenges posed by the digital economy and calls for better tools.  The report calls on the Commission to create a framework for the convergence of the interests of Member States and third countries, with mutual interest in establishing strict protection frameworks with effective remedies, in order to fill gaps in IPR protection. The voted text also encourages the Commission and Member States to better defend IPRs in all relevant multilateral organisations (WTO, WHO) and to promote the integration into the WTO framework of international IPR agreements that are not yet part of it, such as the WIPO Treaty on Trademark Rights and the WIPO Treaty on Copyright.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. Knowledge industries are one of the pillars of our globalized economy and are growing. Indeed, the number of new European patents and registered COMMUNITY trademarks more than doubled between 2003 and 2012. On the other hand, there is a great threat to this positive development: counterfeiting. According to the OECD, these infringements of intellectual property rights (IPRs) represent a loss to the world economy of 200 billion euros per year.  This report proposes to improve the institutional framework of IPRs and to protect IPRs adequately and effectively. Collaboration with third countries, in the form of dialogues and working groups, is being considered to address the main shortcomings of IPR protection regimes. The report also stresses the creation of technical assistance programmes for third countries in the field of intellectual property. The competitiveness of the European Union has been supported and will increasingly be based on creativity and innovation, hence the importance of such a report. That is why I voted for it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Own Initiative Report is to contribute to the definition of a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. Recent studies show that IPR-intensive sectors account for around 39% of EU GDP and account for 35% of total employment. However, it is estimated that the EU is losing around €8 billion of its annual GDP as a result of contractand piracy. For this reason, there is an urgent need to define a 'Strategy for the application of intellectual property rights in third countries', as we are facing a key sector for the EU's growth, innovation and industrial competitiveness worldwide. I agree overall with this resolution and underline the need to improve the collection of data on assets held at EU borders, to improve the international IPR framework, especially in the context of the conclusion of bilateral trade agreements (where adequate and efficient protection for protected rights holders should be ensured), as well as the recognition and effective protection of geographical indications, as well as access to the WTO dispute settlement body for cases of breach of IPR.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the rejection of the ACTA (anti-counterfeiting trade agreement) treaty by the European Parliament in July 2012, the European Commission considered a strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries and published a communication laying the groundwork for this strategy in July 2014.  Commercial interests are reflected in maintaining the balance between rights holders and end-users, an issue that remains complex. As such, it is important for the Commission to analyse the possibilities of holding a public debate on the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries. It is also a question of thinking about improving and properly harmonising Member States' IP rights policies that could improve standards of protection and compliance at the international level.  I have therefore supported this report which calls on the Commission to reflect on the very complex issue of the balance between rights holders, economic operators and end-users.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the text presented, as the report calls on the Commission to organise a public, clear and transparent debate on these rights and the consequences that this entails for consumers; to take into account the specific circumstances of each individual third country; It is therefore necessary to harmonize the policies of the Member States, because a common policy can also lead to better legislation at world level.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I consider the fight against infringements of intellectual property rights carried out by third-country companies against the European production system to be of fundamental importance, especially in a globalised market such as the current one.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it calls for a rigorous extension of intellectual property rights standards in third countries, and even appeals to conditionality in this area to establish economic relations with these countries, without regard to the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights often undermine their industrial and development policies. In addition, the report addresses the problem of access to medicines from the perspective of large pharmaceutical companies, turning their backs on people's right to access medicines. The report responds blindly to past experiences such as Ebola in West Africa or hepatitis C in Spain. There is evidence that research into new medicines is often not guided by public health demands, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. Current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs that are really needed.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the indiscriminate use of intellectual property rights as a trade strategy against third countries. The legitimate protection of copyright and quality control of imported products cannot serve as an excuse for the creation of monopolies by large pharmaceutical and industrial multinationals, or for the expropriation of the knowledge and resources of third States and communities: because they have equal right to health, industrial development and scientific knowledge as those of the peoples of Europe.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this motion for a resolution to call on the European Commission to define a new European strategy for the defence and promotion of intellectual property rights (IPR) in third countries. The phenomenon of counterfeiting and piracy is estimated to cause the European Union to lose around EUR 8 billion of GDP every year, with negative effects on growth and employment. In order to protect the creative and innovative efforts of European companies, we must improve cooperation with our partners by implementing the international legislative framework and by promoting a regular exchange of data and information between our companies and the foreign control authorities. I also think that we should extend the services provided by the European IPR Helpdesk outside Europe as well in order to provide useful technical support to economic operators whose PPE is constantly being breached abroad. I therefore hope that the Commission will pay attention to the proposals made by this Parliament for better protection of intellectual property rights.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report reflects the Socialist & Democrats Group’s position that strong IPR protection is important for our creative and manufacturing industries. It emphasises the importance of distinguishing between counterfeit hard goods and pirated online content. This was a key flaw in the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) in 2012 and a reason for its rejection.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the draft strategy. It is essential that we combat all forms of sale of counterfeit goods, but at the same time, intellectual property rights must also be viewed from the point of view of consumers, especially in the pharmaceutical industry and universal access to affordable medicines.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ One of the core priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy is to develop an economy based on knowledge and innovation. I agree that intellectual property rights contribute to the development of innovation and creativity and that protecting them is a key factor for Europe's competitiveness. Europe therefore needs a more ambitious strategy to protect intellectual property rights in relation to its business partners. The debate on a fair balance between the interests of rightholders and end-users is multidimensional and highly complex and characterised by the economic interests of both parties. In my view, an informed and transparent debate is needed on the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights through which it is necessary to define exactly what it would mean for consumers. The requirement for greater stakeholder involvement in the debate on intellectual property rights must be accompanied by measures to ensure transparency for all stakeholders.  I did not support the strategy, inter alia, as it is unclear which resources will be used and where it will be taken from, also taking into account the limited resources available to support European rightholders exporting or setting up operations in third country markets. The strategy does not pay sufficient attention to the difference between physical forgery of trademarks and patents, on the one hand, and copyright infringements, on the other hand, especially in the digital environment.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution because I consider the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries to be a key issue in terms of Europe's competitiveness, and I believe that this strategy will also improve conditions for intellectual property rights in third countries. I consider it very important that we continue to improve the strategy and uncompromisingly highlight infringements of intellectual property rights, which pose certain risks to the health and safety of consumers and to the environment. I am also in favour of protecting together the values created in the EU and in third countries and preventing economic and social consequences for EU businesses and creators. I believe that, thanks to the strategy and the measures taken, we can prevent threats to cultural diversity in Europe and in third countries and help combat organised crime, money laundering and tax evasion. As one of the main points of protection of intellectual property is the proper enforcement of existing legislation and international obligations, including legislation on penalties, I expect better coherence between the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights and other policies, as well as between the Commission and the Member States, as regards the achievement of this objective.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The debate on a fair balance between the interests of rightholders and end-users is multifaceted and extremely complex, as economic interests are on all sides and need to be coordinated. The protection of intellectual property rights in third countries must be seen as a first step which is necessary but still insufficient to establish access to the third country market. The ability to effectively exercise recognised intellectual property rights depends on good protection, including effective enforcement and remedial action in a particular country. The commercial nature of the numerous infringements of intellectual property rights and the involvement of organised crime is becoming a growing problem. I believe that the current strategy does not sufficiently recognise the difference between the physical counterfeiting of trade marks and patents, on the one hand, and copyright infringements, particularly in the digital environment, on the other. Excessive importance is also given to the protection of intellectual property. The principles of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights must also be safeguarded. I believe that the strategy should be more tailored to the digital environment. An informed, balanced and transparent strategy is needed, involving all parties, and private and public interests equally represented. In view of all the shortcomings mentioned in the current strategy, I voted against the adoption of the report on a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as I believe that strengthening intellectual property rights contributes to the development of innovation and creativity. It is necessary to create a strong safeguard framework in combination with effective remedies and to create environments where the interests of Member States and third countries are complementary.  The creation of an appropriately harmonised policy relating to intellectual property rights would lead to improved standards of protection and the implementation of intellectual property rights globally. I am of the opinion that there is a need for transparent public debate in order to better protect private and public interests and to harmonise internal and external policy on intellectual property protection.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Socialist colleagues I voted in favour of this report because it emphasises the importance of distinguishing between counterfeit hard goods and pirated online content. This was a key flaw in the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) in 2012 and a reason for its rejection.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the Strategy for the Protection and Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights in third countries. Better coordination and exchange of information between Member States can provide new opportunities to achieve common objectives on intellectual property protection in third countries. In particular, EU economic operators and consumers in third countries should be protected by extending the intellectual property assistance service.  IP-intensive industries generate around 39% of total economic activity in the EU (worth around EUR 4.7 trillion per year) and around 26% of all employment (56 million jobs). However, since the entry into force of the trade aspects of intellectual property rights (TRIPS), only limited numbers of significant intellectual property contracts have been concluded. Any foreign policy initiative is linked to internal policy and it should therefore be emphasised that the EU needs to think carefully about internal improvements to its IP rules. Related to EU legislation and intra-EU cooperation, adequate coherence between internal IPR policy could help in the effort to improve the standard of protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights globally.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because I welcome greater protection of intellectual property in third countries as a tool for protecting innovation and creative works.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Report on a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries. Over the past decade, we have seen the enormous speed of technological development in fast-growing countries. Given that the customs authorities in the EU detained almost 36 million items in 2013 suspected of infringing intellectual property rights and the fact that one of the priorities of the Europe 2020 strategies is smart growth, knowledge development and an innovation-based economy, I support the Commission's call for greater involvement of stakeholders in the debate on intellectual property rights.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries also because it appropriately complements the report on the road to a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights: the EU Action Plan of which I was rapporteur. Both reports note the irremensibility of intellectual property rights in the pursuit and development of the modern economy of the 21st century. Both reports draw attention well to the need for greater coherence between the rules governing intellectual property rights inside and outside the European Union. Both reports also highlight the need for up-to-date, objective information and the achievement of the broadest possible consensus in the perception of the role of intellectual property rights and the tools needed to enforce them effectively.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Since Parliament sees the safeguarding of intellectual property rights as a first step towards gaining access to third country markets, we could not vote in favour of this report. Our position as both an ESA/BPA and an ACPL is against intellectual property rights, which mainly guarantee the rights of large companies rather than help development in third countries. The speculation of large European pharmaceutical companies to the detriment of public health in developing countries are such examples, and the report does not deal with them under any circumstances.  That is why we voted against the report

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is moving in the right direction. The protection of intellectual property rights is vital for business, trade and the economy in general. They protect trade from transnational organised crime and the health of consumers. However, a more rigorous approach is needed, not mere observations, with regard to transatlantic trade and investment partnerships (TTP) and imports - exports of generic and biosimilar medicines.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the strategy for enforcing intellectual property rights in third countries. I think it is right to push for greater coherence between the protection of intellectual property rights and other policies, as measures to protect intellectual property rights also contribute to the success of the fight against tax fraud and organised crime, which is currently one of the biggest challenges for the Union. In addition, coordinated policies make it possible to improve global standards. At the same time, I agree with the recommendation in the report that there should be a public debate and broad information on the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights and its aspects for consumers. I also find the other suggestions made by the report concerning better reporting, access to medicines and bilateral free trade agreements useful.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. 2012 36 million counterfeit items were seized at European borders worth more than 760 million euros. These products violate intellectual property rights pose a danger to the health and safety of consumers, the environment and the economy. This traffic also steals the employment of 100,000 Europeans and strikes many SMEs. That is why Parliament voted today in favour of the European Action Plan against Counterfeiting and proposes some additional ways to combat fraud. In terms of numbers, the shortfall of 470 million euros per year and the 100,000 jobs prevented by this shadow economy reveal the scale of the problem. In 2013, 36 million items were seized, 10% of them medicines, but also toys, cosmetics. It is wrong to believe that counterfeiting only affects luxury goods, consumer products are widely affected by the phenomenon.   Finally, I would like to stress the crucial importance of involving all the stakeholders concerned with the subject of intellectual property and possible future legislation: citizens, NGOs, artists, creators, SMEs, associations and not just multinationals as was the case for the now defunct ACTA.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that intellectual property rights must be fully protected in order to provide them with as safe an investment environment as possible. The placement of own products with the aim of finding a trajectory in the international economy needs to be facilitated, not further complicated by the regulation, in order to protect the interests of rightholders, but also ultimately to stimulate the innovation and creativity that are today the main wheel of development and economic growth.  I also agree that further efforts are needed to establish a satisfactory legislative framework in third countries that will not only protect companies entering their markets, but also ensure the development of domestic production through the establishment of trade trust and equal rights for all.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries was supported. Exactly two years after acte's rejection, in July 2014, the Commission published a notice on the basics of the EU strategy for the protection of intellectual property rights in third countries. It would certainly be helpful to unify the arrangements for intellectual property rights within the EU. This would make it easier to protect those rights vis-à-vis third countries. According to the latest statistics from 2012, there were as many as 90,000 such violations. It is necessary to ensure a fair balance between the interests of rightholders and end-users. A separate divorce, taking into account the specific circumstances, should be distinguished between developing countries. I am thinking here, in particular, of China.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it calls for a rigorous extension of intellectual property rights standards in third countries, and even calls for conditionality in this area to establish economic relations with these countries, without regard to the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights often undermine their industrial and development policies. In addition, the report addresses the problem of access to medicines from the perspective of large pharmaceutical companies, turning their backs on people's right to access them. The report responds blindly to past experiences such as Ebola in West Africa or hepatitis C in Spain. There is evidence that research into new medicines is often not guided by public health demands, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. Current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs that are really needed.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. I agree with the incentive to better defend intellectual property rights and combat counterfeiting through legal procedures. But the general content of the report reduces the sovereignty of Member States by drawing a desire to strengthen: - on the one hand, the integration of international standards, agreements (WTO) and the resulting obligations and mechanisms (such as a dispute settlement mechanism) in the field of IPRs; - on the other hand, European integration in this area through enhanced cooperation and led by the Commission from the perspective of the relationship between the Union, beyond the Member States, and third countries.  So I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU Action Plan on Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), as they are one of the main driving forces of innovation and creativity and contribute significantly to competitiveness, job creation and cultural diversity. At the moment, EU states are facing an alarming number of violations of these rights, causing moral and economic damage to European businesses, causing considerable economic and fiscal losses for states. In my opinion, it is extremely important that, both online and offline, all actors in the supply chain are involved in actions to combat IPR infringement - including rights creators and holders, producers, intermediaries, internet service providers, online sales platforms, end-users and public authorities. These actions, together with an increase in the exchange of information between customs authorities, would improve the business environment and help prevent market access for goods and services infringing IPR. It would be a major support for European SMEs and would contribute to job growth.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because it calls for a rigorous extension of intellectual property rights standards in third countries, and even calls for conditionality in this area to establish economic relations with these countries, without regard to the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights often undermine their industrial and development policies. In addition, the report addresses the problem of access to medicines from the perspective of large pharmaceutical companies, turning their backs on people's right to access them. The report responds blindly to past experiences such as Ebola in West Africa or hepatitis C in Spain. There is evidence that research into new medicines is often not guided by public health demands, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. Current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs that are really needed.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries, as we need a legal framework for intellectual property rights holders. The protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights is a very important step to take but not the only one, since further assistance should be considered for developing countries wishing to improve their intellectual property rights systems. Thanks to this report the EU can now protect efficiently its creative industries and jobs, especially if it is combined with further support of institutions such as the European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the communication presented by the European Commission in July 2014, it was necessary for this Parliament to express its opinion through the report discussed in the INTA Commission which reflects key points in this matter. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the indiscriminate use of intellectual property rights as a trade strategy against third countries. The legitimate protection of copyright and quality control of imported products cannot serve as an excuse for the creation of monopolies by large pharmaceutical and industrial multinationals, or for the expropriation of the knowledge and resources of third States and communities: because they have equal right to health, industrial development and scientific knowledge as those of the peoples of Europe.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Socialist colleagues I voted in favour of this report because it emphasises the importance of distinguishing between counterfeit hard goods and pirated online content. This was a key flaw in the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) in 2012 and a reason for its rejection.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The protection of intellectual property rights (IPRs) is necessary in particular to protect the work of artists and avoid counterfeiting. However, particularly in the case of trade with the countries of the South, IPRs serve as a pretext to maintain dominance over these countries.  At a time when the public interest in access to knowledge, health, technology and natural resources should be emphasized, IPRs are being used to maintain monopolies, such as those of pharmaceutical companies, that serve their profits before the public interest. Moreover, it is as if the countries of the North and the countries of the South are equal in the economic and political balance of power, which can only disadvantage the countries of the South, whose IPRs are not as protected as ours.  I voted against this report because I oppose intellectual property of domination and hegemony.  With this vote, the European Parliament seems to forget that it has largely rejected the ACTA agreement on counterfeiting.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. In my opinion, the report contains a sensible strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries. The report calls for further efforts to ensure that the interests of authors and consumers are balanced.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Intellectual property rights contribute to the development of innovation and creativity, and their protection is an essential element for the EU's competitiveness. In the context that the EU needs an ambitious strategy on the protection of intellectual property rights in relation to its trading partners, I welcome the adoption in the European Parliament of the Own-Initiative Report on the Strategy for the Protection and Implementation of Intellectual Property Rights in Third Countries. I voted for this report, while also appreciating the Commission's approach in this area.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Intellectual property rights (IPR) sectors in the EU generate around 39% of total economic activity worth around €4 700 billion per year and approximately 26% of total employment with 56 million jobs. However, few major agreements have been concluded since the entry into force of the International Agreement on the Commercial Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS, 1/1/1995), despite technological and social changes we have transformed the landscape of intellectual property rights. However, there are problems in the report with regard to the issue of IPR and the standards that should also apply to third countries, both in terms of controlling the liability of intermediaries and in terms of managing piracy in the subsidiaries of European companies in those countries. In addition, reference is made several times to the Commission's increased support for European pharmaceutical companies which then sell generic medicines in third countries. For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report on the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries. The report responds to the Commission communication 'Trade, growth and intellectual property'. Firstly, I welcome the Commission's initiative: we should be aware of the way in which the approach taken when the ACTA Agreement was not ratified needs to be drastically reviewed. I also believe that the report addresses the issue of generic medicines in a timely manner, bearing in mind that it is important to encourage the production of generic medicines without, at the same time, excessively penalising pharmaceutical research.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – Reports on the enforcement of copyright both within the EU and in its relations with third countries concern the safeguarding of the interests of business groups, not only in the so-called entertainment industry, but also in those active in the pharmaceutical sector, industry, information technology, etc. , patents for medicines, industrial products, etc., to the detriment of the peoples who have to pay for their medicines, the enjoyment of artistic creations, information and other life-critical goods, which had to be public and free without business action. The authors of works, patents, etc. are not only not protected, but their exploitation is intensified by strengthening the system of so-called "intellectual property rights" in companies that acquire these rights and exploit them when they do not own them. The abolition of the exploitative system is a prerequisite for developing at the highest level the creative, scientific and technological possibilities that exist today, for workers to enjoy freely the achievements of human creation in all areas of their lives.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, it is necessary to be aware of the danger resulting from the purchase of goods that infringe intellectual property rights. I would suggest further promoting to consumers the risks that people in third countries have to take. Due to digitalisation, infringements of intellectual property rights have multiplied many times, mainly due to increasing online sales. A clear use would be to adopt a more effective tool for controlling online sales of physical products. Against this in mind, I fully support the EU Action Plan on intellectual property rights in third countries.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ Just as I supported the new European Action Plan for the Protection of Intellectual Property Rights, I also voted in favour of the proposal on the protection of intellectual property in third countries. At the same time, we support the creativity and innovation of its creators through the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights. In the resolution, we called for greater assistance to third countries in establishing a legal framework for the protection of intellectual property, as well as in ensuring a balance between the interests of authors and consumers, especially in the digital sphere. Given that the proposal is not only intended to protect companies from the Member States of the European Union, but also domestic companies, and to the overall promotion of innovation in third countries, I believe that it will be positively reflected.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution clearly defends the interests of European industry which exports to – or settles in – markets in the poorest countries. The latter require the material protection of Europeans, unless they do not export or settle on the markets of those countries.  The resolution calls for the protection of Intellectual Property Rights in the framework of the TTIP negotiations, thus legitimizing it, as well as its instruments and objectives. As you would expect, it makes it a model for all other free trade agreements.  The resolution discriminates against the populations of the poorest countries in access to health care, justifying the need to take into account 'market distortions caused by the resale of medicines' in those countries. The clear option is to safeguard the interests of the pharmaceutical industry to the detriment of the concrete need for often urgent access to essential health goods.  The resolution makes the 'granting of market economy status' dependent on the poorest countries protection of european interests and subjectthe freedom of trade to that protection, to the ratification of WIPO treaties on trade mark law, benefits and phonograms and copyright, unless there is no foreign investment in those countries.  We voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI).
text: Madam President, I voted against this European Union action plan reforming intellectual property law. This report foreshadows the reform of the so-called InfoSoc directive of 2001. Debates in the Committee on Legal Affairs showed that these provisions were inadequate. We can see that the reality of the digital world is not easily adapted to the European legislative process. This reform is part of a process of harmonization that we are fighting. The means you devote to achieving your libertarian goals quickly become obsolete when they come into force.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the 2004 Directive on the enforcement of intellectual property rights was an important step towards harmonising national legislation in order to ensure uniform and uniform protection of intellectual property and to help fight counterfeiting, patent protection and copyright in the single market.  Given the high number of cases of infringement of intellectual property rights at EU level and the resulting damages, and given the importance of innovation and new technologies for the development and competitiveness of the European Union, I supported this report and further efforts by the European Commission to strengthen intellectual property protection through the implementation of the new action plan, but also to facilitate the application of the rules still defined at Member State level by undertakings and innovators.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I voted with my group on this proposal, and it was easy to do. It was a non-controversial, but nevertheless very important, report, particularly the title: ‘An action plan’. If you have no plan, you cannot go anywhere, but you also need action to implement the plan. In my work in the last couple of years as the rapporteur on the Data Protection Regulation for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), I constantly came across, in particular, artists, SMEs and publishing companies who were very concerned about their intellectual property rights (IPR), especially nowadays in the online world. That is certainly something we need to be aware of and to address. I would like to emphasise here the importance of getting public support for this and creating public awareness regarding the consequences not only for the economy – and, as our comrade Ms Maletić pointed out, it is costing us EUR 8 billion per year – but also for the creativity of artists and their livelihoods. That is something we have to guard against. I also welcome the establishment of an expert working group to monitor online infringement of IPR.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the Svoboda dossier, entitled 'Towards a renewed consensus on respect for intellectual property rights: The European Union's action plan', was negative. This is because, although there are some correct and acceptable passages, such as the recognition of the importance of intellectual property rights, both as regards authors and creators and to stimulate innovation, as well as the role played by organised crime in counterfeiting activities and the 'follow the money' principle, the report presents several critical issues.  In particular, I felt that the approach taken was completely wrong: it cannot be considered that, in an increasingly digital and global reality, intellectual property rights should only be protected through very strict application. This is likely to have negative effects which are opposite to those we are aiming for. Other aspects that led me to vote against were those concerning: the total condemnation of the activities of certain platforms, the responsibility of intermediaries, as well as the legitimization of certain activities, such as the blocking of websites and the removal of content, by simple public authorities and not by the judiciary, the only person entitled to balance the various rights at stake.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this report contains some positive elements, such as the protection of fundamental rights in the online field, it still does not clearly distinguish between those regulations necessary to maintain industrial activity or remuneration worthy of cultural creation and those that de facto signify a restriction of access to basic rights such as information, health, art or economic development. These ambiguities, characteristic of the European IPR agenda, must be clarified as a precondition for a genuine political debate on these issues. For all this, I abstained.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I have voted against this report because it is going in the wrong direction. As far as the Greens are aware, we have proposed wordings that, among other things, different rights need to be balanced against each other and stressed the importance of proportionality and legal certainty. Some of this has also been included in the text, but the report as a whole is problematic. In particular, it pushes for a system that violates the principle of messenger neutrality and where internet service providers are supposed to monitor private mail and internet traffic.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The Commission presented ten points last July under the EU Action Plan on Intellectual Property Rights. Among other things, new and more effective enforcement tools will be created. In particular, the aim is to prevent interference with intellectual property rights by preventing injuries from becoming profitable – a so-called "follow-the-money" approach. There will also be measures in SMEs, in particular with regard to the enforcement of infringements of intellectual property rights. In addition, there will be information campaigns to draw the attention of the population, and especially the younger generation, to the issue. I support these measures and a clear and comprehensive EU strategy on the protection of intellectual property rights.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Since 1957, numerous ip directives have been adopted to facilitate the establishment of a single market and thereby reduce differences between Member States' rights in this area. This report aims to reform copyright and in particular the "INFOSOC" directive dating back to 2001. The balance sheet of this directive is generally negative. I defend the preservation of the French conception of copyright, even if it must necessarily adapt to the information society. A possible liability of ISPs would be a avenue to explore. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, because this report proposes greater European Union involvement in the enforcement of intellectual property rights. In particular, I oppose the second half of paragraph 57 of the report. I was astonished that there were no speakers scheduled for this debate, but I did contribute to the catch-the-eye session. A debate with just a handful of MEPs present is not much of a debate.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because in a context of technological development, increasingly globalised and online trade, the European Union needed to develop a new arsenal to combat infringements of intellectual property rights within the Union. Indeed, in order to deal effectively with intellectual property issues in third countries, the rules within the European Union must also be better coordinated. The action plan focuses on measures related to commercial offences and a public awareness campaign (especially young people) about the consequences of these offences.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Intellectual property rights (IPRs) held by European Union companies (essentially trademarks, designs, copyrights and trade secrets) are frequently infringed on a commercial scale. In addition to counterfeiting and illegal downloading of films and music, these include cases of infringement of patents and designs, as well as theft of trade secrets. With this report, we therefore want the European Union to focus on strengthening IPRs in relation to commercial-scale violations and stress that private consumers and users should not be criminalised. We support the idea of organizing prevention campaigns for consumers on the costs and consequences of IPR violations. We also insist on respect for fundamental rights.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. The report on intellectual property rights: an action plan for the EU seems ineffective in its operation and critical of its aims. The draft initially submitted to the European Parliament was purely and simply a declaration of intent and was therefore ineffective. I am dubious about certain provisions in relation to the consequences of the INFOSOC Directive of 2001. As a defender of France's interests, I am very committed to the preservation of the French model with regard to copyright, especially in its moral aspect. A line of thought would be a possible liability of ISPs. For all these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I find Mr Svoboda's own-initiative report balanced and acceptable, which is why I supported it with my vote. I believe that a European action plan to protect intellectual property rights more effectively is necessary to coordinate all Member States in the fight against infringement. We have a duty to protect all our companies from the damage done to them by the violation of property rights.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The report seeks to strengthen intellectual property rights in a way that further increases the control of large companies in this area. The report argues, among other things, for artists and artists' right to protect their works. That is something I also support, but I do not believe that strengthening the intellectual property rights of large companies will improve copyright.   The report also speaks very positively about the work of the European Observatory, despite its criticism by many citizens and ngos for their unilateral focus on protecting the interests of companies. The fact that the report has fine wording on fundamental rights is positive, but it does not change the whole. That is why I am voting against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. During the past decade, there have been significant changes in the area of IPRs: substantial technological changes related to the Internet, increasing importance of emerging economies, challenges in access to medicines, and an increasing level of IPR violations, among others. I support this action plan presented by the Commission as it is right to concentrate efforts on preventive actions and policy tools aimed at depriving commercial-scale infringers of their income and making it difficult to market property that infringes intellectual property. Support for SMEs and individual creators, who play a key role in the creative and cultural sectors and often do not have the necessary capacities to respect their rights, is essential.  The report, which I supported with my vote, further stresses the importance of ensuring the implementation of due diligence throughout the supply chain, including the digital supply chain, and involving all key actors and operators, such as creators, artists and rights holders, producers, intermediaries, internet service providers, online sales platforms, end users and public authorities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is a statement by Parliament on an EU Action Plan to renegotiate the enforcement of intellectual property rights. The resolution notes that the EU is facing frequent infringements of intellectual property rights and that the extent and cost of these infringements are of concern, as reported by the Commission in its report on the application of the Directive on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. These figures also show the importance of intellectual property rights in the European economy in competition at global level, including infringements of intellectual property rights, including counterfeiting, halting growth, job creation, innovation and creativity, moral and economic damage to European businesses and serious economic and financial losses for states. Parliament therefore stressed the need for transparency and access to information by the public and all other stakeholders in order to ensure innovation, creativity and competitiveness. In its resolution, Parliament also called for attention to be drawn to the fact that, during the financial crisis, when financial support for the cultural sector was significantly reduced, intellectual property rights developers were often the main source of income. He therefore stressed that ensuring fair remuneration for creators should be one of the key aspects of the EU Action Plan.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed report for similar reasons as the Report on Intellectual Property Rights in third countries. Infringements of intellectual property rights and counterfeiting hinder growth, job creation, innovation and creativity, causing both intangible and economic damage to European businesses. Countries also suffer damage, as this causes them significant economic and fiscal losses. It is therefore necessary to strengthen controls on the online sale of goods, as more and more counterfeit physical goods are sold through online markets. The authorities of the Member States have limited possibilities to control sales, and the need to involve market platform owners in their efforts to combat infringements of intellectual property rights is necessary. The latter must engage in efforts to remove counterfeit goods from their platforms and prohibit sellers of those goods from using them. I would also like to highlight the cultural and creative sector, where intellectual property rights are often used very intensively. These sectors, however, generate around 4.5% of GDP and employ up to 8.5 million people in the EU. They are therefore essential for ensuring cultural diversity and make an important contribution to social and economic development. However, inadequate protection of intellectual property rights can make a profound difference to this picture. I also agree that intellectual property rights continue to be regarded as an important factor in the competitiveness of the European economy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. In July 2014, the European Commission adopted a road plan for the regulation of intellectual property rights. I welcome the part of the report concerning SMEs by requiring lower administrative burdens. However, I believe that consumer criminalisation is too harsh a measure and that awareness of the importance of intellectual rights needs to be addressed.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'yes' to this resolution because I believe that the effective application of intellectual property rights plays a key role in stimulating innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution tabled by my colleague Pavel Svoboda is to be supported because it continues correctly in the logic of allowing the participation of all those in the supply chain both online and offline, in insisting on the awareness and correct information of consumers and in reaffirming the centrality of SMEs and the need to develop coherently a new business model, consolidating their work and production , complementing the continued work of the European Monitoring Centre on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights and setting up a group of experts on the IPR, which will compare the work in place in line with the evolution of the current legal framework, while comparing itself with the needs arising from international supply chains, the role of Union customs and international cooperation agreements. Alongside this, we agree with the emphasis on the importance of regular analyses of the factors that drive SMEs to make use of IPR or not, in order to understand how improvements can be made, whether they are innovative SMEs or traditional SMEs experiencing problems, in terms of the exercise of the relevant PPE; In addition, in the cultural and creative sectors, payment service providers need to be involved in the dialogue in order to reduce profits from online IPR breaches.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on intellectual property rights: an EU action plan. New technologies are increasing information exchanges with an increase in the number of recipients and the distance between them. This requires reflection that should lead to adequate protection of intellectual property rights. That is why we must be careful when the Union addresses this subject, in particular by linking it to the opaque negotiations of the transatlantic treaty. Thus, it is preferable to focus on concrete measures. To do this, we need to reflect on the responsibility of those who play an important role in disseminating information, namely ISPs.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report "Towards a new consensus on enforcement of intellectual property rights: an EU action plan" put to the vote today is an extremely important report for the EU, especially since Member States now need more than ever the support of innovation and creativity in order to remain competitive on the world market. I voted in favour of this report, which adds value to the process of creating effective and coordinated collaboration at national, European and global level, with the aim of combating infringement of intellectual property rights in the European Union. The European Union has generated and must continue to generate policies against counterfeiting of any products with a view to increasing its competitiveness in the market. It must also raise consumer, employee and customer awareness of the economic damage caused by the infringement of intellectual property rights on a commercial scale. Last but not least, experts from all Member States play a key role in the exchange of best practices between Member States' authorities, in seeking to strengthen and promote the EU Action Plan on all efforts to support creativity and innovation.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I agree with the need to better coordinate the activities of the Member States in what is a fight to be carried out, especially at transnational level. The text is also acceptable in its references to the problems of SMEs.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Counterfeiting poses a threat to the economy as well as to the health and safety of consumers. It is therefore more necessary than ever to deal effectively with intellectual property issues. The international context requires increased coordination within the UNION to deal more effectively with these issues in third countries. With this in mind, the report aims to raise awareness among young consumers about new digital issues, prevent potential online counterfeiting abuses and help SMEs enforce their intellectual property rights. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on 'Towards a renewed consensus on respect for intellectual property rights: European Union action plan'. Intellectual property rights form the basis of the development of European and international civilisation and cover many areas, from scientific, literary and artistic production to the authenticity of medicinal and food products. In short, they are a fundamental element of innovation and creativity and also make an important contribution to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity.   I therefore voted in favour of this report which, through preventive actions and strategic instruments, aims to ensure respect for intellectual property rights and to make it more difficult to place counterfeit goods on the market.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are some positive elements throughout the text, particularly the reference to fundamental rights and fair trials and the promotion of cultural diversity. However, there was there no mention in the report of the unfair treatment of upcoming artists and creators, and the immense dominance of large rights holders management companies or publishers who profit substantially from an intellectual property rights (IPR) enforcement frame. Many struggling artists have themselves complained about the dominance and unfair treatment from the big rights holder companies. Moreover, the report confers a lot of praise on the IPR Observatory, which itself has been under immense criticism from digital rights NGOs and citizens because of its lack of objectivity and its inclination to side with the big firms and right holders management companies. It was for these reasons that I abstained on this vote.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principal thrust of this own-initiative report is that there should be a significant ramping up of, and extension of, powers over the system of enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR). Although it asserts that prime responsibility for IPR enforcement rests with each Member State’s public authorities, we already have a European Patent Court, thus suggesting that the EU does not view Member States as the best vector for such enforcement.  In any event, this will lead to legislation. UKIP is opposed to EU legislation, hence I voted against this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Intellectual property rights (IPRs) are a key driver for growth and innovation, and businesses relay on the protection of IPRs. I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the parameters set forward in this report in order for adequate protection against counterfeiting on a commercial scale to be established. In its Communication the Commission presented a 10 point action plan on the enforcement of IPRs, notably on the fight against commercial infringements of IPRs. It proposes new enforcement rules and develops issues such as assistance to SMEs, raising the awareness of consumers, employees and clients, and ensuring the integrity of supply chains.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, in support of the approach proposed by the Commission, has very positive aspects, such as the recognition of the need to help small and medium-sized enterprises to assert intellectual property rights. At the same time, however, there are some critical issues related to the exclusive responsibility of national state authorities in the management of the system of property rights and the criminalisation of Internet intermediaries with regard to aiding infringements of property rights - which could result in a limitation of the dissemination by means of the same of content that should be usable. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Pavel Svoboda's report entitled 'Intellectual property rights: an EU action plan'.  The protection of intellectual property rights determines the future of our European companies, the sustainability of our know-how and that of our jobs.  As such, the fight against commercial counterfeiting of content protected by these rights must be at the heart of our concerns and involve all stakeholders in the digital ecosystem. Offenders are becoming increasingly daring and take advantage of new technologies to get their counterfeit products to be transported via the Internet, which makes it sometimes very difficult to capture counterfeits.  I believe that Mr Svoboda's report is moving in the right direction, in particular by involving all the players in the supply chain through a duty of care. I also appreciate in this report the attention paid to public awareness of respect for intellectual property rights and the promotion of legal online offerings. In this time of crisis, we may need to have our citizens measure the impact of piracy and counterfeiting on value added in a globalized economy, and the destruction of jobs they induce.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I have chosen to oppose this report, which continues the process of harmonising copyright at European level following the logic of European integration and the establishment of a European single market. This type of standardisation process, in addition to being harmful to national specificities that are often more protective of freedoms than European provisions, such as the "moral right" aspect of the French conception of copyright - can also be dangerous in terms of protecting consumer freedoms.  Thus, in the field, the transposition into national law of the InfoSoc directive in 2001 led, in France, to the HADOPI law: the "creation and internet law" was thus aimed at protecting copyrighted content circulating on the Internet. It has resulted in an expenditure of almost 12 million euros for the French state. In addition to being costly, such measures threaten the digital freedoms of citizens.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Intellectual property plays a leading role throughout the life cycle of research and innovation projects in the European 2020 strategy. With Horizon 2020, the European Union aims to strengthen Europe's technological and scientific base, supporting industrial innovation at all levels, from basic research to the creation and marketing of products and processes. We see, however, that intellectual property rights still tend to be protected more by national legislation than by European legislation. Instead, it would save time and money by protecting intellectual property at EU level. In this way, innovations and creations would be protected throughout Europe and could become a source of income. I therefore believe that the European Union must defend intellectual property, in order to guarantee adequate means of protection in the event of infringements, so as to be a model for all EU Member States. Finally, I believe that we must create an efficient system of repression in the event of a violation of these rights so that the resources that the EU will invest in this project are not lost. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP motion for a resolution on the EU Action Plan for the Protection of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR). These rights, the protection of which is recognised by Article 118 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 17 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, make a decisive contribution to competitiveness and employment and are of particular importance to SMEs. However, PPE is subject to numerous violations.
