To this end, the European Commission has drawn up an action plan, set up an Observatory for Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights and is committed to promoting consumer awareness campaigns. The protection of IPR must be guaranteed by the Member States and they must cooperate to this end.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report outlining an action plan based on the follow-the-money approach, as I believe that the protection of intellectual property rights is one of the strongest driving forces for innovation and creativity, as well as for the development of healthy competitiveness. This protection triggers a virtuous circle which results in greater employment and a positive enhancement of cultural diversity. Protecting these rights is also a sine qua non for the development of the digital economy and the digital single market, where the boundaries of these rights are still often confused and ignored by most. It should not be forgotten that ensuring such protection helps to strengthen fundamental aspects such as consumer safety and health. In addition to the pursuit of protection objectives, I hope that this plan will raise awareness among European citizens of the seriousness of the violation of these rights, which is often tolerated or even considered physiological.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Action Plan because, in the face of booming online commerce, growing e-commerce and rapid technological development, we need better standards to better protect intellectual property rights. Counterfeiting and duplicates are not cavalier offences. In this sense, the EU should play a pioneering role.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as intellectual property rights (IPR) are one of the driving forces of innovation and creativity and make a decisive contribution to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity. In addition, compliance with PPE plays a key role in ensuring the health and safety of consumers. Unfortunately, especially the cultural and creative sectors, which account for 4.5% of GDP, are subject to a large number of IPR breaches, with strong repercussions on many SMEs and business-to-business services, causing market losses and bankruptcy.  It is necessary to activate a strategy that includes: collaboration between rightholders, platform operators, intermediaries and end users; consolidate audit measures and apply the follow-the-money principle to protect consumers and the supply chain; inform consumers and specifically young people about PPE and what can and cannot be done with protected goods and content; and, finally, to encourage industry to place on the market diversified, more accessible and legal products in order to meet consumer demand.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The ability to create and innovate is fundamentally important, enabling stakeholders to be effective contributors to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity – elements which constantly assist our economies to face challenges. Intellectual property rights are essential if we are to continue to promote creativity and innovation, and the enforcement of such rights is necessary not only to protect creators but also to ensure that consumers are protected from fraud. The measures reflected in this report will continue to make enforcement more effective, so I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Svoboda report represents Parliament's reaction to the Commission communication of 10 July 2014 presenting an action plan on respect for intellectual property rights in which the Commission supports an approach based on preventive actions and strategic instruments aimed at depriving offenders on a commercial scale of revenue flows and making it more difficult to place counterfeit goods on the market. The Svoboda report supports the approach proposed by the Commission in its communication. It stresses the need to encourage the participation of all actors in the supply chain, to support targeted information campaigns and considers it necessary to support SMEs in protecting and enforcing their intellectual property rights. There are, however, some elements that run counter to the positions held with regard to intellectual property by the M5S, such as the reference to the exclusive responsibility of national authorities with regard to compliance with PPE or the criminalisation of Internet intermediaries with regard to aiding IPR infringements. For the reasons given, I voted against.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this report contains some positive elements, such as the protection of fundamental rights in the online field, it still does not clearly distinguish between those regulations necessary to maintain industrial activity or remuneration worthy of cultural creation and those that de facto signify a restriction of access to basic rights such as information, health, art or economic development. These ambiguities, characteristic of the European IPR agenda, must be clarified as a precondition for a genuine political debate on these issues. For all this, I abstained.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted calls on the Commission to provide the Commission with new and more effective tools to tackle counterfeiting, the sale of counterfeit products through online platforms. This is unfortunately a common practice, which does so much damage to our businesses and to our research. A billionaire turnover which, not by chance, is increasingly attracting the attention and involvement of organised crime in third countries. The S&D Group has helped to improve the proposal, through a number of points such as the need to prioritise the application of intellectual property rights over commercial infringements, rather than simply criminalising private consumers and users. Furthermore, on the consumer side, act instead through the development and dissemination of awareness-raising campaigns, on the costs and consequences of infringements of intellectual property rights, on our businesses and on our workers. The report is very balanced and is heading in the right direction. We are now calling on the Commission to act quickly and to respond to our production system and to protect it by taking concrete action.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report comes as a response to the Commission communication regarding a future EU action plan for intellectual property rights (IPR) enforcement. It focuses mostly on supporting SMEs in enforcing their intellectual property rights, reducing administrative burdens, developing mechanisms for countering infringements, involving all stakeholders, and international cooperation. The report sets out to protect the work of individuals in developing methods and practices which are unique, and I believe that such efforts need to be protected, as they enrich and improve Europe’s economic performance.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the cultural and creative industries of the European Union are a driving force for social and economic development, as well as for job creation in Europe, and is brought about by creators, designers and institutions that rely on copyright exceptions and limitations. In this context, I believe that future legislative initiatives to modernise copyright should be based on independent evidence of the impact on growth and jobs, especially when it comes to SMEs in the cultural and creative sectors with regard to access to knowledge and culture, but also the possible costs and benefits.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report follows on from the European Commission's action plan to create an effective IP policy at European and national levels. The report broadly supports the Commission's approach, including the need to protect intellectual property rights, the need to organise awareness campaigns among end-users and European citizens, the role of rights holders and the need for an intellectual property strategy including a legal framework adapted to internet developments. Supporting this constructive approach, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament supports the Commission's policy of protecting intellectual property rights (IPR), particularly in the area of e-commerce. Cultural and creative industries account for 4.5% of the EU's gross domestic product, as well as 8.5 million jobs. Those are not insignificant numbers; it is therefore necessary to raise awareness among all citizens, let alone young people, of the importance of respecting IPRs and promoting legal online content. IPRs maintain high standards of consumer, public health and environmental protection in the domestic market.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Effective application of intellectual property rights is essential for the innovation and competitiveness of our businesses as well as job creation. The Commission's current approach does not make a clear enough distinction between physical and digital copyright infringements. That is why the European Union needs a comprehensive IPR strategy, which includes a comprehensive and robust legal framework for the fight against counterfeiting and piracy, and which is in line with the digital age.  This includes increasing legal and affordable offers. This response must be a step towards the European Digital Single Market.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I also voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's intellectual property rights action plan. The European Union must have a comprehensive legal framework, adapted to the online environment, to combat infringements of intellectual property rights within the Union.  More and more websites are selling counterfeit or plagiarized products. Frequent seizures and high-profile operations to destroy counterfeit products attest to this. The Commission and EU Member States must, in collaboration with online sales platforms, identify the best way to detect and combat the marketing of counterfeits. The addition of an anti-counterfeiting protocol to the UN Convention against Transnational Organized Crime could also be a useful initiative, as could the organization of awareness campaigns on the consequences of intellectual property rights violations for society as a whole, and for consumers and citizens in particular.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, including a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is absolutely imperative that we as legislators provide all possible support to new and existing businesses in order to protect intellectual property. This is particularly important for enterprises in the creative and cultural industries, which in many EU regions, including my own Northern Ireland, have witnessed a boom and experienced growth in recent years. In our region of the United Kingdom, specialist advisors from Invest Northern Ireland – through the Department of Enterprise – provide businesses with up-to-date help on patents, trademarks, designs and copyright. It is crucial that new enterprises and entrepreneurs have access to financial assistance to secure IPR and thus underwrite their innovative ideas and projects.  However this report rightly stresses that raising awareness must not stop with businesses. Consumers too must be the subject of information campaigns to deter copyright infringements, counterfeiting and the sale of illicit products in the single market. Only when this holistic approach is taken can prospective entrepreneurs have the maximum confidence to enter the market and aid growth in national economies.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on intellectual property rights: an EU action plan. New technologies are increasing information exchanges with an increase in the number of recipients and the distance between them. This requires reflection that should lead to adequate protection of intellectual property rights. Caution should be exercised when the Union addresses this issue, in particular by linking it to the opaque TTIP negotiations. Thus, it is preferable to focus on concrete measures. To do this, we need to reflect on the responsibility of those who play an important role in disseminating information: ISPs.

name: Angel Dzhambazki (ECR)
text: in writing. – I greatly welcome the action plan initiative. It is essential to have a strong enforcement mechanism throughout the EU, and especially in countries dealing with combating counterfeit trade intensively on a daily basis whilst lacking the proper support and resources. Bulgaria is one of those countries and we see that the consequences include not only damage to our and the European economy, but also consumer insecurity, child labour, issues of security, etc. Therefore, the EC proposal is a valuable step forward to strengthening local resources and combating counterfeit goods and intellectual property rights (IPR) infringements more strategically and efficiently. After all, a legal framework is only effective if it is properly enforced.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. As the only Spanish MEP to hold the JURI Commission, I am aware of the importance of this issue, which I have followed, and therefore voted in favour of the report. Violations of intellectual property rights, especially counterfeiting, harm growth, job creation, innovation and creativity. Intellectual property rights are one of the driving forces of innovation and creativity, competitiveness, and cultural diversity. Law enforcement is critical to the predictability of legislation, and it is essential to find effective, proportionate and dissuasive means of respecting intellectual property rights at the cross-border level. Improving civil procedures for the protection of intellectual property would be a benefit for SMEs and all individual creators, as SMEs play a key role in the creative and cultural sectors. The Commission should adopt a clear strategy in this area, including a comprehensive legal framework to combat infringements of intellectual property rights that is adapted to the internet environment, in full respect of fundamental rights and freedoms, the principle of proportionality and data protection.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technological evolution has drastically transformed the way intellectual property rights are applied. Despite this, few agreements have been concluded since the entry into force of the International Agreement on the Commercial Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights in 1994. Although I agree with the initiatives promoted by the rapporteur, who largely accepts the Commission's guidelines, I voted against it. The Svoboda report, although it emphasises the importance of promoting information campaigns, which aim to protect by informing small and medium-sized enterprises, contains elements that are not in line with the positions of the M5S, such as the removal of content without prior authorisation by the judicial authority and the criminalisation of Internet intermediaries, in the event that it is found to facilitate infringements of intellectual property rights.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Action Plan focuses primarily on responding to trade-scale violations and raising citizens' awareness of the intellectual property problem. An effective campaign is needed, especially among the younger generation, involving the criminalization of the individual user. Another aspect that deserves my agreement is the need to support small and medium-sized enterprises in the field of the application of their rights.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, because I do not understand that the European Commission can take charge of the issue of intellectual property law and arrogate itself exclusively the right to legislate in this area.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an own-initiative report on the application of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), addressing economic, social and health issues. The report is vast in its content. If some general principles can be supported, in particular with regard to the remuneration of artists (copyright – an integral part of intellectual property), other aspects cannot be supported: for example, the proposal for operators to exchange information between them to prevent the infringement of intellectual property rights as early as possible. We have tabled in the National Parliament a proposal on sharing, an innovative proposal, not only at national level but even at European level. This report, despite talking about internet operators and the "follow the money" strategy, does not go as far as it could and should, and merely urges operators to reduce profits made on the basis of sharing. Now, we propose the tax of the operators, which is undoubtedly something different. The report also calls on operators to find ways to ban access to websites and to prevent content from being available in more permanent ways than we do today (which is the opposite of what we propose), which is why we cannot support this report.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of paragraph 17 split vote No 1 because it stresses the importance of sector-based agreements and good practice guides to combat intellectual property rights (IPR) infringements

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The enforcement of intellectual property rights is not only an important factor for stable growth and increased employment in the European Union, but also for the proper functioning and completion of the single market idea. It is for these reasons that I welcome the action plan on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. Although the main responsibility for the enforcement of intellectual property rights lies with the public authorities of individual Member States, the European Union must become more actively involved and contribute with its action plan to more effective enforcement of intellectual property rights through preventive activities and policy instruments. This action plan is extremely important because we must not forget the fact that, at a time of economic and financial crisis and at a time of significant cuts in the areas of culture, income from intellectual property rights is often the main financial resource for individual creators. In order to establish a system of effective and effective control of the enforcement of intellectual property rights, it is necessary for the European Commission to work closely and intensively with Member States in exchanging information, appropriate procedures and coordinating activities related to the cross-border enforcement of the rights in question.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I share the fight and the need to better coordinate member states' work for a transnational approach and that one of the priorities is attention to the Internet, an instrument through which many infringements of intellectual property rights are carried out.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the inclusion in the final report of issues such as focusing the enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) on commercial-scale infringements, not criminalising private consumers and users, the need to develop awareness-raising campaigns for consumers on the costs and consequences of IPR infringements; and respect for fundamental rights in relation to enforcement measures and sanctions for infringement. The general approach taken by the report on the future EU action plan for intellectual property rights enforcement will have, in my opinion, very positive outcomes as it focuses mostly on supporting SMEs in enforcing their IPR and lowering administrative burdens, on developing mechanisms for countering infringements, involving all stakeholders, and on international cooperation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting industrial property rights today means not only protecting and stimulating creativity and innovation but also guaranteeing consumers high-quality goods and services, while relaunching employment and the economy. The European Commission's figures express these concepts better than any word: intellectual property already today, net of all infringements, accounts for 4.5% of European GDP and employs 8.5 million European citizens. The strategy we have voted on today contains several new protection measures, following an approach called 'follow the money', depriving offenders of any economic benefit from criminal activity. Measures to support SMEs, chargingback systems, increased cooperation between the different national authorities in law enforcement activities, more information and public awareness have also been envisaged. I welcome these measures and voted in favour of today's report.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mr Svoboda for his report on respect for intellectual property. We all hope that this legislature will finally lead to the introduction of long-awaited reforms to the digital agenda and copyright. It is an economic necessity, it is an ever-increasing cultural need.  I believe that any legislative proposal for a reform of the sector, as mr Svoboda rightly does in the report that Mr Svoboda has presented to us, must start from the absolute and legitimate recognition of intellectual property, the fair remuneration for artists, the promotion of the high social and cultural value that copyright assumes as a legal institution. Attempting to relativise these fundamental principles will not benefit the European economy or support the promotion of a more mature and conscious legal and civic culture. I emphasise this because I agree, as the report states, with the lack of information and perception from citizens and consumers, especially younger consumers, about the permitted uses of cultural products online.  Information and awareness-raising campaigns are essential, but they are not enough: as legislators, we must be able to take up the challenge of bringing about legislation that anticipates the future, a system of rules that can be compatible with subsequent technological developments and social changes. I believe that we should ensure that the general context of the digital agenda stimulates investment in innovation and the introduction of new models and forms of cultural use. I am convinced that, however much rules we can introduce to combat piracy and counterfeiting, the best solution always remains to expand the legal offer through a new and simpler (but more certain) legal framework in this area. I therefore call on my fellow Members to consider European copyright reforms in their overall approach and open to the synthesis of multiple demands, without ideological demands for position but with a concrete approach, which aims to facilitate solutions also on other expected measures that can increase the supply and cross-border availability of digital content, such as new consumer protection regulations , the development of e-commerce, the approximation of VAT rates and the strengthening of digital networks.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on an EU Action Plan for a new Consensus on the Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights - partly because I consider the focus of better universal access to affordable medicines in emerging countries to be a central theme of European development policy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Svoboda report because I believe it is crucial that we develop an EU action plan on the enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) that strikes the right balance between protection and the remuneration of creators, the public interest in accessing cultural content, and the needs of industry. Conservative parties in Parliament have been pushing for ‘market-based solutions’ to be the dominant approach to IPR, but if this approach is applied blindly across the line, how do we ensure affordable access to knowledge for our students, academics, SMEs and others? Also, while proper enforcement of IPR rules is paramount, we should focus on commercial-scale infringements rather than going after private customers and consumers. And we should make sure fundamental rights are protected. The bottom line is that intellectual property is not just a technical, far-from-our-bed issue. It touches upon every aspect of our lives, from the performance of our companies to the viability of our cultural sector, to the education of our children, and that is why I urge the Commission to approach this issue with the utmost attention.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal on a European Union action plan on the protection of intellectual property rights. While it is important to protect these rights, which are sources of wealth for our economy, the proposal provides no concrete solution, other than the creation of a group of experts on the protection of intellectual property. The draft presented is therefore a statement of intent. More importantly, the vagueness of this proposal should encourage caution, as intellectual property rights have often been used as a pretext to encourage the intrusion of public authorities into the private sphere. This was the case in France with the adoption of the HADOPI law, which allows users to monitor downloads in the name of copyright protection. However, as a principle, I oppose any provision to extend the monitoring of their electronic communications to as many people as possible. However, I will remain attentive to proposals to protect the intellectual property rights of companies and in particular SMEs, since these proposals do not violate the fundamental freedoms to which we are all attached.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite including references to linking intellectual property rights with respect for fundamental rights, the report is very strict in addressing sanctions, specifically through Internet Service Providers (which involves cutting access to the network). The report also deals very vaguely with the problem of data protection that could arise from its proposals. Finally, the report lacks a flexible approach that facilitates adaptation to fair standards for different creators.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 As rapporteur for the Socialists on the opinion of the Committee on Culture in the Action Plan on the Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights, (IDI) I would like to express my satisfaction with the final result. Effective enforcement of IDs guarantees the creativity, innovation and competitiveness of the creative industries, as well as the cultural diversity that characterises the EU. I would also like to stress that the absolute priority should be that any attempt to modernise and harmonise the legal framework needs to be implemented within the framework of the basic principles that guarantee intellectual property. Exceptions and restrictions should be targeted and limited and should not interfere with the normal exploitation and dissemination of cultural and creative content. At the same time, the role and responsibility of intermediaries needs to be clarified as well as their dominant business model that generates minimal percentages of their profits to creators. We are living in a time of crisis when funds for culture are increasingly being reduced. We must therefore ensure that artists continue to enjoy copyright from their work and that they receive a fair fee, while at the same time users enjoy the widest possible variety of cultural goods.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report as it strikes the right balance between protection and remuneration of creators and the public interest in accessing cultural content.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU Action Plan with a view to re-agreeing on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. The countries of the European Union are faced with a high number of infringements of intellectual property rights every year, as well as significant financial and economic losses at both state and business level. In order to ensure competitiveness and innovation in business, the European Union must combat and defend infringements of intellectual property rights.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to protect intellectual property rights (IPR) and also to protect patents and copyright. SMEs, creative industries, artists and others have significant concerns with regard to IPR, and I welcome the establishment of a working group to monitor infringements of IPR, as well as the recognition of a need for precise detection systems that lead to the swift interruption of commercial-scale IPR—infringing strategies.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. This is to better counter infringements of intellectual property on a commercial scale, both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter of parliament's action plan agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy. In particular, it aimes at developing a clearer business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ In protecting intellectual property rights there is always a fine balance between rewarding innovation, on the one hand, and preventing monopoly, on the other. Whilst there were aspects of this report I could support, on balance I was unable to vote for all of its conclusions.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite including references to linking intellectual property rights with respect for fundamental rights, the report is very strict in addressing sanctions, specifically through Internet Service Providers (which involves cutting access to the network). The report also deals very vaguely with the problem of data protection that could arise from its proposals. Finally, the report lacks a flexible approach that facilitates adaptation to fair standards for different creators.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Intellectual property rights help the cultural and creative industries in the European Union to make a significant contribution to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity. A wider information campaign on the intellectual property rights platform is welcome, but at the same time consumer rights must be respected.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's Communication "According to the new consensus on the protection of intellectual property rights: the EU Action Plan", because of the importance that creativity, innovation and research, and their protection, have to drive economic growth.  In the context of the protection of intellectual property rights, it is essential to establish an effective mechanism whose measures are transparent in order to be preventative and to create new jobs. I strongly support the establishment of the Commission's expert group on intellectual property protection and efforts to strengthen international cooperation between Member States and the exchange of good practices. However, there is a need to raise awareness among EU citizens about what intellectual property really is and what it entails in breach of that right.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal on a European Union action plan on the protection of intellectual property rights. Indeed, while it is essential to protect these rights, sources of wealth for our economy, the proposal provides no concrete solution, other than the creation of a group of experts on the protection of intellectual property. The draft presented is therefore a statement of intent. Beyond that, the very confusing substance of the text must encourage caution because intellectual property rights have often been used as a pretext to encourage the intrusion of public authorities into the private sphere. However, I will remain attentive to proposals to protect the intellectual property rights of companies and in particular SMEs, since these proposals do not violate the fundamental freedoms to which we are all attached.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pavel Svoboda's report on the EU IPR action plan.  Given that the cultural and creative sector accounts for 4.5% of the EU's GDP and 8.5 million jobs, but also includes, among others, trademarks and patents, the fight against IPR fraud must take place at all levels, such as supply chain control or consumer awareness of counterfeiting. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the communication entitled "Towards a renewed consensus on the protection of intellectual property rights: an EU action plan". Intellectual property rights are essential to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity. In Europe, it is essential to protect these rights in the context of the growing use of the internet today.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report is, in my opinion, absolutely worthy of support. Copyright must be protected more effectively, otherwise Europe would be hit by negative economic consequences that would damage Europe's innovation potential.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on moving towards a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights: an EU action plan. This report stresses the importance of the exercise of intellectual property rights in the digital age in line with its trends and requirements. The technology and digital environment, the offerings it offers, are evolving at a tremendous rate, but the laws and regulations for this sector are not being brought along. That is why modern and unified intellectual property rights will guarantee creativity and innovation, as well as promote favourable competition. These rules should take into account the innovative online environment and the various distribution tools that would ensure the interests of consumers and also support artists and authors in a way that would encourage authors to creative innovation and further improve content quality. This motion for a resolution is also an important milestone towards the preconditions for the development of the Digital Single Market.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The fact is that 39% of EU GDP (some EUR 4.7 trillion annually) and approximately 26% of all employment (56 million jobs) is generated in the Intellectual Property Rights (IPR)-intensive sectors. The Commission’s proposed action plan, which is backed by the report, includes new enforcement tools and a ‘follow-the-money’ approach to deprive commercial-scale infringers of revenue flows. Awareness raising is needed, but the first tasks concern the integrity of supply chains, the reduction of profits in the online environment, assisting SMEs, chargeback systems, better cooperation between national authorities, and screening public procurement for IPR-infringing products. SMEs, especially, need particular support in fighting against counterfeiting. Bearing in mind the EU digital strategy, the Union’s copyright legislation also needs to be updated. I hope the Commission will come up with adequate new legislation, at the latest by next summer, accompanied by other necessary measures to turn digital strategy into digital action.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report as it addresses the important and complex issue of intellectual property rights (IPR) enforcement in a balanced fashion. In particular I support the calls for further attempts to make EU citizens, and young people in particular, aware of the real consequences of IPR infringement, both the economic impact and the detrimental effect it has on businesses’ willingness to innovate, and to provide more information on identifying IPR-infringing products. Without public support, any IPR legislation will be difficult to enforce. I also support the calls to assist SMEs in upholding their IPR, in particular by limiting their burden and costs in any IPR-related legislation. Finally, keeping legislation up to date with ever-changing online IPR infringement should be a priority and I support the call to establish an Expert Group to facilitate this.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it strikes the right balance between protection and remuneration of creators, the public interest in accessing cultural content, and the needs of industry.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 9 June 2015, I supported my Czech colleague Pavel Svoboda's report entitled 'Intellectual property rights: an EU action plan', because I believe that the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights contributes to universal growth and much-needed job creation across the Union. The document deals with the economic, social and even health impacts of infringements of intellectual property rights and their protection also in the context of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. In my opinion, if we want to continue to develop and ensure the proper functioning of the EU single market, which the Czech Republic has always consistently supported, we have no choice but to avoid the tax and economic losses that infringements of intellectual property rights represent for EU Member States. I see the biggest problem with infringements in the case of young people who continue to live recklessly at a time of wild internet development in the previous two decades, when intellectual property rights were almost not protected at all on the Internet, and mistakenly believe that everything found on the Internet is free. It is not only for this group that knowledge of the social and cultural importance of the protection of intellectual property rights needs to be intensively developed.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Although there is an exaggerated shift in emphasis in the report towards the protection of cultural intellectual property, I considered it to be supported overall. Let us not forget that it is vital for inventors, indkers and SMEs to protect their intellectual property and inventions from counterfeiters, who often come from organised crime circles. Products that violate intellectual property rights cause significant loss of income for fair, legitimate businesses and result in job losses and loss of reputation. More importantly, they pose a potential threat and a threat to the health and safety of consumers, even if the quality and safety of products are not automatically linked to their authenticity.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, infringements of intellectual property rights are moral and economic damage to European businesses and result in serious economic and fiscal losses for states. In order to ensure respect for intellectual property rights (IPR), it is also essential to take account of international aspects, as infringements of these rights are a global phenomenon. I voted in favour of this proposal, which includes, among others, a follow-the-money approach to protecting the interests of consumers and the integrity of the supply chain.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report to put in place an action plan to strengthen the protection of the European Union's intellectual property rights.  By voting overwhelmingly in favour of this report entrusted to my EPP colleague Pavel SVOBODA, we have called on the European Commission and the Member States to put in place a comprehensive legal framework adapted to the digital environment, to combat more effectively against infringements of intellectual property rights (IPR) in the European Union. Because intellectual property rights are a key factor in Europe's competitiveness, innovation and economic growth, European legislation must protect them effectively.  Beyond the political message to the European Commission and the Member States, this report also has the merit of proposing concrete solutions to combat IPR infringements.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. We are against this report because it is important to preserve the French conception of copyright (even if it must necessarily adapt to the light of this "information society"), in particular the moral right aspect, and to question the possible liability of the ISPs.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it announces a reform of copyright that does not coincide with the French conception of this branch of law and which seems too repressive (see paragraph 19). It is feared that its purpose is to pave the way for the Americanization of copyright, which will be carried out by TTIP.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this report contains some positive elements, such as the protection of fundamental rights in the online field, it still does not clearly distinguish between those regulations necessary to maintain industrial activity or remuneration worthy of cultural creation and those that de facto signify a restriction of access to basic rights such as information, health, art or economic development. These ambiguities, characteristic of the European IPR agenda, must be clarified as a precondition for a genuine political debate on these issues. For all this, I abstained.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Union's plan in general is quite good, as it opens up broad prospects for ensuring intellectual property law. I voted in favour, supported all the voting amendments separately together with the majority of my political group. Those who voted against do not understand the idea of intellectual property. I'm ashamed of others.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Respect for intellectual property rights is a lasting economic value for the European Union and a driver of innovation and creativity. This contributes to increasing its competitiveness. The EU is facing a high number of infringements of intellectual property rights, the volume and financial value of which are alarming and which ultimately harm not only the interests of intellectual property owners, but also the economic and economic interests of the EU. The EU Action Plan on Intellectual Property Rights can be a way of strengthening their protection. It is therefore necessary for the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, to proceed with its application as soon as possible.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the pursuit of a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights in the internal market: EU Action Plan, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/6/2015, and because this report includes the adoption of an approach consisting of monitoring the money line in order to hit intellectual property rights violators who traffic counterfeit pirated products over the Internet.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Intellectual property rights were not part of the negotiations that led to the Treaty of Rome in 1957 and had to be harmonized through multiple successive directives over the years. This harmonization effort has paid off, as there are very few differences between national rights today.  Unfortunately, the European legislative process is so cumbersome that the reports and directives proposed in this area are already inadequate: the world and technology have evolved too fast. We oppose this text because we want to protect our sovereignty and our specificities, as well as preserve the French conception of copyright.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the EU action plan on respect for intellectual property rights, as it allows effective and effective protection, protecting one of the driving forces of innovation and creativity. A determined policy towards both the protection of intellectual property and all infringements of intellectual property also contributes to a positive atmosphere for innovators, potentially stimulating the market through the resulting work.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of new, especially digital, technologies also entails a requirement for adequate protection of intellectual property rights. I am of the opinion that infringements of intellectual property rights constitute economic harm to European businesses and cause economic and tax losses to States. It is clear that people lack adequate knowledge of the social and cultural importance of protecting intellectual property rights and the activities considered to be violations of them, and that young Europeans in particular are not sufficiently aware of the potential consequences of infringements of intellectual property rights I am of the opinion that the promotion of intellectual property rights not only contributes to job creation and growth throughout the Union, but is also a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the Single Market , in particular with regard to factors such as the share of EU GDP, employment and the range of industries that benefit from and benefit from intellectual property rights. Protection through intellectual property law also plays an important role in stimulating innovation, creativity, competitiveness and cultural diversity. In order to better protect consumers and raise their awareness, we need an action plan to promote intellectual property law at EU level, which is why I supported the report.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving standards to ensure greater respect for intellectual property rights is directly proportional to the increase in employment, and the advancement of growth, in the European Union. In view of the fact that the European Union is being forced to deal with a large number of infringements of intellectual property rights and that the financial scope of these infringements is alarming, a public debate on this issue must be inaugurated, involving all interested parties. For the reasons I have just given, I have decided to support the Svoboda report, a document that sets out the lines for a strategy to strengthen the standards governing respect for intellectual property rights.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is based, among others, on the idea that strengthening intellectual property rights is decisive for the development of the economy, an idea with which it could not be more at odds. On the other hand, it is very vague on the issue of data protection, which I consider essential. Finally, this proposal for an 'EU Action Plan' does not include a flexible approach that fairly includes the different breeders. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the need to establish a renewed consensus on respect for intellectual property rights and to establish an EU action plan in this area supports the Commission's proposals to protect intellectual property rights and to undertake policies aimed at depriving commercial offenders of their income and making it difficult to enter the market for goods infringing intellectual property. My support for this proposal therefore states that the essential objective of the action plan should be to ensure effective and evidence-based respect for IPRs, which plays a key role in promoting innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Svoboda report on intellectual property rights (IPR). This text aims to curb the inflow of counterfeit products and to develop defences in the most affected sectors. With this in mind, it advocates for the deepening of the European system of due diligence, which is applicable throughout supply chains to prevent IPR breaches. There are also plans to facilitate agreements with providers, particularly on the internet, to limit the sources of income of offenders. The report, supported by the group S and D, goes even further and places particular emphasis on the association of all players in the supply chain, while also emphasizing consumer awareness and information. IPR revenues are sources of funding for research and innovation. They are also an effective instrument of cooperation between universities and businesses. Finally, they promote a value dear to the French socialists: cultural diversity.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I consider the report on the EU plan for more effective protection of copyright to be useful and have therefore given my assent.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the EU’s current approach does not differentiate clearly enough between physical counterfeiting and digital violations of copyrights. We need a comprehensive legal framework, tailored to the online environment, with which to combat infringements of intellectual property rights in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Intellectual property is, according to the editor, "an engine for jobs and growth" essential to the "good functioning of the market", boosting innovation and competitiveness in knowledge-based sectors. The text therefore aims to better protect intellectual property rights (copyrights, trademarks and patents) within the Union. But far from encouraging open research and knowledge sharing, this system strengthens the position of the dominant market players at the expense of users. In the absence of a balanced proposal, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Since 1957, numerous ip directives have been adopted to facilitate the establishment of a single market and thereby reduce differences between national intellectual property rights in this area. This report aims to reform copyright and in particular the "INFOSOC" directive dating back to 2001. The record of this directive is rather poor. It is important to preserve the French conception of copyright, even if it must necessarily adapt to the information society. A possible liability of ISPs would be a way of thinking. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report entitled 'For a renewed consensus on the effective protection of intellectual property rights (IPR): an EU action plan'. I share the guidance followed in the European Parliament resolution that, in order to enhance IPR, it is necessary to raise awareness and raise awareness among Europeans themselves of their social and economic importance through an internal action plan, which will be reflected in the future in the effective protection of these rights.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it highlights the fact that proper enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) is crucial for the functioning of the single market and also a driving force for job creation and job security. An EU action plan on IPR will support creativity and innovation and aid in the Commission’s push for increased European competitiveness in the global economy. Both this report and the action plan also stress the importance of enabling SMEs to protect their intellectual property.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As intellectual property rights affect a very significant part of the EU's overall economy and jobs within the EU, the enforcement of these rights is crucial for the EU's economic interests both within the EU and in third countries. The report is, in my view, a decisive step forward on this issue, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Intellectual property is an important driver of growth and innovation. However, it is currently suffering numerous violations on European territory. While high-density sectors of intellectual property rights account for almost 40% of Europe's GDP, it is necessary to fight hard against growing counterfeiting in order to preserve and strengthen the European Union's global industrial competitiveness.  My attention is particularly focused on small and medium-sized enterprises, an essential link in the knowledge economy, which must be helped and supported in order to defend their rights. I also consider customer and consumer awareness essential. Communication campaigns aimed at raising awareness among EU citizens of the impact of IPR infringements, particularly on employment and the economy, need to be set up. These campaigns should aim to facilitate access to ip-respecting products and demonstrate that it is in the interests of consumers to choose such products.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Intellectual property rights are crucial for fair competition in the European Union, as the success of commercial transactions depends on them and without them trade could not function effectively. As the EU and its Member States are members of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and are therefore committed to the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS), in 2014 the European Commission presented a 10-point plan laying the foundation for the effective protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights. I support the renewal of these rights and legal aspects and the gradual harmonisation of intellectual property rights at European level, because European laws can help improve the global protection of intellectual property rights better and more clearly. I agree with restoring the protection of these rights, as these rules are now obsolete and action is needed to stop them being infringed outside the EU' borders. I therefore support the proposal for greater harmonisation in the form of exchanges of information between Member States during transit through their territory and a more complete processing of trade and intellectual property laws, from which the author or owner should benefit as an incentive for gradual innovation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Intellectual property rights: an EU action plan, which took a general approach to the action plan and focused mostly on supporting SMEs in enforcing their intellectual property rights and lowering administrative burdens, developing mechanisms for countering infringements, involving all stakeholders, and international cooperation.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. It is important to preserve the French conception of copyright, even if it must necessarily adapt to the information society, in particular the moral right aspect, and to question the possible liability of ISPs. This report does not offer these guarantees and therefore calls for a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Infringements of intellectual property rights represent a moral and economic loss for European businesses and cause heavy economic and tax losses for Member States. These offences, including contrapartite, discourage growth, job creation, innovation and creativity. Thus, it is essential to redouble efforts to combat the illegal trade in infringing goods and to make it clear that no one should profit from infringements of intellectual property rights. This report, in presenting a European Union action plan on property rights, emphasises the importance this issue has for our market, innovation, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity. I am voting in favour of this report, given the relevance of intellectual property and the congregation of the measures set out.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The report on the strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights in third countries makes laudable findings, but the solutions provided are critical to say the least.  The fight against counterfeiting of intellectual property rights (IPR) is an urgent need for public interest, especially for SMEs, which are often the first victims. But this report is yet another attack on the sovereignty of the Member States, since it is further strengthening European integration in this area by proposing, among other things, the creation of a new European body, while a national policy, coupled with controls at the Union's external and internal borders, would be much more effective.  For these reasons, I have decided to vote against the report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it stresses the importance of remuneration of creators in order to ensure a consistent supply of cultural content.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on an EU action plan for the protection of intellectual property rights. It calls for an end to the fight against IPR violations and the moral and economic damage they cause to European businesses. An EU action plan in this area is particularly important, particularly for SMEs, whose vulnerability to market losses caused by the trade in counterfeit goods exposes them to bankruptcy. In particular, the resolution calls for increased public awareness, and more specifically of younger generations, of the consequences of intellectual property rights violations.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Intellectual property rights are one of the driving forces of innovation and creativity and make a decisive contribution to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity. The EU is facing an increasing number of infringements and counterfeits, with huge financial consequences as well. We therefore welcome the Commission communication presenting an action plan on respect for intellectual property rights, supporting the approach based on preventive actions and strategic instruments that aim to deprive offenders on a commercial scale and make it more difficult to place counterfeit goods on the market. Respect for intellectual property rights is also essential to promote the proper functioning of the single market by stimulating employment and innovation. We also believe it is important to provide for targeted awareness-raising campaigns, involving individual consumers who must be able to better identify offers, deciding to buy legal goods or use legal content. Finally, we welcome the development of the activities of the European Monitoring Centre on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights, as a useful support for the reflection of policy-makers and as a means of collecting and exchanging information and data on all forms of infringement.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the Lisbon Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights place a heavy emphasis on respect for intellectual property rights, as these rights are an engine of European competitiveness. Today, the Union is facing a large number of infringements of intellectual property rights, the volume and value of which are alarming. These violations discourage growth and creativity. The effective application of intellectual property rights must therefore be ensured.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Svoboda's report examines in detail the Intellectual Property Rights Action Plan presented by the European Commission in July 2014. The action plan, which is a first step towards building an effective intellectual property enforcement policy for commercial infringements at Community and national level, proposes new reinforcement instruments, including the follow-the-money approach, to protect consumer interests and the integrity of the supply chain. As intellectual property rights are one of the driving forces behind innovation and creativity and make a decisive contribution to the EU's competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity, I have decided to support this report. In recent years, the EU has faced a growing number of breaches in this area, with an alarming financial volume. I therefore believe that action is needed in this regard, based on preventive actions and strategic instruments aimed at depriving offenders on a commercial scale of revenue flows and making it more difficult to place counterfeit goods on the market.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Intellectual property rights are one of the driving forces of innovation and creativity and a key contributor to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity. I voted for this report and strongly support the necessity for an open dialogue and an action plan on the future of intellectual property rights.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as we do need a realistic action plan to address intellectual property (IP) theft and fraud inside our own borders. The Union needs to protect both creativity and fair competition in the market in this area, without stifling the free sharing of information on the internet. At the same time, the ‘follow the money’ approach initially proposed by the Commission could be highly beneficial for many users unjustly accused of IP violations or infringement, and we can hope the Member States will try to adapt their practices to bring them fully into line with this action plan.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Rights Action Plan because I believe that the EU should make considerable efforts in this area. Infringements of intellectual property rights, including the widespread practice of counterfeiting, hinder economic growth, job creation and innovation and cause serious economic and tax losses. And it demotivates economic activity in this area. A worrying finding is the tendency of a significant number of Europeans to consider infringements of intellectual property rights acceptable. It is therefore necessary to raise users' awareness and awareness of intellectual property rights, particularly in the digital environment, which brings new temptations and opportunities to violate them.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report has also received my support, as the text makes a useful complement to the plan and copyright can be protected more effectively within the EU. Instead of punishing citizens for often unknowing infringements of intellectual property rights, the action plan presents information measures and treats them in a differentiated way with those infringers who knowingly commit an act.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's resolution on the application of intellectual property rights addresses the economic, social and health consequences of non-compliance with these rights, as well as methods to better respect these rights. Our group has made a number of progress, such as respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union or the principle of proportionality. Failure to respect intellectual property rights can undermine innovation, SMEs, creativity and cultural diversity, particularly on the internet, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft European Union Action Plan on intellectual property protection. There are numerous infringements of intellectual property rights in the EU and the volume and financial value of these infringements are of concern. This hinders development, job creation, innovation and creativity. The main objective of the Action Plan should be to ensure effective evidence-based protection of intellectual property rights, which is central to promoting innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour since the defence of intellectual property rights in the digital world requires our special attention. We must take great care in implementing appropriate measures to combat violations of these rights, as these can contribute to the fight against organized crime, money laundering and tax evasion, but they can also mean severe harm to human rights, public health and security; in particular, users: you have to put control over the online sales platforms of physical products that sell counterfeit products worldwide without surveillance. There is one aspect that we strongly support: strengthening public debate and raising Europeans' awareness of the economic damage caused by counterfeiting and IPR infringement.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – In particular, the EU Action Plan must ensure effective and evidence-based enforcement of intellectual property rights. It would also help to promote innovation, creativity, competitiveness, economic growth and cultural diversity. I believe that ensuring fair remuneration for creators should be one of the key aspects of the EU Action Plan. In addition, it is essential to provide legal protection for new works as soon as possible in order to stimulate investment and innovate. As internet use is growing, illegal products are distributed instantly around the world. This creates difficulties in identifying and combating infringements of intellectual property rights, as infringements are internationalised, complex and more diverse. It is therefore essential to develop a comprehensive strategy on intellectual property rights at EU level. This strategy should establish a comprehensive legal framework to combat IPR infringements, consistent with the online environment, in full compliance with fundamental rights and freedoms and the principles of fair trial, proportionality and data protection.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Svoboda's report on a renewed consensus on respect for property rights, as infringements of intellectual property rights are moral and economic damage to European businesses and result in serious economic and fiscal losses for states, discourating growth, job creation, innovation and creativity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for this 'Action Plan' because I think we need to guarantee effective protection of intellectual property rights in the EU market, as it plays a key role in fostering innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth, development and cultural diversity of the EU. I also supported it because it will actively, through campaigns, strengthen end-consumers' awareness of the importance of intellectual property rights, especially younger consumers. Its harmonisation regulations in member states' internal markets will increase consumer awareness of the importance of this topic.  After the Commission published a report on the application of the 'IPR Enforcement Directive', it became clear that it was not in line with the digital age in some respects, and was an alarming extent of infringements of intellectual property rights that produce major financial damages. The rapid development of e-commerce and online activities has changed the way intellectual property rights should be viewed, so I agree that this urgently needs to be adapted.   Cultural, creative and online platforms, where intensive use of intellectual property rights is common, account for up to 4.5% of GDP and account for around 8.5 million jobs in the EU. It is clear that counterfeiting disincentives growth, job creation, innovation and creativity, and by supporting this "Action Plan" this problem will be addressed more effectively.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on intellectual property rights: an action plan for the EU seems to me to be ineffective in its operation and critical of its aims. The draft initially submitted to the European Parliament was purely and simply a declaration of intent and was therefore ineffective. I have serious doubts about certain provisions in relation to the consequences of the INFOSOC Directive of 2001. As a defender of France's interests, I am very committed to the preservation of the French model with regard to copyright, especially in its moral aspect. A way of thinking would be to think about a possible responsibility of ISPs. For all these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Intellectual property rights are one of the drivers of innovation and creativity and contribute in a key way to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity, as product authenticity should not always be identified with product safety and quality issues and that the protection of intellectual property rights plays a significant role in ensuring consumer health and safety, while revenue from counterfeiting usually contributes to the black economy and organised crime.  The European Union is facing a high number of infringement cases of intellectual property rights, with the alarming extent and financial value of these infringements at issue. This is why the European Union needs a comprehensive action plan that needs to be aimed at ensuring effective, evidence-based protection of intellectual property rights and plays a key role in fostering innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity. Similarly, measures taken to protect intellectual property rights should be based on precise, reliable data. This will particularly benefit the cultural and creative sectors where intensive use of intellectual property rights is common, already accounting for up to 4.5% of GDP. It accounts for up to 8.5 million jobs in the EU and is necessary to achieve cultural diversity, but it also contributes strongly to social and economic development.  For all of the above, I support this report, which provides useful guidance to the Commission for the creation and refinement of the action plan.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported fellow MEP Pavel Svoboda's report on the European Commission Communication "Under the new consensus on the protection of intellectual property rights: the EU Action Plan". In my view, there is a need to increase awareness of the existence of intellectual property rights and to protect rights more effectively from counterfeiting and abuse, as infringements of intellectual property rights have reached record levels in the context of significant technological changes in the last decade. The EU has designed many programmes in which it invests significant resources in supporting research and innovation companies (especially SMEs). Due to major changes in the nature and scope of challenges and risks to the intellectual property of European companies, the EU is obliged in the new situation to redefine the framework of promoting intellectual property rights and the strategy to combat its infringement. Given that the EU's competitiveness is based on creativity, innovation and the development of a knowledge-based economy, it is important to ensure the continuity of the EU's policy in the field of intellectual property rights protection and to develop new mechanisms and adapt existing protection tools in light of the new technological environment.  With this report, Parliament acknowledges the importance of intellectual property as a key driver of growth and jobs and focuses on the necessary fight against counterfeiting in order to strengthen the industrial competitiveness of the EU and the Member States globally.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the action plan on respect for intellectual property rights because I believe it is important that preventive action is taken and that a strategy is put in place that blocks and discourages offenders from marketing counterfeit goods. In order for the plan to work, it must be transparent and the public, the ultimate user of the goods, must be given the most complete information to involve it and make it aware of the fight against infringements of intellectual property rights. I would like to stress the importance, for the success of the action plan, of cooperation between The Member States, the exchange of information and the value of coordination activities for cross-border application.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2012, statistics showed that there had been more than 90,000 cases of infringement of intellectual property rights at the EU's external borders. In order to strengthen the Union's competitiveness, it is necessary to put in place adequate protection against counterfeiting and unfair competition.  The European Parliament adopted a EU action plan for the respect and protection of intellectual property rights at the plenary. I am proud to have voted in favour of this text. This European strategy will introduce new instruments to ensure a high level of protection of intellectual property rights and support the competitiveness of European SMEs.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of considering that the implementation of an action plan for the protection of intellectual property rights is crucial to stimulating growth and innovation.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Europe's added value comes from its creativity and its capacity for innovation. The knowledge industries and innovative SMEs have weathered the crisis and are experiencing strong growth. They play a major role in getting the European economy back on track by creating cutting-edge products and services and sustainable jobs: an annual contribution of some EUR 4,700 billion to European economic activity and 56 million jobs generated. This positive development is threatened by counterfeiting and an ever-increasing number of infringements of intellectual property rights, particularly within the Union itself. This shows that protecting innovation is as important as innovation itself. Europe must promote more effective protection of intellectual property rights by facilitating close cooperation between the competent authorities on the one hand, and between these authorities and economic actors on the other. This will protect not only our economies and our competitiveness, but also the health of European consumers.
