But beyond the numbers, it is essential to make consumers aware of the role they too must play in protecting intellectual property rights through their choice and behaviour.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Intellectual property law reform has emerged necessary in light of the growing number of violations 2012. That is why I supported this resolution calling on the Commission to submit a proposal to adapt the regulations, particularly to the new trading platforms. Copyright, due to the evolving nature of their scope, must be regularly changed. I welcome the adoption of this resolution, which proposes, among other things, the introduction of preventive information and awareness-raising measures, but also European aid to improve national remedies.         Nevertheless, we will remain alert to the commission's proposal that does not hinder competition and support creativity and innovation, ensuring a safe, adequate and secure environment for inventors and creators.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the protection of intellectual property rights. These are essential rights to the preservation of cultural diversity and the artistic world. In times of crisis, they are the main source of income for cultural professionals.  Any IPR infringement must be combated, whether offline or online, with the sale of counterfeit goods on the internet, for example. To do this, Europe has several instruments. Cooperation between customs in cross-border trade must be facilitated, the legal framework must be adapted to developments in the digital age and consumers need to be better informed. The Commission has chosen to set up awareness campaigns so that Europeans understand the concrete consequences of IPR violations for society and we welcome this initiative.  We reiterate our call for a comprehensive IPR strategy that brings together all stakeholders, from Member States to governments at all levels, including local, regional and national.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Treaty of Lisbon and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union guarantee the protection of intellectual property. In addition to intellectual property rights (IPR) being an important means for wealth production and job creation, it is also an impetus for innovation, creativity and competitiveness. Now more than ever, consumers should be informed about what IPR is and what can and cannot be done with protected goods and content, and I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to develop awareness-raising and clarification campaigns for consumers.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. During the past decade, there have been significant changes in the area of IPRs: substantial technological changes related to the Internet, increasing importance of emerging economies, challenges in access to medicines, and an increasing level of IPR violations, among others. I support this action plan presented by the Commission as it is right to concentrate efforts on preventive actions and policy tools aimed at depriving commercial-scale infringers of their income and making it difficult to market property that infringes intellectual property. Support for SMEs and individual creators, who play a key role in the creative and cultural sectors and often do not have the necessary capacities to respect their rights, is essential.  The report, which I supported with my vote, further stresses the importance of ensuring the implementation of due diligence throughout the supply chain, including the digital supply chain, and involving all key actors and operators, such as creators, artists and rights holders, producers, intermediaries, internet service providers, online sales platforms, end users and public authorities.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which welcomes the European Commission's willingness, through its 'action plan', to put in place a comprehensive legal framework to combat counterfeiting and piracy within the Union. The text also calls for greater involvement in all players in the supply chain, both online and offline, and to adapt the legal corpus in this direction.  Given the growing number of online platforms for selling counterfeit products, the text suggests that the EU executive and the 28 Member States establish a dialogue with platform managers to identify the channels of these products.  Finally, the document calls for campaigns to raise awareness of the consequences of intellectual property rights violations, especially for young people, as well as for the implementation of a harmonised European system of notification/removal of illegal goods and content, to enable better information for consumers and businesses through alerts.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. The cultural and creative industries sector, which makes extensive use of intellectual property rights (IPRs), generates almost 4.5% of the EU's GDP and accounts for up to 8.5 million jobs. In these times of financial crisis, IPR revenues are often the main source of income for artists and creators; guaranteeing and safeguarding fair compensation for holders of such rights are therefore key points of the action plan. To achieve this goal, this report aims to involve all players in the online and offline supply chain, each with a role to play in the fight against IPR breaches. In addition, it is proposed to improve civil procedures for defending intellectual property for SMEs and creators, as they play a key role in the cultural and creative industries and often lack the capacity to enforce their rights.  To protect innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity, I voted for this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. We are looking at an own-initiative report which aims to contribute to the creation of a ten-point European action plan for the defence of intellectual property rights. In view of the matter itself, which encompasses an extremely comprehensive universe of rights, I believe that the main aspects and sectors that are the target of this regime are listed and defended, especially in economic and social matters. Particular emphasis should be made on proposals on copyright, consumer protection and sme aid. It should also be noted that I consider very positive cooperation between national authorities to share best practices, to encourage intellectual property training programmes targeted at each Member State in the context of the single market and the Commission's proposal to develop, promote and publish a guide on best practices for public authorities in order to avoid transactions in counterfeit products. I agree overall with this report, which is why I have voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. In general, the European Union faces numerous infringements of intellectual property rights and this has a negative impact on growth, job creation, creativity and innovation.  It is in this sense that I have supported this report which calls for all stakeholders to be involved in combating infringements of intellectual property rights and to help small businesses in the pursuit of this objective.  The report also encourages the Commission to carry out targeted awareness campaigns to raise awareness and inform consumers, as well as to set up a harmonised European system for the notification and removal of illegal goods and content.  Ultimately, the challenge of this action plan is to achieve a modern, pro-competitive framework that is tailored to consumers' intellectual property rights needs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Legal Affairs has worked on the internal aspect of the European strategy for the protection and respect of intellectual property rights by analysing the ten points of the action plan presented by the Commission. The most important figure on which we have been asked to vote and for which I voted in favour concerns the follow-the-money approach, which will serve to better protect the interests of consumers and the integrity of the supply chain.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour because I share the view that it is necessary to better coordinate the activities of the Member States in a fight which must by its very nature be carried out mainly at transnational level.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report because, despite including references to linking intellectual property rights with respect for fundamental rights, the report is very strict in addressing sanctions, specifically through Internet Service Providers (which involves cutting access to the network). The report also deals very vaguely with the problem of data protection that could arise from its proposals. Finally, the report lacks a flexible approach that facilitates adaptation to fair standards for different creators.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this report contains some positive elements, such as the protection of fundamental rights in the online field, it still does not clearly distinguish between those regulations necessary to maintain industrial activity or remuneration worthy of cultural creation and those that de facto signify a restriction of access to basic rights such as information, health, art or economic development. These ambiguities, characteristic of the European IPR agenda, must be clarified as a precondition for a genuine political debate on these issues. For all this, I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU Action Plan for the Protection of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) against commercial infringements at EU and national level. Since 2003, the number of new registrations of European patents, Community trade marks and Community designs has more than doubled. However, this positive trend can be undermined by the large number of counterfeit products mainly placed by organised crime in the European single market. The latest statistics produced by the EU's border control bodies have found 90 000 cases of goods suspected of violating PPE. In my opinion, our main aim must not so much be to punish and penalise individual offenders, but to destroy illegal trade on a commercial scale. I believe that the new approach called 'follow money' through which the entire chain of management of counterfeit goods from sale and distribution to production can make a positive contribution to this, with the aim of tracing the final beneficiaries of the income produced by these trades. I also hope that information campaigns will be promoted to raise public awareness of the economic damage caused by IPR violations in order to increase consumer awareness.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in favour of this report as it strikes the right balance between protection and remuneration of creators, the public interest in accessing cultural content and the needs of industry.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: unfortunately, in writing ‒ the European Union still faces a very large number of cases where intellectual property rights are infringed. I therefore voted in favour of adopting the motion for a resolution of the EU Action Plan on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. I also consider adequate protection of intellectual property rights to be an important part of the development of the EU economy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the EU faces a high number of infringements of intellectual property rights, which cause both immaterial and economic damage to European businesses and brings major economic and financial losses to European businesses and states. I voted in favour of the resolution of the strategy for the protection of rights and intellectual property in third countries, and I also support this report, which comes up with concrete measures that should ensure the effective enforcement of intellectual property rights. As infringements of intellectual property rights have a particular impact on SMEs, including the services that businesses provide to other businesses, I appreciate that with the EU Action Plan we want to help these businesses to enforce their intellectual property rights more effectively. I presume that assistance to these enterprises could be reflected in improving civil proceedings, improving cooperation between Member States and facilitating the exchange of good practices. I trust that the representatives of the Member States will stick to the objectives set and act in accordance with the steps planned in the Action Plan. I consider the approval of the strategy and action plan to be a very important step towards the enforcement of intellectual property rights, but what I personally consider to be even more important is that these documents are also applied consistently in practice.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Report on Intellectual Property Rights (EU Action Plan) states that the enforcement of intellectual property rights is key to job creation, growth in the Union and the proper functioning of the common market. The report offers, however, an improvement and awareness of intellectual property rights themselves. Some amendments have been adopted concerning basic rights and judicial review. Unfortunately, the report focuses too much on strengthening intellectual property rights and increasing the obligations of internet service providers. A wider and more diverse debate is needed on the actual contribution of enhanced intellectual property rights. These should mainly support business development and small and medium-sized enterprises. It is also of concern that all actors in the supply chain are involved in the processes of combating infringement of intellectual property rights. Such an approach is too one-sided and problematic. Generally speaking, intellectual property rights do not constitute an important source of funding for research projects. In doing so, it is assumed that universities and other publicly funded research institutions do not sell their research to private companies. The importance of the predictability of the law should be emphasised. Basic rights require judicial review, which cannot be carried out by commercial operators. On this issue, I voted against the report on intellectual property rights.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution calling on the European Parliament to draw up an EU Action Plan on Intellectual Property Rights (IPR), with a view to establishing a comprehensive legal framework, adapted to the online environment, to combat IPR violations within Europe's borders. Supporting the need to involve all stakeholders in the implementation of the plan, the paper suggests the formulation of awareness-raising measures on the consequences of the breach of PPE on society and consumers through better information, but also the development of new business models better suited to address the challenges posed by the rapid technological development of the media. Parliament is also showing renewed attention to the sector problems of small and medium-sized enterprises, so that their PPE are also fully respected.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: In writing ‒ the main objective of the Action Plan should be to ensure the effective enforcement of evidence-based intellectual property rights and play a key role in fostering innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity. The main responsibility for the enforcement of intellectual property rights should continue to be the responsibility of the public authorities of the Member States. There is also a need to raise awareness and combat more actively violations of these rights.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as I consider intellectual property rights, including trademarks and patents, to be essential for the proper functioning of the single market. Products infringing intellectual property rights not only cause a direct loss of income for legitimate companies and the European economy, but lead to direct and indirect job losses, reputational damage and an increase in the cost of enforcing protection.  There is a need to focus on cooperation with other Member States and sharing information as well as possible. One of the ways to better protect it is to set up an expert group on intellectual property rights for Member States, as the exchange of best practices will contribute to policy-making and the implementation of a data-based action plan and research prepared at national level.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the communication report "Under the new consensus on the protection of intellectual property rights: the EU Action Plan". The action plan focuses on issues such as raising awareness of consumers, employees and customers, how to ensure the integrity of supply chains, copyright infringement of products online. An important item is also helping SMEs enforce their IP rights and cooperation between national authorities.  Emphasis should be placed on the establishment of an expert group on the implementation of intellectual property rights, the development of an effective and effective memorandum of understanding, on an intellectual property rights protection strategy and consumer information and the development of new business.  The report recognises that tackling infringements of intellectual property rights is effective and complex and underlines the request of the Commission and the Member States to combat intellectual property infringements by protecting the fundamental rights of all interested parties implementing intellectual property rights.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because I consider a more effective fight against intellectual property infringing goods to be beneficial. I also welcome the fact that the present proposal highlights, in particular, the evidence-based approach.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Progress Report towards a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights: an EU action plan. I supported the report because of the major infringements of intellectual property rights in the European Union and the resulting damage. I am also aware of the importance of innovation and new technologies for the development of the European Union's competitiveness and for the eu's economic development. One important strategy is also an information campaign to inform consumers about their rights and obligations, while simply accessing and using creative content.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly we are in favour of copyright protection and copyright safeguarding. However, we cannot vote in favour of a proposal for an EU Action Plan which states that intellectual property rights must guarantee the competitiveness of the cultural and creative industries as well as other business sectors. We also disagree with the approach that the enforcement of intellectual property rights should be used for the smooth functioning of the internal market. In view of these positions set out in the report, we have decided to abstain.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The enforcement of intellectual property rights (IDPs) is not only a driving force for employment and growth in the Union but is vital for the smooth functioning of the internal market, especially in view of factors such as a share of EU and Member State GDP. Emphasis is placed on regulating the enforcement of IDRs, including the adoption of an approach consisting of 'monitoring the money line', aimed at ensuring that the most important IRS offenders, particularly on a commercial scale, are identified and suffer financial losses

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2014, the Commission issued a communication on intellectual property regulation, which contains a 10-point action plan. The action plan aims to take better action against commercial infringements of intellectual property both at EU level and within Member States. The reporter agrees with the Commission's vision for a new comprehensive IPR strategy, including the development of a more transparent business model, a higher level of consumer information and a more cost-effective, more accessible legal protection system, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU Action Plan towards a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights.  Intellectual property rights are of great value to the European economy in global competition, which is why the increasing number of related infringements is a problem, which in many cases can also hinder innovation, job creation and thus growth. I agree with the report's suggestion that greater publicity and full information is needed on measures to protect intellectual property rights. Information is of the utmost importance because, as the report points out, many Europeans do not recognise the potential impact of infringements of intellectual property rights on the economy, society and consumer safety. I think it is important that the interests of the consumer, the European citizen, be at the fore of all our actions. I also underline the report's recommendation on SMEs. Since SMEs are the driving force of the European economy, the Commission's intention to help small and medium-sized enterprises to assert their intellectual property rights is to be welcomed. I urge that their interests continue to be taken into account when drafting legislation, so that they are clear and easy for SMEs to enforce.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. 2012 36 million counterfeit items were seized at European borders worth more than 760 million euros. These products violate intellectual property rights pose a danger to the health and safety of consumers, the environment and the economy. This traffic also steals the employment of 100,000 Europeans and strikes many SMEs. That is why Parliament voted today in favour of the European Action Plan against Counterfeiting and proposes some additional ways to combat fraud. In terms of numbers, the shortfall of 470 million euros per year and the 100,000 jobs prevented by this shadow economy reveal the scale of the problem. In 2013, 36 million items were seized, 10% of them medicines, as well as toys, food and cosmetics. It is wrong to believe that counterfeiting only affects luxury goods, consumer products are widely affected by the phenomenon.   Finally, I would like to stress the crucial importance of involving all the stakeholders concerned with the subject of intellectual property and possible future legislation: citizens, NGOs, artists, creators, SMEs, associations, and not just multinationals as was the case for the now defunct ACTA.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on an EU action plan on intellectual property rights (IPR). The EU needs innovation and creativity to stay competitive and intellectual property is a key driver for our growth. We have to fight counterfeiting to enhance the EU’s industrial competitiveness globally. That is why I am in favour of the creation of an EU action plan to ensure the effective, evidence-based enforcement of IPR, which play a key role in stimulating innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity. Moreover, in respect to the better regulation objectives, I fully agree that measures taken to enforce IPR should be based on precise, reliable data.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. The protection of intellectual property rights is fundamental in today's society. Today, the quality of our manufacture is at risk and, in a context of global competition, it is therefore essential to act effectively to limit the entry into the Eu-ion market of counterfeit products that harm consumers and the economy. That is why we must strive to enhance and protect intellectual property rights, by improving civil protection procedures in favour of SMEs and individual creators, but also by informing consumers through awareness-raising campaigns. We must continue to promote a balanced approach between the interests of intellectual property holders and consumers, ensuring the full involvement of all actors and with the ultimate objective of eliminating counterfeiting, which unfortunately also causes serious damage to health, as demonstrated for cosmetic products, food and medicines. The European Union's action plan is heading in the right direction, but it is essential that all violations, which undermine the high quality of "made in Europe" products, are punished and that a global legal framework is created as soon as possible that is also suitable for the dissemination of digital content.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this Commission report because I believe it highlights the need to strengthen intellectual property rights and reduces the possibility of infringement of intellectual property rights on the market.  I wholeheartedly support efforts to achieve fair remuneration for authors, as intellectual property plays an important role in fostering innovation, creativity, competitiveness, growth and cultural diversity, as well as the requirement to increase consumer awareness of the need to protect these rights. I consider international cooperation in this sphere not only necessary, but also necessary in the fight against organised criminal groups involved in the production and distribution of counterfeit goods, which, due to the overall digitization of the market, show a dangerous tendency to further spread and strengthen.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the progress report towards a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights: an EU action plan. In July 2014, the Commission presented an action plan which represents a first step towards building an effective policy for the enforcement of intellectual property rights. Intellectual property rights are also a key driver of development and growth. Protecting these are important to increase the EU's competitiveness. According to the latest statistics, around 39% of EU GDP and 26% of all employment in the EU comes from industries strongly tied to the protection of intellectual property rights. It is necessary to draw attention to the complexity of effectively combating infringements, especially when it comes to the international web.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST this report because despite including references to a link between intellectual property rights and respect for fundamental rights, the report is very strict in addressing sanctions, specifically through Internet Service Providers (which involves cutting access to the network). The report also deals very vaguely with the problem of data protection that could arise from its proposals. Finally, the report lacks a flexible approach that facilitates adaptation to fair standards for different creators.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. It is important to preserve the French conception of copyright, even if it must necessarily adapt to the digital information society, in particular on the aspect of moral law, and to question the possible liability of ISPs.  I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted AGAINST this report because despite including references to a link between intellectual property rights and respect for fundamental rights, the report is very strict in addressing sanctions, specifically through Internet Service Providers (which involves cutting access to the network). The report also deals very vaguely with the problem of data protection that could arise from its proposals. Finally, the report lacks a flexible approach that facilitates adaptation to fair standards for different creators.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report supports the Commission's approach developed in the action plan on intellectual property rights. Consensus needs to be developed so that ip property protection policy focuses on combating activities that violate it on a commercial scale, and this report is on that line so it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. While this report contains some positive elements, such as the protection of fundamental rights in the online field, it still does not clearly distinguish between those regulations necessary to maintain industrial activity or remuneration worthy of cultural creation and those that de facto signify a restriction of access to basic rights such as information, health, art or economic development. These ambiguities, characteristic of the European IPR agenda, must be clarified as a precondition for a genuine political debate on these issues. For all this, I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report deals with the protection of intellectual property rights (IPR) and addresses the economic, social and even health problems posed by infringements of intellectual property rights, particularly through the internet. There is a need to protect intellectual property rights, particularly in the cultural sector, and to reflect on how best to enforce these rights, encouraging and protecting creation.  It is also essential to help SMEs enforce their innovations in the face of large groups, for example through simpler access to justice.  My group, the GUE-NGL, has fought a real battle to demand that any application of IPR be carried out in accordance with fundamental rights and in particular with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and that any application be subject to the principle of proportionality. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which is in line with better protection of IPRs and encourages stricter monitoring of the enforcement of legislation in this area.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I think the report on the EU's plan for more effective protection of copyright makes sense.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on an EU Action Plan for a new Consensus on the Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights, together with my group. This report supports the enforcement of intellectual property. Its aim is to make it more difficult to place goods on the market that infringe intellectual property rights. The report emphasises the role of intellectual property rights in promoting innovation, creativity, competitiveness and growth. It also underlines that adequate remuneration for authors should be an essential element of the EU Action Plan. It also includes the need to raise consumer awareness and disseminate information on infringements of intellectual property rights.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the Report entitled 'Towards a new consensus on enforcement of intellectual property rights: an EU action plan'. I welcome the rapporteur's attention to SMEs, in the idea that they and the creators play a key role in the creative and cultural industries and often lack the capacity to exercise their rights because of the complexity, costs and duration of these procedures in the case of the protection of intellectual property rights. I appreciate the rapporteur's request to the Commission to take account of SMEs when drafting legislation in this area and to ensure that all measures relating to the protection of intellectual property rights have a limited impact in terms of the burdens and costs imposed on the SME sector.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report 'towards a renewed consensus on the implementation of intellectual property rights', as it outlines a future IPR action plan. it is absolutely necessary to apply intellectual property rights, defending those who conceive and create content from those who benefit commercially from infringement of rights, without at the same time criminalising simple private users. I believe, however, that it is appropriate , and here too my opinion coincides with what is stated in the report, to develop information campaigns and to raise public awareness of the costs and consequences of infringements of intellectual property rights.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the new action plan on the protection of intellectual property rights, as I consider this area to be important in view of the need to protect and exercise the rights of intellectual property authors. At the same time, I believe that by promoting the protection of intellectual property rights, we are contributing to the development of creativity, growth and giving a positive signal for innovation. I also consider it beneficial that the proposal works with the concept of raising consumers' awareness and awareness of manufacturers producing imitations and thereby infringing intellectual property rights. I also welcome the emphasis on the need to share examples of good practice between Member States, the role of customs controls and international cooperation. I therefore supported the proposal.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is extensive in its content. If some general principles can be supported, in particular with regard to the remuneration of artists (copyright – an integral part of intellectual property), other aspects there are that cannot merit our support. For example, the proposal that operators exchange information between them to prevent infringement of intellectual property rights as early as possible. We have presented in the National Parliament a proposal on sharing, an innovative proposal, not only at national level, but even at European level.  This report does not go as far as it could and should and merely urges operators to reduce sharing profits. Now, we propose the tax of the operators, which is undoubtedly something different. The report also calls on operators to find ways to ban access to websites and to prevent content from being available in more permanent ways than we do today (which is the opposite of what we propose).

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the recommendation from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of commitments thereunder (10400/2014 – C8-0029/2015 – 2013/0376(NLE)) (Rapporteur: Elisabetta Gardini) (A8-0167/2015), and – the recommendation from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one part, and Iceland, on the other part, concerning Iceland’s participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (10883/2014 – C8-0088/2015 – 2014/0151(NLE)) (Rapporteur: Giovanni La Via) (A8—0166/2015).

name: Elisabetta Gardini
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the text on which we will vote tomorrow forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha Amendment by the European Union and lays down the conditions for the joint fulfilment of commitments by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland, which will then be dealt with in detail by my colleague, Giovanni La Via. The text defines, as you know, the obligations of the second Kyoto commitment, the so-called Doha Amendment, from 2013 to 2020 and, above all, requires Member States to take the necessary measures to complete their national ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015.  Although the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the relevant commitments is certainly a positive step, it must nevertheless be stressed that it is above all the countries of the European Union that participate in the second commitment period, while some of the most polluting countries unfortunately do not participate. In this context, I believe that it is appropriate for the Union to use all possible political, diplomatic and economic instruments available to ensure that an international agreement is reached in Paris at the end of the year, as comprehensive as possible, also in order to break this long tradition, in which the European Union, very often alone, makes all its climate commitments. In this sense, last week's G7 meeting marks, albeit with lights and shadows, some important points towards this goal. In particular, I would like to mention the cut in greenhouse gas emissions by between 40 and 70 % in 2050 compared to 2010 levels and the commitment to contain the increase in global temperatures in 2 centigrade, seem important points, others are important. Just as at the G7 meeting there appeared to be a desire, particularly at german pressure, to phase out the use of fossil fuels such as oil, gas and coal during this century.  Chancellor Merkel called it the decarbonization of the global economy. This, however, seems to me to be a project that is practically difficult to implement. We know that a number of European countries, on the other hand, have, in contrast, increased the use of fossil fuels with a high environmental impact, including lignite in particular. So, if this is the scenario at European level, with lights and shadows, we find on the other side of the Ocean Obama who seems to be giving signals that also go in the direction of an effective contrast to global warming, at least in the intentions because, as we know, Obama's policy in the words of some illustrious political commentators, Obama's policy precisely , seems to have a weak point precisely on the environment, and so I believe that, as the G7 communiqué concluded, the challenge can only be overcome by a global response. So, even if the G7 countries were to eliminate all carbon monoxide emissions from tomorrow, the problem of climate change would not be solved. Here the emerging countries must also make their own contribution: to abandon the rhetoric of differentiated responsibility between rich and emerging countries. In this context, the Kyoto Protocol 2, which requires the parties to communicate, I do not have time to mention everything now, is an important step in the right direction and I really hope that the Paris Summit will finally be that day when we can applaud a binding global agreement to which we will all contribute with Europe, as commissioner always strongly at the head of this process as a global leader.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner Cañete, ladies and gentlemen, the report we are about to deal with concerns the signing by the European Union of an agreement between the Eu ropean Union and its Member States on the one hand and Iceland on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments of the European Union and its Member States for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.  I do not repeat what Mrs Gardini said, reconstructing the history of the Kyoto Protocol and commitments, but I would remind you that at the twentieth Conference of the Parties in Lima in December 2014, the appeal made encouraged all 192 parties and the Kyoto Protocol to ratify the amendment. As of 14 May 2015, this amendment had been ratified by 31 countries. But for it to enter into force, it needs to be ratified by 144 other parties. Specifically, I would like to point out that Iceland is already part of Annex 1 to the Kyoto Protocol and has achieved its individual target for the first commitment period, during which it was to limit the increase in emissions to less than 10% on average.  In the end, Iceland's emissions fell on average during that period. In 2009, Iceland expressed its intention to fulfil its commitments in a second commitment period jointly with the European Union and its Member States. Iceland also participates in the Eu ropean Union emissions trading scheme, the so-called ETS, and in the Eu ropean Union regulation on the MMR monitoring mechanism for greenhouse gases. It has therefore fully embarked on this path, as are the other 28 Member States of the European Union. Iceland is therefore interested in joint compliance with the European Union and its Member States, whether or not it joins the Union.  In conclusion, I believe that this agreement will be a strong signal, which will highlight coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level, especially in view of the forthcoming COP 21 in Paris. The European Union, as has already been said, has a world-leading position in the fight against climate change and has always supported an ambitious climate policy. We are leaders at international level and we are political leaders, we are leading the fight against climate change and we must do so with greater commitment and even more commitment in the run-up to Paris, stepping up efforts for an ambitious, comprehensive and legally binding agreement. In this overall framework of commitments, Iceland has so far played its part, it is continuing along the path together with the other 28 States of the European Union, and that is why I believe it is appropriate, in this context, to call on all my fellow Members to support this ratification, which supports our European action on climate change and will also be able to contribute with iceland's small contribution to the current international debate on reducing emissions globally. I therefore call on all my fellow Members to support the ratification of this agreement, which marks a further small step towards even more ambitious agreements that we hope to reach at the end of the year in Paris.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by welcoming today’s debate. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Ms Gardini and Mr La Via, for their work on the recommendations on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the Agreement between the European Union, its Member States and Iceland concerning Iceland’s participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments. The same also applies, of course, to the shadow rapporteurs for the file. I welcome the suggestions in the recommendations to give consent for the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and to the joint fulfilment agreement with Iceland. Ratification will give an important signal to the international community that we stand by our commitments. This is especially significant this year in the run-up to the United Nations Conference on Climate Change, to be held in Paris in December this year. The second phase of the Kyoto Protocol serves as a bridge towards a post-2020 global climate change agreement. In this context, the European Union and its Member States, acting jointly – together with Iceland – have committed to reducing their emissions during the period 2013-2020 to 20% below their levels of 1990 or other chosen base years. We are already implementing and, as a result of robust policies, are on track to meet the target. The Commission welcomes the texts transmitted by the Council to the Parliament for consent. The draft ratification decision enables the European Union, as a Party to the Kyoto Protocol, to formally ratify the Doha Amendment. It also sets out the terms according to which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland, will fulfil their emissions reduction commitments jointly. The draft ratification decision is consistent with the 2009 Climate and Energy Package and does not change any national targets set in the climate and energy package, nor does it change the emissions cap of the European Union Emissions Trading System. However, the ratification has gained significant value in the international climate change negotiations and is a demonstration of our continued commitment to the UNFCCC process. Iceland participates in the joint fulfilment on the same basis as the Member States. To ensure that Iceland and the Member States are treated alike, the emission level for Iceland was determined in a way that is consistent both with the Doha Amendment and with Union legislation, including the 2009 Climate and Energy Package and the principles and criteria on which objectives in that legislation are based. Finally, I would like to invite you to support the texts in front of you. Ratification of the Doha Amendment will show that, as the world prepares for the adoption of a new global climate agreement, the European Union stands by its commitments. It will also provide an example of cooperation between ambitious partners.

name: Peter Liese
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to congratulate and thank both rapporteurs, Elisabetta Gardini and Giovanni La Via, for their work. The PPE-DE will, of course, support both reports. It is an important signal for the Paris conference that we are now bringing this to a conclusion. I would also like to thank and congratulate the G7 participants, who took very far-reaching decisions on climate protection at the weekend. I believe it is important that we need a long-term decarbonisation objective, and I would ask the Commissioner, Miguel Arias Caete, to bring this into the European debate on the mandate for Paris. At the moment, of course, it seems difficult to give up fossil fuels altogether. But this is a very long-term process, and there are examples of how, if this is well taken into practice, it can already function economically well today. The Commissioner is aware of a project in the Canary Islands that we have visited with a number of Members and which we will be presenting in Parliament next week. It is already possible to supply at least part of the area with 100% renewable energy and a combination of efficiency. That is why this must at least be our goal – even if it is not so easy. We need, and this is very important, a dynamic agreement in Paris. We must be realistic: we will not have an agreement in December of this year that will solve the climate problem, but we must renegotiate, continue to negotiate and take further steps. This should be laid down as best we can. We must take climate protection seriously, and I would like to end by quoting a very conservative American senator, John Warner, who once introduced a climate change law in the United States that did not have a majority at the time. John Warner was asked why, as a Conservative, he was committed to climate change, and his answer was: science and grandchildren. Science tells us that we have to act, otherwise our grandchildren will run into great difficulties. We should take this to heart together.

name: Miriam Dalli
text: f'isem il-grupp S&D. – Tajjeb li nitilqu mill-premessa li kien hawn min jaħseb li t-tibdil fil-klima hija sempli大i kwistjoni li se ssolvi ruhaħħedhaħdhaħna ma nagħmlu l-isforz min-naħaħa tagna. Però dak li qed naraw jiġri madwarna llum jixhed għal kollox xi ħaġa totalment differenti. I nistgħux noqogħdu naħsbuha għax m'aħniex f'sitwazzjoni fejn l-għażliet individwali taħdwali-ħddini waħedhom se jagħmlu xi differenza. Neħtieġu azzjoni de大iżiva mill-gvernijiet u anki mill-industriji tal-pajjiżikollha. U din hija problema universali, problema ta' kulħadd u jekk mhux se niġbdu ħabel wieħed, se jbati kulħadd. Fil-fatt fi ftt żmien, it-tibdil fil-klima jista' jkun anki fattur maġġuri li jwassal biex persuni jisuni大aqalqu minn kontinent għall-ieħor. L-agħar milquta huma l-pajjiżi ż-żgħar li għadhom qegħdin jiżviluppaw, jikkontribwixxu ftit li xejn emissjonijiet imma sfortunatament qegħdin iġorru piż kbirħafna.  Il-partijiet kollha, inkluż l-Istati Membri għandhom jirratifikaw it-tieni committment period tal-Protokoll he' Kyoto u f'Di大embru l-Unjoni Ewropea għandha tkun minn ta' quddiem nett fin-negozjati ta' Pariġi biex jintlaħ ftehim internajonal li verament jagmel differenza. U hawnhekk l-appell tiegħi lilek Gumssarju għaliex inti se tkun qiegħed tmexxi wkoll f'dawn in-negozjati, imma ejja nkunu ikeari wkoll għaliex il-mexxejja tal-Istati Membri għandhom opportunità li jkunu kuraġużi u jindirizzaw, issa, illum qabel għada, din l-isfida ambjentali.

name: Ian Duncan
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Gardini and Mr La Via. Unfortunately our translation failed but it sound very poetic in Italian, Mr La Via, so I was quite impressed with that. 37 out of 192 states have ratified Kyoto. That is only a small step; we have got to be doing much more. Talking of the notion of steps, I was sharing a platform recently with Christiana Figueres, the UN climate change negotiator, and she, quite presciently, said: ‘You do not win a marathon by taking only one step’. I can think of no better way of stating the obvious, which is that we have many more steps to take – but because a distance is far does not mean we should not be pushing as hard as we possibly can. Right now, the Scottish Government have announced that they have failed to meet their ambitious climate change targets for the reduction of carbon dioxide. That is unfortunate, but we should in no way condemn them for it. Rather, we should ask them again how much more they can do to push forward. I am reminded again of a quotation which I think is appropriate: ‘When it is obvious that the goals cannot be reached, do not adjust the goals, adjust the steps’ – Confucius.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, after thanking the two rapporteurs, I would like to broaden the scope of this debate towards the general debate on climate change, and the headlines in today’s newspapers. In quoting the newspapers I would like to praise Chancellor Merkel for her leadership not only at the G7 but also on the energy transition in Germany. At the G7 in particular, however, I think what she did in the last couple of days showed leadership. We heard extremely strong language coming out of the G7 meeting this week. But these are words, words and more words – and the words are not new, because in 2007 the G7 embraced the target of not exceeding two degrees centigrade, and in 2008, at the Climate Conference in Cancún, the same was done. So words are important, but even more important is how they are interpreted, and the deeds that follow. Talking about the interpretation of words, let me quote the Canadian Prime Minister, Stephen Harper, speaking after the G7 meeting. He said: ‘We should not fool ourselves: nobody is going to start to shut down their industries.’ I guess that is the whole point. If we want to avoid the closure of industries, we need extremely ambitious policy. We need new technology, we need alternatives for current industries. Only in that way, via very ambitious policy, can we avoid the future closure of our industries. Turning to the EU and to the Commissioner, it is extremely important that the Commission should come forward with its revision of the emissions trading scheme (ETS) proposal before the summer, because that will be crucial in terms of our own road to Paris.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Let me thank both rapporteurs for, in my opinion, the excellent report and the Commissioner for being here with us today. The Kyoto Protocol was signed back in 1997, but has never been ratified by the biggest polluters such as the US or China. I would like to remind all my colleagues here that, after the Protocol was definitively refused to ratify the United States, its fate depended on Russia.  Yes, it was that, as some say, a terrible Russia, which has been depicted here for the past year often as the very bottom of hell that made the fight against climate change possible at all. If Russia could sign this agreement, I do not see a single strong argument as to why the Protocol and its amendment could not be signed by our most important trading partner, the United States of America.  In Doha in 2012, the Parties to the Protocol adopted an amendment introducing a second commitment period between 2013 and 2020. Yes, the fact that the EU and Iceland will continue to participate in the second control period of the Protocol helps our fight against climate change, but this is quite negligible when we cannot ensure the participation of the largest polluters, such as China, India or the United States, whose share of emissions was only about 36% in the original protocol.  It must be said loud and clear: current emissions from the EU and Iceland are not a problem, it is a mere gesture on the part of the EU. Without the EU's biggest polluters, there is nothing it can do on its own. That is why we must urge these countries to join us during the forthcoming Paris climate change conference.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and the two rapporteurs, Mr La Via and Ms Gardini, for their work. To be honest, I think that these votes will not be the tightest we will see tomorrow. There is another issue on the agenda, so I would like to broaden the scope a bit, not only because of what we have seen at the G7 but also because, as we speak, there are negotiations ongoing in Bonn. What is striking is that everyone is brilliant with words. We are all willing to have global decarbonisation at the end of the century. We are reducing our emissions by 2050 – with a total shift in our energy system. So it all sounds great, and indeed we have to thank Chancellor Merkel for getting some of those words in, but at the same time we know that climate change will not stop because of words. It will stop only because of action, and I have some questions in that regard – mainly to the Commissioner, because I foresee some problems, including with the Commission’s input. For example, at this moment in Bonn, India is asking whether the EU wants to step up its ambition level before 2020, which is one of the negotiation tracks. The EU can do that very easily, for example by elimination of the huge surplus of allowances. But the EU is refusing to do it, and that is, of course, greatly annoying to India, which will be an important country in Paris. So what is the EU going to do to help a country like India? Because another issue where India is having a problem is the global phase-out of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). Is the EU going to propose, as part of the Montreal Protocol, a global phase-out there, or are we only going for words? That is something else I would like to know from the Commission. On the question of the transformation of the energy sector, I do not see why the Commission is, at the same time, going to North Africa and doing a lot of deals on gas – giving us a huge lock-in to gas – whereas we are talking about decarbonisation for the longer term. So, stop this gas lobby too! I would like to hear some comments on that.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the ratification of the Doha Amendment and the agreement between the European Union and Iceland to continue together in the continuation of the Kyoto Protocol meet with a general consensus and are almost a formality that we will carry out with tomorrow's vote, without detracting from the two rapporteurs who have done an excellent job. There is no doubt that all the attention now is, of course, on Paris and the Conference of the Parties next December. There is a strong and justified expectation, the feeling is unanimous: either you come out with a strong, decisive and widely shared agreement or the conference itself will be considered a failure.  From Kyoto to today, there has been a lot of road travel. But we're a long way from the goal. Strategies have changed and words have changed, which no longer talk about future scenarios, but about ongoing phenomena: no longer just reducing emissions, but also mitigation, adaptation, resilience, transformation. The statements made by the G7, with a commitment to keep the global temperature rise within the 2 degree limit, are important but they are not enough. It is clear that we need a breakthrough in negotiations and agreements. We need a strong and binding commitment from all states and we need it now because we have no more time.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI).
text: Madam President, we all agree that we must change our way of life to protect the environment, but once again the countries of the European Union are the good students who sacrifice themselves. For this is what it is all about: a sacrifice for an issue that is beyond us and which we cannot take up alone. Every euro that is not invested in our industrial economy to produce what we need here is a euro that funds globalisation, pollution and, therefore, CO2 production. However, our production standards are of the highest standard. So let's end our companies and SMEs cutting their means of production and innovation.  The United States recently submitted its contribution to COP21. They say they want to reduce their carbon footprint by 26%, but an American will still pollute five times more than a French person, for example. So, is that really credible and acceptable? How can we still negotiate a free trade treaty with the United States and, at the same time, pretend to want to reduce pollution? Everything is implemented in total schizophrenia, without a global vision and without a real perception of the issues. These texts proposed to us will, once again, lead to a disproportionate effort by Europeans in a fight that is not just their own. Everything gives the impression that the ultimate goal is not to save the climate and the planet, but to completely disarm the European economies. To meet this climate challenge, we must therefore change the paradigm, change the model and challenge the sacrosanct rules of the WTO.  In conclusion, let us allow intelligent and ecological protectionism that preserves our local economies, our jobs and the climate.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. We are all well aware that if we have to carry a very heavy burden, we load it into a wagon, we put the horse cart in front so that the horse can tow the burden. If we put the cart in front of the horse, nothing goes forward. Now let's think about it for a second! We all know that in order to reduce the threat of global warming, we need to reduce CO2 emissions. That's where we agree. The question is just how we do it best and best to do it. If we look at the world as a whole, in 2007. In 2005, the G8 estimated that CO2 emissions would have to be reduced by 50% by 2050 – half – but now the European Union is about a tenth of all global emissions – around 10-12%, not more – which means that even if we reduce to zero in Europe, if we no longer have emissions, we will still not meet this 50% target. So we don't need to put a cart in front of the horse. We need to ensure that the large emitter economies – the United States, it is China – finally sign such protocols and also begin to reduce their emissions, because if in Europe we take the burden of all that on our shoulders, we will not only achieve common targets because we do not have so much emissions, we will continue to sink the European economy into global competition. Let's not put the horse behind the cart, let's put the horse cart in front of us!  Thanks for the attention!

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Is the EU putting the cart in front of the horse, as my colleague has just said? I believe that we must also have elements that point the way. Europe has a responsibility to show the direction when it comes to climate protection. That is why it is right that we are ambitious, that we should go ahead. Because, as we saw at the G7 summit, this is a policy for the whole world. That will not stop at Europe, not even with America. As chairman of the China delegation, I know how ambitious China is for the next five-year plan and what huge investment it will invest in technologies, in products, in services for climate protection. So let's not fool ourselves! We are not alone, we are in the worldwide competition for the best ideas, even for the best products. That is what it is all about! The G7 summit sent out a strong signal. Decarbonisation is the guiding principle of the coming years and decades. The question is only for the Commission: are we as good as we always are? We also need carbon divestment in the EU. We have to look at where we are still deep in the fossil fuels. One question, Commissioner, is this: do we really have a strategy for 2050 to reduce greenhouse gases by up to 95%? The third question of credibility would be: what are we doing to provide the USD 100 billion for climate protection in developing countries? So there are still many unanswered questions on the way to Paris.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to say thank you to our two rapporteurs. I am happy to vote in favour of their position on both files. I would like to say that in my group we believe that it is possible to be ambitious and pragmatic in our approach to greenhouse gas emissions. I do not agree that words are cheap. Words, like those expressed at the G7, are important. They set the scene and they should not be belittled or set to one side. We all saw recently the US Senate voting against the general scientific advice, grudgingly accepting that climate change existed but denying any anthropogenic connection, and indeed those of us who went on the environment trip to Washington saw that at first hand. So these discussions on the road to Paris are important. It is important that we set the scene and the tone, and I would like to give my thanks to Mr Arias Cañete for his role in this, because all the feedback I have been getting has been that he has been playing a very strong role on that international stage. So they are important, but I would like everyone to remember that you do catch more wasps with honey than vinegar. Let us make sure that the EU rhetoric is ambitious, encouraging, but not filled with recrimination and the language of shame and blame. We should truly have a united front and move forward together.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Representative of the Council, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteurs of this important document: Elisabetta Gardini and Giovanni La Via.  Ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased with the ratification by the European Union of the second period of the Kyoto Protocol. This is an unequivocal sign, important to our external partners, of the Union's commitment to stop global warming, which is already incorporated into its energy and climate strategy by 2020.  We must continue to do work and there is much work to be done to achieve ambitious and binding commitments later this year at the Paris Conference of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, covering the 195 countries involved.  In Europe, we are making good progress in reducing CO2 emissions in certain areas, such as industrial, energy or housing sectors. This work must continue.  On the other hand, we continue to see CO2 emissions in the transport sector increase due to forms of mobility that we have not yet changed, either because we are stuck with sectoral interests, or the existence of technological barriers, or the need for large investments to make the transition to a new paradigm of mobility. Let us not forget, however, that there are also opportunities for green growth that will be triggered by this investment. If we don't take advantage of them, someone else will.  At the international level, it is imperative to make decisions and these can only be taken at the highest level. The negotiating process cannot be dragged indefinitely and there are countries for which climate warming poses a threat to its very existence. I therefore call for talks to be resumed at ministerial level and at the level of heads of state and government, so that we can reach an agreement and overcome a stalemate that has lasted for too long.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the EU’s conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. It signifies an important step for the continued effort in the EU to tackle its emissions output. Nevertheless, as we gear up for the most significant global climate summit in a decade, ambition remains uneven across the Member States. In my own country, Ireland, the government is currently progressing a climate bill which has no binding targets for lowering carbon emissions – not even the mandatory targets set at EU level. It talks of a low—carbon Ireland, but it does not even define what that means in real terms. It also – worryingly – has no mention of global climate justice. To add insult to injury, the Independent Advisory Council is anything but that and lacks safeguards against short-term political pressure. So Ireland, as with the other EU Member States, must outline a long-term credible vision for a transition to a low-carbon economy. This current whitewash of green policies is not acceptable if serious climate action is to take place.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, despite the fact that there has been no evidence of global warming for the past 15 years, the EU is now ratifying a new agreement to approve yet more ambitious targets for the Union and its Member States, when burdensome EU regulations and utopian green goals are already ruining our industries and driving a large number of our companies abroad. The rapporteur states that, in order to strengthen its role as a world leader, it is important that the EU supports ambitious targets to combat climate change. But few are now following the EU’s stance, as illustrated by Annex B to the Kyoto Protocol. Major polluting countries are abstaining when it comes to committing to the Doha Amendment. The EU is alone in saddling itself with stringent climate commitments, as other countries are not doing so. Major economies have abandoned this obsolete theory – to which some never subscribed – and giving priority to the prosperity of their countries and their people. Let us be pragmatic. Let us start having a more realistic attitude towards this topic. We need to reinvigorate the declining EU economy with a new competitive approach.

name: Olaf Stuger (NI).
text: – The G7 has decided to allocate EUR 90 billion to combat the alleged global warming, promising that this will be no more than 2° compared to 1990. It shows courage to call these kinds of hard numbers. You may wonder how they get these numbers and whether this amount and that promise are well founded. After all, this is a subject that we now know that fiction and reality are mixed up.  The question is whether the earth is warming, and what is causing it, and it is completely uncertain what measures might help. A rather shaky basis for eur 90 billion. If you're so tough as to call hard numbers, have the guts to say who should bring them. And that is the taxpayer, the hard-working middle class in the Netherlands, among others, who will see their energy bills rise. That can be calculated exactly. What cannot be calculated is how much of that 90 billion will end up in the pockets of Al Gore's companies.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to thank Mrs. Gardini and Mr. La Viji who made this report and although it seems as if the formality is the signing of this agreement with Iceland, I would nevertheless like to say that this is an agreement that will give us an incentive on the way to Paris, and also gives us the opportunity to once again examine our positions on climate change.  It is not easy to be both ambitious and at the same time pragmatic. We've heard that here, but it also needs to be ambitious and pragmatic to preserve our economy, our industry, and at the same time to leave this globe to our successors to enjoy. So we still have to make a sacrifice. We've heard the example of the Canaries here. Canaries are an exceptional country with specificities and it is certain that it was easier for them to use wind energy, etc., than it is in some highly developed industrial countries.  But at the same time I want to remind you that what we heard that was discussed yesterday at the G7 summit, it should be commended, fossil fuels removed, it is a long-term project and we certainly need to advocate for it. I'm a supporter of that, and I'll agree with what my colleague said. "If we can't reach our goal, let's not change the goal but change the step, change the method, invent new technologies, find alternative solutions and go to Paris in 2015."

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, it must be acknowledged that the Doha amendment has been a good dressing place to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive. But the hour of truth urgently knocks on our door. We can't tell him to come back in a century, just like the G-7 has done in the Alps. The most industrialized demand 85 more years. There has been more talk of the G-7 than is likely to be talked about this week's Bonn meeting, where the 145 Parties remain enged in an eighty-page maze, when what the planet needs first and foremosth is a figure and a date. Let's be practical once and for all. The new Paris agreement will not be achieved with one-century moratoriums or farragosous documents. In Paris, it's not just about building a better world, it's just about keeping it alive, giving Kyoto a worthy heir.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I have never been and will not become a supporter of a climate policy in which the European Union acts almost alone and the major emitters – the United States, Canada, Japan – do not impose similar restrictions on themselves. However, the Union's commitments for 2020 have unfortunately long since become a fact of law. Poland was one of the countries that contributed the most to reducing emissions during this time, although some Member States significantly increased them. Contrary to popular opinion about my country as Europe's main polluter, today we are only responsible for about 8% of the European Union's total emissions, and emissions per capita are only slightly above the European average. Higher are, for example, in Germany, the Netherlands or Luxembourg. I therefore believe that the Union's accession to the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol must fairly reflect the burden that individual countries have taken on in reducing emissions. The proposed Council decision goes in this direction and can therefore count on our moderate support.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, what future are we going to leave to the next generation if we are not able to stop climate change? What planet will remain tomorrow if we are not responsible today? We know very well where the problem is. The thing is, we don't dare stop him. It is the brutal dependence that States—and consequently the population—have on fossil fuels, because, again and as always, of the interests of large corporations. Fossil fuels are double-edged weapons, which eventually wipe out the health of our people and, of course, the environment. That is why we need Member States to make a real commitment to our land, and that is why the Paris Conference, which should serve to set the course for future, plays a key role; a future that makes us transcend an efficient, sustainable and above all fair renewable energy model. Once again, it's about political will, putting people's needs and the health of our planet above the interests of markets and big companies. On this issue we must also be brave and decide which side we want to be on, whether on the side of the planet and the people, or on the side of the corporations they pollute.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course we too agree on the desirability and importance of ratifying the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol with a view to partially remedying the failure of the Copenhagen Summit in 2009. It is important that the intermediate 20% reduction targets are preserved by 2020 and that the EU's effort in this direction can be shared with other contracting parties to the Protocol who should adopt the amendment under discussion. However, there is still a great deal of doubt that, however necessary this process may be in vain for two reasons: firstly, it concerns the risk that the amendment will not enter into force in good time, since, to date, it has been ratified by 32 contracting parties, a figure which, although it will rise to 61 with this vote, is still far from the 144 ratifications necessary for its entry into force; the second risk is that the Protocol will end up being adopted only by those contracting parties, such as the European Union and its Member States, for which the 20% reduction target to 2020 does not involve any immediate additional effort. So the risks are real and demonstrate the importance of a serious, binding, ambitious and comprehensive agreement being concluded in Paris.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The subject of the current debate is formally the adoption of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. In fact, everyone is looking ahead to the Paris climate summit. The rapper also stated that the European Union must pursue very ambitious and realistic goals. Well, I find that very ambitious and realistic together doesn't fit together. Here, we are proud of how much the European Union is at the forefront of the climate fight. That's true. But setting ambitious goals will not help this global problem.  It should be noted that the European Union is responsible for 10% of emissions. So what's at stake at the Paris meeting? Whether the two biggest polluters, the United States and China, will finally be forced to make a real commitment, because so far there are only words and words. Thank you very much!

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this decision is a testament to the fulfilment of an important promise and is a sign of the Commitment of the European Union to remain at the forefront of the fight against climate change. With this decision, the European Union also encourages other international partners to behave responsibly. Responsibility for your actions is a characteristic of wise management. The level of accountability of aspects of action has many and they intertwine: responsibility for the planet, responsibility for society and responsibility for its economy. With its recommendation, the European Parliament demonstrates its responsibility in European society in taking such an important decision. We are pleased that we are not alone in this and that other world economies are approaching this goal with their ambitions. We witness the consequences of climate change on society and its intensification on a daily basis. Thanks to the media coverage of our planet that the development of civilization and technique has enabled us, we can monitor the more frequent and serious consequences of our actions and actions of our ancestors. Sometimes we feel these consequences on our own skin. They are not pleasant and very expensive. That is why the development of technology and civilization must also serve the more responsible behavior of everyone, states and regions and individuals. Fighting climate change is a common struggle, fighting for our planet, and that's why it's a priority today.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (S&D).
text: I would like to make it clear from the beginning that we are not in a competition. It is clear that if we treat this debate as a competition and we lose this competition, we will all suffer. We all know what the main objective of the Kyoto Protocol is to reduce gas emissions internationally. This is an important step forward in the fight for global warming, containing binding and quantified targets for limiting and reducing greenhouse gases. Given that climate commitments can only benefit us, I welcome the Doha Amendment, which strengthens this period of legal commitment under the European Union's climate and energy package. I believe in the leadership taken by the European Union at international level and I am convinced that the national ratification processes on the adoption of the Doha Amendment will take place by the end of this year, but also that the other parties to the Protocol will try to do the same. Therefore, all the authorities and actors involved must be aware of this, whether they are from the north, east or west of the globe. And we have to be concerned about one more thing: the effect of warming that manifests itself in one area of the globe will affect the other areas as well. It is our duty, all of us, to give future generations the right to breathe fresh air.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – The second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol covers only 14% of global emissions, which is less than the first period and of which European emissions account for around 11%. 14%, this percentage puts the finger exactly on the wound. A globally binding agreement for the period after 2020 is an absolute necessity. The signals we are receiving from the G7 are cautiously positive in this regard. We must avoid the important efforts made by the EU that are a hot plate. We must strive for a climate strategy that not only reduces emissions in Europe, but also aims to develop competitive technologies that offer innovative solutions to the climate problem both inside and outside Europe. We need to make policy choices that are efficient, sustainable and effective. In concrete terms, a circular model, in which we use our raw materials, materials and products more efficiently, will recycle, restore and reuse our products, will improve the climate and will also significantly improve our competitiveness. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I want to ask about short-termism and arbitrary targets. There is a danger, is there not, that new technology is often introduced before the research has been done to be able to make that technology competitive.
