Do you agree with me that there is a danger that we might end up bringing in the wrong types of renewables by putting the cart before the horse in that way?

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. I am not sure that I understood your question very well. In any case, I believe that research and development are very important and that climate policy choices can be effective and efficient when based on efficient research and development. I'm convinced of that.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL).
text: – It seems that frogs do not stay in a container of warm water at all when it always warms up a little. They jump out and they save their vege bodies. Fortunately, that's very sensible. We're dumber than those frogs. Because we'll stay in that hot water bowl. There's always a degree. The danger to our own lives and that of our planet is getting a little bigger. The first climate refugees have already been spotted. And yet we just keep lingering. There's still a meeting to be had. There are still some lobby groups we need to talk to. There's another scientific report of a depraced soul that we need to wait for.  You may know the beautiful work of art by the Spanish artist Isaac Cordal, called "Politicians Discussing Global Warming". We see about 30 politicians standing up to their shoulders in the water, talking, talking, talking. We cannot afford that luxury. We've been waiting two years and there's no more waiting to be done. We need to get out of that bin and get to work. Let us lead by example, let us start up the Paris climate conference and ratify the Doha Report today.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, we have wasted vast amounts of money on expensive and intermittent renewables. We have forced up the price of energy and undermined our industrial competitiveness. We have driven jobs and investment offshore. We have created what our colleague Antonio Tajani has described as an industrial massacre in Europe. And why have we done this? To tackle global warming. But, colleagues, there has been no global warming for nearly 20 years. Here are the official satellite data from remote-sensing systems. No child in school today has actually experienced global warming. We are bankrupting Europe for a theory that was speculative to start with and is looking increasingly implausible. Future generations will look back on our catastrophic collective climate paranoia and compare it with witch-burning in the 16th century, or with the Dutch tulip mania in the 17th. Colleagues, it is time to wake up, face the facts and cut our losses.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday's news at the conclusion of the G7 summit about the commitment of the Heads of State or Government to keep the rise in world temperatures within two degrees of pre-industrial levels gives our debate this afternoon a special value. The ratification of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, which does not present any political problems in substance, allows us to return to the Paris Conference with the United Nations on climate change. We need the agreement – to be reached at the end of the year to prevent the world temperature from rising by more than 2 degrees centigrade from the pre-industrial level – to be global and binding, and the G7 commitment can give us hope that this will happen. However, the objective can only be achieved if the so-called emerging and developing countries also accept a binding global path of mission reduction.  That is why we welcomed with cautious optimism, since it is a non-binding bilateral agreement, the agreement signed a few months ago by the United States and China. Today, on the road to positive involvement of emerging and developing countries, another element is the reconfirmation by the G7 of the commitment made in Copenhagen in 2009 to set up a Global Climate Fund of one hundred billion dollars. Mr President, Commissioner, the conditions are in place for us to move from words to deeds in Paris.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many members have already pointed out that, in view of the PARIS COP, the adoption of this amendment to the Kyoto Protocol is a good sign of the commitment to combating climate change, and the decision taken yesterday by the G7 allows us to approach our debate with cautious optimism.  Yesterday there was a clear recognition, as they have already said, of the binding target of containing global temperature and the confirmation of the fund for initiatives in the poorest countries, but that is not enough. I want to take advantage of this forum, not only to highlight the importance of reaching a binding global agreement in Paris, which is fundamental to the sustainability of our planet, an issue on which we are all already convinced, but also to stress how much more important it is to act now to involve the most polluting emerging economies in joining this agreement. That is why, Commissioner, the diplomatic action that we will be able to put in place in the coming months remains central, not least, if I may say so, in order to dispel the doubts of those who, in the end, want to maintain the status quo. Without agreement, however, with all the major international players, we could perhaps be the first in the class, as Europe, but I agree with those who say that our efforts will be worthless and will risk becoming an additional element of distortion of the global market, which I believe is no longer needed.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Most of this topic is, after all, about reaching an agreement with Iceland, and it occurred to me that not only Iceland, but also other European countries, are in a position to adapt. They are, by definition, aligned with the European Union. However, we have a responsibility to them, which means that, especially in the transatlantic negotiations, the TTIP negotiations, their interests must also be taken into account.  I think that this should be taken seriously by the European Union, given that we have nowhere to back down, so that everything cannot be subordinated to efficiency, trade, industry, and I think that we do need the maximum protection that the Commission can provide in the course of the transatlantic negotiations. Thank you very much for your attention!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think the chasm we are in can be summarised by two quotations from Members here this afternoon. Firstly, from the Left, Madam Dalli said: ‘this is everybody’s problem’. Then, from the Right, Mr Duncan pointed out that 37 of the 192 states have ratified Kyoto; that is 20%. So there is a global problem and only 20% facing up to it. Obviously the problem is going to get worse. So for that reason, Europe has to take a very firm line in Paris to show that we are willing to go and meet our commitments. But this is conditional on others doing the same. Otherwise, as my colleague Mr Kariņš pointed out, we are not going to make any difference. Our emissions are 11% of global emissions, so either we are all in this together, or we will all fall together. Hopefully we can get an agreement, because if it is not global it is not worth doing.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with tomorrow's vote, the European Parliament will give the green light to extending the commitment of the Kyoto Protocol until 2020, which will lead to a 20% reduction in CO2 by that year. The European Union has the opportunity to highlight once again the important efforts it is making in tackling climate change, affirming its leadership at international level, in anticipation of the United Nations Climate Change Conference scheduled for Paris this autumn. 2015 is a crucial year to give renewed life to the fight against climate change, and even from the G7 summit that has just ended in Germany, there has been clear recognition of the objective of accelerating on the climate front. The agreement reached by the Heads of State to keep the rise in global temperature within 2 degrees is certainly an important signal that represents a good result in the run-up to the Paris Agreement.  However, we must remain firmly aware that global warming is an emergency and that, although the path mapped out is correct, speed, ambition and specific actions are needed to lead to the phasing out of fossil fuels.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the issue of climate change is particularly important because it poses a threat to human societies, it mainly hits our poorest fellow human beings, creates new migratory flows, reduces water resources and destroys flora on the planet.  The conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol are important because they send a strong political signal to the international community as to the European response to the problem of climate change.  But other countries on the planet, which have a historical and important responsibility because they have high emission rates, should also take part. After all, the countries participating in the second commitment period 2013 - 2010 are European countries, while major polluting countries are abstaining.  We look forward to important decisions at the UN conference in Paris in December, as the decisions taken by the G7 yesterday on the climate issue are disappointing

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, I am pleased with the report of our colleague and our colleague, I am pleased with this discussion, because as much as there are different tones, it is nevertheless very clear.  We want Europe to remain a leader in the fight against climate change and I can't help feeling that we are in some way almost a bit lonely on this planet and that we need a really strong alliance precisely with those with whom we are negotiating with TTIP tomorrow or with those in Asia with whom we trade in the most diverse ways possible. I think Europe has to bring its ambitions to Paris, but it has to put those ambitions on the table for our partners as well, in anticipation only for these partners to understand that this planet is common. It's not just European, it's all of us who live on this planet and we're all responsible for its future.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to make it clear that I consider the extension of the Kyoto Protocol to be an important step towards fighting for a better climate for our planet. However, I share the rapporteur's concern that the effort to reduce emissions is mainly being made by European countries and that the most polluting countries do not seem equally determined. In March, the Union's position was set for the forthcoming Paris climate summit. An extremely ambitious position on even greater gas reductions after 2020. I am of the opinion that a realistic broad international agreement based on the principle of voluntary is better than setting high binding targets, which we only decide on among the 28 countries. At the same time, I take for granted the need to diversify the commitments of individual countries, as the poorest countries are unable to meet such ambitious standards. I think it is high time that the major polluting countries also made more effort and signed a joint international agreement.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, under the Doha agreement we commit to limit our average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013-2020 to 80% of our 1990 emissions. I am completely in favour of the ratification of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol as it will send a strong international signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change. I believe we need to increase political momentum towards a strong Paris agreement, and this is why I believe that all the other parties to the Kyoto Protocol should rapidly advance their ratification process. We should call on all these countries to ratify as soon as possible, because this is of tremendous importance to ensure the necessary global response to climate change. A signed agreement will keep us united on the right track, sharing a vision of a climate-safe world with sustainable growth for all.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, although the conclusion of the Doha Amendment would not bring any change in terms of Member States’ CO2 reductions and commitments, it would nevertheless give a clear signal, before the Paris climate change summit, about Europe’s ability to face its responsibilities as a polluter and its commitment to be at the forefront of the fight against climate change. However, as the report rightly points out, we must use all possible political, diplomatic and economic tools at our disposal to take on board the still uncommitted major polluters in the new international agreement in Paris this year. In this sense, yesterday’s breakthrough agreement from the G7 summit is an encouraging development. We should do our utmost to use it in the creation of a global climate change action plan that is economically efficient and politically bold and farsighted.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to reiterate my thanks to the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs who have taught in this area. And, as I said in my first speech, Parliament's decision to adopt this amendment and Iceland's process will send an important signal to the international community that the European Union continues to strongly support the process of negotiating a new international agreement on climate change, under the auspices of the United Nations, and that we maintain our commitments , which is especially significant this year, before COP 21 in Paris. Many of you, in the context of this debate, have referred to the G-7 agreements, and let me make an assessment. The Commission welcomes the G-7's fundamental commitments to take the necessary measures to ensure that global warming does not exceed 2oC from pre-industrial levels. More specifically, however, the G-7 declaration also includes a medium-term target of reduction at the top of the recommendation of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, between 40 and 70 %, and a long-term target of 100% emission reduction by the year 2100. As you all know, the 2050 target is a target that the European Union wants to see incorporated into the Paris agreement, because this medium-term objective will allow us to assess whether collective efforts are sufficient to prevent the increase in the world's temperature by 2oC and to periodically review the level of our ambitions. Therefore, this decision, contained in the final joint communiqué, is an important step forward to the December Climate Summit in Paris. Moreover, it is positive that all G-7 countries, except Japan, have already presented their national adaptation and mitigation commitments, the so-called "INDC", although Japan announced yesterday that they are in the final phase of internal consultations, so we expect its INDC to be approved in the coming weeks.  Let us remember that the countries that ratified Kyoto at the time, the 28 in the European Union plus Austria, Norway, Switzerland, Iceland, Liechtenstein and New Zealand accounted for 14% of emissions. At the moment, 37 countries have made adaptation and mitigation commitments, which account for 30% of global emissions, giving the idea that we are on track for all Parties to the Convention to be able to submit mitigation commitments and to cover 100% of emissions. It is true that for the time being only the 28 countries of the European Union have ratified it plus Switzerland, Mexico, Russia, Liechtenstein, Andorra, Canada, Morocco, Norway and the United States, but we are already at an emissions level of 30%. In addition, the G-7 reiterated the binding nature of the agreement and was determined to financially support the Green Climate Fund and to implement other mechanisms to support the most vulnerable countries.  If it is joined that it was agreed to make possible throughout this century a global economy in which fossil energy sources are not used and that clean energy production was encouraged before 2050, the overall assessment of the G-7 agreements is frankly positive and puts the European Union in a very positive position for negotiation , especially if, by the time we arrive in Paris, we will have already presented , or very soon we will present it – our new STD system, the European emission allowance system. Some people want us to present it immediately, we are working on it right now, but in any case the European Union will arrive in Paris with a new emission allowance system in which we have to address all the issues that affect this regime and in which we cannot improvise by making unique changes, but we have to set up a system that is positive , which has a functioning carbon market and which, in turn, warns of the so-called problems of carbon leakage or relocation of our industries, which has also concerned many of you.  In short, it seems to us that paving the way for ratification of the Kyoto process is very positive, especially as a signal to negotiate this ambitious, binding agreement at COP 21 in Paris, on which we are still working at the moment. We have worked to have the G-7, all countries, present its INDCs; we are now working to get them presented as soon as possible by all G20 countries, and it will be desirable that, when we arrive in Paris, a large number of countries have made mitigation and adaptation commitments that set up a much more ambitious scheme than in the past.

name: Elisabetta Gardini
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that this debate that is taking place today really makes me positive. I have been involved in climate change since the Copenhagen Conference and I must say that I really do find that we have managed to transform over the years, a debate that was ambitious – and pointless – into the debate that everyone had hoped for, and which has been mentioned several times today, in an ambitious and pragmatic debate. I believe that this was not an easy achievement.  We have said that it will not be difficult to vote tomorrow. However, we have all remembered how complex and complex the situation in which we are moving is. We all hope that, after Parliament has worked quickly, the Member States will also arrive at ratification quickly and absolutely before the Paris Conference. We have mentioned – as the Commissioner also mentioned – that it only covers 14% of global emissions, and we all know that up to now, we have not been able to reach that binding agreement because countries with very different situations are on the ground and it is difficult to find a single strategy for action against climate change, starting from the needs of growth, development and development. , so distant, from institutional and social stories, so different.  But it is also true that the climate has changed around this issue. Today there is a much more concrete and pragmatic approach. We all recognise that the agreement must be binding and comprehensive. We all recognise that Europe alone would do nothing, it would not be able to change the situation that needs to be changed. So I, who have been very sceptical in previous years, have to say that I join those who are convinced today that the possibility of Paris turning into a new Copenhagen, that is, yet another confirmed failure, this time is far enough away and so I am positive, good work at all.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the interesting debate we have had here today. It is clear from the debate that tomorrow there should be no problems in this House for the vote, both for ratification and amendment, and for Iceland's ratification and participation in this Doha amendment as well. As we had strongly requested in the context of the Lima appeal, the path of adoption of the amendment and ratification by all cop members is gradually proceeding and tomorrow we are taking another small step in the right direction.  But on the other hand, the debate was an interesting debate because it covered the whole issue of climate change policies. It has shown us how everyone and more and more believe in these policies. Just a small, perhaps out of tune, intervention by those who do not recognise the existence of climate change, but in principle we are all moving in the same direction and we are doing so with conviction. However, it is necessary for Paris and in the run-up to Paris to run its course and for there to be more and more binding commitments on the part of all the COP countries, so that we can move towards a binding agreement, but certainly a global agreement. Finally, I would like to underline with pleasure what I said in conclusion to Commissioner Cañete, who spoke of the possibility of coming to Paris, including with a new proposal from the CO2 emission ETS. This is an important step, because it would mean making it clear to the outside world that Europe is not only confining itself to the choices that are made at the conference of the parties, but is moving forward and equips itself with new systems in a positive direction, and so I welcome the fact that the Commissioner will present us to the Paris Conference, with the proposal of the new ETS system that we will be considering in this Parliament.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 10 June 2015 at 12.00. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – I believe that the European Union must continue to take a major approach under the Kyoto Protocol and, in this respect, I support the adoption of the Doha Amendment, which provides for commitments to reduce GHG emissions in the period 2013-2020, to 80% of the legally binding emissions in the reference year. Given that Romania is the first European country to sign the Kyoto Protocol, by which it has committed its commitment to support the fight against climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, I believe, like the rapporteur, that the formal adoption of this Amendment is among the European Union's priority objectives, contributing fundamentally to global efforts to address climate change.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997, setting a binding target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions at international level. We know, however, that Kyoto has not been ratified by all the world's leading polluters. In particular, it has not been ratified by the US – the world's largest polluter (in absolute terms and in per capita terms) for decades. In 2012, in view of the end of the Kyoto period – and in the absence of a comprehensive and effective agreement capable of replacing it – it was decided to extend the Kyoto Protocol, extending with it all its weaknesses, including the perverse flexibility mechanisms. The EU has proposed a reduction in its emissions by 20% (compared to 1990) for the second Kyoto commitment period. Despite frequent propaganda about the EU's "leadership" role in tackling climate change, this figure was below that recommended by the UNITED NATIONS Climate Change Panel – a reduction of no less than 25% by 2020. But above all, the biggest problem is that a mercantile approach to climate change, ineffective and perverse, of which the carbon market is a paradigmatic example, continues to prevail in the EU.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – As we approach the Paris climate summit, it is important to appreciate the efforts and intentions made so far. The declarations of consent covered 34% of the world's energy-linked CO2 emissions. Unfortunately, this 34 percent is still not a high enough number. If more countries cannot be persuaded to support the convention, the conference cannot be said to be effective. In terms of the magnitude of emissions, the commitments of China and India are key. On the one hand, it is understandable that ensuring economic growth is a top priority for these countries, but the long-term goals must not be lost in sight: the impact of climate change is projected to be felt more strongly in China and India (floods, crop yields), which will also have a significant impact on economic performance. Europe's leading role in the fight against climate change can only be successful if partners are involved.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We welcome the commission today's decision on CO2 emission commitments to strengthen the European Union's negotiating position in its emissions reduction target to 20% by 2020. But we must not forget that Europe as an emitter has a different impact on the overall computation of the one it has through its consumption patterns or the overall organisation of production. Global emissions growth of more than 50% since 1990 is no stranger to us, but in Europe the economic crisis (not permit markets) has stabilized CO2 generation. The relocation of European production, the investments of our multinationals and the export of our mode of consumption have contributed growth in global emissions. Solving the contradictions of climate change means betting on a different, self-centered and sustainable development model, capable of being exported to all regions of the globe. It means upward harmonization of global environmental standards, provided the technical and financial means for this transition. This is not an easy agreement, but above all, it cannot be carried out without abandoning the prevailing neoliberal framework.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the two-degree limit has long been known to climate scientists' view of how high the rise in temperature on our planet can withstand without serious and irreversible changes in habitat. It is important that the leaders of the world's largest economies also take this objective seriously. The EU, the US and China, among others, have already announced their emission reduction targets for the Paris meeting, but two thirds of the world's CO2 emissions are still outside the reduction commitments. The EU's pioneering action against climate change risks becoming an illusion. On Monday, member states' energy ministers ultimately did not intervene in any way in state aid for the production and use of fossil fuels. Direct payments to this industry alone amount to EUR 100 billion a year. Although the use of fossil fuels in energy production could be stopped by 2050, germany, Great Britain, France and Italy have increased the use of coal in recent years. In the absence of a strong political message, the EU has missed the potential that the renewable energy sector could bring at best. For example, there are no European companies among the top 10 solar panel manufacturers, but the focus of expertise has shifted to China. Investment in renewable energies is also reflected in china's early progress in meeting its climate targets.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Algirdas Saudargas, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on European Energy Security Strategy (2014/2153(INI))(A8-0164/2015).

name: Algirdas Saudargas
text: Rapporteur. – Dear colleagues, first of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the Commission for their excellent cooperation and very thoughtful advice, to the shadow rapporteurs for their rich cooperation and hard work. Dear colleagues, the energy security of the European Union is particularly important in the current geopolitical context. Europe's dependence on energy resources not only prevents us from pursuing an independent foreign policy, but also affects the competitiveness of our industry and the daily lives of all citizens. Therefore, without better communication, cooperation and speaking with third countries, Europe will not be able to ensure a unified energy policy and energy security. We must make solidarity between Member States in the event of a disruption of external energy supply not only words, but also concrete actions. I believe that we must pay particular attention to the coordinated diversification of suppliers, routes and energy sources and to the increase and promotion of local energy production. We have and can use local energy sources, and this includes fossil fuels, renewable energy sources and advanced technologies, where Europe is leading with its innovation and skilled workforce, and we must make better use of this potential. As has been said on several occasions, an efficient internal market is the basis for ensuring energy security and solidarity between Member States. We need to pay sufficient attention to the development and optimal use of connections. It must be remembered that there are still energy islands in Europe and that their security must be integrated into continental European networks. Finding the right balance between the various energy areas will be one of the main challenges of the energy union being created.  Mr President, dear colleagues, I do not want to repeat the importance of energy efficiency, renewable energy sources and decarbonisation of the economy. As regards energy security, all energy-related topics are inevitably intertwined. I am convinced that it is equally important to implement both the internal and external energy policies of the European Union. However, I would like to draw the attention of my colleagues to the fact that in this report the issue of security must remain at the top of the area. The aim of this report is not to address how much energy efficiency we need to achieve, or how many buildings we need to renovate, but rather to set out the basic guidelines on which we will seek to ensure our safety, both in the long term and in the short term. Other energy-related issues should not be taken hostage by the issue of security, but will be subject to a more detailed examination within the framework of European Energy Union policies. Once again, we thank all and I call for support for this report in tomorrow's votes.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am pleased to take part in this debate on the European Energy Security Strategy. I would like to extend my sincere thanks to all members who will participate in it, but I am particularly grateful to Mr Saudargas and all the drafts members of the opinion for their efforts to achieve this balanced report by the European Parliament on an issue which is very current, but at the same time very sensitive. I would also like to thank you for the excellent cooperation you have had with the Commission throughout this process, providing us with many opportunities to share and explain our views. The draft report before us is an excellent result of the work and commitment to energy security, which adds to the political momentum we have wanted to give to this and other issues with the Energy Union. Let me explain why we think this is an important report. First, because it maintains and reinforces a balanced and comprehensive approach to energy security. Energy security is a very complex issue that requires action in different policy areas and various levels when it comes to decision-making. We need to keep this approach balanced if we are to successfully address this collective challenge. In this regard, the draft report reflecting the structure of the May 2014 energy security strategy seeks to respond not only to our short-term challenges, however politically sensitive they may be, but also to look further, taking into account strategic priorities, both within and outside the European Union. In this broad concept of energy security, achieving a true internal energy market is essential, as is research and innovation. I would like to congratulate myself on the fact that the draft report we are discussing today has placed particular emphasis on the need to moderate energy demand and increase domestic production, mainly from renewable energy sources. The Commission fully shares this approach. We will continue to move forward on the basis of this strong political message from Parliament, especially in the context of this year's forthcoming COP 21 Conference, with the aim of reaching a historic agreement to combat climate change. At the same time, this draft report, in its external dimension, mentions the most urgent supply problems we face and highlights in a very clear way the dependence of a single supplier on energy resources, with the vulnerability that this creates and the lack of competition, because it can impede economic growth and jeopardize security at national level of the European Union. The Commission shares this view. Therefore, we will work to diversify our sources and supply routes. To do this, we will continue to work in the southern gas corridor, the Southern Gas Corridor, the Mediterranean and Algeria, as well as relations with our traditional partners, such as Norway, the United States and Canada. I have already visited several of these countries in recent months, aware that diversification of routes and suppliers is essential for the European Union. In northern Europe, the establishment of liquefied gas hubs, with multiple suppliers, is greatly improving security of supply, and this example must be followed in Central and Eastern Europe and in the Mediterranean area. In this regard, we are preparing a liquefied natural gas and storage strategy to be adopted at the end of this year, together with the revision of the Regulation on the safety of gas supply, two essential parts for diversification of supply and to be prepared in the event of gas supply interruptions. I have also been able to see with satisfaction that the report once again stresses the need to speak with one voice on the international stage and calls on the Commission to develop a proposal for mandatory ex ante assessments of intergovernmental agreements with regard to their impact on the internal energy market and their compatibility with European Union legislation. I can assure you that the Commission is working on this and plans to submit a proposal in the first half of 2016. Finally, I would like to underline the emphasis that the draft report places on the Energy Union Strategy, adopted by the Commission in February this year. As you know, energy security is one of the three overall objectives of the Commission's Energy Union Strategy. Our energy has to be safe, competitive and sustainable. Of course, all three objectives are interdependent and go hand in hand. Therefore, the implementation of the European Energy Security Strategy has been fully integrated as a central element of the Energy Union Strategy. We are planning to publish at the end of this year the first report on the implementation of key actions related to the European Energy Security Strategy and I hope that dialogue in the European Parliament will be, throughout the process, a key pillar of our action.

name: Arne Lietz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I want to talk first and foremost about the external aspects of our report. The creation of a European Internal Energy Union must be accompanied by a coherent energy and climate foreign policy. One of the most pressing issues is undoubtedly the diversification of our energy imports and the need to speak internationally with a common European voice. However, energy and climate policy must not be limited to pure security of supply. This includes the global fight for climate protection. Europe must make better use of its foreign policy instruments in order to support European projects such as decarbonisation and the energy transition to the outside world. New nuclear power plants do not increase our security of supply, but represent a constant security policy risk in addition to the outstanding issue of nuclear waste disposal. This is particularly true if Russia is allowed to build new nuclear power stations within Europe and continue to operate them.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The Trade Committee stresses the special role of trade in energy security. We see the king's way in building energy partnerships that bring security not only to ourselves but also to our partners. Access to energy is a basic need of the people, and energy poverty is unfortunately a growing phenomenon also in Europe. The INTA therefore insists that energy security ensures affordable, sustainable, stable, secure and predictable access to energy for citizens and businesses, and must be part of an inclusive strategy for economic growth and a coherent interrelationship between EU trade and energy policies. These partnerships should be embedded in the goals of global climate protection and corresponding binding commitments in energy chapters in EU trade agreements. We call on the Commission to take strong action against environmental dumping by third countries that do not comply with international decisions. The INTA stresses that reducing dependence on one supplier should not be replaced by a new dependence on another supplier. Europeans oppose fracking and are in favour of a decentralised replacement solution. The export of environmentally friendly energy technology is an opportunity for Europe. Energy agreements will in future have to be adopted under the co-decision procedure.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – In our view, the European Energy Security Strategy contains some really good points that can improve the quality of the environment in order to strike a balance between environmental and socio-economic factors. This is primarily about energy efficiency. Full use of its potential and the development of smart infrastructure would stimulate growth and create quality jobs and reduce energy consumption. Reducing energy consumption, together with energy efficiency, is a fast and efficient way to tackle many problems, such as energy security, dependence on resources from abroad, high prices and unemployment.  Eliminating unnecessary consumption through better efficiency, stronger connectivity, greater market integration and sustainable investment in energy, especially as regards buildings, could enable households to gain equal access to a single, affordable, competitive and secure energy market and avoid the energy poverty that affected a quarter of EU citizens in 2012.

name: Филиз Хюсменова
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the IMCO Committee. – Madam President, as rapporteur for the opinion of the IMCO Committee, I have made clear my position on the need to overcome the strong dependence on external energy suppliers and the high prices they impose to achieve a functioning internal energy market.  One of the key elements for achieving these objectives is the improvement of energy infrastructure. Therefore, as a Bulgarian representative, I want to draw your attention to the importance of integrating the southeastern region of Europe into the European gas market through the construction of a gas distribution center in Bulgaria and interconnectors to its neighboring countries. This will provide natural gas flows from a variety of sources, including the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. I believe that the implementation of such a project will be a real expression of the policy we are discussing today.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. Europe is currently in a precarious situation. We are, as we know, import more than half of all our energy consumption, with a growing trend each year. And the largest supplier is Russia, and it is about natural gas, about oil, about coal, even about uranium. The largest supplier is Russia. But, colleagues, what does this same Russia do?  We know that in 2006 and 2009 it cut gas supplies to Ukraine because of disagreements, but for a year now it not only cuts gas supplies to Ukraine, it is activeing in to ukraine and openly uses gas supply as a weapon of blackmail. Russia - whether we like to admit it or not - has proven that it is no longer a fully trusted partner country for us. So what can we do to increase our security? The report prepared by Parliament seems to me to have made this quite clear (and there is a request to the Commission to take this into account when presenting the specific legislation): to connect the networks in gas, electricity, to diversify sources, to increase energy efficiency, to make more use of domestic resources, and to learn to speak with one voice. The European Union market has a total of 500 million consumers. At the moment, we each buy natural gas separately, for example. If we could join forces, our citizens, entrepreneurs and competitiveness in general would benefit. Thank you for your attention! (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Can you tell us the price which Russia is taking from Ukraine, and the price which Russia is taking from Poland or Germany?

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Colleagues, it is quite clear that Russia supplies about a third of its natural gas to Europe via Ukraine. If Russia can blackmail Ukraine, Russia can blackmail us all. It is not about prices, it is about the possibility of blackmail, from which we have to get rid of.

name: Miroslav Poche
text: On the part of the S&D Group.  Our current way of life, the functioning of our economy and, in fact, the whole modern society are completely dependent on uninterrupted supply of available energy, both affordable and physically. Naturally, we must consider ensuring energy security to be one of our main priorities. Measures will not only be taken by the Member States, but measures taken by the European Union will also play an increasingly important role. That is why we need an effective and strong European strategy to meet our energy needs in the future. A strategy that will not simply be a repetition of traditional recipes for our energy problems. The view has long prevailed among experts and the public that energy security is limited to seeking access to new fossil fuels, especially oil and natural gas. That is why the discussion has very often turned to plans to build new pipelines and pipelines. This view was based on a century of dependence on these raw materials. Personally, I believe that this position is long overdue. It is the unsustainable that threatens our long-term energy security today, I would say, an unreasonable dependence on oil and natural gas. These are not just imports from countries that tend to use the so-called energy weapon to advance their foreign policy objectives. I also consider the non-critical support for mining unconventional ... (interrupted the chair speaker). The technologies used today clearly have a negative impact on citizens' health and the quality of the environment. In itself, this should be enough to prohibit hydraulic fracturing mining in the European Union.  That's not the only reason. The great danger is also that our dependence on oil and natural gas would only be extended. Thus, the extraction of these unconventional resources will only lead to a much-needed transition to a low-carbon economy being postponed again into the future. That is why our faction is tabling an amendment calling on member countries to stop the extraction of unconventional resources by hydraulic fracturing in Europe.  I am very glad that the report presented is not limited to a short-sighted effort to promote the construction of new pipelines and pipelines or to find more reliable partners. On the contrary, it comes with very concrete proposals and measures to gradually get rid of our dependence while strengthening the competitiveness of our economy. The European Energy Security Strategy must first and foremost start at home, in our European Union. We need to fundamentally change the way we use energy, or in other words, how we tend to waste it.  Energy savings are one of the least costly ways to strengthen our energy security. At the same time, lower consumption means less dependence on oil and gas imports. Sadly, it was in this area that the Member States had no greater ambitions last autumn and did not adopt a higher binding target for energy efficiency.

name: Ashley Fox
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the European Union has an energy security problem because it is too reliant on one source of energy – Russian gas. I agree with Mr Kariņš that Russia is ruled by an unfriendly government which uses energy as a political weapon. We saw this happen in both 2006 and 2009 when Mr Putin decided to cut off gas supplies to Ukraine. The continuing crisis in Ukraine has only exacerbated the danger of this happening again. While improving energy efficiency and our use of renewable energy are both important, they will not have much impact on the EU’s energy dependency on Russia. If we are to relieve the focus on energy security, we should be willing to use all the tools at our disposal, including shale gas and nuclear energy. We should also encourage the development of new technologies, especially carbon capture and storage. I reject the calls in this report for binding climate and energy targets and interference in the energy mix of Member States. That is a national competence and I want it to remain so. Commissioner, the best way to ensure energy security for the whole of Europe is to have a properly interconnected single market. We need the ability to move gas and electricity around the continent, so that if one source is ever unavailable, another can be used. I would ask Members to imagine how differently we would have approached the crisis in Ukraine had we been able to replace Russian gas with imports from elsewhere. The Commission should concentrate on resolving the technical and legal issues which prevent the free exchange of energy, and they should also use their funds for projects of common interest to improve the connectivity of our energy networks. A properly-functioning and free market in energy across the EU will reduce prices for consumers and businesses and provide energy security for all of us. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under rule 162(8))

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I would like to ask Mr Fox a question. Earlier, there was a debate on climate change: we need to reduce greenhouse gases. And you just said that every state must keep its energy sovereignty and that the exploitation of shale gas must be encouraged. Explain to me, how can we reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and fossil fuel consumption, and at the same time address the problem of climate change and achieve the COP21 goals?

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I want Member States to take sensible and proportionate steps to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, but that does not mean destroying our enemies (because we are doing this so much more quickly than all our competitors), and it also means that we maintain our standards of living.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the EU Energy Security Strategy is at the very heart of our energy politics in these uncertain times. Ensuring that our supplies of energy are stable, secure and reliable is not just about convenience for consumers but also about ensuring that people are warm enough to survive in winter. By fundamentally changing the way we supply, distribute and consume energy, we can ensure that European citizens do not have to fear such threats in the future. I am glad that in this report we have been able to agree, across party lines, on the need to look not just at the issue of gas imports. We have taken a step further by also addressing the link between the need to reduce gas imports and the benefits that more efficient use of energy and renewables can bring. This will not only address security of supply but also offer significant opportunities for local jobs and growth within the EU through productive investment in infrastructure and renovation. Reducing dependence on fossil fuels, particularly gas and oil, has created local jobs and a competitive economy, as well as a thriving export base in the development of renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies in my own country, Denmark. I think that it is important that Europe should undertake such a green transition, delivering both energy security and economic prosperity at the same time. This very important report could contribute to all this. I want to end by thanking the rapporteur and colleagues for such good cooperation on this very important file. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I appreciate my colleague's intervention, I also appreciate the report, but I have a one-off question. How do you think we will be able to make the Energy Union, how will we be able to reduce the difference in development in energy and transport infrastructure in the Member States if the Junker investment plan does not take into account social cohesion and geographical criteria, by allocating funds on technical criteria?

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you. I am not saying – and I do not think anybody will claim – that this is going to be easy in any way, but I think we all see increasing willingness to cooperate across party lines in this house and hopefully also between Member States, because the challenges that we face are for real. This will require more cooperation and thereby, hopefully, also fulfilling the wishes from the person asking this important question.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, despite the improvements made in the report, there are significant omissions and problematic references that we cannot ignore.  Energy for us is a social development good, to which we must all have responsibility and equal access. The primary objective must therefore be to combat energy poverty. To achieve this, neoliberal austerity policies must be ended and policies to support social development and enhanced state control promoted.  That is why it is important to ensure public ownership and infrastructure management with strategic importance by the state, based on the interests of society and the people. Particularly negative in the text is the proposal for the Commission's compulsory participation in negotiations on intergovernmental agreements, as well as the ex ante and ex post evaluation of these agreements.  The GUE will not support the promotion of an energy policy controlled by the Commission, limits the sovereignty of states and reduces national flexibility in the formulation of multidimensional and efficient international energy relations. Much more so, the Commission cannot ask for increased powers, while there are significant problems in the energy supply of the Member States and also the energy isolation of many Member States, but also regions, from the Union's major energy networks continues.  In response to these problems, we welcome the proposals to exploit domestic gas sources in the eastern Mediterranean and to create a Mediterranean gas hub with LNG development, in order to exploit the prospects created in the region for the Union's energy security.  The European Union must also support the efforts of a Member State, Cyprus, to exploit its mineral resources, especially now by declaring the Aphrodite deposits as marketable, we are talking about 140 PCMs, it is important that the European Union finances, but also provides technical support for the implementation of the necessary infrastructures. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), blue card question*. Madam President, do you not believe that in order for the European Union to finally be able to develop an integrated energy strategy, it must not only highlight the Mediterranean and the Eastern Mediterranean, where there are proven energy reserves, as a hub, but at the same time the European Union, to start investing in energy infrastructure, particularly in the Eastern Mediterranean, taking advantage of Cyprus, Greece and Israel? , but also other countries which appear to have the possibility and the possibility of being an energy aid agent of the European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a blue card question*. Madam President, first of all I wanted to say that it is important and we thank the rapporteur for that, as well as all the colleagues who have accepted this amendment of ours. It is important to look at the Union's domestic deposits, particularly those in the Eastern Mediterranean, but also how we create infrastructure.  I spoke of the isolation of the Member States and, while it has been set that by 2015 this isolation should be brought to an end, there are still Member States, such as Cyprus, Malta, but also other island regions, which are isolated. It is therefore necessary to exploit the domestic deposits and create the necessary infrastructure, particularly in the Mediterranean.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, energy security has become a primary concern over recent years in Europe, especially in the light of the Russia-Ukraine crisis. The Commission has rightly identified the fact that reducing energy dependency is a key to strengthening energy security in Europe, especially considering that approximately EUR 400 billion is spent yearly by the EU on energy imports. Yet the strategy they came up with has not managed to translate this high-level ambition into the most needed actions. The own-initiative report of the European Parliament contains several more forward—looking elements than the Commission proposal. I would like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Algirdas Saudargas, and the shadow rapporteurs for their constructive work in this regard. These achievements include the chapter entitled Moderating Energy Demand and reiterating the position of the European Parliament on 2030 climate and energy targets. However, in my opinion, this own-initiative report only gives a partial answer to energy security challenges. I fear that the extreme dependency on Russia will simply be turned into a dependency on other external fossil energy suppliers. This is not what we should be aiming for. The future energy policy of the EU, as also mentioned in the Energy Union Package, should be fully coherent with other EU policies and be based on reduced energy demand, energy savings and the use of renewable sources with the increased role of consumers/prosumers. It should also tackle the pressing issue of energy poverty. Unfortunately, in many areas the report does not set clear directions and it lacks long—term thinking when it comes to concrete measures. I would like to highlight the selection of projects of common interest – PCI’s – where we experience a strong bias towards fossil fuel projects, which is neither defendable nor in line with the decarbonisation pillar of the energy union package. The report mentions several types of technologies, including shale gas, liquefied natural gas (LNG) and carbon capture and storage (CCS), which should be supported. This would lead to a severe lock-in effect in the European energy system. The report remains very much focused on gas and other conventional energy sources and does not tackle the multiple forms of energy dependence – technological and financial fuel dependence. Also, it does not acknowledge the important role of renewables – we only find a few hints in the strategy. The EU should, rather, take steps towards an energy transition using sustainable renewable sources of energy, which are becoming increasingly cost—competitive with conventional sources and provide multiple benefits, including more jobs, opportunities for the local economy and lower energy import costs. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I would like to thank you for your support. In his speech, he mentioned extreme dependence on external sources and the fact that we can switch from one extreme dependence to another, although he also mentioned the importance of shale gas. To be honest, I consider shale gas to be a seriously environmentally detrimental story, and I wouldn't get into that, but do you see an opportunity to replace the straining imports that we're now operating in with energy efficiency?

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Blue card answer. Thank you for asking. We agree on shale gas, and I also consider it to be a very serious source of pollution. I didn't mention the importance of it, I put it on the table as a problem.  Energy efficiency and renewable investments can replace Europe's dependence on Russian gas. Instead of joining Europe with this fossil fuel system through gas infrastructure developments, it is precisely necessary that the money we spend on these developments or part of these developments is absolutely necessary, certain grid developments are absolutely necessary, certain new resources are needed, but with this money we need a sustainable renewable energy system ...  (the President has withdrawn the floor from the Member...)

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we would like this Parliament to take note of a number of facts: in May Saudi Arabia declared that for the middle of this century it aspires to become 'a global power in solar and wind energy' and to export not oil but electricity; in June, the Norwegian Parliament voted to divest from coal; This year in Poland Chevron, Total, ConocoPhilips, Exxon, Marathon Oil have abandoned shale gas, in the Member State it was believed to hold the largest European reserves. Finally, in May, a recent study by the Monetary Fund reveals that between direct subsidies and environmental and health damage, fossil fuels this year will cost humanity $5 000 billion or 6.5 % of the world's GDP. The energy security strategy, despite the substantial improvements – and I thank Saudargas – therefore appears not only out of history but also unfortunately schizophrenic: on the one hand, there is a declared war on climate change and the desire to reduce energy and political dependence, on the other hand it provides for the import of fissile material, clean coal, new drilling and the use of shale gas, and new investments in infrastructure that will still result in climate gas emissions. Time wasted, money thrown away and attitude from complete irresponsible. If we want a solid and lasting European sovereignty, it is time to invest unequivocally in a renewable model, not only the real economy, but the need for real security, geology, the climate of the planet and european citizens and their health.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI).
text: Madam President, in the name of highly questionable geopolitical considerations, you intend to replace Russian gas with American shale gas or even The LNG of Qatar - a great democracy... - in defiance of the criteria that make Russia our natural partner, namely the available stocks and the ease of transit.  Thus, Mr Saudargas's report is akin above all to an indictment against Russia, a political report which cares little about the economic and ecological imperatives of our energy security. I want to prove that there is no mention of biogas. However, this is a future path to be encouraged. Biomethane comes from the methanization of organic materials such as agri-food waste or sewage sludge. This is, in fact, an energy that creates jobs and is not relocated. Better yet, if it is provided in a decentralized way on waste generation sites, its production contributes to the development of our rural areas. Finally, the solid residual part of biomethane production replaces natural fertilizers with chemical fertilizers.  So, before we move from a Russian dependency to a US-Qatari dependency, start by relying on the know-how of our industrialists.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – Madam President, energy security is certainly a crucial subject for us, and we have two sides of the coin: external and internal. Internally, indigenous energy resources are the most important consideration. Of course, efficiency is very important – nobody disagrees with that – and so are renewables, new technologies, and also clean coal technologies. If we use coal in a clean way – in an environmentally-friendly way – we can achieve a lot in terms of energy security. In the internal energy market, infrastructure is also absolutely necessary, as is implementing the existing law. And, of course, there is an energy community. Eight countries surround the European Union, making for an Energy Union of 36. We should build an Energy Union of 36, not just 28. I am glad that, externally, the first EU-USA Energy Round Table, which we held two weeks ago in the European Parliament, was a success, because we should cooperate closely with all our partners – in the West, the East, the North and the South. Another important issue is energy solidarity. Sometimes we omit this issue, but we have written it into our treaties, and energy solidarity is so important. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President (and thank you, Mr Buzek, for such an interesting speech), we have been looking from a Swedish point of view at the energy security situation in Poland. One big part that you did not mention – which I would give you the chance to elaborate on – is the biomass industry, which is producing more than 52% of Sweden’s energy. Poland, too, has huge potential for developing a big biomass industry. Would it be in the interest of Mr Buzek to work together to strengthen the biomass industry in Poland?

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am very interested in strengthening this sector. Thank you for this remark, but we do not have as many forests as Sweden does. Probably you are the best country in Europe from this point of view. We must remember that forests could be the most important source of biomass and biofuels, maybe second-generation or third-generation biofuels – not first-generation biofuels. We checked properly that the first generation was a mistake for all of us.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: – Energy security, many have already pointed out how important this is for our economy, but also for our social policy, for our families, for our industry. After analysis, I think we can agree if you have to get more than half your energy outside europe. Every year we are talking about EUR 420 billion, which is more than EUR 1 billion a day that we spend unnecessarily outside Europe. As far as the solutions are concerned, we still need to discuss them and there are still differences between the different political groups. In the short term, we must ensure that we act together in the world with regard to the different suppliers. We have to sign contracts together.  But above all, we must think in the long term and therefore frame energy security in the energy union and also in climate policy. I am pleased to refer to what the great leaders decided yesterday at the G7. That is all still a lot of words, but I am assuming that we will take action. That is a very important framework for me, the long term and the long-term investments. Because, Mr Buzek, coal, for example, is not an investment in the long term and in the future. If you build new coal-fired power plants now, you're going to hang on to that for the next 30 years, and that can't be the intention.  In the past, the Commission has actually chosen the way. In the 2050 roadmap, she said, there are no-regret options.  There are options that we can take now and which are actually the right options from all possible points of view, from the social and economic and the ecological, are: renewable energy, energy efficiency and not continuing to invest in fossil fuels. That is why the amendment on shale gas tabled by our group is so important. After all, why invest in a technology that we know will re-use fossil energy, re-use polluting technology for our environment? Let's immediately make the right choices and the right choices that lie ahead. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – What do you think, Mrs Van Brempt, of ground-based coal gasification, during which we can simultaneously produce gas, electricity and heat using our coal, while using co2 produced by up to 40% in methanol production and plastics in turn? I am talking about clean technologies for the use of coal. This gives us great prospects, including in terms of new jobs.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. – There is the short and there is the long term. In the short term, these technologies are acceptable to enable a transition. Gas and coal have a role to play in our industry. In our energy supply, we will have to abandon working with fossil fuels in the long term. So these technologies are not long-term technologies. That distinction is extremely important.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Energy Security Strategy is the next step in building an Energy Union. The completion of this project is today the foundation of the European Union. Among the many important demands on the energy efficiency of the internal market or on increasing domestic energy production, particular attention should be paid to conventional and unconventional energy sources within the European Union. No energy source should be discriminated against. I would like to pay particular attention to cleaner and more efficient coal burning technologies and shale gas production. These are the two elements that have the most important impact on ensuring energy independence in Europe on the basis of domestic resources and significantly affecting the price of energy, especially electricity, which is one of the highest in the world in the European Union.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We now have the chance to move from a society dependent on fossil fuels to a society based on renewable energy sources, and this is one of our biggest challenges. The EU is the world's largest importer of energy. The EU imports 53% of its energy at a cost of over EUR 400 billion per year.  We are already on track to reach the 2020 target of 20% of total energy being renewable. But if we are to reach the 2030 target of 27% of energy coming from renewables, we need to make a move. In order to progressively and effectively integrate renewable production into a market that promotes competitive, renewable energy sources and drives innovation, the energy markets' networks must also be adapted to renewable energy sources. If we miss this part, we also miss one of the most important components in creating a better environment and also in strengthening our energy security.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, several important questions arise when we approach an energy security strategy in Europe: the critical importance of progress in energy efficiency in transport, industry, buildings; the need to diversify the origins and sources of energy supply internally and externally; increased enhancement of renewable energy and recognition of the inexorable long-term depletion of fossil fuels; the need for major investments in energy production and distribution chains and in the research and development of less mature technologies; remove certain Member States from energy isolation.  Finally, these and other issues will not be properly addressed and implemented but in the context of public, democratic, energy sector control, including energy planning, production and distribution. It is not the myrific virtues of the internal energy market that will ensure objectives of progress, social justice, sustainability, development. Energy is a precious public good that is urgently necessary to rescue from the hands of private monopolies.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is an important and central area for ensuring independence and independence, not least in view of the fact that Russia has increasingly chosen to use its energy resources for political purposes through both blackmail and intimidation. The Commission's communication and the report have many good things, but also a great deal, unfortunately, that go in the wrong direction.  Here, for example, there is talk of new major investments in fossil energy sources, new gas pipelines and also extracting more oil where possible, no clear idea of phasing out coal dependency or the use of coal, even though everyone really knows that it is unsustainable. The report also states that climate and energy safety objectives can be reconciled. I agree with that, they can pull in the same direction and should do it too, but why don't you do it later?  We are well placed in Europe to make the transition, but we are hesitating and we are pointing in different directions. It creates uncertainty instead of clarity, confusion instead of activity. Would you please tell me which way to leave? It depends on where you want to go, said the cat. It doesn't really matter, Alice said. Then it doesn't matter which way you go, said the cat.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, there is almost no problem which cannot be made worse by regulatory intervention, and energy markets are a perfect example. We have hit them with emissions targets, an emissions trading scheme – including backloading and a market stability reserve – feed-in tariffs, renewable obligations certificates and, in my country – the UK – a carbon price floor. We have set aggressive targets for biofuels and then cut them, doing huge damage to investors. Is it any wonder we are seeing investors shy away? Is it any wonder that nuclear, coal and gas power plants are being closed or mothballed? Do we not understand that intermittent renewables can never replace base—load generating capacity? In my country, where we used to have a comfortable spare capacity margin, we are now down to low-single-figure percentages in winter. Blackouts and power cuts are a real possibility. The rapporteur is right to call for energy conservation measures and indigenous energy production, especially shale gas. But more than that, we need a stable regulatory environment to promote investment. We need to understand that we cannot continue to rely on expensive and intermittent renewables. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE)
text: question ("blue card"). I would ask my honoured colleague to take a look at reality. Because in reality, it's in a completely different way. It is there that renewable energy sources are today lowering prices across Europe in terms of energy, in terms of electricity. It is wind power that is the cheapest to invest in today, and so should the UK invest in more, and that is also a lot of planning from the energy authorities. So look at reality – it would make things easier. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Eriksson, I have been looking at reality, and when somebody stands up in this House and says that wind power is the cheapest generating technology to invest in, I do not know how to respond. I have never heard anything so absurd in my life. Wind power onshore is much more expensive than conventional generation, and wind power offshore is more expensive again. We are ruining our economy by wasting money on these fabulously expensive initiatives. They cost more to build per unit of capacity and they cost more to run. You may be living in fairyland; I am not.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a seven-year-old would understand that the energy market cannot be an open and competitive market and that it is part of the natural state monopolies for energy security. Indeed, let's take the electricity market: what is expensive are the production overcapacity that can be used episodically during peak demand. Make the competition and prices work, and then we abandon these overcapacity to get a lower price and gain market share, at the expense of energy security. So why is this House in favour of liberalising the energy sector? Why did you choose energy insecurity? Incompetence, first of all, because many do not know this market. Secondly, to obey speculative finance, present here and at the Commission. Because, make a spot market for electricity, gas or oil, and you can, by derivatives, buy or sell a hundred times, a thousand times production, create scarcity, play on prices and speculate. Finally, to obey the United States, and thus wage war on Russia, get out of energy security with Russia for energy insecurity without Russia. This parliament is under the domination of the liberal kleptocraticism.

name: András Gyürk (PPE).
text: – One of the biggest challenges facing the European Union today is to ensure security of energy supply. Our continent is dangerously vulnerable to external suppliers.  When looking for a remedy for this situation, we also need to know that there are also more vulnerable people among the vulnerable. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. In Hungary, for example, 80% of condominiums are heated by gas from a single source of imports. We need to change this situation, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report can serve as a compass for this work.  I agree that our task is to achieve a single energy market, to apply existing legislation to increase energy efficiency and diversification, and to develop infrastructure. The best rules are worthless if the pipelines are missing to transport energy.  The Commission and the Council should therefore pay particular attention to compliance with the requirements of the energy package. It should encourage energy market participants to make better use of existing infrastructure, e.g. two-way interconnection and the construction of infrastructure that is still missing.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. If we go down this path, the Energy Union could become a realistic objective. (The speaker agreed to answer a question marked with a blue card in accordance with Article 162(8))

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. When it comes to energy security, you have highlighted infrastructure and transport capacity. This is really important. But going back to the example in Hungary, you, as you mentioned, will increase the infrastructure in any way, if we cannot find a new source of supply – perhaps in the short term – then this dependency will not change. So how do you see the diversification of the gas source itself Hungary the short term?

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. "Thank you very much for asking, Congressman. I argued, among other things, for two-way traffic when it came to infrastructure development, so that we could get more resources. Hungary has made considerable efforts in recent times to improve its position in terms of infrastructure. It has also built storage capacities and inter-outlets. Now it is up to our neighbours, if you will, to create the possibility of two-way traffic so that we can actually get gas from other sources. Thank you!

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Is-sigurtà Ewropea tal-enerġija hija sfida waħda fil-qafas tal-Energy Union li għandha twassal għal aktar sigurtà, sostenibbiltà u anki kompetittività. Imma x'ifisser dan fil-konkret għall-konsumaturi tagħna? Jiena ġejja minn Malta, pajjiż b'sistema iżolata u allura nifhem l-importanza li l-ebda pajjiż ma jibqa' maqtugħ, [u li] jiddependi minn s wieorsħed tal-enħija bil-konsegwenzikollha li sitwazzjoni bħal din tista' ġġa maghaha. Irridu nħarsu lejn sistema sigura li fil-qalba tagħha jkollha l-interess tal-konsumaturi, ta' dawk il-familji li jħallsu l-kontijiet tad-dawl u tal-gass, ta' dawk in-nisa u rġiel li f'ħafna pajjiżi madwar l-Unjoni Ewropea qegħdin jgħixu f'dik li tissejjaħ energy poverty għaliex m'għandhomx il-finanzi meħtieġa biex imqarħ isaħnu jew jiffriskaw id-djar tagħhom.  Jien esperjenzajt kif roħs fil-kontijiet jista' jwassal għal kwalità ta' ħajja aħjar u anki tkabbir ekonomiku. U f'dan il-qafas ukoll irridu nżommu quddiem għajnejna l-ħarsien tal-ambjent, il-kwalità tal-arja li ngħixu fiha u t-tnaqqis tat-tniġġis bħala prijorità. Hemm bżonn li naħdmu aktar biex ikollna skema effettiva li tnaqqas it-tniġġis filwaqt li na大大ertaw ruħna li nissalvagwardjaw il-kompetittività. U fuq kollox irridu nkunu ferm aktar ambizzjużi, billi ninvestu aktar f'riħerka u innovazzjoni ħalli niżviluppaw aktar teknoloġiji li permezz taghom nistgħu niġġeneraw enġerija aktar nadifa. Din hija sfida komuni tagħna lkoll. Opportunità li tista' toffri sigurtà akbar lill-pajjiżi kollha tal-Unjoni Ewropea, ħajja aħjar għaħaħ-ħdini tagħna u ambjent aħjar għalina u gatħ-tfal tagħna. (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura).

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Energy—intensive industry is moving from Europe to countries with cheaper energy costs. That is why I know, for example, scrap metal merchants who are selling now to India because they can get a better price for doing so, even with all the carbon footprint involved in transporting that metal from the UK to India. High energy prices push more of this to happen and cause fuel poverty for pensioners. Could, therefore, the European Energy Union prove counterproductive if it is not competitive?

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: tweġiba karta blu. – Dak li għadek kif għidt inti, irriaffermajtu wkoll fid-diskors tiegħi; il-ħtieġa li nilħqu bilan大. Għaliex inutli li nħarsu lejn ħaġa waħda jekk imbagħad ikollna konsegwenzi oħra. U dak hu li qed nitkellmu dwaru, u dak hu li hemm bżonn; li kulħadd joqgħod bilqiegħda u naslu għalih, għaliex dak li qed issemmi wkoll jirrelata per eżempju mal-emissions trading scheme.
