Imma tajjeb tfakkar ukoll li għandna industriji li llum il-ġurnata qegħd jimbuttaw biex anki jkollna prezz realistiku tal-karbonju, ħalli iva, din is-sitwazzjoni i tirrealizzax ruħha.

name: n/a
text: . – As the morning debate also pointed out, any EU dependence on Russia and its energy raw materials is indeed a big gamble.  The best way to ensure energy security is to ensure alternative supplies and better energy interconnections between Member States, but also to maximate self-sufficiency and rational management of our own resources. Unfortunately, the report again contains things that we have repeatedly spoken out against. I will mention the binding targets for 2030, we see once again calls for the decarbonisation of the mix and the preference for renewables. Unfortunately, we must keep reminding that the energy mix is in the hands of the Member States. These have different conditions and use different sources, technically it is simply impossible to dictate one model across Europe.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I agree, of course, with many of the statements which have already been made here. This goes without saying for import dependency, as well as for the fact that we need, in particular, to secure the gas sector and to move forward in that respect. But if there is one thing that can really make a large contribution to increasing our energy security, it is to finally create that internal energy market. It is something that has been on the table for a very long time, but many Member States are lagging with the implementation of the measures they themselves have agreed upon. Well-functioning gas and electricity markets will secure affordable energy prices for consumers, as well as improving industrial competitiveness. Unfortunately, the internal energy market is still kept divided by too many different national policies: we are looking at a dragon with 28 heads, all looking in different directions. A truly common vision, also guided by market logic, will help to improve investment and create a single market. The time has come to really move forward, to make sure that we implement – fully implement – EU rules and guidelines. We need the further development and modernisation of our transmission infrastructure, and we really need the network to start implementing energy security. I am therefore very glad that already this week 12 Member States have addressed this at European level. Yesterday they agreed to start collaborating and working together, so in that respect we have seen the first steps towards a true Energy Union that will also deliver on energy security.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, it is obvious that we are dealing with the energy security issue in a diametrically opposite way. For us, energy is a basic human good. The European Union's energy security strategy must therefore have as its main objective the effective eradication of energy poverty.  But apart from any legal disputes, I am impressed by the way we operate as a Parliament. At the same time, which is rightly pointed out in the resolution that energy should not be used as a political pressure tool in any context of international cooperation, elsewhere, but also in the opinion of the AFET Committee, it is proposed to use energy as a means of exerting political pressure and even with blackmail.  You are asking the Member States for a single energy expression on the basis of so-called solidarity and you are targeting their right, or other acceding states, to abstain from agreements because they affect the policy that certain European interests shape. Such policies allow Mr Schulz to abandon democratically elected governments for their choices in the energy sector.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it took a major crisis with Russia for us to finally seriously discuss the European energy security strategy. It's about time.  We face at least two challenges. The first is our energy dependence. We import more than half of the energy we consume, which is about 400 billion euros a year, or more than a billion a day! According to the figures, 95% of our uranium, 90% of our crude oil, 66% of our gas and 40% of our coal come from abroad. And Russia accounts for almost a third of these resources, of all types. The second challenge is climate change. We are told that in order to limit the temperature rise to 2oC, two-thirds of our fossil fuels must remain underground. That's the problem. So what is the proposal of the Commission and the Member States? We are told that we need to diversify our sources of supply. But the same system remains unchanged because we hear that we have to provide for other pipelines, other pipelines, and that brings us back to fossil fuels. We are also told that it is absolutely necessary to exploit indigenous resources. What are these indigenous resources? It's unconventional gas, shale gas. In Europe, we do not want shale gas! We are also talking about nuclear energy, but we are going to be dependent on uranium supplies, because we do not have independence at that level, and we will also be dependent on the Russians for Rosatom.  Therefore, the solution is really to develop renewable energies, since they are a matter of European sovereignty and contribute to energy efficiency. That's the real solution.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Rivasi is good. We are here talking about energy security and energy mixes, but I would like to ask you what diversification we intend to achieve if we talk about renewable sources, but in practice do the Member States be allowed to cancel the incentives for renewable sources and at the same time increase subsidies to fossil fuels in electricity and gas bills for millions of CITIZENS of the European Union? According to the International Monetary Fund, fossil fuel subsidies in 2015 were higher than the health spending of all governments around the world: $5.3 trillion per year. By eliminating these subsidies, you could increase government revenues, cut global carbon emissions by 20%, reduce premature pollution-related deaths by 55%.  That is why fossil fuels are by no means cheap, as this Commission would have us believe. The real costs are gigantic and Europe must give a clear signal by eliminating fossil subsidies once and for all because they have devastating consequences for the climate, the environment, public health but also our fragile economies.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Caete, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work In the course of today's debate on European energy security, far too little has been highlighted as the point that yesterday an important first step was taken, namely by the signing of a declaration for enhanced regional cooperation in the field of electricity markets by 12 European Energy Ministers: enhanced regional cooperation, strengthening European security of supply. A second point has not yet been mentioned today, namely that yesterday a study was published on behalf of the World Energy Council, which shows that billions of savings would also be possible in the interests of European security of supply, billions of savings by reducing reserve capacity. Up to 100 large-scale power plants could be saved if security of supply is taken seriously to the extent presented today. What does regionalisation mean? What steps should be taken? The main objective is investment in the development of the pipeline network, the second of which concerns cross-border interconnectors and, thirdly, the reduction of bottlenecks within national borders. These three points are important for regionalisation. The report we are debating today has chosen more complex access, namely more complex access in the sense of a cross-policy nature. Two dimensions that have also been chosen quite correctly, namely the Internet dimension, where they say: what should be done to increase energy security? More in-house production of energy. Renewable energy is the main focus here, which is a good thing. And a second point, namely the increase in energy efficiency and, thereby, the attenuation of demand. It should be borne in mind that energy efficiency also costs money. And the foreign policy dimension, diversification of third countries – please do not fall from one dependence to another. And the last point that has already been raised today: EUR 400 billion is invested annually by Europe in energy purchases. This is where we need to be coordinated.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Today we have a debate that takes us into the future: 2020 – what can we do for the next generation? Of course, it is not only security of supply that is important, but also the prices that are then to be paid in this area. That is why it is a question of redefining the price zones. Price zones across national borders would be particularly important; emphasis should be placed on promoting more competition. The second area, of course, is the use of renewable energies, and in particular hydropower. The storage of hydropower in particular is the basic prerequisite for being able to use renewable energy more efficiently. What do you propose in the area of Natura 2000? Is there also the intention to define in future areas in which water can be stored and where hydropower can take place? And, of course, how are you going to deal with the Water Framework Directive in order to increase the efficiency of power plants here? My final point is that the quality of the electricity must be ensured. What do you have in the area of frequency stabilization? How can we bring the phases, which vary widely across Europe, into a single framework, and how can the voltage in the network be guaranteed in quality?

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their very good cooperation and to draw attention to two other aspects. I find it regrettable that the current political debate on energy security is dominated mainly by foreign policy issues. It is above all a question of our heavy dependence on imports towards Russia and the question of from which country or region we can then obtain our gas in the future. I consider this development to be counterproductive, because new energy partnerships alone will not be able to secure our energy supply in the long term or reduce our dependence on imports. The second aspect I would like to draw attention to concerns the EU's so-called domestic energy sources, which are often referred to in the report. This concept has already appeared in the Commission's communication on the energy supply strategy, without it being defined in any way. I therefore wonder what exactly this term is meant to mean. For example, is nuclear energy also one of the EU's domestic energy sources, even though 95% of the uranium used in the nuclear sector is imported from outside the EU? For example, despite environmental concerns in many Member States, is hydraulic fracking also one of these so-called promising domestic energy sources in the EU? This concept requires a very clear definition on the part of the Commission. That is why I put a written question on this last week.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – The advantage of the European Energy Security Strategy is that it recognises the need to ensure diversification of energy supply and sources. It is also an important element that strengthens regional cooperation in the field of energy. These are very important demands. However, we cannot be indiscriminately against this document. I personally strongly protest against the demand for decarbonisation. For countries such as Poland, the decarbonisation of the economy means the collapse of many workplaces and the increase in energy poverty. Ignoring this problem contradicts the idea of Solidarity of the European Union and undermines the sincerity of the intentions in building a reputed Economy of the European Union.  You say that countries like Poland have to adapt and they have to give up fossil energy resources. You utter these words and demands with lightness and without deeper reflection. You are not interested in what the cost means for me and several other countries. You're not interested in who's going to pay for it. Did you know that meeting these demands will mean losing 500,000 jobs in the next decade in my country? Who will compensate for this and how? It is easy to talk about the demands of decarbonising you, wealthy countries whose economies have been unlimited by any such restrictions for decades and have developed unrestrictedly. Dear President, the energy-secure European Union is one that respects the interests of all its members, not just the strongest players. I ask you to remember this. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". You are talking about price security. What is the real state of play? If you take renewable energy; is this much cheaper in the long term and also in the medium term? Let me just compare that if we take the solar energy that is described as priceless, it is much cheaper in Germany today than, for example, electricity from new nuclear power stations – take the data from Hinkley Point – apart from the jobs it generates.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I have not heard the question, but I will answer that, in terms of energy costs, there are no costs cheaper than those based on fossil sources, namely coal, which in my country accounts for 90% of the total energy resource, that is, all the energy raw materials from which we obtain electricity. The costs of renewable energy are very high, and if it were not for the subsidies it receives, they would be incomparably higher than the energy we obtain, for example, from coal or gas.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, one of the main reasons we have failed to build the internal energy market so far and ensure energy security is the national protectionism still practised by many Member States. I therefore welcome the fact that this report sees the energy security issue as a European issue rather than a national one. I also strongly welcome the Memorandum of Understanding signed yesterday between the Commission and the Member States to strengthen security of supply through further market integration. A functioning internal market and the free flow of energy across borders is the key to ensuring security of supply. More work needs to be done, however, and I hope that the Commission will build on the strong will shown by the Member States yesterday and translate this will into action to build energy security and the energy union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President; Mr Cañete, it is not the electric oligopoly that will solve energy security problems: it is the States that must direct resources towards improving energy efficiency and generating with their own resources.  We are not just talking about renewables, hard hit by the Government of which it was part in Spain. We are also talking about coal, a safe alternative that also involves the development of clean combustion, R&D&I technologies, as is the case with ELCOGAS, and not as fossil imports and the development of energies as dangerous as nuclear or fracking.  Minimum local coal generation quotas and thermals need to be met for more efficient combustion, and Miner Funds and subsidies should be extended beyond 2018. Only in this way can the employment and settlement of stocks in mining basins be ensured and, moreover, intervene in the price of energy established for the benefit of multinationals.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report. It is good that we started at 3 o’clock with the climate debate and are now having an energy security debate. Maybe we could have merged those two discussions because, very clearly, energy security and climate protection can – and should – go hand in hand. Therefore, if one really takes this seriously, it is a clear agenda for energy efficiency – the fastest, cheapest way of reducing our dependence on energy – and renewables. None of the other options have those advantages. Maybe there is still someone asking about nuclear energy; well, I would say, go to Finland or Hungary where they are building nuclear – or want to build nuclear – and are now deeply dependent on Russian technology and Russian uranium. So that is no longer any help in terms of energy security. I have one question for the Commissioner, to end once and for all the gossip: will you now make very clear that the EU will never ever again allow public money to go into nuclear? It would be very helpful in this debate if we closed that circus as well.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – I think that EU energy policy has made a lot of mistakes in the past and we should admit it. In the Czech Republic we have a country flooded with solar panels. This also applies to consumers who pay billions of crowns a year out of their pockets to pay for the EU's preferred energy. We should get rid of prejudice, there are prejudices about nuclear electricity, we could have heard that from a colleague a while ago. There are prejudices against natural gas, if we do not get rid of these prejudices, then we will get into other problems. Now that the wind is blowing more strongly in Germany, the energy from the wind must be sused, and we must all invest more money in the grids. It's costing us all a lot of money, so please get rid of these prejudices.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen– excuse me, I am not feeling very well – I think that energy policy in Europe should be a whole and should be collaborative. Let me give you an example: I come to Strasbourg, when I do not come by car, I take the plane to Milan and then I have to stop in Lyon, and then take another plane to come to Strasbourg. From Lyons to Strasbourg, I see nuclear power stations, practically on the border with Italy, on france's side. If a problem ever happens in France, it would obviously also be a problem for Italy. So what's the point of discussing energy, when then in fact each state makes history in its own right.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: "I hope that the thud will return to strength and health. Returning to the subject, the European Energy Security Strategy should be one of the most important Community documents. It concerns ensuring a good future, development and relative independence from energy or its sources outside the territory of the Member States. Such a document should therefore be narrowed down to strategically necessary priorities. It should be in line with the energy union and the policies of the individual Member States. One of the main pillars of such a strategy should be a strong inclusion of indigenous energy sources, as they ensure external independence. In this respect, therefore, no policy of discrimination between any indigenous source, including coal or shale gas, should be pursued. Emphasis should also be placed on supporting research and development on modern technologies for the clean use of indigenous sources. Unfortunately, this strategy does not, in principle, provide for such assumptions, on the contrary. For these reasons, it is more of an ideological rather than a substantive position. For these reasons, it is a document which , it is a pity to say, but nevertheless, will be difficult to accept.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – I congratulate my colleague Algirdas Saudarg on the comprehensive and very important report that has been prepared.  I have three observations: 1. The resulting and deepening tensions between the European Union and Russia send a strong signal to the entire European Union to create a fully connected, integrated and shock-resistant energy union as soon as possible. However, such a union is only possible when there is a strong political will to make difficult decisions. The use of energy resources as a powerful political pressure against the European Union is breaking down, causing internal tensions and depressing the economy. 2. I miss a regional approach in terms of energy security. The Commission should make concrete proposals, taking into account the energy specificities of individual regions of the European Union and assessing optimal energy mixes. One of the essential work in the field of energy security is the synchronisation of the baltic region's electricity networks with continental European networks. 3. To date, the Commission has not presented a strategic approach to the development of nuclear energy in the European Union, although the Energy Action Plan presented by the Commission stresses the role of nuclear energy and its importance in the future production of clean electricity. So far, however, no action has been taken to politically support those Member States that continue to want to use or develop nuclear energy.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have spent this life in industry, and I cannot vote in favour of this report, because I do not see the necessary technological neutrality, particularly in two areas. Firstly, with regard to nuclear energy, how can we achieve the necessary decarbonisation of industry worldwide if we want to do without this industry? Seventy nuclear power stations are currently under construction in the world, and the contribution to decarbonisation will not be possible, especially outside Europe, without nuclear energy. And the second area for me is fracking. There is now a new study that makes it clear that the risks of fracking have been vastly exaggerated. That is why we in Europe must also strive for these two technologies. Fear is a bad guide here.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, welcome to this discussion, Commissioner. What did we actually learn in connection with the so-called ILUC file? We learned that we have a considerable amount of Member States afraid of being left behind and therefore opposing targets and paths towards producing a more energy-efficient Europe. In the closing debate on ILUC, I said that we have to revisit this issue in three years. I think I was a wrong. If we are seriously going to tackle the question of energy security, we need goals and targets as soon as possible. Part of the solution of the energy security issue is actually linked to our ability and willingness to get the circular economy up and running. If you look at the means of energy production for the moment, we see that we have a huge challenge – we have a mountain to climb. I hope that our beloved Commissioner will do his utmost to get this on the table as soon as possible.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I would like to congratulate my colleague Algirdas Saudarg on a well-designed document. The document is well balanced on both technological and security of energy supply. Most of the solutions he proposes, such as the development of local renewable energy, respond well to both security and environmental challenges. And most importantly, the successful implementation of the proposed green energy measures, the launch of the energy resources themselves, will also be able to make a significant contribution to the achievement of the European Union's other objectives, such as the creation of new jobs in the regions.  We Greens have made a more determined call in the report to renounce loyalty to the artifacts of the last century, nuclear energy that is causing severe damage and fossil fuel-based energy. The report could also be improved by enabling the Participation of partner countries with European values in the European energy market. (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question of the person who raised the Blue Card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – What do you think about the so-called energy mix? When we burn gas, this is CO2 emission, and when we burn biomass it is again not very good for the environment. What do you think for the future? Nuclear energy is quite clean and it does not have any impact on the environment.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: answer to the blue card question. "Indeed, the questions you have asked are very important, but we must first of all choose reliable, safe, environmentally friendly, uncontaminated, uncontaminated waste for future generations, cheap enough and sustainable energy with nature. I think that is our priority. With regard to the nuclear power plant, I can say yes – in production, if there are no accidents, everything is fine. But how to then solve spent fuel, nuclear waste? There is no answer in Europe today, there is only a solution for 50 years. What's next? Thousands of years will need to work with him.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, the European Union's energy union and security, by promoting its independence from Russia, strengthening investment in renewable sources, further liberalising the energy market and privatising its infrastructure, serves the interests of monopolies. It develops into an environment of business contradictions within the Union, geopolitical rivalries with Russia and China, involving the United States that are sharpening, with imperialist interventions and wars, where the European Union, the United States and NATO are at the fore, with peoples, waves of migrants and refugees at the fore.  The Communist Party of Greece has revealed that behind the Greek government's positions on a "geostrategic upgrade" to the energy "game", the country is promoting greater involvement in imperialist competition on behalf of major interests.  As long as wealth is in the hands of the few and energy goods, folks will pay more for fuel and electricity, thousands of households will be deprived of heating. This is how the working-class forces must shape their stance, develop their struggle on the basis of their own interests.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, more than EUR 1 billion of energy is imported into Europe every day, which shows how dependent we are on imported energy. Moreover, the stress tests showed how dependent many Member States are specifically on Russian gas and that they are in a very vulnerable position in this way, because we know that Russia has included energy policy in its range of foreign policy instruments. It is a significant change because, even during the Cold War, this was not the case.  Europe therefore needs reliable partners, and it is therefore important that we try to get its own part of the TTIP agreement negotiated with the USA for energy. It would play a particularly important role, particularly in the case of gas and LNG.  At the same time as opening up new energy routes to Europe, it is important to strengthen our own internal transfer possibilities so that we can get rid of the energy islands, just as Mrs Saudargas points out in her excellent report. The objectives set out by the Commission in the Energy Union, particularly in terms of increasing energy self-sufficiency and increasing energy efficiency, also offer many opportunities. But at the same time as increasing the share of renewable energy in Europe, it is important to ensure that it can be done on the most market terms possible.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the security of our energy supplies is the central issue for the future of the social, economic and productive fabric of the European Union. We only have to consider that we import 53 % of our needs at a cost of EUR 400 billion. We are the largest energy importer on the planet as the European Union.  That is why I believe that the report offered to us by Mrs Saudargas on energy security is important and balanced. There is a balance found in the Committee on Industry, External Economic Policy, which is particularly advanced: it focuses on energy efficiency, infrastructure and renewables as non-exclusive carriers of europe's internal energy supply, and above all sees investment in the diversification of energy lines and sources and suppliers – primarily in favour of those Member States that, more than others, see the areas of sovereignty as reduced – see this as the way forward.  This report seems to me to be a solid starting point for the discussion with the Council, which only yesterday reaffirmed at the meeting of permanent representatives the commitment to a supply policy that takes into account the path towards the completion of the internal market, in line with the conclusions of 20-21 March 2014. This also seems to me to be an opportunity to relaunch a more ambitious vision of climate and energy policies, where the growth factors of the economy do not contradict the factors of improvement of the environment and vice versa. The challenge is complex and we must continue to work on it.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Tomorrow we will vote on the report on energy security. I regret to note that mr Saudargas' meritorious report has turned into a Christmas tree of ideas. Colleagues use - or should I say abuse - this kind of report to reopen legislation which is not in question. For example, several left-wing groups are trying to use the competence of the Member States to determine their own energy mix. In my opinion, the solution to our energy dependency is a clear policy with a focus. Unfortunately, the report lacks broad-based compromises that set ambitious but realistic objectives and provide solutions.  Of course, there are also a lot of positive elements in the report, and I am thinking in particular of the focus on energy efficiency, the better connections of the energy networks and more investment for research and innovation. However, it is a pity that the negative elements threaten to overshadow the positive ones. However, as a Parliament, we will have a new opportunity in the autumn with the energy union report. I therefore call for the opportunity we have to seize to ensure affordable energy for our families and our businesses.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I do not like the word ‘strategy’ in our discussions. I think we are beyond that, and we need action. The energy market is waiting for action and not strategy. Today we have a situation in Europe where three Member States are dependent on one external supplier/operator for the operation and balancing of their electricity network. Currently a third country – Russia – can significantly influence electricity systems in these Member States. This creates vulnerability, not only from a technical perspective, but, given the current geopolitical situation, it also diminishes significantly the level of energy security. It is not enough to build adequate infrastructure within, and between, Member States to develop a resilient energy union. Full EU support should be given to end the situation. Synchronisation should constitute a part of the energy union concept. Without this concept, the energy union would not be full and consistent. We need solidarity, cooperation and a European approach among Member States to end this unacceptable situation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, respected colleagues, respected citizens, if we want to be leaders in the fight against climate change and thus ensure the technological competitiveness of the European Union, if we are to reduce the European Union's macroeconomic deficit due to imports of fossil fuels amounting to eur 1 billion per day, it is necessary to change the European Union energy policy to a sustainable energy policy that will stimulate the development of new fuels for the successful replacement of imported fossil fuels , which will encourage the development of (incomprehensibly) technologies, policies that through renewable sources and energy efficiency will enable citizens to participate actively in the decarbonisation of society.  Instead, as energy security, we are offered a policy that encourages Member States, such as Croatia, to the exploration and exploitation of domestic unconventional and conventional energy sources, mainly fossil sources, which takes us back to the beginning of the 20th century instead of introducing us to the 21st century and what it declaratively stands for: safe, clean and cheaper energy. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Dear Mr. Advocate, thank you for accepting this blue card. You mentioned Croatia. It is certainly known to you that the project of the new coal-fired Plomin thermal power plant and you know that the intention is to explore the Adriatic, or rather exploit the Adriatic. Do you agree with me that plomin on coal must not happen, and that as far as exploration of the Adriatic, i.e. exploitation of the Adriatic, should be done to maximize the provision and protection of the Adriatic from future exploitation?

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I fully agree with you that Plomin C on imported coal must not be built because it does not provide energy security to the Republic of Croatia, but in fact, it is still dependence on energy imports. As regards the exploration of exploitation in the Adriatic Sea, there is a clear view that Croatia has not complied with european union directives that require that the marine environment be managed in a good and safe manner in cooperation with its neighbours.  And that is why, as long as an effective way of protecting the Adriatic Sea is not ensured, I am against going into the exploitation of oil and gas in the Adriatic.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, I am sorry but the best description of this report is the German word ‘Scheiße’ – thousands of words, politically correct, with no real meaning. Perhaps I am the only one who read through it. I would ask you to read through Chapter I, for example, to see what is in this report. The discussion here has also been absurd. Somebody said that Russia is waging war on Ukraine through gas sales, but when I asked for the price he refused to answer because this price is one third lower than the price at which they are selling gas to Poland or Germany. This is not a war: it is cartel assistance. China and the United States have gas four times cheaper than in Europe – four times cheaper! It is shale gas. Now, when I hear that the last American company withdrew from Poland last week because of bureaucratic obstacles, I find myself asking whether they were obstacles or perhaps Gazprom agents. When I hear all these tales about gas sales again, I have to ask whether I am listening to a huge idiot or an agent of Gazprom.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the development of the Single Energy Market is one of the dossiers in which the European Union has been delayed in relation to the dynamics of globalisation, technology and the needs of sustainability and competitiveness. External pressure, in particular the conflict with Russia, has forced a change of attitude. We must therefore take this opportunity, not only to respond to the immediate challenge, but to give a decisive impetus in the European leadership of the energy transition. We have learned the lesson so that we do not repeat the same mistakes in other dossiers. For example, the Digital Union dossier, which links so strongly with the Energy Union and which indicates security threats due to our delays in creating a regulated and transparent single market. But let's get back to energy security, Commissioner. The strategic pillars highlighted in this report are adequate: more efficiency, more own production with priority to renewable and environmentally friendly energies, technological leadership, an integrated market with strong interconnections, diversification of sources and geographical origins of the necessary imports. The implementation of this strategy involves a single market and an Energy Union. Levels of planning and regulation must be supranational and strengthened. But it also means giving a new impetus to the sustainable growth of the European economy, with a new model of organisation of space, mobility and social organisation. Let's not let ambition die. Security and change go hand in hand. Energy security and economic change as well. Let's take a chance.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think that no one in this House needs to be convinced of the great importance of the European Union's energy security and of its impact on our position, on Europe's political and economic position, especially in the context of the crises that are at European borders. The European Union, in my opinion, should step up its efforts to diversify its supply, because we cannot rely solely on a single source that comes from an uncertain country, Russia, a country that explicitly challenges EU rules and uses energy for political purposes.  But there is another aspect to this: it seems to me that energy security, the security of the European Union cannot rely solely on and be equated with renewable energy. I think we should do everything we can to ensure that there is access to the use of energy sources such as shale gas in European countries, which I am convinced will contribute to increasing the diversification and security of the Countries of the European Union in terms of energy.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Europe has had to endure many experiences, with one example being Russia cutting off gas to its neighbouring countries. We see once again that Europe is very vulnerable. I cannot stress this enough: we need to diversify our energy sources and make sure we prioritise energy security and supply. European gas markets need to be developed, and electricity grids in remote places in Europe, like the Baltics, need to be connected to the rest of Europe. All EU Member States must be interconnected. I am sure that the strategy on LNG terminals would enhance the diversification of energy resources. The internal energy market, including the implementation of infrastructure projects and the harmonisation of market regulations, must be a priority. We need to agree on the free trade agreement with the United States, and we should also concentrate on cooperation with Turkey and Central Asia on new energy rules. It is also important that the EU, in its energy and foreign policy, speaks and acts with one voice, and that the EU is able to resist pressure from third states if energy is used as a political tool.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Energy security, or the broader Energy Union, already has a permanent place in the European Union dictionary. The battle of words was won. It is not surprising that we are influenced by such an important geopolitical lesson as modern Ukraine provides. Previous gas supply disruptions were not sufficient as a lesson. This lesson is sufficient, but since we do not question the objectives, it is our shared responsibility to implement so that energy security does not share the fate of all those declarations that have remained declarations. As usual, the most difficult thing is to balance the European Union's climate and energy agenda. It seems to me that the original Saudargas report follows this trail. It is also a follow-up to our efforts, which I remember from the end of the Barroso Commission, which resulted in a proposal to focus in one hand on the climate agenda and the energy agenda, as happened in the case of Commissioner Cañete. If such a balance is lacking, it is difficult to achieve other objectives: competitiveness, security, reindustrialisation, and it is wrong if the Union declares and does not achieve the objectives. What is highlighted in these documents is the poorly sketched, timidly outlined external aspect of the coordination of EU policies towards the main suppliers. However, I also see amendments that strike a balance between the climate and energy agenda, and therefore probably do not deserve support.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Energy Union is intended to be a consensus between climate priorities and a strategy for security of energy supply, low prices and competitiveness. This will be done, on the one hand, by strategic investments as well as by increasing energy efficiency and increasing the share of RES on the other. The current Efficiency Directive is flawed because it is the same in EU countries with different energy use. The performance indicator as a policy objective for Member States should take into account their GDP per capita. The aim of the new directive must not be to restrict the use of energy, but to physically increase its efficiency as the main method of decarbonisation. In the diversified economies of EU countries, which are seriously different in energy consumption, the lack of a way of counting the rate of this target – different for whole countries and different for industrial sectors – does not stimulate innovation in both efficiency investments and RES. There is also a lack of coherence between the EU ETS and other climate policy objectives, as the increase in energy efficiency and the use of RES by economic operators does not result in additional emission allowances for them on the market.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate is once again extremely useful in identifying a strategy that will give the European Parliament the right authority on this issue, in a debate that has as its core the European Union's development policy.  Today, the European Union is still one of the markets, perhaps the most fascinating market we have at international level, but it is marking time from the point of view of the competitiveness of its production sectors. And one of the reasons that prevents Europe from still being so competitive is precisely the lack of strength – sorry but there is a strange noise, I beg your pardon – do I go on?  From our point of view, as far as the industrial pattern of our continent is concerned, the soundness of our energy policies is certainly a central point. We cannot imagine playing this game with environmental misunderstandings such as those we have often seen in the debate that brought this report. I acknowledge that Mr Saudargas has produced a very balanced result, I do not entirely agree with all the passages in the proposal because we will still have to work on some points, but I am certainly aware that on this game, the way is the right one.  We do not lazily look at our production realities moving where constraints that we consider necessary today are not respected. I am thinking in particular of the Chinese market. As Europe prepares to recognise the status of a market economy for an economy such as China's, it runs the risk of losing both the game of energy balance and the game of industrial competitiveness.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, on Monday the G7 leaders agreed to cut greenhouse gases by phasing out the use of fossil fuels by the end of the century. It is paramount that this objective is intertwined with our work on energy security. Energy security has become an increasingly important issue, not only for policymakers and the energy industry but also for the public, who are becoming more and more concerned about where their energy comes from and its affordability. A recent study in the UK showed that 82% of the public are worried that the UK is becoming too dependent on too many countries for its supply. Energy security is a crucial part of this puzzle. However, to help design our Energy Union, we should not forget that millions of people in Europe and in the UK are energy poor. So how do we ensure that our energy is secure and affordable? Our actions and our policies need to be guided by three major responsibilities: affordability, security and also sustainability. For all of these reasons, the S&D Group has pushed to include binding targets on energy efficiency and renewable energy in the energy security strategy report, which we will be voting on tomorrow. I believe that this vision is the only way to achieve our climate change targets, to combat energy poverty, to guarantee energy security across Europe, and to protect our most vulnerable citizens.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – The Energy Security Strategy must first ensure that the purchase of energy resources, in particular gas from Russia, is negotiated with one voice. We should start at regional level, with the assistance of the Commission, in order to create regional energy infrastructure axes. New gas sources are needed, limiting energy dependence on Russia, expanding and strengthening transmission and distribution networks. The energy world involves coordinated governance of the internal market as well as strategic interconnectors especially in the Western Balkans. Member States need incentives to develop a diversified energy mix based on indigenous energy sources to cover demand from renewable sources, including hydro, but also from fossil, thermal or nuclear hydrocarbons. A clear coal strategy is needed to ensure continuity of energy supply. The Black Sea region is of geostrategic importance and cooperation is needed to develop the southern corridor and connect with the Caspian Sea area, the Middle East and Central Asia, to strengthen security of supply and to eliminate the Russian monopoly. The Commission must create the necessary conditions for integrating the offshore potential of the Eastern Mediterranean, the North Sea, the Baltic Sea and the Black Sea, which is essential for the development of the European internal energy market. The European Union needs to monitor more closely the Strategy of the Russian Monopoly including geopolitical purchases of the energy network and distribution points and storage facilities. The failure of the Nabucco project should not be forgotten but used as a lesson for the development of new gas transport corridors.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has sun, winds and tides; therefore, we could clearly say that Europe has clean energy, and it would not be understood or understood — or at least we do not understand much of the Socialist Group — why resort to energy sources whose extraction is at least controversial.  Hydraulic fracturing requires huge amounts of water, highly polluting chemicals, and it is unclear that it does not produce ground tremors, among other things because there are no rigorous environmental impact studies under any circumstances. For these reasons, ladies and gentlemen, I tabled in committee an amendment calling on the Member States, governments, not to authorise new prospecting techniques, new prospecting techniques, until it is shown that this technique is safe for health, the environment and workers. This is why I am re-tabled by this amendment — my group recovers this amendment and re-introduces it in plenary - and I hope that tomorrow I will welcome the majority of those here, for the reasons I allege. And finally, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on including the socialist petition to the Commission to draw up a communication on energy poverty, which has accompanied an action plan to combat it seriously.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think that it is important to state that this discussion has arisen very much from the fact that Russia is using its energy resources for political and strategic purposes against Member States of the European Union, as well as others. This is a threat to peace and stability, and also to the sovereignty of our societies. We need to diversify, we need to develop new energy sources, and we need to phase out those energy sources that have the highest levels of carbon dioxide emissions. This is very compatible with the climate strategy of the European Union, because when we reduce fossil fuels we are also reducing our dependence on Russia and on other regimes that use their petrol resources in order to have a political impact. This leads me to an important conclusion for this Chamber: the Green’s policies are leading us to the increased use of black fossil fuels. We see it in a number of countries: when phasing out nuclear power instead of phasing out fossil fuels, we are increasing our dependence on countries like Russia and we are increasing our dependence on fossil fuels. Let us do it the other way around: reduce fossil fuels and reduce our dependence on the countries we do not want to be dependent on.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Madam President, the overall energy strategy outlined in the Saudargas report is rather a good move. Indeed, it echoes the objectives of the Delvaux report, which advocates three binding guidelines: reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40%, reaching 30% renewable energy and achieving a 40% increase in efficiency. These objectives are more ambitious than those adopted by the Council and we can only welcome them. However, there are a few problems, including shale gas development and, more broadly, unconventional fossil fuels. It is not enough to point out , and only point out - that the extraction of these fuels is not very clean. This is why many of us believe that the use of hydraulic fracturing, a technology poorly controlled in Europe, poses risks and adverse effects on the climate, the environment and public health.  Economically, the benefits will be far below those expected or promised by some experts. Operating costs are much higher than in the U.S. and gas inventories are also lower. Moreover, the American oil companies themselves are going backwards by stopping drilling in Poland and Hungary. Even the impact on employment is limited as experts estimate that the total number of workers in this sector has increased between 0.1 and 0.2%. We therefore call on the Member States not to persist in what could be a major fault against the planet and the younger generations. Unconventional fuel exploration and extraction must be stopped. We have the means, if we want to, to support energy policies that promote jobs and the preservation of the planet.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, let me say that I highly appreciate the quality of the report, and I appreciate the concept of an energy union, as it wisely merges the issues of affordable energy and energy security and also the issue of sustainability and responsibility. I have just three comments. First of all, the efficient and responsible use of energy savings should be one of the key priorities of our energy policy. We should focus on an ambitious goal in this area, bearing in mind that the development of new technologies is making that more affordable than ever. Technologies are real game-changers, and this is the game-changer that is on our side. We must fully utilise it to merge the goals in the areas of security, to support the economy and to use energy resources responsibly. Secondly, energy security should not be an issue only at times of political crisis, like now in Russia. There should be a long-term focus. At the same time, we should bear in mind that making energy more secure means making it more expensive, and people will have to pay the price. It is not for free, so we should focus on the tools that are the most efficient and offer the best cost-benefit ratio. Lastly, we should focus on the energy we can generate most easily. That would seem to be electricity produced in a responsible, economical away, especially through new technologies.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – Russia is no longer a predictable partner when Europe's energy security is at stake. The annexation of Crimea, the events in eastern Ukraine, or even the anti-competitive pricing of Gasprom show very clearly that we must wake up and not put Europe's energy security in the hands of a single monopoly supplier. At the same time, we must put an end to the separate energy policies of the Member States, because this threatens Europe's energy independence. We do not need nuclear power plants to be built with separate deals or gas contracts to be concluded with separate deals, because it undermines the solidarity that could be the basis for the establishment of the European Energy Union.  On the contrary, we must go further on the proposal that is on the Table of the European Parliament, for example by trying to include the possibility of purchasing energy jointly from the Member States in the European Energy Union, because it increases our bargaining power and, ultimately, it can serve the energy security of the European Union and the Member States.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today’s debate is important on several levels. First of all, it is important politically, because it comes at a time when we are faced with various geopolitical challenges. Secondly, it is important economically, because the European Union’s prosperity and security hinges on a stable and abundant supply of energy. Thirdly, it is important technically, because it requires the Member States to successfully implement complex infrastructure projects. Let me tell you the story of the country I know best, which has been active on all these levels in order to contribute to long-term energy security. Bulgaria is still dependent on Russian energy supplies but did not give in to recent pressures and instead took a step forward by working together with the Commission and the Member States in creating the High Level Group on Central and South Eastern Europe Gas Connectivity (CESEC). The aim of this group is to support cross-border diversification projects in the region, starting with a regional hub in Bulgaria. This regional approach is the basis to developing key infrastructure better and faster, bringing success to the improvement in our energy security and, finally, achieving a diversification of suppliers. As I said before, and I would like to state it one more time, to me, European energy security means working together and staying connected – both politically, economically and technically.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, good luck with your first sitting. Energy runs our daily lives, but also our society as a whole. However, we import more than half of the energy we consume, over EUR 400 billion a year. We need solutions for security, trade, employment and climate change. Almost half of the energy consumed is consumed for heating and cooling. It's going to take a quarter of the traffic. It is a problem that we in the EU do not have a target for renewable fuels in transport only four and a half years away. Own biofuels, and later electrification, would also make sense from a safety point of view. Heating is more than just gas: it is biomass, waste, solar heat and geothermal heat. Unfortunately, 40% of heating is still done with fossil gas. Renewable waste is now 25%, 20 years ago only 3%. Cleaner technologies, storage and smart network technology help energy efficiency and, consequently, sustainability and safety. As the share of renewables increases, we need flexibility in the electricity market through the reform of the market model, i.e. also internal security of supply.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: – Increasing the security of energy supply must also include stronger support for renewable energy sources. Many of them are operated mainly by small and medium-sized enterprises. Unfortunately, the situation in Slovakia is such that the competent authorities have long prevented the development of small hydropower plants as well as the use of FOTOVOLTAItic energy for business purposes. They deny owners the payment of legitimate profits and refuse to involve their facilities in the public transmission system. In the hydropower segment only, 1,200 small producers are affected in Slovakia. There is a significant contradiction between the declared objectives and reality, which reduces the credibility of the declared European objectives. I have already brought this to the attention of the European Commission. If the legislation and documents adopted by this Parliament are to make any sense, the European institutions must be more interested in implementing them in individual Member States and responding more flexibly to the complaints of the victims. I believe that such an approach and control will just contribute to increasing energy from domestic sources and thus to our better energy security.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has That is the premise: the European Union must ensure the energy supply to its citizens. If, at the same time, Russia is triggering a crisis here in Europe and blackmailing states through gas supplies, that is certainly not the case. It is therefore essential to diversify our energy sources in a sustainable and far-sighted manner. We need to build supply relationships with new countries and work our energy efficiency. After all, the cheapest energy is the one we do not consume. Reducing our consumption will help us drastically to save costs and reduce our energy imports. The funds freed up could be invested in the expansion of renewable energies. We could send out a signal of sustainability, creating a large number of jobs – jobs that Europe desperately needs. I would like to say a few words about energy poverty: it is unacceptable that people in the EU cannot afford energy, and that those affected should not be excluded from care in winter.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Madam President, the European Union's energy security strategy sounds ambitious, but on these issues everything is judged on the basis of the result. I therefore believe that, in addition to the general framework, which I endorse, there must be a step-by-step approach to the issues. As far as Greece is concerned, the european Commission needs the support to limit unacceptable over-pricing of 20-30% in terms of Russian oil and gas. I estimate that the Greek economy could save over EUR 500 million by seriously negotiating their price. The European Commission could also give the green light to the privatisation of DESFA, a state-owned gas company, through an investment by SOCAR, an Azerbaijani company. This approval would also facilitate the construction of the pipeline, which will supply natural gas from Azerbaijan, from the Caspian Sea region, to Greece, thus reducing energy dependence on Russia. In my view, the European Commission should promote serious energy investments in Greece, such as the underwater connection of Crete to the energy system of mainland Greece, taking advantage of the possibilities offered by the Juncker plan and the partial privatisation of PPC.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in general I am aligned to the principles of this report and also the proposed actions which should be taken into account in the planning of the European energy security strategy. But, in this respect, it is necessary to stress the role of energy efficiency as a new energy source and of further renewables, since they contribute both to the increase of EU energy security and to the transition to a low carbon economy. Since in the EU we are always concerned with the diversification of energy sources, let me just underline the importance of the Trans-Adriatic pipeline, which is a project that is almost under construction in the Southern Gas Corridor and has already been selected to transport diversified gas supplies to Europe. In addition, the discovery of significant gas reserves in the Eastern Mediterranean offers us potential for a future supply from indigenous energy sources. So we should pay special attention to these new discoveries. I believe that we cannot build energy security without investing in our own resources. We should also work on the stability of the area and the continuity of research.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Thank you to Mr Saudarga for his very well-drafted report. We need an Energy Union more than ever. It will be able to ensure both the free flow of resources between Member States and to increase our competitiveness, as well as help to form a level playing field with our suppliers. More than half of Europe's energy is imported. A large proportion of imports come from one supplier, russia. The Putin regime is known to use energy issues to put political pressure on its production strippers. We have seen this in the Baltic States, Ukraine and other countries of the European Union. We therefore very much need diversification of energy resources in the European Union. We must be open to new markets, to improve relations with the countries of Central Asia, with Azerbaijan. It is absurd that Turkmenistan, for example, is forced to sell its gas to Russia, which then sells the same gas to us at a much higher price. A direct gas pipeline is required. If Russia implements the 'Turkish stream' instead of the deferred 'Southern Stream', well, then we will see it, and that will be the case. It is urgently necessary to build interconnections in order to break the energy isolation of certain countries, including my country, Latvia. It is also important to diversify energy sources. Let us not belittle shale gas, too. An effective energy and security policy will be in the interests of all of us. Thank you!

name: n/a
text: – We use the most energy in Europe for heating and cooling. Therefore, investments in the economy of buildings will also be the most profitable for citizens and industry. The best, fastest, cheapest way to energy security, but also to reduce our bills, to achieve climate targets and to create hundreds of thousands of jobs, is to increase energy efficiency in buildings. Investment in the economy of buildings is particularly slow for low-income owners. Even with rental buildings, owners do not have much incentive in this area because 'however, tenants pay for energy'. Investments in the economy of buildings carry hardly any risks for investors. Commissioner, let us try, with the help of banks and investors, to create a system that generates enough spare resources for investments in the field of energy performance.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Yesterday, ten Member States including Germany, France, Poland and the Czech Republic signed a joint declaration on the regional initiative to develop a single electricity market, with the aim of strengthening security. We note that the formation of the European single electricity market is going through the formation of regional markets as an intermediate stage. I believe that concrete steps need to be taken to achieve a regional single electricity market and for the Member States of Southern and Eastern Europe together with the third countries in the area. This is a way to strengthen energy security. To this end, we need the support of the European Commission for the development of the necessary physical interconnections, the harmonisation of regulations and the transfer of energy-efficient technologies.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Thank you to the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs. Europe is torn apart in a tension between a national energy mix, a desired climate policy and a heavy dependence on external fossil fuel suppliers, which often come from countries with dubious regimes. Because of this tension, energy in Europe is expensive, polluting and also unsafe.  Now that we have expressed our ambitions to achieve a green, cheap and guaranteed energy supply, the time has come for action to throw away the patchwork of national and private interests and achieve a common interest. That starts with a decent price for pollution. Oil giants such as Statoil and BP are already asking this. That starts with good access to everyone's markets.  In short, that starts, and that can only be done with a Europe and a European Commission that takes the lead and dares to take the lead. Continuing along the same path is to finance oligarchs and oil sheikhs. Let us opt for a European approach and for European investment in order to achieve a safe, sustainable and also cheap energy.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Saudargas on his report and thank him for the hard work he has done. I fully support many points included in the report. For example, the rapporteur correctly emphasises the need to reduce the EU’s dependence on foreign energy sources, including Russian oil and gas, and to establish an energy union in Europe. Nevertheless, the current version of the text is, in my opinion, not as good as the original draft. The main weakness of the document is that it is one-sided and focused excessively on environmental and climate aspects of energy policy at the cost of energy security as such. A good illustration of these biased proportions is that the word ‘renewable’ appears 74 times in the text of the report, while the word ‘competitiveness’ only appears 10 times. Clearly, the issue of the impact of the Energy Security Strategy on the growth and competitiveness of European companies is not given sufficient attention. Another weakness of the report is that it largely ignores the potential role of some indigenous sources of energy such as clean coal and shale gas. In particular, the issue of clean coal has not been discussed at all, which I found very surprising. The report is very optimistic on the issue of expanding energy generation from renewables. However, there is no solid evidence that a massive and rapid shift from fossil fuels to renewables is indeed technologically feasible and economically viable in the foreseeable future. I hope, Commissioner, that these points will be taken into consideration.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, energy policy is now of central importance for European competitiveness and the Union's climate objectives. We need energy at competitive prices, safe energy, clean energy. Electrical interconnections are essential for balancing higher levels of renewable energy penetration into the grid, thus contributing to lower ing their cost to the final consumer and the taxpayer. I would therefore like to stress the need for binding, non-indicative, interconnection capacity targets. On the other hand, gas interconnections and the reception capacity of liquefied natural gas in the Iberian Peninsula can also contribute to the diversification of sources of supply, energy security and price convergence in Europe. I therefore stress the urgent need to implement the third energy package, to support investments in interconnection infrastructure and close and real-time monitoring by the European Commission of the implementation of these priority projects.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to congratulate Mr Saudargas most warmly on this report, because he has made us a very good proposal, which was also adopted by a large majority in the ITRE. I would like to highlight one aspect in particular, namely the issue of energy efficiency. The cheapest and safest energy is the one we do not need. And President Juncker announced before his election that he would commit to at least 30% energy savings by 2030. In a paper that we jointly adopted in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we also confirmed our support for this 30% target. If you compare this, an important energy security project was the Nabucco pipeline. It is probably not being realised now. If Nabucco had come, it would have accounted for 3% of the European Union's total energy supply, because gas is, of course, only part of it and because, of course, it would have secured only part of the gas supply. So 3% Nabucco with all the political discussions that we have had about it – 30% energy efficiency: I think that shows the perspective. We need to make energy efficiency more effective as the most cost-effective means of energy security and climate protection, and I am sure, Commissioner, that I have you at my side when I call for this.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Madam President, I think it is undeniable that the European Union is really energy dependent and that it has a steady economic bleeding from the energy sector of EUR 400 billion a year, which is truly shocking.  How do we respond to this challenge? There are solutions. One solution is certainly the development of renewable energy sources, which we support and support. The second credible, important solution is for the European Union to use its own energy sources. At the moment, the Eastern Mediterranean is offering to give way to the European Union's energy problems.  It is for this reason that if the European Union really has the political will and determination to open energy corridors and solve the problem of energy dependency and costs, it must invest in energy infrastructure and - I expect the Commissioner to respond to this - in the Eastern Mediterranean, Cyprus, Greece, Israel, but we also say to any other countries that they have the option and the ability to offer energy deposits , which are European energy deposits and we must use them here and now and not tomorrow.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, allow me to quote a Commission report which says there is no diversification or back-up in the event of supply problems, whether for technical or political reasons. You know that Russia could cause significant disruption in the EU energy sector, and not only with regard to gas supply but also in relation to nuclear supply and nuclear fuel. As you know very well, there are 18 Russian-designed nuclear reactors functioning in European Union countries using Russian atomic fuel: in Finland, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary. This is a subject that has to be addressed quickly by the Commission in the future energy security strategy of the European Union. It is a subject of tremendous importance for Europe’s energy security in the future.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the debate on energy security is multidimensional as it toes with our internal market and the competitiveness of our economies, but it also goes back to the sphere of foreign and defence policy of the Member States. I am pleased that the rapporteur recognises this and highlights the need for a wide range of European energy sources and a wider range of partners globally. In this regard, I would like to point out that the additional capacity for sequestered natural gas in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea should be high on our list of priorities, as their contribution to the energy independence of Central and South Eastern Europe would be truly enormous.  Therefore, from this place I invite all stakeholders in the construction of the LNG terminal on the Croatian island of Krk to take all necessary steps in removing the remaining obstacles in order to launch an already created project that has been waiting too long for implementation from the impasse.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, the Single European Energy Market is the only possible way to achieve our energy security. Namely, for a number of reasons, and I will of course list only two common knowledge, one is our dependence on Russia and the other our competitiveness in relation to American energy prices or energy prices in some other competing markets.  So, I am committed to creating a single energy market, based on the principle of creating first regional energy markets, and I will stop there in eastern Europe, in the Balkans, where we have exceptionally high possibilities of hydro potential, wind and solar, but we also have lng terminal construction projects, not only on the island of Krk in Croatia, but also in Albania and elsewhere. So, I think it's a good way to create a unified European market through regional markets and thereby enable our security.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the international scenario, which has been made even more complex by the well-known events in Russia, shows that energy security means above all political independence. The construction of a genuine stable and protective European Energy Union proves to be urgent and binding, not so much and not only in order to pursue the objectives highlighted in the motion for a resolution which, together with the careful suggestions of the committees, I share, primarily because it is a geopolitical objective. The energy, the resilience of our nations, the fight against so-called energy poverty are in fact exploited, becoming with worrying escalation, an instrument of diplomacy of pressure and aggression. The road to the European Energy Union is still fragmented and uncertain when it is not inconsistent if, according to the accurate analyses carried out, energy security, competitiveness and sustainability stand in the way of unresolved issues about our internal and external energy dimension that amplify vulnerability. Of all these critical issues that I would like to see as opportunities for growth, I am convinced that affirming the general principle of solidarity between states, combined with moderation, decarbonisation and innovation, is the decisive step towards a truly common energy policy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, European energy security must aim over time to ensure energy independence for the Member States of the Union. This means unity in the diversity of the different Member States. It means coordination of action but also flexibility. It means a common strategy, but also a use of the principle of subsidiarity. It means establishing a common framework for action of the European Union with common principles, but within which the Member States of the Union should retain their sovereign rights and exploit their sources of wealth.  In relation to Greece, this means that my country will have to move in two directions. First, to turn it into a modern energy hub, making the most of the TAP pipeline, but also the Greek stream, as well as liquefied gas. Secondly, to use without commitments, in the public interest, the natural gas and oil found in the Greek EEZ.  For this reason, Greece must create a public body for researching and exploiting the country's resources of wealth, without guardianship from the Troika and the lenders.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D).
text: – For many Central and South-Eastern European countries, the concept of energy security is essential, both in terms of national security and the well-being of citizens. Already under the sign of the vulnerability generated by the dependence on imports mainly from politically unstable regions, these states have seen an escalation of fears in the context of the crisis in Ukraine. A crisis that brought up the urgent progress in terms of: European energy infrastructure, the completion of the internal energy market and the diversification of import sources. Despite this context, there are also states that are temporarily making considerable progress on energy independence. In the last three months the moderation of demand for natural gas on the Romanian market could be covered by domestic production without resorting to imports. We need more examples of this kind, and I am glad that we have agreed on the terms of a European energy security strategy. The creation of the Energy Union is the only solution to the vulnerabilities that logically derive from regional instability. The Energy Union can provide Member States with a physical and legal framework through which they can cooperate and provide each other with the energy resources necessary to increase the economy and create jobs, the well-being of citizens, the competitiveness of industry and the business environment.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to reiterate my thanks to the rapporteur for the enormous work he has done to make a report of enormous complexity, as has been seen in the interests of the speakers – more than eighty speakers – and for the variety of views that have been put on the table and, therefore, I believe that he has sought a balance of positions which is very laudable.  I, throughout this debate, have seen, first of all, the interest in the issue of energy security. It is normal: a European Union that imports 53% of its energy; where six Member States depend on Russia as the sole external gas supplier; in which three states depend on Russia for the operation and balance of their electricity grid; and taking into account the geopolitical situation we have experienced, as this issue is hot.  But the approach to its solution is polyeedric, as we have seen: there are many ways to increase our energy security.  The highest level of consensus I have seen in the debate is on energy efficiency policies. Here's a consensus that it's a win-win policy, it's a winning policy, it's a policy worth pushing. And one fact is enough, which is that for every percentage point when we increase our energy efficiency, we reduce our gas imports by 2.6%, we manage to increase our energy security and, in addition, we achieve fundamental savings for European consumers.  The second major policy in which there is a basic agreement is the development of a true internal energy market in the electricity sector and in the gas sector. In the electricity sector, the biggest problem has been posed by interconnections: the fact that there are still many Member States that do not reach 10% of the interconnection target set for 2020 or 15% that was set for 2030. And so one of the European Commission's policies is going to be to promote interconnections, the development of smart grids and that electricity flows can be a reality in the European Union.  But the same goes for gas interconnections: we don't have all of our interconnections resolved right now. We have to solve it: the Midcat corridor in the Pyrenees; we need to develop the networks of southern France to connect with the Central European network; in central, eastern and southern Europe we have to carry out more than fourteen projects for real interconnection in the area. And, therefore, we must also have an ambitious policy of interconnecting the territory, because we have seen, during ukraine's recent crisis, how reversible flows and European solidarity were very important to ensure energy security in times of crisis.
