And finally there is a policy, which everyone has also advocated, which is the need for source diversification, route diversification and diversification of suppliers. The Commission is seeking that no country should depend on a single supplier and may depend on at least three suppliers, which involves the development of interconnections; which means supporting the southern corridor to make the gas connection with Azerbaijan and, in its day, turkmenistan; and which involves developing a liquefied natural gas strategy that is very important as an element of energy security and as a guarantee at times when there may be a crisis. But it also produces immediate effects: it increases the competition. The development of liquefied natural gas with a strategy produces immediate effects. We have seen this in Lithuania, when the construction of a liquefied natural gas plant automatically resulted in a 20% price reduction because there was competition in the market. The Commission will therefore continue to support all developments, all actions within the framework of the Energy Union to make energy security one of the priorities, and using all instruments. And I conclude by reiterating my congratulations on this report to Mr Saudargas and to the four rapporteurs of the four committees which have issued opinions, for their work and for their cooperation with the Commission for its development.

name: Algirdas Saudargas
text: Rapporteur. – I thank the Commissioner, who listened patiently to us for almost three hours. Indeed, he has saved me a lot of time in this speech, because he has provided an excellent summary of the whole debate. I can sign and endorse this summary completely under this summary. And I will not repeat again, because developing this topic would be the same as going out into the endless sea. I just want to say one thing that the honourable Commissioner emphasised, that it was indeed a very important task to strike a balance between different things. And not only the mechanical balance, but to achieve a meaningful balance to give it content. I hope, honourable colleagues, that we have been able to bring some content together, so that for the first time, all those issues that are no longer new to us have been discussed so widely. They've had many debates. But they were viewed from a security perspective. And not only the old issues, but all the issues that are now emerging from the european energy union being created. That is why I believe that we have done that job hard, created some content. I call for him to be supported in the vote. Once again, I would like to thank the Commission for an excellent and timely initiative and for a very meaningful and meaningful communication. I would very much like to thank my shadow rapporteurs. We had a rather tense but very thoughtful and meaningful debate. Once again, I would like to thank all our colleagues, both in my own way, and in our group and in the shadow rapporteurs, who have done very difficult technical and at the same time political work. Thank you very much to everyone and I invite you to vote tomorrow in favour of this report.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 10 June 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – In order to reduce dependence on oil and gas imports, commitment to energy efficiency and renewable energy is vital for Europe. At the same time, we provide growth and jobs in this way. But of course more is needed. We must also work towards more cross-border interconnections and put an end to the fragmented landscape of uncoordinated national energy markets. This requires a broad-based long-term vision and more regional cooperation. This is the only way to set out the beacons to realise much-needed investments in the energy market. We should not turn a blind eye to this. The G7 agreement, which states that "serious reductions in global greenhouse gas emissions are needed with a complete decarbonisation of the global economy over the course of this century", sends a clear signal about where we need to go in the long term. Even though it is beyond our imagination at the moment of how to proceed without fossil fuels, we still need to align our research efforts with that goal. That's the only way to really drive our businesses and our economy forward, to become leaders and to remain leaders in sustainable innovation and technology.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. - A stable and sustainable energy supply and a rational and efficient use of energy contribute to prosperity and security in the European Union. Therefore, the issue of energy security must not only be dealt with at national level, but a European strategy must be adopted that takes account of the interdependencies of the Member States. The strategy for a secure European energy security is necessary because it is an important pillar in the creation of an Energy Union. The crisis in Ukraine in 2014 showed us that we need a common European energy policy!

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – There are pitfalls in the development of a single EU energy policy due to differences between Member States. The solution to this is to conconnect, but there are differences that can only be bridged by mutual sacrifice. The development of a Community energy policy will be a long process and I think that we are on the right track, but it is feared that the crisis will put a little bit of a hold on efforts at Member State level, because countries are more focused on public debt and budget deficits. I agree with what was described in the report that we must stick to the objectives, since energy efficiency measures and investments in bio-power plants contribute to reducing energy consumption and creating jobs, thereby reducing unemployment. It is clear, however, that energy policy does not stop on its own and cannot be isolated from other policies, since an investment or measure automatically has an impact on processes and areas which are essentially part of another Community policy. This is why strategies and objectives need to be coordinated across all areas in order to achieve maximum efficiency and thus support each other in different policy activities.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the UK over 80% of people express concerns that we are becoming too dependent on other countries to secure our energy needs and nearly the same number of people say we are not doing enough to tackle climate change. More than two million households in our country suffer from energy poverty, meaning they are not even able to secure the necessary fuel to heat their homes in winter. The answer is clear: acting as a bloc, the EU has the potential to develop new technologies to increase energy production while reducing primary demand, optimise network infrastructure, and diversify supply options to decrease our dependence on uncertain imports from third countries, including Russia. All of this is possible while respecting national energy choices. Meeting the energy needs of our constituents should be a priority even for Conservative and UKIP MEPs. It is therefore disappointing that they are against progress on this issue; could it be down to undue influence of vested interests? The path to energy security lies in an EU strategy that puts energy efficiency first, promotes renewables, and invests money domestically to develop our green technologies industry and create jobs rather than wasting scarce resources on expensive imports.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Energy security is undoubtedly a pillar of the Energy Union. Recent events in eastern Ukraine, as well as endurance tests carried out last year by the European Commission, have clearly demonstrated the risks associated with energy dependency. The European Union's priority should therefore, in my view, be to diversify its gas supply and to reduce dependence on third-country supplies. I am pleased that Mr Saudargas clearly emphasises this in his report and calls for an acceleration of efforts to diversify energy suppliers, routes and sources, which I believe is the right thing to do. Furthermore, I consider it essential that the European Union, as a powerful one of the world's largest energy markets, speaks with one voice on key issues such as the Turkish Stream project, for example.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The crisis in Ukraine and the lack of a long-term solution for the region call into question the provision of reliable energy supply. Diversification of energy supply is more important than ever because the EU's prosperity and security require a rational and highly efficient use of energy. The Commission's gas stress tests have proved the EU's vulnerability due to its dependence, and high energy costs are forcing industry to leave the EU, hampering Europe's economic growth. In this regard, I believe it is necessary to pay particular attention to the most vulnerable Member States and to promote the exploitation of local conventional oil and gas fields in full compliance with the acquis communautaire. We need to focus on infrastructure development, the integration of sustainable energy sources and support for new projects. The creation of a single energy market requires, above all, political independence, and it is achieved only with an affordable and sustainable energy supply.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Given that energy security is largely linked to political independence, the EU should seek a common and effective energy security strategy. It should be borne in mind that the EU continues to import as much as 53% of the energy it uses, and many Member States depend on supplies from a single external source. In addition, a significant proportion of energy imports come from politically unstable regions, which greatly increases the threat to energy security. Therefore, the EU should work together to create an internal energy market, develop energy technologies and diversify its energy supply. However, the European Energy Strategy should be based on the diverse energy resources of the Member States. When introducing new criteria for a low-carbon economy using renewable energy sources, it is important to take into account the situation of countries that base their energy production on coal. The new strategy cannot be implemented at the expense of those countries whose primary energy fuel is coal.  We will all agree that we need a coherent and long-term energy strategy, but it must be based on fair conditions.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – Increasingly lately, when talking about energy security, we need to recall the precedents of gas supply disruptions from Russia. As a result of the second such shutdown of gas supplies in 2009, the losses for the Bulgarian economy amounted to over EUR 250 million. European. The crisis in Ukraine and the stress tests carried out by the European Commission have given a clear signal of the need to update policies to ensure energy security in Europe. The European Energy Security Strategy proposes a package of short- and long-term measures aimed at increasing the EU's capacity to deal with a significant disruption in natural gas supplies during the winter season; strengthening emergency mechanisms and solidarity mechanisms, including the coordination of risk assessments and contingency plans, as well as the protection of strategic infrastructure; reducing energy consumption; building a well-functioning and fully integrated internal market; diversification of external supplies and related infrastructure; improving the coordination of national energy policies and standing up for common positions in foreign energy policy. I am convinced that only with coordinated action will we be able to counter potential risks to energy security in the Union.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. - The European Union imports 53% of the energy it consumes and pays more than €1 billion a day. Thus, the EU imports almost 90% of oil, natural gas 66%, and on a smaller scale solid fuels such as coal 42% and nuclear 90%. I strongly advocate full respect for subsidiarity, respect for national energy choices, especially when it comes to the sufficiency of their domestic sources or in a situation where there is no possibility of diversification.  However, how can we react to irresponsible behaviours by individual Member States and their governments which, in their strategic document, regardless of the availability of renewable energy sources, choose energy sources that only increase dependence on imports? Europe seems to lack bold and strong decisions that would ensure strong breakthroughs towards greater green energy use and energy efficiency over the foreseeable period of time.  Yes, Europe is at the forefront of climate policy, but making a responsible decision to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions we are discussing is as painful as pulling teeth. This decision must also be accompanied by the direction of the economy in a new direction, towards reducing dependence on imported energy. We need to focus on the green economy, green growth and green jobs. There is money, 365 billion euros a year, only missing decisions.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the report on the European Energy Security Strategy because it highlights the main problems in the EU energy sector. Although significant progress has been made in recent years towards strengthening the EU's energy security, we are still facing a number of challenges, such as instability in energy supplier regions or fragmentation of the internal market. I consider it important that the Commission also seriously address the problem of energy poverty. I myself pointed out in the report the importance of measures to improve consumer information on the structure of energy prices and energy efficiency measures that would allow consumers to be actively involved in the management of energy consumption, including the possibility of easily switching suppliers.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. It is very regrettable that the debate on secure energy supply in Europe is still too focused on the import of energy and the use of controversial energy. The import of energy has not only occupied us since the Ukraine crisis, but nevertheless we in Europe have slept to develop concepts to meet our energy needs in such a way that we are not dependent on a few partners. If the commission's report and communication are so resolutely committed to the future use of domestic energy sources, then please know what that means. In addition to renewable energy, many conservatives also include nuclear power and hydraulic fracking. This must not be allowed to happen, however, because we must set clear priorities for the future of energy supply. Nuclear power must not play a role in this. Nor can we use other methods that contribute safely or possibly to pollution. We must consistently focus on renewable energies and energy savings if we in Europe are to guarantee a sustainable energy policy and security of supply.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Energy security is very important for the European Union. All our objectives for greater employment, for economic growth and also for a better global position of the EU are based on our economy. And that, in addition to our households, needs a secure supply of electricity. We can't afford electric eclipses these days. Adequate infrastructure must be provided, which will be crucial for ensuring energy security throughout the European Union. I agree, it is also important to define the wider importance of energy policy in the EU. The report on energy security should form the basis for a long-term strategy. Europe must not tremble every winter as to whether Russia will prevent gas supplies. We need to stand together and look at what we can do within the EU. What are our opportunities and where we can move forward. Only by working together in this area will we be able to stand up to external suppliers that have power over this area.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today, energy security presents a major challenge for the EU in the context of the Crisis in Ukraine, which has created a new geopolitical fuel situation, especially for the countries of Central and South-Eastern Europe. That is why energy security is going through a reduction in dependence on russian gas imports at least to a manageable level. This can be achieved by increasing energy efficiency, building a fully integrated internal energy market and its single regulation, by decarbonising the energy mix, on the basis of reliable and emission-free nuclear energy combined with renewable energy sources and increasing local energy production. The EU should support any sustainable local energy source that can contribute to our energy security. A key prerequisite for achieving this objective is to strengthen regional cooperation between Member States, including energy community countries, with a view to better coordination of national energy policies and full synergies in pan-European positions in energy negotiations with third countries. I categorically do not accept the drastic amendments by some political groups to ban fossil fuels and nuclear energy and favour energy efficiency and renewable energies alone. Thus, we can only thwart a decision in Parliament on one of the most important European priorities for the Union's energy security.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Fortunately, the Union's approach to energy security is changing. In recent years, it has been understood that the level of this security is fundamental to Europe's position, its economy and the lives of its people. Let us remember that 53% of the total energy consumption in the Union is still covered by imported energy, and many Member States depend on a single, external supplier. The European Parliament should therefore vigorously support those activities of the European Commission which not only increase security of supply but are heading towards a European Energy Union. Such a Union should be based on close coordination of national energy policies and the presentation of a common position in dealing with suppliers.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the Intelligent Borders Package (2015/2614(RSP)).

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank you for a further opportunity to reflect with you on smart borders and, in a more general way, the need to modernise EU border management. The Commission’s Smart Borders Package of 2013 has already been discussed with Parliament and the Council. As announced in the Agenda on Security that we adopted, as you will remember, on 28 April 2015, and in the Agenda on Migration presented on 13 May, it is now our intention to present, by the beginning of 2016, a revised proposal on smart borders. Today’s reality is that Member States face difficulties in managing the growing traveller flows at borders and in fulfilling the obligations set by the Schengen Border Code. There were an estimated 200 million border crossings by third country nationals last year, and a 50% increase is expected in the next decade. Borders must benefit from technology. The smart borders system will automatically record all incoming and outgoing third country nationals and will support border guards in their tasks. It will also enable the automation or semi-automation of the border controls for travellers already known by the system. This will allow us to face the increases in traveller flows. Smart borders will also help us in making our policy against irregular migration more effective. How? By systematically recording all incoming and outgoing third country nationals, the system will automatically identify the travellers who stay longer than the authorised period. Smart borders will also help in identifying undocumented persons present in the Schengen area. Lastly, the system will support an informed visa policy decision-making process, taking into account the actual overstayer figures provided by the system. Possible law-enforcement access will be a key issue to be addressed in the impact assessment for the new proposal. The Commission has already acknowledged, in the impact assessment for the 2013 proposal, that the data generated at entry/exit could be of use to law-enforcement authorities in the fight against terrorist offences and serious crime in specific cases – both as an identity verification tool and as a criminal intelligence tool. But any decision to allow law-enforcement access from the outset will need to be based on the demonstrated necessity and proportionality of the measure. Strict, specific substantive and procedural safeguards would need to be laid down, taking into account, inter alia, the rulings of the European Court of Justice on data protection. Let me now share with you some of the emerging ideas on how we could increase the efficiency and effectiveness of border management. These are, of course, not yet conclusive, as discussions are still ongoing and the testing phase is still under way. These issues will all be covered in depth in the updated impact assessment the Commission is undertaking in order to inform its revised proposal. The initial findings of the technical study seem to point to potential advantages of a single piece of legislation. As in 2013, this would be accompanied by a technical modification of the Schengen Border Code. Let me give you an idea of the questions which, in my view, need to be answered in the context of our impact assessment, in addition to the already-mentioned issue of law-enforcement access and, of course, the financial implications and efficiency questions.  As regards the architecture of the system: should smart borders rely on a single system rather than separate systems for entry/exit recording and registered traveller management? Can we further reduce the number of data items about each traveller while still achieving our objectives? How long should the data retention periods be for entry/exit and for registered travellers, in full compliance with data protection rules? Can we introduce a ‘lighter’ form of biometric identifiers while maintaining the effectiveness of the system? How can we facilitate border crossings for the very large majority of travellers who do not pose any problem or risk? How can we benefit from the experience and solutions found in the existing large-scale systems, in order to reduce costs? While preparing the revised proposal, the Commission will continue to listen carefully to the opinions expressed by the European Parliament.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to Mrs Fajon for her good work. As has been said, 300 million border crossings, produced by approximately 76 million third-country nationals, are expected to reach 300 million border crossings in 2025, which require us to improve passenger traffic management, given the proven inadequacy of SIS II and VIS. As Members, in the face of a still very vague legislative package — even though it was born in February 2013 — we are determined that Parliament's voice will be taken into account throughout the legislative process and in the face of the new revised proposal of 2016. As for the architecture of the system, what we want to know, Commissioner, is clearly what your ideas are about it: an input and output system and an RTP?; Both of you?; One or the other?; Mixed? Because this is an essential issue and it is also essential for the budget, of course. Furthermore, the Commission needs to clarify and commit to the main objective and possible secondary ones. For example, the fight against migration mafias and other serious crimes such as terrorism. We're talking about technology, and technology to give this one added value. Everything I say, of course, must have the legal and primary packaging, with the maximum guarantees, as far as fundamental rights are concerned, in order to comply well with Article 77 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. And only from being clear about this general framework can we talk about biometrics, interoperability, accelerators, passenger information systems or the role of transport companies. The technical report and the conclusion of the pilot projects or testing phases — sixteen in twelve Member States — shall provide the information necessary for the launch of the new legislative proposal at the air, land and sea borders. On the other hand, Commissioner, interinstitutional dialogue needs to be strengthened in order to strengthen data protection, access to the system by law en forces and law enies or the consequences of the removal of stamps on passports. I would remind you that all but one of the national parliaments were in favour of access by law en forces and law enies, as you say: taking into account proportionality and necessity.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. What is the purpose of smart borders? Make Europe more attractive or build new walls? At the moment, the debate is going in the wrong direction. Spending money on a new system, new technology is anything but smart. Especially if the Commission does not take into account our concerns about data protection and costs – almost €800 million. We focus too much on safety, disproportionate to the risk that exists. I am particularly concerned about the scope of access by judicial authorities to data when the proposal is renewed. It is a very serious question of who will store and process the data and how this will affect the fundamental rights of passengers. I would like to point out seriously here that the Socialists and Democrats have a very clear red line, and I am pleased, Commissioner, that you are aware of this. My next concern: we have never heard a detailed answer in Parliament: will the costs that Europeans spend on new technologies justify the purpose of the project? I admit, I'm very skeptical. Connoisseurs and professions point to different solutions. Better border management and easier passenger crossing could be achieved by upgrading the existing VIS system, where we are already collecting biometric data on visa holders entering the Union. A simple operation could extend this system to those travellers who do not need visas to enter. Why not take advantage of these systems, as well as SIS2? Last but not least – the proposal for a programme for registered travellers, of which I am a rapporteur. If this is not the case in the new proposal, we will lose even that glimmer of hope that the purpose of the contested legislation, to facilitate border crossings for third-party citizens, will be sincere. Dear Commissioner, I know that we want the same thing: an attractive, free and secure Europe. I call on you to take into account all the concerns mentioned in the preparation of the recast of the proposal. Almost €800 million, or at least part of that money, could be used much more meaningfully. For example, emergency rescue and assistance to refugees dying in the Mediterranean today. What we do not want to do is to create a system, new smart borders, which would mean two things in practice: waste of money and new unnecessary barriers for passengers. That would be anything but smart or smart. Thank you very much.

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the free movement of persons is often mentioned as one of the greatest achievements of European integration from the point of view of an ordinary European citizen. However, the absence of internal borders benefits not only bona-fide travellers. It is vital for the credibility and acceptability of the Schengen area that we effectively control our common external border. Third-country nationals that cross the external border should be reliably identified and their right to enter the Schengen area verified. The collected data should be stored in shared databases and be available to all relevant authorities. Also, the same standards should apply to all border-crossing points. The manual checking of travel documents is both slow and unreliable, which leads to long queues and more mistakes at the borders. The Smart Borders Package aims to address such challenges. The objective is to facilitate smooth and easy travel for the vast majority of travellers and, at the same time, make life more difficult for those who seek to abuse free movement inside the Union. The ECR supports these objectives. My question to the Commissioner is this: given the very large and ever-growing number of travellers into the European Union, how do you see the future if we do not create a common EU-wide solution, such as smart borders? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – You said that information has to be available to all relevant authorities. Do you believe that access to the system for law—enforcement purposes should be granted, or not?

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – This is a political decision and has to be decided by us in the future. We have a national entry-exit system and we have law—enforcement access in my country, which works well. I believe it serves a legitimate purpose, so my answer is yes.

name: Филиз Хюсменова
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Thank you, Madam President. Some of the most important issues under the Smart Borders package remain the outline of clear project objectives and the proportionality of the proposed measures against the need for a legislative solution.  There are many uncertainties about the current legislative proposals. It was pointed out that their objectives are to tackle the increasing flow of passengers, collect statistics, track illegal residents and provide a higher level of security for European citizens. At the same time, however, law enforcement authorities in the Member States continue to not cooperate fully and do not exchange information in order to prevent and combat international crime.  Furthermore, the technical study of legislative proposals indicated that facial recognition as isolated geometric recognition for the identification of passengers is also seen as an option. It is also subject to analysis during the test stage currently underway. It is true that additional methods such as fingerprint collection provide greater accuracy, but a large number of fingerprints slow down the process. Their continued storage entails additional costs, and too short storage does not facilitate the management of passenger traffic. The question arises as to whether it is justified by the additional funds that Member States will have to invest and on the integrity of the individual.  Secondly, as shadow rapporteur for the report on the amendments to the Schengen Code, I would also like to address the Representative of the Council and reiterate to the Latvian Presidency that Bulgaria and Romania are carrying out their obligations to protect Europe's external borders, have met reception requirements and will bear the burden of introducing all standards , requirements and security systems on an equal footing with the Schengen countries, which is another argument for our adoption in Schengen.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, 'smart borders', 'smart borders'... Let's move on to the vocabulary used. This system at exorbitant cost, even if it has been revised downwards, is a paradox in itself. It is claimed to make the European Union more attractive, facilitate free movement, improve border control and better combat irregular immigration. In order to do this, we want to leave all those who enter the European Union, i.e. 500 million people a year, the equivalent of the population of the Union.  The United States has implemented a similar program, which cost a billion and a half, to block 1,300 people, or more than one million per refusal. So we're going to set up a gas plant that will create more problems than it solves. Fluidity is not for tomorrow. The Commission has withdrawn its project, so much the better. But it wants to build on a pilot project led by eu-LISA and present us with a new one. This is a purely technical validation that is far from taking into account the magnitude of the problems. Let us turn to the conditions for setting up this test, which is just a smokescreen to force the hand of the European Parliament, a way of resuming the obsessions of the Member States - border control and migrant registration - after Eurodac, SIS and SIS II, which were already very expensive. These instruments are already questionable, but at least we can make real assessments of them. There is no justification for this project, except the security dogma and the obsession with the hunt for migrants. What is a "risky traveller," Commissioner? Let's put an end to the liberticidal forward leakage, far from any efficiency. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Vergiat, you say that Europe should be an attractive destination, and I fully agree with you. But one of the objectives of this Smart Borders Package is to facilitate smoother and swifter border crossing for the vast majority of third-country nationals who cross the external borders of the European Union. Creating longer queues at border-crossing points hardly makes Europe a more attractive destination for anyone. Do you not agree?

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer. My dear colleague, it is not I who have set out the four objectives I have mentioned, it is the Commission itself. I think that before there is fluidity - as I said in my speech, it will be a long time before all citizens are registered before they freely cross the border.  In my view, these are not ad hoc means. Principles of proportionality and necessity must be established. Here, we spend a colossal amount of money - no financial problem in this area - for a result that will be above all liberticidal for all those who will return to the European Union, without having the slightest effectiveness.

name: Ska Keller
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the With smart borders, we would create one of the largest fingerprint databases in the world. All arrivals and exits into and out of the EU would have to be recorded there. That is alarming enough. But there is not even a proper purpose for which this is supposed to serve. According to the Commission, the database is intended to ensure that overstayers no longer stay too long. But exactly how this is to happen is completely unclear. Finally, we only have the database for statistical purposes. We Greens are also firmly opposed to simply extending the purpose and also giving the police access to these fingerprints. The Commission must not give in to the pressure of the Member States, because that would simply trample European fundamental and data protection rights underfoot. And even from a financial point of view, smart borders is not a particularly smart project, because the costs will definitely be significantly higher than they have now been calculated in the study. After all, everything that the Member States have to buy in terms of equipment, scanners, ABC gates, kiosks and all the drums is not included. And how do you want to tell countries like Greece that, while they are supposed to cut pensions, that they should lay off people, but that there must be money to buy such expensive equipment that serves nothing but a statistical purpose. I don't see how the intelligent boundaries are supposed to be intelligent in any way. I think they are a big waste of money and we are wasting far too much money and time on them. We should finally look again at the real problems and first look at where the problems are and then see what solution suits them. Do not look at what the solution is, and then whether we can also think of a problem about it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr President, through you, I would like to ask my colleague whether she really believes that she is a well-informed security expert who can assess the benefits of this package, which is the purpose of the security of EU citizens. How will they then respond to EU citizens who have been the victims of an assassination that we have hesitated now with the introduction of this package, which is recommended by security experts?

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for calling my qualification into question: that is always very much appreciated. However, I am not sure that you have fully appreciated the proposal, because it is in no way going to make Europeans more secure – in no way whatsoever. The only advantages it might bring are in relation to increased automation at borders, but we actually have studies that show it is going to make queues and waiting times longer. So there is no benefit in this system. If you want to look into it further, we can surely talk about that: it is an issue I have been working on for a couple of years. The proposal has been around for some time and has not really improved, and there has never been a substantive answer from the Commission on what this is actually good for.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the smart approach, which the Commission needs to understand, is that continental Europe will never have an effective external border strategy until it has a smarter internal one. Schengen is now 30 years old, but this approach will not be smart until European countries within the Schengen area stop illegal or irregular migrants traversing Europe, be it to enter the United Kingdom unlawfully or otherwise. People traffickers, illegal migrants and invalid asylum seekers are not going to be deterred by the so-called smart measures. EU purpose, intent and cost are all open to question here. This response has been overtaken by external circumstances and events, and a major rethink is required. A rethink of the cause is paramount, because an overly complex technology application which fails to address the problem areas but which penalises, inconveniences and deters lawful movements is not the right approach to take.

name: Vicky Maeijer (NI).
text: – When I first came across the term Smart Borders Package, I actually had to laugh. After all, what are the limits of the Commission here? Our internal borders were already abandoned in 1995 and the external borders we still have today are as leaky as a basket thanks to shuttle service Frontex. The EU has no borders at all.  Smart borders in the eyes of the European Union mainly mean weak borders. Millions of illegal immigrants are already roaming the European Union and hundreds of thousands are ready to come this way. People who travel thousands of kilometres to enter the EU will not be stopped by a new electronic system. That's what we need boats to send them back.  My party, the Party for Freedom, does not need 791 million in hot air. Let us simply restore our old borders. That would be really smart.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have so far heard criticism, but not alternative proposals to this smart border package, which has a dual purpose. First of all, to highlight the fact that freedom of movement is a resource and also a challenge for the European Union. I believe that in this Parliament we must all agree that we must pass the manual control, also on a matter of security, in the face of all the people, and on the increase that will cross our borders. So I think that those who think that the position of stamps on travel documents on passports that can be lost destroyed, that they do not take into account extended stays beyond the deadline can be better than automation, so on the one hand, it facilitates entry, on the other hand it facilitates controls. So this is an answer that is being given, I think I still hear the PNR debate. Parliament was divided on those for and against. So there will certainly be a data collection, a log. Well, the also important challenge will be to focus our efforts on the fact that it must be all this data entered on the net, put together, because there is Schengen data, data for the visa information system, the SIS and therefore this data must then be collected and, above all, well used, both for law enforcement and security.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, should we not be careful about something or someone who claims to be intelligent from the outset? Unfortunately, the "Smart Borders" package does not seem to escape this precautionary rule.  Caution, first of all, with regard to its objective: the access of enforcement services to the personal data collected is now under discussion. This debate is obviously not just about the "Smart Borders" package. Enforcement agencies are increasingly leaving access to data from people who are not, in principle, suspected of any crime. So it's a question of what we're talking about. A border management system or yet another security tool?  Prudence, then, with regard to its impact on fundamental rights. On the one hand, the scheme proposes to facilitate the journey of some privileged travellers and, on the other hand, it wants to combat the overspending of the length of stay of slightly less fortunate travellers. Won't this differentiation between travellers lead to a form of discrimination? On what basis would the criteria for access or denial of access to the registered traveller program be assessed?  Finally, in terms of its cost, a smart border seems to be a border that costs a lot of money, which has probably not gone unnoticed by industrial players.  In addition to the intense lobbying that this scheme must generate, is there no reason to question its cost-effectiveness? As has already been pointed out, the experience of the United States has largely questioned this report: more than $1.5 billion of investment for only 1,300 refusals of entry. At a time when the European Union and its Member States are struggling to unlock a budget to save lives in the Mediterranean, one wonders if the game is really worth it.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – I welcome the Commission's Smart Borders proposals, in particular the entry and exit system that records the time and place of the entry and exit of third-country landers crossing the EU external borders, thus calculating the duration of their stay and reporting when the permitted period of that stay is exceeded. This package will improve the assessment and control of irregular migration and will also improve the protection of the EU external border from security threats. That is why I am very interested in the results of the pilot project which will examine the options for the implementation of the said package.  But to justify the cost of the two new systems, we need to take biometric data and provide access to police and security services from the operational start of that system. At present, the possibility of doing so will only be discussed two years after the launch of that system. It is high time to take our common security seriously.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for being with us today, because we are in urgent need of clarification. What we need is a debate on the fundamental questions of how we got to this point and where we want to go from here. We should start by questioning the process by which the increased use of information technology in border controls has become the norm and the policy trend in Europe. We also need to discuss where the limits could and should be drawn for a fundamental rights perspective. Therefore, before proceeding, we have the duty to examine the fundamental rights implications of collecting, storing and using biometric data for immigration, asylum, visa processing and border control purposes, thus bridging the topics of migration and data protection. The smart border system should not be put in place at any cost. We need to make sure that the system is really needed and that it will be an asset, without undermining the fundamental rights of EU and non-EU citizens. I am particularly concerned, in this respect, about access for law enforcement bodies. So should we not first of all explore the possibilities of using existing systems before building a new one, considering both budgetary and data protection aspects? As you have already mentioned, Mr Commissioner, the second key point is the data retention period. The ruling of the European Court of Justice does not leave any room for interpretation and we cannot ignore it. Where interferences with fundamental rights are at stake, the extent of the EU legislators’ discretion may prove to be limited. And the question that remains is: how can we make sure that the principles of necessity and proportionality are respected?

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, they want to sell us the Smart Borders project as a project to speed up and facilitate border inspection procedures, but what is actually behind this project is the creation of a police register which makes anyone entering the European Union suspicious; a search with data available to law enforcement authorities. In addition, a system that divides people into three classes: first classes, citizens of the European Union; the second-rate ones, those who consider legitimate, those who do not bother because they come here on business; and the third, the poor, targeted by the entry and exit system, criminalizing, once again, and pointing out migrants as enemies, treated as criminals simply because their visa has expired. The entry and exit system aims to further close borders; an alert system, a search-and-capture system for those who have dared to penetrate the 'Fortress Europe'.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, pending the Commission's legislative proposal, it seems to me that there is a great deal of confusion on this issue of smart borders. The only certain fact is, as Mrs Fajon said, that EUR 791 million was allocated in 2013, and a subsequent study told us that half of it is probably enough. So, we wonder whether we should continue to maintain such a high figure for a project whose scope and usefulness are not yet well understood: one, because we have more serious emergencies, the example of the Mediterranean emergency, I think is quite valid on which resources should be allocated; secondly, because it is not clear how these intelligent borders were to interact with the Shengen information system, which is still more or less concerned with the same thing. So while you're waiting for reliable data on limits and costs, it's hard to make assessments.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Madam President, the migration problem is becoming increasingly acute as a result of the escalation of imperialist aggression. The European Union, with the active participation of the Greek Government, under the pretext of dealing with traffickers, is forming a naval military force for interventions in third countries.  The european Union's so-called smart borders are nothing more than opening up and closing the cannula of the flow of migrants, as defined by the interests of business groups for a cheap workforce. The only data are the iron-blocked suppression systems, the fingerprint file, the concentration camps, Frontex, Schengen, which are where thousands of refugees and migrants are frozen in Mediterranean waters every year.  The Commission's proposals for resettlement are a mockery, since in addition to being a drop in the ocean, Dublin and other European Union regulations are in force and that is the bottom line. So here and now to take measures to address the problems of refugees, the rapid and reliable provision of asylum or subsidiary protection, the creation of state and decent accommodation structures.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The smart border management package at the EU's external borders for third-country nationals, i.e. non-EU nationals, has as its background the number of 200 to 300 million border crossings per year and the fact that two to an estimated four million people with expired residence permits are currently in Europe illegally. At the same time, however, impeccable, ordinary frequent travellers do not receive any relief when crossing the border. This perfectly justifies the project. Parliament has played a part in the Fact that the Commission is now reviewing the reality of these planned two regulations at border points such as airports, motorways and station border posts in pilot projects in order to offer us, in practice, a clear knowledge of the functioning at the end of the year and, furthermore, to examine the very important cost-benefit factor. That is a good thing. The cost factor in particular has been emphasised and must be emphasised. Replacing the old travel stamps is an extraordinarily logical consequence. We must, of course, network with the visa and Schengen system here. Illegal stays in the EU must be effectively prosecuted and frequent travellers must be given appropriate relief. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you, Mr Becker, for being able to ask the question. Suppose the problem is as you described it. So how do you explain to me that the smart borders system fits the problem? You have said that irregular residence must be limited. But how do you intend to do that when smart borders just tell you that a person is there longer, but not where that person is? So, how do you want to solve this? You don't get the person out of European territory with smart borders.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I am happy to address this and perhaps i disappoint you, because I am addressing two aspects that you do not like either. One is that I naturally hope that we will also reform the screening of people who are illegally, which must not, of course, mean that we are now issuing a general suspicion. However, we know that people, even with other visas, are really almost free to move where Europe is supposed to be, and in doing so they have only solved the visa for one Member State. Here, too, of course, we have some catching up to do, and I suspect that these regulations will subsequently lead to implementation. We cannot discuss them now, there is no time to do so. The second and final point I would like to make, which I am sure I do not like, is that I naturally hope that the data can subsequently be used for prosecution, which brings enormous added value.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his The Commission's proposal has raised important objections both in terms of costs and in terms of personal security and privacy and fundamental rights. It is good that the Commission is considering making revised proposals, because it gives us the opportunity to really have fundamental discussions on this, on the need and the new system of border crossings.  I believe that the starting point for a new system for regulating border crossings must be the aim of making it easier for anyone who wants to come to europe to cross borders. If the proposal does not serve that purpose, Then I do not see that it has relevant added value. We cannot have an order of first and second-class migrants, with some going through revolving doors and others having to undergo an invasion of privacy. This is not in line with the view of human beings that should guide us in building our policies, either at national or European level. I also do not believe that it is justifiable to spend money on increasing control over people at the expense of their privacy. At the same time, there is an urgent need for resources to save lives on the EU's borders and create safe paths to europe for those fleeing war and poverty.  A small personal part: In Sweden, there was a computer bank with the police. I was one of those standing there, out of 5,000 – me, my four children and my eight grandchildren. I've never been spoken to by the police. A thousand dead people were on the register and a thousand children. It is people who are in charge of these data banks, we do not yet know in Sweden who will be able to take advantage of this data. So we need to be afraid of certain things, otherwise we should not pursue politics out of fear, but we should be innovative ... (Speaker interrupted by The President)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Unlike my colleagues in the Socialists and Greens group, I am not suspicious. I do not assume in advance that the intelligent borders system is a threat to fundamental rights. However, truth be told, the ball is on the pitch of the European Commission, and Commissioner Avramopoulos in particular. Much greater clarity on the part of the Commission, a precise explanation of the added value, the presentation of the work calendar, the presentation of the work calendar, the need to say today when further, renewed legislation will be presented, is to be expected. If there were more transparency and precision on this issue on the part of the Commissioner, perhaps the discussion would not be so general and would not be marked, even burdened, by suspicion.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I have a number of concerns with the smart borders proposal. In particular, I am dismayed that the EU feels it is appropriate to invest colossal amounts of funding on biometric and technological smart borders rather than investing in saving lives, as required by the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Thousands of migrants continue to try to reach the EU in overcrowded boats, risking their lives to escape poverty and violence. I commend the crew of the Irish naval vessel, the LÉ Eithne, which has now rescued over 1 000 people since it left Ireland. This illustrates the need for increased search and rescue activities. The smart borders proposal appears more concerned with the mass collection of data than with addressing this humanitarian crisis. It is imperative that the Commission prioritises the saving of lives, in line with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, and forgets this smart borders proposal. ‘Expensive borders’ would be more accurate – serving multinational interests with the imposition of expensive machines.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI).
text: Mr President, since 2013 the Commission has wanted to set up what it calls 'smart borders'. On the one hand, it is a question of registering foreigners who come frequently to the Union, in order to speed up border control, and, on the other hand, to check the biometric data of all foreigners who want to enter the Union. This project seems to me to be critical for two reasons. First, it is a dangerous project for freedoms, as it intends to computer-file the personal data of millions of people; it is the same liberticidal logic as that of the PNR project on the use of passenger record data. Secondly, these "smart borders" are a cover-up designed to strengthen the Schengen system. However, Schengen is a terrible failure since, every day, migrants manage to enter the EU illegally, especially in Greece or Italy. These are real state borders that we need, not these smart pseudo-borders.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, the current situation of increased terrorist threat over Europe and of illegal migratory pressure at the external borders requires clear and concrete measures to be taken to ensure European security, while not violating fundamental human rights. The Smart Borders proposal is such a measure. European Union border guards and law enforcement authorities need to know who, when and how they cross European borders. Only in this way will we reduce illegal migration, fight trafficking in human beings, prevent terrorist attacks in European cities. At the same time, the European economy will be supported by facilitating the travel of third-country nationals who often come to the European Union for business or tourism purposes. I believe that I will find support from many of my colleagues, saying that the Smart Borders package should not be implemented regardless of price, but must be secured by reasonable financial means. At a time when the EU must set an example with careful spending of European funds, no overpriced project should be paid. Nor should the safety of personal data be compromised, especially in the context of the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the storage of personal data. I therefore call on the European Commission to carefully analyse the most financially efficient Smart Borders project, as well as the legal basis and compatibility of the package with existing European data protection legislation. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You say that knowing who is in the European Union at any given time would assist in the fight against terrorism. However, all the different countries have their own different legal systems, different police forces and so on, and Europe is such a vast continent. Surely the only way that this would make a serious difference is if we actually knew who was in each individual country at the same time? Therefore this hugely expensive project – carried out with taxpayers’ money – is not going to make the kind of difference you suggest.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – At a time when there is a technical possibility of monitoring who passes through the external European borders, the necessary mechanisms can be achieved if each Member State wishes to locate potential terrorist threats, people linked to organised crime and, with the assistance of the security services, to take appropriate measures in each Member State in Europe.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the lack of internal border controls and the growing number of travellers arriving from third countries require effective and efficient management of the European Union's external borders. The Council, in the strategic guidelines for the area of freedom, security and justice adopted in June 2014, also called for more modern measures in the field of border management and these new measures were finally included in the so-called smart borders package. However, I must stress that these proposals raise certain problems linked to respect for fundamental rights: the new border controls focus on the use of a new computerised system of entry and exit. In this regard, my main concern concerns the keeping of records containing a substantial amount of personal and biometric data. We must not be caught up in the rush to adopt legislative texts that are not fully in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  Moreover, the need for an in-depth assessment of the compatibility of the legislative proposal with Articles 7 to 8 of the Charter was reiterated by the European Data Protection Supervisor in an opinion some time ago. And this assessment, and I repeat, must also be made in the light of the judgment of the Court of Justice on data retention. I therefore call on the Commission to carefully assess the compatibility of the legislative proposal with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, as well as with the cost-benefit profile, also taking into account the results of the ongoing pilot project.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, adopting such a package would be a technological shift in the management of the Union's external borders, but I believe that our primary objective is not to make the control system modern, but above all effective, safe and rational as far as costs are concerned. This package falls on all three criteria listed. The question arises as to how effective the entry and exit system would be if the identification of persons who did not leave the European Union on time would not be possible by the time of their exit. The storage of large amounts of data on migrants and regular travellers is in turn a security problem, and the projected cost from 2017 to 2020 exceeds the expected benefits in such a short period. I believe that pressure on external borders must primarily be reduced by changing migration and asylum policy, rather than simply applying costly technological solutions. While we encourage the influx of illegal migrants through these policies, smart borders will not help us too much.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I am committed to secure external borders of the Union that we will ensure by using, nevertheless, new technologies, but also by strengthening cooperation with third countries, so that the increase in human trafficking, smuggling and deaths in the Mediterranean is drastically reduced and eliminated.  I will support this package of smart borders, because today, 25 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, we do not need a closed Europe, but an open one with well-controlled borders. Of course, doubts arise about new technologies, about digitalization, but at the same time we have to believe it.  I have another problem that I want to highlight here, namely the results of the fifth report on the post-liberalisation of the visa regime for the control of western Balkan countries by the European Commission, which states that the European Union does not exclude the possibility of reintroducing visas for citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Albania, Montenegro and Serbia, all because of the huge increase in the number of citizens of these countries in the Countries of the European Union.  I think we should take into account that these are countries that want to become part of the European family, and additional controls can only further undermine trust in the Union. Therefore, I am committed to digitalisation, I am committed to intelligent border control, but at the same time that Europe, after 25 years since the fall of the Berlin Wall, is controlled but at the same time open.  This is not easy, but it is for the Commission to do due diligence and to tell us all aspects, both economic and legal, and in particular compatibility with regulations in the Member States. In my view, Member States need to get involved in this project.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Avraboule, I welcome the Commission's decisive stance in building the principle of solidarity in the field of refugee flows. We have raised this issue often in this Chamber, and the criteria for the distribution of refugee flows, namely GDP, the area, the population of the Member States, and the level of unemployment are fully in accordance with the thoughts we have expressed on this issue. So we think it is important that 16,000 refugees from Syria who are hosted in Greece will be redistributed on the basis of the above allocation key within the European Union.  However, this practical application of Community solidarity must also be extended to migration flows. Greece cannot afford other illegal immigrants and the Member States of the Union must understand this. We must proceed with the abolition of Dublin III and replace the Dublin system with a genuine system of European solidarity and co-responsibility. In this context, the intelligent borders system is an important tool, but it must respect personal data and fundamental rights, as you mentioned.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, i would like to start by congratulating you and saying that I am very glad that you are coming between us with more and more controversial topics. Personally, I would recommend changing the PR manager as we need to communicate very much with us on these topics.  From this discussion, I feel that some colleagues are not well informed enough on these topics. There have been a number of myths associated with this package. I personally consider the package to be essential for the overall security of Europe and European citizens.  I believe we will achieve greater control of our external borders. Especially at a time when we are facing increasing threats of terrorism, we must be able to monitor people moving within the EU. Undoubtedly, the proposed measures will contribute to reducing the number of people living in the EU illegally. That's what we have to tell one. In my view, it is not even sustainable nowadays that, as the number of people crossing the border increases, there are still paper versions of the documents where the stamps will be put.  Let us remember that we live in the 21st century, and we cannot rely on someone to properly stamp or stamp a passport. Personally, I think it was too late today with the introduction of smart borders.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the debate on the access of police forces to databases has relaunched with the attacks on Paris. With the tragedies in the Mediterranean, border management has moved to the front pages of newspapers. And suddenly, an entry and exit system and a program of registered travelers appeared as a solution to both problems. It seems that we have forgotten its initial objective: to facilitate border control and to know how many overstayers we have in the European Union. We continue to ignore the impact of the judgment of the Court of Justice of the Union which annulled the Data Retention Directive, although several officials have repeatedly ensured that this impact would not be ignored. And we have persisted in moving forward with more, and increasingly comprehensive, data collection and processing tools.  I have no doubt that the safety of citizens must be a priority and that we need to act. But we cannot ignore the work that has been done, we must not devalue the instruments we have on the ground and whose potential we have not yet fully explored, nor should we give up on identifying flaws and correcting gaps in the systems we have before proposing costly new systems.  There is therefore a need for urgent clarification, such as those requested by colleagues Días de Mera and Tanja Fajon. In particular, the Commission must react to these amendments and fulfil Vice-President Timmermans' commitment to ensure systematic checks of fundamental rights throughout the legislative process, to clearly define the purpose of the systems and to present an impact assessment that fully demonstrates their need.

name: József Nagy (PPE).
text: – The protection of our external borders is important because of the unity and security of the Union and the illegal migration of people. On the basis of the Commission's 2013 proposal, faster and more effective checks are needed at the EU's external borders in order to improve mobility and security. However, these measures should also take into account the migration situation and economic recovery.  A smart EES would make it easier to control frequent travellers to the EU, which would save not only them but also EU bodies a significant saving of time and energy. Moreover, working with the electronic system would also make it more effective to detect possible abuses in relation to staying in the Union and could also reduce the misuse of travel documents. The re-use of alleged lost EU passports for illegal entry could be stopped with this system.  I believe that the current system is not suitable for Member States to cope with the increasing burden of passengers entering and leaving the EU, as it is estimated that by 2030 the number of passengers at air border crossing points will increase by 80%, from 400 million to 720 million, and I have two high expectations for the EES: be simple and safe. Thank you very much!

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the solution to irregular migration lies in regular migration. In order to keep the European Union open, we need to convince our citizens that there are strong control and safeguard systems in place, which, besides ensuring easy access for travellers, also allow for the detection of irregular situations. I am confident that the proposed use of a common platform for an entry/exit system and a registered traveller programme, as well as the efficient monitoring of traveller flows, will form a large part of the solution in proactively fighting against irregular migration. I hope that the pilot programme started at Lisbon Airport will be helpful in this regard, and I think we are all looking forward to learning more about the outcomes of the first trials of the proposed system.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, of course it is necessary to set smart borders for the European Union and of course we need to use new technology and all that new technologies enable in order to have a safer life in the European Union and it is not in dispute that we need to have smart borders both because of the problems of terrorism, migrants, everything we have experienced in recent months and years. However, I insist on a flexible system, I insist on a system that will protect personal data, I insist on a system that will not challenge the tourism economy of the European Union as today the largest destination of tourism in the world. And I insist that a cost-benefit analysis be done very well, because the price expected of this system is extremely high. So, I expect a really right answer from the Commission when we talk about this smart borders project.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to express my thanks to all of you for this very fruitful exchange of views. Let me start by telling you that I took note of all your remarks and concerns. They are substantial concerns, and you can be sure that we are not going to repeat past mistakes, as happened with the Schengen Information System II. We are going to assess carefully the costs and the architecture, as well as fundamental rights and safeguards, which are very important. And proportionality and necessity will be our compass in any future discussion. The ruling on data retention will also guide us. Today’s debate confirms the vital importance of Parliament’s input into our joint efforts to create a smart border system that meets its objectives and offers genuine value for money. Since we know that traveller flows will continue to grow, we need a better and smarter border management system. If we do nothing, we will either have to face much longer queues at the borders or we shall be obliged to employ more border guards in the near future. Neither of these options seems acceptable or feasible. As you understand, we are going to meet many times in the future in order, first of all, to discuss the results of the testing phase and the impact assessment. I want to assure you that the Commission is looking forward to working closely with Parliament in this very important fight and that it is counting on your support and cooperation in achieving the final balance.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. –  Free movement of persons is one of the most important achievements of the European Union since its foundation. The absence of internal borders makes it therefore crucially important that our common external borders are controlled reliably and consistently. In order to better manage the growing flow of travellers, we need to modernise the European border control system, by increasing its efficiency and effectiveness. The result should be smooth and easy travel for the majority of third-country travellers who cross the EU borders yearly on the one hand, and an impossible mission for those who abuse free movement, such as organised crime and terrorist organisations, on the other. We look forward to the findings of the Commission’s impact assessment and the pilot projects currently being carried out, to understand what new architecture will be implemented, what the single system for entry-exit should look like, what biometric identification should be applied, how data retention and protection would be handled. The recent dramatic increase in migrants through the Mediterranean and the Balkans makes it even more urgent to adopt the Smart Borders Package, in order to strengthen border control and guarantee the protection of our citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. If the European Commission's objective is to make border management modern and efficient, we can only agree. However, the 'Smart Borders' reform proposed by the Commission, including following the adoption of the Security Agenda and the Migration Agenda, requires deep reflection in order to allay the real concerns that exist about the excessive attention paid to security issues, which are not commensurate with the current level of risk. The dilemma between which and how much passenger data will have to be used and stored and what the effects of this use will be on fundamental passenger rights remains open.  I therefore share the very sceptical position expressed by our Socialist colleagues who are at the forefront of these matters, because I believe that there is no need for a new system, which is also expensive, but which would be enough to make it work better, updating and strengthening the existing system, based on the VIS and the Schengen Information System (SIS II). Caution is urgently needed with regard to the impact that the Intelligent Borders package could have on fundamental rights, and prudence towards the creation of differentiation between privileged travellers, who should be facilitated on their journeys and, less fortunate travellers, who could go beyond the length of their stay. This distinction could lead to real discrimination.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Making full use of the potential of the Smart Borders Package can bring tangible benefits in border management by enhancing Europe's capacity to reduce irregular migration, ensure the return of irregular migrants and fight terrorism. Security and the fight against terrorism should be a top priority of the Smart Borders Package, which will consider making the system available to the security services, taking into account the principles of proportionality. In this context, we should ensure adequate data protection at both national and Community level.  Another aspect is the optimisation of the budget allocated to the establishment of the system, assuming greater interoperability with existing national systems. Climate conditions and the specificities of the various border controls should be taken into account here: climatic conditions, different lengths of borders, number of border crossing points and volume of passenger movement, infrastructure, etc. For example, in Polish this will require, according to preliminary estimates, the employment of 60 additional consular officers, and the cost of such an official is EUR 100 000 per year. We also need to answer the question of whether we are effectively exploiting the potential of the systems currently in place, e.g. SIS II, and whether costs have been correctly estimated. We cannot afford to adopt a project that will eventually be more expensive, and it is not yet known whether the effect will be in line with the initial assumptions.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This Commission statement is, of course, nothing new. The European Union, which is in its globalist well-being, once again welcomes the removal of the national borders of the Member States and the free movement of goods and people. As for the borders of the European Union, they turn out to be real sieves.  The European Union is moved by the plight of illegal immigrants and is even considering imposing quotas on Member States. Member States already suffering the full brunt of the austerity measures put in place by Brussels, which are seeing the unemployment rate of young people under 25 soaring and the number of people living below the poverty line soaring.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – There is currently a wide-ranging debate in the European Parliament about the smart border system whereby Member States want to create mechanisms by which the system of interconnection and border protection is strengthened. This requires a better correlation between Member States and a record of citizens entering or crossing Europe. Even if this brings many advantages, I take the opportunity to reiterate that any discussion of border security must also include Romania, even if it is not currently in the Schengen area. I consider it an abuse of the tendencies of some States or colleagues who want to exclude my country from this integrated border management system by creating the premises for an additional barrier to the right to mobility in the European area. We cannot create a border in the European Union, and I believe that Romania, given the success of its border protection programmes, but also by meeting the criteria for accession to the Schengen area, must and can be included in this system of smart borders.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on: - the question with an oral response to the Commission on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Monitoring Committee, Petri Sarvamaa, on behalf of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats), and Bart Staes, on behalf of the Green Group/European Free Alliance (O-000060/2015 – B8-0553/2015), - the question with request for an oral response to the Commission on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Monitoring Committee, Dennis de Jong, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left (O-000061/2015 – B8-0554/2015), and - the question with request for oral response to the Commission on OLAF investigations , by Michael Theurer, Martina Dlabajová, Nedzhmi Ali, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Dita Charanzová and Frédérique Ries, on behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (O-000066/2015 – B8-0555/2015).

name: Bart Staes
text: Author. – Let me first bring some positive news. Within OLAF, many hundreds of people work hard and well, and their work makes them a fight against fraud, corruption and illegal practices that cost the taxpayer a great deal of money. However, the activities report of the Supervisory Committee is sweeping the floor with some of olaf's practices and the concrete functioning of olaf's Director-General.
