Some examples: 1) investigations are opened without a sufficiently serious suspicion of fraud and corruption, even though this is legally necessary;  2. olaf's Director-General does not take seriously the recommendations of the Supervisory Committee;  3. the Supervisory Committee is hampered in its work and has no or insufficient access to documents and information;  4) there is no legal basis for recording private phone calls and yet this has been done in an important investigation;  5) statistics on the duration of investigations are manipulated to speed up or at least make the investigations appear to be so;  6. the Secretariat of the Supervisory Committee is under enormous, sometimes personal pressure, because it falls under the administrative supervision of the Director-General of OLAF, so the auditee has control over the auditor.  The Supervisory Committee shall consist of five members. They work collectively and are known in their Member States as extremely competent, with a great deal of expertise in combating fraud. In the activity report we clearly read that there is a difference of opinion between the Supervisory Committee on the one hand and the Director-General of OLAF on the other hand on the role of the Commission. This is where the Commission comes in. That's where you have to take responsibility. Commissioner Georgieva, who is the anti-fraud commissioner, must take a position. The findings of the Supervisory Committee are serious, concrete and have been going on for a long time.  So our question is: what measures are you going to take to ensure that the supervisory committee's comments are followed up and the problems are resolved? No one is asking you to intervene in operational activities, not even the supervisory committee, but there must be action, there must be an action plan. Something needs to be done here so that these problems can be resolved. I am eagerly awaiting your answer.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: author. – Mr President, this is something that I am sure we all are aware of, and the Commission certainly has to be aware of what we are dealing with and talking about tonight. There have been so many questions raised during the past years that I do not think they need to be repeated in detail. But what really needs to be said tonight in this debate – and when we are putting these questions to the Commission – is that for the first time we are witnessing a crucial and damning report from an independent supervisory committee consisting of five independent experts. Their role in supervising the work of OLAF is not just anything; it is absolutely crucial and essential to the credibility of the Union in the eyes of EU citizens. Therefore, we are asking you tonight not just what the Commission has done, but what is the Commission's doing? What is the Commission doing to deal with the problems that clearly are present? The Supervisory Committee is calling into question its ability to conduct its work. This is not acceptable. We really need to see some action, so our main question tonight is: what is the Commission doing to change this?

name: Dennis de Jong
text: Author. I am pleased that we can have this discussion with the Commission today in a business-like way. I have no need for any attacks, neither on the person of the DG OLAF nor on the Committee on Budgetary Control. The fact is, however, that the supervisor has included a number of specific criticisms in its annual report and that OLAF's responses do not allay the concerns of many colleagues and myself.  Opening things up, for example, needs to be done carefully. You don't start an official investigation until there's a sufficiently serious suspicion of fraud. OLAF points out that the new rules were not in force at the time. However, the supervisor does not rely on the new OLAF Regulation but on the case law of the Court of Justice. OLAF admits that this case law was not followed and that is serious.  It is just one example, i believe that the real discussion between the supervisor and OLAF is mainly about how to monitor if you do not have enough or at least too little insight into individual cases. Of course, DG OLAF is right to say that the privacy of suspects must be safeguarded, but even then OLAF can ensure that the information on selection criteria and prioritisation is sufficiently substantiated to be submitted to the supervisor. The institutions have been talking about this for years now, and I think there is a very clear task for the European Commissioner. It seems that more specific information is required to the supervisor in order to break the deadlock.  Finally, it is noticeable that OLAF wants to keep a lot of things indoors. For example, there is the proposal to place a controller on procedural safeguards within OLAF. But it certainly applies to the regulator as well. It depends on OLAF's budget and information. The European Commissioner must look at this explicitly. How can the supervisor really become independent of the organisation he oversees? It is in everyone's interest to improve the relationship between the supervisor and OLAF quickly. These organs are clearly not coming out of their own. That is why I hope that the Commissioner will quickly take up the gauntlet and in the resolution we are calling for a concrete action plan. I trust that the Commission will commit us to come up with such a plan quickly. We owe it to the citizens of Europe.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The matter we are discussing today is a very serious matter, and I agree with colleagues. And it's not new. In the last mandate, in the role of Chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I saw that, as early as 2011 and 2013, the Report of the Supervisory Committee pointed out that the members of the Supervisory Committee were experiencing difficulties in carrying out their work, that they were not getting close to the information they deems necessary, that there appear to be repeated conflicts of competence between management. , the Director of OLAF and the Supervisory Committee. That is why we feel compelled today to put a question to the Commission here in plenary, because OLAF is independent. We need a strong and functioning anti-fraud authority, that is right. And we, as the European Parliament, also defend independence. But in a state governed by the rule of law, there must be checks and balances. In other words, the question is: who actually controls the inspectors? In the OLAF regulation, we have introduced the supervisory committee, the supervisory committee. It is extremely worrying for us, as the Committee on Budgetary Control, if the members of this Supervisory Committee turn to us and point out difficulties. We want the Supervisory Committee to be able to carry out its tasks. In other words, if OLAF is the police authority, then the European Public Prosecutor, whom we have been calling for for years, is missing at EU level, who can then monitor the police if necessary. Against this background, we believe that the Supervisory Committee must now be strengthened or that the Commission must take measures to ensure that the Supervisory Committee can actually fulfil the tasks laid down in the regulation. We expect the Commission to give us answers here.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Vice- President Georgieva regrets that she is not able to participate in this debate tonight. I therefore represent the Commission on this occasion. The fight against fraud is of the utmost importance for the Commission, and I know that it is the same for Parliament. In this context, Parliament has repeatedly shown great interest in the work of the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Supervisory Committee. Most recently, when the Supervisory Committee presented its annual activity report covering the year 2014, this gave rise to discussions in the Committee on Budgetary Control. Some honourable Members have stated that the report identified serious deficiencies in the work of OLAF. The Commission would like to emphasise that the role of the Supervisory Committee is to reinforce OLAF’s independence as an investigative board. The Supervisory Committee can identify issues which, in its view, require further improvements with the aim of making OLAF stronger in its core mission. In this context, the Commission has received three oral questions covering matters referred to in the Supervisory Committee activity report or in other discussions concerning the Supervisory Committee of OLAF. Furthermore, four motions for a resolution touching on the same subjects were tabled by different political groups. Allow me to elaborate on the matters raised in the oral questions. The first is the opening of 423 cases on 12 February 2012. The second is the Commission’s position with regard to ensuring that OLAF complies with the legal requirements placed on it in the OLAF Regulation. OLAF has been criticised for the opening of a large number of cases, by a single decision, in February 2012. The Commission has been informed that this decision was taken transparently; that all investigative units and OLAF management were involved; and that the decision and its impact on OLAF’s resources were transparently reported on in OLAF’s annual report for 2012—2013. The decision was due to internal reorganisation and the need to clear a backlog. The Commission also notes that OLAF does not agree with the Supervisory Committee that the opening of the cases failed to meet the legal requirement for the opening of an investigation. OLAF does not share the Supervisory Committee’s legal assessment on this matter. The Commission emphasises that the opening of investigations is an investigative act, that OLAF is fully independent in those acts, and that the Commission is required to respect the independence of OLAF in its investigative functions. The decisions that the European Union and national authorities may adopt in the follow-up to OLAF investigations are subject to judicial review. It should, furthermore, be noted that it is not the role of the Supervisory Committee to pass judgment on the legality of individual investigative acts, as recognised by the Supervisory Committee itself. My third point concerns the Commission’s perception of the working arrangements and working relations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee, and its intention to facilitate those relations and to make OLAF more efficient. The Commission is aware that OLAF and the Supervisory Committee are working very hard to improve their relations. In particular, OLAF and the Supervisory Committee are currently reviewing their working arrangements in order to align them better to the needs of the Supervisory Committee. The Commission, and in particular Vice-President Georgieva, has regularly raised with both sides issues linked to the relations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee. The Commission’s aim is, of course, to facilitate and foster good cooperation and constructive dialogue. It should be noted, however, that OLAF and the Supervisory Committee are two independent bodies which are already in dialogue and work together with the same aim. The Commission can offer its advice and support, but it is the responsibility of OLAF and its Supervisory Committee to develop sound and constructive cooperation. Referring, in its activity report, to the independence of its secretariat, the Supervisory Committee mentions legal requirements. The OLAF Regulation specifies that the Supervisory Committee secretariat shall be provided by the Office in close consultation with the Supervisory Committee. In its most recent opinion, No 1/2015, on OLAF’s budget 2016 – an opinion not yet shared with the institutions – the Supervisory Committee recognises that the current arrangements with OLAF come close to sufficient financial autonomy for the Supervisory Committee and its secretariat. As stated by my colleague Vice-President Georgieva at Parliament’s March 2015 part-session, the Commission is currently exploring ways in which it can further strengthen the independence of the Supervisory Committee in its human resources and budget management within the existing framework. Fuller formal independence of the Supervisory Committee and secretariat, in terms of both budget and human resources, would, however, require the legislator to amend OLAF Regulation 883/2015. In view of the international role of both OLAF and the Supervisory Committee in the protection of the European Union’s financial interests, the relations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee are, of course, a matter of interest to Parliament, the Council and the Commission. We would like to propose that the subject be discussed further in the context of the annual interinstitutional exchange of views provided for in the OLAF Regulation. The next exchange of views will take place in September 2015. Fourthly, on the question of whether the Commission is to propose an action plan to resolve serious deficiencies highlighted in the Supervisory Committee annual report, the Commission is of the opinion that it is excessive to consider that the Supervisory Committee has identified serious deficiencies. It is the very purpose of the Supervisory Committee to identify issues which, in its view, require further improvement in the work of the Office, and to make the corresponding recommendations. Many of the issues raised by the Supervisory Committee in its activity report refer to OLAF’s investigative activities, such as the opening of the 423 cases in 2012, the investigative policy priorities and the participation of the office in the Commission’s Clearing House meetings. Last week, on 2 June 2015, OLAF presented its annual report for the year 2014. It reports on the efficacy and results of its investigations, providing a positive picture of its achievements. It is for OLAF, as an independent investigative body, to give proper follow-up and to inform the Supervisory Committee and the institutions thereof. The Commission has been informed by OLAF that it has responded to, or is in the process of responding to, many of the Supervisory Committee’s recommendations and requests. As mentioned by the Chair of the Supervisory Committee during his speech at the meeting of the Committee on Budgetary Control on 4 May, the important professional work carried out by OLAF deserves all our appreciation, and the statutory role of the Supervisory Committee is to improve this work and to contribute to trust in OLAF’s investigative activities.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Sometimes it would be better if you didn't read out what others were writing down. The lecture now was so marked by a lack of expertise and one-sidedness that I almost left my voice. What would happen if a police authority in the EU or in third countries manipulated statistics, opened cases in order to be better able to stand up, confronted Parliament with embellished figures and allegedly informed and at least achieved unclear results at the core of its task, namely the protection of funds? The EU would have been there and would have had a lot of good advice for a long time. In the core area of what is concerned with the EU, namely the Anti-Fraud Office, you have now explained to us for a long time that all this is not so bad, that we can see the matter from two sides and that we should not be upset at what is happening, because on the one hand those who find out – the Supervisory Committee – would overstretch their mandate. Commissioner, that was all great crap. Sorry, that was all big crap. It was, at least factually, completely inappropriate. We have a big problem, it literally stinks to heaven. And you, the Commission, are pretending that none of this is a matter of doing anything. The Commission is trying to sit it out. That's what you've been trying to do for two years now. We are dealing with serious breaches of the law, and you are telling us: folks, don't be so, we are not interested in that. Think twice about what you are saying here. I am sorry. We will work it all out. I have to tell you that I did not think it was possible. It's good that I was there. (Applause)

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I welcome those colleagues who for years ignored and persecuted OLAF's Surveillance Committee, when I alone understood that their work should be secured, which is to protect OLAF's independence and now also to protect those investigated. But those were other times. Precipitation is always a very bad adviser, and more so in the treatment of the body responsible for combating fraud inside and outside the European Union, pending the next European Prosecutor. That is why, since my group, we have considered this debate to be hasty — which addresses only one part of the problem and has been organised even before we heard the annual report of OLAF itself, which is the central body we should be talking about — as we consider at the time to have precipitated the debate on the Supervisory Committee's annual report, almost before we even made it public , without having invited the CEO. It would become as if, in the face of the presentation of the annual discharge of the Court of Auditors, the Commissioner responsible was not invited. Well, that was done. What urgency was there? That said: precipitation. That is why our resolution focuses on deploring that Parliament, in its Committee on Budgetary Control, rather than offering citizens and colleagues the opportunity to carry out a full debate with all the necessary opinions and responses, has preferred, on the part of some groups, to offer a partial debate. OLAF is the body for carrying out the Treaty's mandate to combat fraud, and the Surveillance Committee is the auxiliary body to protect OLAF, ensuring its independence, and protect the rights of those investigated. There has always been a proper tension between the two. If it didn't exist, they wouldn't do their job well. What we cannot do in Parliament is to unbalance the balance maliciously, deliberately ignoring the answers and explanations of one of the parties, putting back on the table some of the points that this Parliament has already voted on - and voted against - although some colleagues want us to vote again and again until we get the vote to change. I, in truth, understand that eriating the Surveillance Committee as a judge, rather than as protector of OLAF, and also party, since it would not exist if there was no OLAF, I understand that it is not the functioning or our role. I therefore ask the Commission to undertake as soon as possible the work of ensuring the proper functioning of both and clarifying whether there has been what some of the colleagues are saying and for which we have not even been able to verify the answers.

name: Richard Sulík
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Their explanations are flimsy and implausible. Anything you are talking about would not be a problem if the EU and OLAF were really interested in combating fraud. But they don't – and so there is a war of bureaucracy, endless discussions, action plans and blah blah blah blah blah. I myself have submitted 14 cases to OLAF in the last 12 months, most of which were very clear. None of them has really been studied to date. In six cases I have not received an answer and in a further six cases I have received an unsatisfactory reply. OLAF is not working as it should. If the Commission really wants to combat fraud and is looking for someone who takes the matter seriously, I am available.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the report on OLAF's activity during 2014 suggests that the European Parliament's supervision of this body leaves much to be desired, in particular in the lack of access to OLAF information that we receive from this Parliament and which raises numerous doubts about investigations already carried out or ongoing by that Office. And I give an example: the report on the Tinduf refugee camps. He talks about fraud, but he doesn't make an estimate of it. He says it was conducted and yet did not visit the camps at any time and did not consult data as basic as the UNHCR refugee census in October 2000.  I would like to express in a resounding way that, as a result, there can be a greater humanitarian tragedy than Sahrawi refugees already experience if they finally see their aid reduced.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the OLAF Agency was set up to combat corruption and fraud against the European Union. However, the report of the competent supervisory body shows that it acts opaquely and nothing guarantees the effectiveness and legality of its actions. It is clear that the European Commission, which has ultimate responsibility for the Union's services, is unable to secure the most basic and necessary reform, namely the fight against corruption within its own home.  In an oxymoron, the European Commission, acting as a member of the troika, is demanding that it impose so-called reforms on the Member States. These are not the fight against corruption and delinquency in general, but the imposition of neoliberal ideologies and the deregulation of the labour market for the benefit of capital.  We must stop this hypocrisy and rebuild the Union on the basis of genuine respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, ‘quis custodiet ipsos custodes’. The ancient Roman poet Juvenal knew the problem all too well: who guards the guards? Who polices the police? And who notices when the EU’s anti-fraud office itself breaks the rules? Well, in this case, it is supposed to be the scrutiny committee, and their report is pretty scathing. You cannot record phone conversations without legal basis, you cannot open 423 cases on the same day without so much as reasonable suspicion, and you cannot mislead Parliament about fraud figures. But now we need to know the truth. We need these questions to be put to Mr Kessler in public at the Committee on Budgetary Control. We need to grill him and find out exactly what has been going on. If there is no satisfactory response, then – for once in this place – heads must roll. It is not just about Juvenal, but Caesar’s wife must be above suspicion.

name: Louis Aliot (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is edifying because it once again enshrines a European structure that is not working properly, on a subject that is so important: fraud. This report is worrying, as the comments made by the oversight committee are relevant: a high number of investigations with too long delays; Number of cases opened without the necessary resources; basic legal procedures that are violated, which undermine the rights of the defence - consubstantial rights to a democracy worthy of the name; and finally, suspicions about certain investigations, which are all pressures exerted against parliamentarians and their internationally recognized and consecrated mission. These elements lead us to see that the various criticisms are justified, that they threaten the credibility of OLAF, and therefore of the fight against fraud, and that they would require, if the European Union were a true democracy and our Parliament a genuine parliament, a parliamentary inquiry into the organisation and functioning of OLAF. Since the Commission does not want to settle it, parliamentarians, an expression of the general will of the peoples, must take up this issue and allow full transparency.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – The reason why you are receiving criticism from us here is mainly because it is not the first time that we have discussed misconduct. Olaf's misconduct, which is in the European Parliament's crosshairs, but our concerns about olaf's independence are constantly increasing.  Following olaf's supervisory committee's annual report for 2014, doubts about the proper functioning of the Office and its management are intensifying. Authoritarian action within an institution, which is intended to exemplify accountability and internal integrity, and the fact that it itself does not comply with the rules and procedures, is not only shameful for the whole Union, but, above all, threatens the financial interests of European citizens. Commissioner, the Committee on Budgetary Control, as well as civil society, has long highlighted the conflict between the Supervisory Committee and olaf's management, which undermines the effective work of the whole institution. If OLAF cannot function effectively, the European budget and the supervision of its correct use are at risk, affecting the entire European Union.  If the current management is unable to deal in the long term with these problems affecting the quality of OLAF's work, management needs to change and the internal relationship between the two institutions needs to be re-established. That is why I ask, is it really not time for the EU to make a real change in OLAF?

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am quite surprised to welcome our debate today. I agree with all these concerns, with the statement that it is not working – only we are in the following situation for the moment that one party, the Supervisory Committee, has submitted a report. The OLAF report, which no one reads, has been ready for four or six days. If we, as Parliament, want – and I think we should – to have an equal distance between the two institutions, we should not today express such opinions, which are so unequivocal, but on the basis of what the Advisory Committee was polite to write. Because if olaf's report is different, and we do not know what it is – we have not debated it – we can find ourselves in a rather complicated situation, that is, to contribute to the dissuasion of these institutions, to the deepening of all sorts of feuds, rather than looking for what unites us. That is why I would like us to make it very clear to ourselves that we are not making any decision today. We are waiting, in the Committee on Budgetary Control, for olaf's report. Let us assess them in kind and then let us just try to determine who is right here. I would urge far-reaching restraint, after all, this applies to us.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in 2012 OLAF opened 423 investigations, 198 in cooperation with the authorities of the Member States, 225 direct investigations. Can the Commission tell us what is the result of these investigations almost two years after they were started, because the outcome of these investigations depends on the credibility of the institution, the fight against corruption and, finally, the European Union? These referrals include 20 cases concerning funding through SAPARD projects in Romania. The vast majority of these projects concern agriculture. It is apparent from the report of the relevant Romanian authority that in one case there were suspicions of fraud, the rest were closed. But the rest led to the bankruptcy of the companies that were investigated and attracted these European funds. In these circumstances, does anyone assume any responsibility in relation to the frauds, the fairness of these investigations or are we in the presence of the purely formal opening of investigations? We need clear rules because respect for the European citizen and even here is a priority.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry that Commissioner Georgieva is not here to answer some of the questions I had to ask, that I would have liked to put to OLAF and that I would have liked to put to her, as a representative of the Commission. At this particular moment, since my movement was also born in Italy, we are engaged in the fight against fraud, corruption, we are always at the forefront of denouncing any abuse of public funds.  In this case, however, there is a battle which, in my opinion, is more political than on the substance, because I want to have information on these 423 cases that are open and closed in such a short time. I want to understand why they were in a drawer up to that point and I want answers to so many questions that I have, so in the resolution that we tabled on behalf of my group I request that there be a meeting in the Committee on Budgetary Control to define these doubts, before taking any decision.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, I absolutely reject Commissioner Avramopoulos’s remarks. I am sorry, Mr Avramopoulos, but you said that the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) should engage in dialogue with the Supervisory Committee. The Supervisory Committee does not need a dialogue with anybody: it is here to supervise and not to dialogue. You say that OLAF did this, and OLAF did that. It was not OLAF, but the Director-General, Mr Kessler, and the problem here is with Mr Kessler, not with OLAF. We should look directly at the activities of Mr Kessler, because he does not investigate officials of the European Union; he investigates external firms. Moreover, Mr Avramopoulos, do you know – or perhaps it is only gossip – that Mr Kessler has promised Ms Catherine Day that he will give her information on the investigations led by OLAF? You should check whether this is true.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I agree with my colleagues that Commissioner Avramopoulos' statements and replies and comments were purely bureaucratic, formal and did not give us any information. On the contrary, they are very worrying because they show that they will do nothing to remedy the situation at OLAF. And in this context I would like to ask him whether he believes in the fight against corruption and fraud, and I also ask him if it is true that he has altered, deprived of substance, brushed the biannual Eurobarometer of corruption by the European Commission? Now, on how OLAF is supervised by the Commission, I think we have said enough. The report of the Supervisory Committee is very unhappy with OLAF's work and we are really talking about the management work here and not the work of the investigators. There is insufficient data transmitted so that the control cannot be carried out. OLAF's statistics are also not credible, they differ from year to year or from a few months to months or from a few years to a few years, and they differ greatly, so we cannot rely on them. And I recall in this context that fraud with European money is at least EUR 3 billion. And this is our money, and we want everyone who steals it to take their hand out of our pockets. You too, Commissioner Avramopoulos, have a very important role to play, and you should live up to that role in relation to what OLAF is doing. That's why it's so good that we're setting up the prosecutor's institution... (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for all we know, all these allegations might be true. However, the question is: how do we find the truth? It is not possible to arrive at an acceptable solution if we do not observe elementary rules of democracy and the democratic process. Why was OLAF’s report not presented to the Committee on Budgetary Control? Why was OLAF not invited when the Supervisory Committee report was presented? The explanation that they are too confrontational, so they cannot sit in the same room, is ridiculous. It is the business of the Committee on Budgetary Control, in collaboration with the Commission, to see that an end is put to this absolutely unacceptable situation as quickly as possible because – as we repeat all the time – we need the confidence of our citizens. We have to show them that we are responsible. What are we doing? We are exchanging, through the media, through all sorts of different channels, allegations which cannot be examined in conjunction, and then we wonder why we look ridiculous in the eyes of our citizens. Again I say: the procedure followed in the Committee on Budgetary Control is beyond any acceptable standards. It is open to severe criticism.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, I can really just sympathise with you today that you have to represent such a rather complex issue that the previous European Parliament and members of the Committee on Budgetary Control have been debating and will probably continue to debate for many years. And today there is a certain divide in this Chamber, and a rather cardinal split of opinions. And I think we should avoid this in the future. It has been said that there are certain procedures, and we, too, politicians or Members of the European Parliament, must stick to them. And firstly, that both the Supervisory Committee and olaf should be assessed on the basis of specific facts. And it really needs to be accepted that olaf's report needs to be awaited, the achievements have been assessed, so that there are no misunderstandings about the opening of certain cases and the outcome of those cases. And I think this issue will be resolved. The Director of OLAF has been appointed in accordance with procedures which were discussed for almost a year during the previous term of office. The Supervisory Committee is also the Supervisory Committee. And the most important role – I really understand – must be played by the European Commission and, in particular, by the Commissioner responsible for these matters. If you exchange views only in September, because of problems that have existed for several years and which cannot be solved in any way, then we will not achieve any results for several more years. I therefore propose that the Commission take the initiative.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the annual report of olaf's Supervisory Committee has indeed highlighted a number of critical issues in olaf's work, while OLAF in its annual report for 2014 presented last week highlighted the good results of its work on investigations into cases of fraud against the European Union's financial interests. Without prejudice to the work carried out by the Monitoring Committee and respect for the institutional role of OLAF, which we know to be of fundamental importance in the fight against fraud against the European Union, it cannot be understood that a situation of great tension has now been established between the two bodies. I therefore believe that we need a great deal of caution, and I therefore believe that we need to clarify the situation by listening to both bodies before taking any decision and every decision.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, I support the dialogue between the institutions that we have tonight, but I expect concrete answers. People and businesses outside are waiting for them, too. And I assure you that the support of the people outside ends where their tolerance begins, and the people's tolerance for outrage is zero.  In the case of OLAF, we may find ourselves having broken rules. But it may be that we have violated the rights of the beneficiaries – both the people and the business. That's why we need results, and fast. Otherwise, we risk the trust of both people and businesses, and they are at the heart of cohesion policy. And both people and businesses are asking how 423 cases open in 24 hours and why only 8% of them are completed. I hope sincerely that OLAF will have answers to these questions and have iron logic to explain them, because otherwise we lose confidence – both in us and in the institutions and in the European Union, and we do not need it.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would really like to know why some Members of this precious, democratically-elected Chamber are consciously misleading people who are watching this debate live. To say that OLAF did not have a chance to be heard by the Committee on Budgetary Control is an outright lie. (Applause) It has nothing to do with truth. I absolutely want to make that clear to everyone in this room and around the world, and especially in Europe, because over 500 million people – European taxpayers – are being held in contempt by this ridiculous answer from the Commission tonight.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – I think that at the end of this debate, it is worth noting a few things. My first observation is that there are three actors here: OLAF itself, OLAF's supervisory board, and, well, the main character is the Commission. I would very much like to reassure the dignity of this House and the souls of European taxpayers when these organisations are not bringing their problems before Parliament, but with the leadership and cooperation of the Commission. That is what we want, not a public debate here, to serve one of the most dissemily people in the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, don't you find this strange? Don't you find it almost absurd, perhaps I could even say bizarre?  So what message are we sending to our fellow citizens tonight, what message are we sending to taxpayers tonight, what message are we sending to the economy and all the other institutions that know about olaf's existence and who believe in the credibility of both OLAF and the European Union? What message do we send today when we talk about something that is completely clear and has experienced, unfortunately, a serious debacle in recent years. That is why I am very clear in my demands that the European Prosecutor's Office be finally introduced, because I believe that, if anything, this is one shorter way to respect justice and laws in the European Union.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must express my concern about the way in which the Supervisory Commission interacts with OLAF, with regard to the lack of method, transparency and procedure. I believe it is essential to clarify the role of the Supervisory Committee and to finish its scope. One thing is certain, we cannot wait, fraud is a gigantic problem. I would have liked to talk tonight about the results of the last report. I would have liked to talk about how much the numbers and the scale, the quality of these frauds have increased. I would have liked to talk about the fact that we cannot pass the blame on to the efficiency of local authorities, but the controls must start in Brussels. I would have liked to talk about how important transnational action, European action, is, and how important it is, therefore, for the European Public Prosecutor to harmonise individual national legislation and allow for greater judicial coordination; instead, what do we do here? We are calming between two bodies, both of which are important in the fight against fraud.  As coordinator of my group in the REGI Committee, we will demand to hear from both OLAF and the Supervisory Committee. Has this been done in the CONT Committee?

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable Members of Parliament, I have taken note of the questions and issues you have raised. As you understand, I cannot elaborate further on your questions: I am not the expert or the competent Commissioner. Let me remind you, as I said at the beginning, that I represent here the Commission. Of course I will inform Vice-President Georgieva of the issues of our debate accordingly. Let me tell you that the Commission is now looking forward to the annual Interinstitutional Exchange of Views that will take place, as you know, in September and which will provide a forum for discussion of the progression of relations between OLAF and its supervisory committee. As for the motion for a resolution following its adoption, the Commission will, of course, give you a detailed reply in due time.

name: El Presidente. –
text: Four motions for resolutions have been submitted to close the debate in accordance with Article 128(5) of the Regulation. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The debate on the joint motion for a resolution must be held on the basis of the facts contained in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 annual report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised in it for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored and, as members of the Committee on Budgetary Control, we are obliged to express our opinion on this matter. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in the relevant cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activities affecting the Union's financial interests.  It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met, and the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control has a duty to raise its word to this end. I fully support the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – According to a 2014 OLAF report, the current Hungarian government has tested for corruption. Since 2010, the Hungarian Government has acquired the title of the second most corrupt Member State in the EU. The Hungarian authorities did not suspect abuses in any case last year, while there were 28 reports from the private sector. The government and Peter Polt do not suspect anything, despite the fact that we are falling out of billions in the EU because of institutionalised corruption, and government officials are being banned from the United States. OLAF's obituary is synonymous: today the Hungarian Government is fighting the EU with European taxpayers' money, trying to build an illiberal state in Hungary with European money. János Lázár openly admitted this in Brussels last week when he accepted the billion-dollar EU fine imposed by the Orban government for suspected corruption. We are also not surprised that the Hungarian Government is trying to derail the European Public Prosecutor's Office and weaken its powers.  DK, on the other hand, will do its utmost to establish an independent, strong European Public Prosecutor's Office with exclusive jurisdiction to eradicate fidesz corruption in Hungary. The DK advocates that in future only Member States that accept the exclusive jurisdiction of the European Public Prosecutor's Office from 2016 will be able to receive EU funds. After the fall of the Orban government, we will investigate suspected corruption, we will not let the Hungarian people and businesses lose EU funds because of their corrupt government.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: it's a. – As regards relations between the European Union and Russia, I consider that Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, direct and indirect participation in the armed conflict in Ukraine and violation of Georgia's territorial integrity undermines democratic and international principles. Moreover, the economic coercion and political destabilisation that Russia is pursuing towards its European neighbours constitutes a conscious violation of international law. In view of this, the European Union must thoroughly assess the relationship with Russia and prepare a comprehensive plan on the future of relations with Russia and its eastern neighbours. For years, the European Union has strained to build a mutually beneficial strategic partnership with Russia and remains open to such a relationship and dialogue in the future when the preconditions are met. Russia is an important partner of the European Union and we should, for mutual benefit, define and constructively establish a long-term sustainable relationship based on respect for international law.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. Mr President, I would like to thank the The motions for resolutions by the political groups note the inadequate position of the Supervisory Committee, citing, among other things, unsatisfactory cooperation, inadequate implementation of recommendations or the SC's lack of and unresolved legal means of establishing DG OLAF as the justification. I believe that DG OLAF needs to recognise the position of the SC and reconsider its allocation of funds, as around 86% of the investigations had to be carried out in the field of agriculture and structural funds.
